headline: Geneva Convention to Be Applied to Captured Taliban Fighters
abstract: President Bush has decided to apply the Geneva Convention to Taliban fighters, the White House announced today.

headline: Pakistani Suspect Tells Court Abducted U.S. Reporter Is Dead
abstract: Ahmed Omar Saeed Sheikh said today that Daniel Pearl was dead. But Pakistani authorities held out hope he was alive.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Fine Living, Los Angeles, named the Los Angeles office of Crispin Porter & Bogusky to handle the creative and media planning duties for the introduction of the Fine Living cable television network, Web site and magazine.

headline: Business; Insurers Find Profit in a New Risk Consciousness
abstract: Insurance companies are doing brisk business in political risk coverage as American companies with overseas operations seek protection against against terrorism, riot, civil war, strikes, coups d'etat, nationalization and government interference with flow of profits back home; terrorism coverage used to be included in general property policies at little or no extra charge, but many property insurers are refusing to provide terrorism coverage that way, forcing companies to buy it separately or as part of political risk package; photo; table (M)

headline: TITAN BUYS A MAKER OF RADAR SYSTEMS FOR THE MILITARY
abstract: Titan Corp acquires Jaycor Inc, manufacturer of radar and communications systems, for $95 million in stock (S)

headline: Wall St. Analysts Tell Congress They Were Misled by Enron
abstract: Analysts told lawmakers today that they were fooled by misleading statements from the company.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Afternoon Trading Resumes
abstract: Philippine Stock Exchange will resume afternoon trading Feb 21 for first time in more than two decades (S)

headline: MCI Names Deutsch For Consumer Ads
abstract: MCI, unit of WorldCom Inc, expands its agency roster by shifting consumer advertising for MCI brand without review to Deutsch; assignment had been held by Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG; billings could reach as much as $100 million (S)

headline: Beijing Journal; Seeking Justice, Clad in the Armor of Persistence
abstract: Thousands of petitioners make way to Beijing each year when China's National People's Congress meets, in hopes of redressing unresolved complaints; must contend with wide dragnet of police officers and officials whose job is to protect city's image of untroubled stability, especially while country's legislators are on show; photos (M)

headline: PAPER AND BOX MAKER DROPS TENDER OFFER FOR RIVAL
abstract: Temple-Inland, a paper and box maker, dropped its $841 million tender offer for a rival, the Gaylord Container Corporation, after the bid failed to attract the minimum amount of shares and notes. The takeover bid drew criticism from some of Gaylord's bondholders, who said the offer was inadequate. Temple-Inland, based in Austin, Tex., offered 87.5 cents on the dollar for the bonds and $1.25 a share. As of yesterday's deadline, only 84 percent of Gaylord's 47.2 million shares were tendered. Temple-Inland will return all Gaylord shares and notes to their holders. Gaylord is based in Deerfield, Ill.

headline: Afghan and Pakistani Pledge To Move Beyond Old Grudges
abstract: Afghan interim leader Hamid Karzai and Pakistani Pres Pervez Musharraf, meeting, Islamabad, Pakistan, agree to focus on future and bury past problems; Karzai holds Pakistan is poised to become cornerstone of region's work against terrorism and radicalism; says he hopes to soon release as many Pakistanis who fought with Taliban as possible, but not those with ties to Al Qaeda; says he hopes to make it possible for 1.6 million Afghan refugees in Pakistan to return home; says United States forces are needed in Afghanistan to continue war on terrorism (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Phone Executive To Leave
abstract: Tormod Hermansen is stepping down as chief executive of Telenor; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Venture On a Small Scale
abstract: Technology Briefing: Venture on A Small Scale**

headline: ISRAEL IS LEAVING PALESTINIAN AREAS IN THE WEST BANK
abstract: Israeli forces begin withdrawing from Palestinian-controlled territory in Bethlehem, Beit Jala and Jenin as Israel moves under American pressure toward meeting Palestinian conditions for formal cease-fire talks; withdrawal comes during visit by Vice Pres Dick Cheney, who met with Prime Min Ariel Sharon; Cheney reaffirms Bush administration's commitment to ending violence after nearly 18 months and to achieving settlement under which Israel exist peacefully beside Palestinian state; Israeli withdrawal follows rare joint session of Israeli and Palestinian security chiefs, drawn together by US Middle East envoy Gen Anthony C Zinni; photos; map (M)

headline: Tyco Paid Director a Fee of $10 Million
abstract: Proxy filing with Securities and Exchange Commission shows Tyco International Ltd paid total of $10 million to outside director Frank E Walsh Jr and contributed $10 million to Community Foundation of New Jersey, charity which Walsh is trustee, in exchange for Walsh's help in arranging $10 billion purchase of commercial lender CIT Group last year; filing also shows pay for Tyco chairman-chief executive Dennis Kozlowski fell 42 percent, to $62.4 milllion (S)

headline: Jonas Savimbi, 67, Rebel Of Charisma and Tenacity
abstract: Biographical profile of Jonas Savimbi, who spent more than 35 years in African bush battling first for Angolan independence and then for personal power; he died in battle with government troops; he was 67; photos (L)

headline: Rise in Mergers Anticipated
abstract: Sixty percent of senior executives at large multinational companies anticipate increase in merger activity in next 12 months, and 90 percent anticipate increase in next two years, according to survey by PricewaterhouseCoopers (S)

headline: Fear and Flight in Deadly Kashmir
abstract: Division between Hindus and Muslims is being played out in remote hill towns of Indian state of Kashmir in small-scale, day-to-day savegery; slayings by Islamic militants are spurring some Hindus to flee predominantly Muslim areas; map; photo (M)

headline: Killings in Kosovo Are Described at War Trial
abstract: Albanian doctor testifies at war crimes trial of Slobodan Milosevic; describes war in Kosovo in 1999 and recounts how he watched through window as Serbian police executed two of his relatives, then four more people in house nearby, then set building on fire and placed bodies there to be immolated along with it; Milosevic, in cross-examining doctor, tries to make NATO airstrikes the issue; he has seized every opportunity to blame NATO and Albanian guerrillas for killings in Kosovo; legal experts point out that alleging guilt of others may not help Milosevic rebut specific allegations against forces under his command; prosecutors intend to call dozens of eyewitnesses like Albanian doctor (M)

headline: Newly Hot Manila Exchange Tries Trading All Day
abstract: Philippine Stock Exchange in Manila reintroduces afternoon trading for frist time since 1970's; foreign funds are returning to Philippines and stock trading levels have more than doubled; graph; photo (M)

headline: WILLIAMS, THE ENERGY COMPANY, TRIES TO REWORK DEBT
abstract: Williams Companies expects to get more time from creditors to make payments on $1.4 billion in notes used to finance telecommunications subsidiary, Williams Communications Group, which last week said it might file for bankruptcy (S)

headline: MALAN REALTY, SHOPPING CENTER OWNER, TO LIQUIDATE
abstract: Malan Realty Investors Inc, citing decline in its stock price, says its board voted to sell company's 58 shopping center assets and liquidate company (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil falls on report showing that inventories are adequate for refiners to make heating oil and gasoline; in New York, crude oil for February delivery falls 64 cents, or 3.1 percent, to $20.37 per barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Insurers Fault Enron Deals At Morgan
abstract: Several insurance companies being sued by J P Morgan Chase for refusing to honor its $1 billion in claims relating to its dealings with Enron Corp accuse bank of deliberately camouflaging loan to Enron as commodity transaction in order to perpetrate fraud on them; cite similarities to bank's dealing with Sumitomo Corp in effort to argue that there has been pattern at J P Morgan; J P Morgan maintains that there is nothing unusual, much less fraudulent, about sorts of transactions involved in cases; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: F.T.C. Clears Acquisition Of Compaq by Hewlett  The Federal Trade Commission unanimously approved Hewlett-Packard's deal to acquire Compaq Computer. The move, while expected, paved the way for a tightly contested vote of Hewlett-Packard's shareholders on March 19.    The F.T.C. said it ''did not find reason to believe that the proposed transaction would impair competition in any relevant market,'' and did not ask for concessions. [Page C4.]    US Airways Appoints a Chief  US Airways, which like many other airlines has had financial troubles since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, said it had hired David N. Siegel, 40, left, a former executive at Continental Airlines and chairman of Avis, as president and chief executive. He succeeds Stephen M. Wolf, who reassumed the post after Rakesh Gangwal resigned in November. [C4.]

headline: Survivor and Humanist, Celebrating con Brio
abstract: Profile of cellist-conductor Mstislav Rostropovich, who has brought his blend of Old World virtuosity and antic wit to London for series of concerts and Buckingham Palace gala, all commemorating his 75th birthday on March 27; photo (M)

headline: U.S. PRODS ISRAEL TO ALLOW ARAFAT TO GO TO SUMMIT
abstract: Vice Pres Dick Cheney says it is important that Yasir Arafat attend upcoming Arab summit in Beirut, development that would require Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel to lift travel ban; says he has no immediate plans to meet with Arafat because of failure to meet US condition that he take steps to establish cease-fire and stop terrorist attacks against Israel; Sharon weighs Cheney's appeal; says Arafat has given no orders to halt attacks; US officials hope Beirut meeting will endorse Saudi peace plan calling for Israel to withdraw from territory it has occupied since 1967 in return for full normalization of relations with Arab nations; fear meeting could turn into cascade of criticism of Israel and US if Israel does not allow Arafat to attend; Saudi and other Arab leaders also urge Cheney to help Arafat attend Beirut meeting (M)

headline: A Portable Printer Turns Out Instant Snapshots on the Road
abstract: Canon's new portable Photo Printer CP-100 makes digital photos almost instantly available; printer can be controlled with commands on tiny LCD screens of four recently introduced Canon digital cameras; photo (S)

headline: 3 Held and Computer Seized In Case of Missing Reporter
abstract: Pakistani police arrest two men suspected of sending e-mail messages with photographs of Daniel Pearl, American reporter kidnapped in Karachi 13 days ago; believe they are on verge of breakthrough in investigation (M)

headline: Scientists Discover a Dinosaur Clad in Flightless Feathers
abstract: Chinese and American paleontologists find fossils of feathered, flightless dinosaur, slightly bigger than pheasant, that they say should settle once and for all that feathers originated before birds or flight; discovery of 125-million-year-old dinosaur in China is reported in journal Nature; scientists suspect feathers evolved for some purpose other than flight, perhaps for warmth, and only later and with other physical changes were they used to help takeoffs (M)

headline: Federal Court Moves to Loosen F.C.C. Rules on TV Ownership
abstract: A federal appeals court struck down today a rule that had prevented the nation's cable operators from owning television stations.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   8.50       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   5.00       Federal funds   1.75   1.80   5.38       3-month T-bills   1.84   1.81   4.37       6-month T-bills   2.07   2.01   4.22       10-yr. T-infl.   3.37   3.38   3.29       10-yr. T-note   5.30   5.33   4.81       30-yr. T-bond   5.74   5.75   5.29       Telephone bd.   7.90   7.93   7.70       Municipal bds.   5.38   5.42   5.27          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Helping Hands, but Not Quite Mentors
abstract: Lisa Belkin comment on mutual mentoring of Judy Katz and Dian Griesel; adds her own appreciation for role models who have helped her along the way, particularly strong women who came before her at The New York Times (M)

headline: E-Mailing Your New PC
abstract: Joseph H Zimmerman letter comments on transferring files from old personal computer to new one (March 21 article)

headline: U.S. Woman Jailed in Peru Won't Get a Presidential Pardon
abstract: Lori Berenson, American woman whose conviction for collaborating with Marxist rebels was upheld by Peru's Supreme Court, will not be granted presidential pardon; Justice Min Fernando Olivera says Berenson is proven terrorist, who was convicted in new trial with all guarantees; says sentence must be served since law should be applied equally to everyone (M)

headline: China, Russia and 4 Neighbors Seek Common Front on Terror
abstract: After a daylong meeting here, foreign ministers from China, Russia and four Central Asian countries said today that the fall of the Taliban in Afghanistan did not end the terrorist threat and that their governments would continue to work together against ''terrorism, separatism and extremism'' to promote regional stability.    In their joint statement, the ministers tried to link their countries' sometimes controversial efforts to suppress Islamic fundamentalists and separatists within their own borders to the larger United States-led war on terror. The six countries, which have formed a loose economic and security alliance called the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, had long ''been threatened by terrorism and drugs'' from Afghanistan, the statement said, adding that they ''have actively participated in the international alliance against terrorism and have adopted measures to further strengthen the group's antiterrorism work.

headline: Chief's Words Paint Hands-Off Image, but Actions Offer Different View
abstract: Analysis of when and what Enron Corp chairman Kenneth L Lay knew of company's accounting practices; says in August, Lay said that questions about deals that Enron used to shift debt off its books were way over his head; holds different picture has emerged over last 10 days as to what Lay knew about company's accounting practices and when he knew it; says disclosures by Congressional investigators and lawyers suing Enron show Lay helped create and oversee some of company's suspect financial arrangements (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Privatization Fails
abstract: Plans to privatize Czech electricity company CEZ are thrown into disarray when lead bidder, Electricite de France, pulls out, saying government's minimum price of 200 billion koruny ($5.5 billion) for 67.6 percent stake is too high (S)

headline: The Golden Years For Silver Prices
abstract: Money management expert Fred Waddell contends financial estimates of what is needed for retirement are inflated by mutual fund industry; says many people oversave for or put off retirement, fearful that they will not have enough money, but that many can retire on much less than they believe; Web site Bestplaces.net allows user to compare cost-of-living and quality-of-life data for areas across US; photo (special section, Retirement) (M)

headline: Economic Scene; The real value of Enron may be as a worst-case example of the need for clearer accounting rules.
abstract: Hal R Varian 'Economic Scene' column holds Enron Corp's greatest contribution to American economy may be reform of accounting rules and clearer reporting of corporate finances; says Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill was right when he said in January that market does punish those who mislead, but that may not be enough to ensure good corporate behavior; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: MSC Will Buy Mechanical Dynamics
abstract: MSC.Software Corp, which makes simulation software for manufacturers to test designs of their products, will buy rival software maker Mechanical Dynamics Inc for $120 million (S)

headline: Brazil's Coalition Loses a Key Partner Over a Police Raid
abstract: Brazil's four-party governing coalition collapses in storm of rancor with pullout of country's second most powerful political force, right-of-center Liberal Front Party; split results from police raid on business office of husband of party's presidential candidate Roseana Sarney; it promises to complicate presidential election scheduled for Oct; Sarney has been running strong second in opinion polls; her brother Jose Sarney Jr resigns as minister of environment in protest against raid (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fujitsu Expects Loss
abstract: Fujitsu lowers its earnings forecast for full year in light of slump in global demand for semiconductors and telecommunications equipment; expects to lose net 380 million yen ($2.8 billion) in fiscal year ending March 31, 23 percent more that it planned last October (S)

headline: India Presses Its Conditions For Pullback From Border
abstract: Defense Min George Fernandes says India will not withdraw its forces from border with Pakistan until raids across border end and Pakistan hands over suspected terrorists; conditions he specifies suggest there will be no early end to tense standoff along India-Pakistan border; he makes demands in Washington, during meetings with Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, National Security Adviser Condoleezza Rice and Deputy Secretary of State Richard L Armitage; photo (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Internet experts wonder if Weblog technology is a powerful new media species, or just another fad.
abstract: Weblogs on which Internet users post their thoughts and read thoughts of others have been growing more quickly in recent months, and they are winning praise mainstream media analysts for bringing new type of expression to Internet; companies hoping to make money from medium are finding opportunities selling supporting technology to consumes and -- if all goes as planned -- portals that would do same; whether Weblogs have a future or or fad destined to fade remains a question; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Telecom Sale Closer
abstract: Min Jiri Rusnok says Czech Republic may complete long-awaited sale of Cesky Telecom before June elections; three binding offers have been submitted (S)

headline: Who Stands To Benefit As Military Expands
abstract: Excerpts from interview with Goldman Sachs aerospace and defense analyst Howard A Rubel on US military industry and which companies are best positioned to benefit from $48 billion military budget proposed by Pres Bush; photo (M)

headline: U.S., in Pakistan Talks, Seeking Transfer of Suspect in Pearl Case
abstract: Officials have begun talks on arrangements that could lead to the extradition of Ahmed Omar Sheikh, the chief suspect in the murder of Daniel Pearl.

headline: Do Cellphone Users Need Even More Coffee?
abstract: Starbucks Coffee begins pilot program in 12 Seattle area cafes that enables customers to order coffee from their wireless phones, bypassing cash register altogether; photo (S)

headline: At U.N., Debating Who Gets the Right to Debate Human Rights
abstract: Western regional group of countries on United Nations Human Rights Commission seeks way to avoid repeat of embarrassing surprise 10 months ago, when United States lost its seat on panel; proposed formula would allot each Western state fixed number of years on commission over next 20 years; question now is how many years should be allotted to each country; everyone agrees US should have most, but that is where consensus ends; Amb Thorsteinn Ingolfsson of Iceland has unenviable task of rotating 20 seats among 29 nations for 20 years, based on size, merit and history of countries (M)

headline: Reporter's Notebook; A Diplomatic Star With a Singular Style
abstract: Reporter's Notebook compares and contrasts Secretary of State Colin L Powell's style during weeklong trip around world to two predecessors, Henry A Kissinger and Madeleine K Albright; says unlike Kissinger, Powell is all business, with no taste for dramatics, dinners, ceremonies or wasted motion; says unlike Albright, Powell likes to limit his travel, and to make every minute count while on trips; photo (M)

headline: A Qaeda Leader Is Reported To Plan New Raids on U.S.
abstract: American officials say Abu Zubaydah, elusive Palestinian who travels world using false passports and multiple aliases, is new chief of operations of Al Qaeda and is now believed to be organizing remnants of terrorist network to carry out new attacks against US and its allies; he has been linked directly to planning of Sept 11 strikes in US, and also to plans for wave of terror attacks in Europe last year that were thwarted by arrest of several other plotters; American investigators say he is trying to activate so-called sleeper cells of Al Qaeda for new strikes; say they are eager to apprehend him because he knows identities of thousands of terrorist recruits who passed through Al Qaeda's training camps in Afghanistan, and are now in their home countries, or elsewhere, waiting for instructions; photo (M)

headline: Qwest Plan Stirs Protest Over Privacy
abstract: Some customers of Qwest Communications and privacy advocates are angry over latest mailing from company, which describes ways that Qwest will use customer's personal data; FCC notes that other telephone carriers will be sending out notices as well (S)

headline: Details of Victory Are Unclear but It Is Celebrated Nonetheless
abstract: Afghan soldiers celebrate with their tutors from American Special Forces in Shah-i-Kot Valley, which is finally wrested from Al Qaeda and Taliban after 11 days of fighting; details of victory are unclear, and stated death toll among enemy continues to fluctuate; photo (M)

headline: Dell Reports Strong Earnings for Quarter
abstract: Dell Computer reports profit of $456 million in quarter ended Feb 1 compared with earnings of $434 million year earlier; says sales were $8.06 billion, down 7 percent from year ago; chief executive Michael S Dell says sales for current quarter will slip from previous quarter, but not by as much as in rest of industry; photo (M)

headline: DaimlerChrysler Gives Outlook, And Some Analysts Fault Report
abstract: DaimlerChrysler reports net loss of $589 million for 2001, in contrast to $7 billion net profit year earlier; operating profit for year was $1.2 billion; chief executive Jurgen E Schrempp says company will exceed its 2001 operating profit by more than two times this year (M)/

headline: Article 2002010392630557688 -- No Title
abstract: A {text-decoration: none} A:hover {text-decoration: underline} .nav {font-family: Arial,Helvetica,Sans-serif; font-size: 10px; color: #000066} .tools {font-family: Arial,Helvetica,Sans-serif; font-size: 10px; color: #000066} .kicker {font-family: "Times New Roman", Times, serif; font-size: 10px; line-height: 13px; font-weight: bold} .bodytext {font-family: Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 10px; line-height: 11px} .title {font-family: "Times New Roman", Times, serif; font-size: 14px; font-weight: bold} .nytkicker {font-family: "Times New Roman", Times, serif; font-size: 10px; line-height: 13px; font-weight: bold; color: #666666} The New York Times on the Web

headline: Nigeria Grows Disenchanted With Democracy
abstract: Nigerians are growing disenchanted with democracy as government's positive steps are being eclipsed by unmet promises, uncontrolled violence and string of disasters; spasms of violence are expected to grow more frequent as politicians position themselves for 2003 presidential vote; over 10,000 people are believed to have been killed in ethnic and religious clashes since military rule ended in 1999; photos (M)

headline: Indian Leader Feels Pressure From All Sides Over Violence
abstract: Temple that Hindu hard-liners seek to build on site of razed 16th-century mosque in Ayodhya continues to create problems for government led by Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party of Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee even though showdown at site was averted on March 15; even as Hindu fundamentalists persist in their desire to build temple, party faces ever greater pressure to keep them in check; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: More Held In Attack At U.S. Center
abstract: Calcutta police say they picked up about 20 more people for questioning in attack on police officers guarding American Center, which killed 4 and wounded 19; about 75 people have been detained (S)

headline: A Fund Plea From Volcker Aroused Hopes at Enron
abstract: When Paul A Volcker, chairman of parent organization of International Accounting Standards Board, sent letters to major corporations seeking financing for board, Enron appears to have concluded that there was chance to gain some influence; letter from Volcker was sent to Enron's chairman Kenneth L Lay and evidently passed down to Richard A Causey, Enron chief accounting officer, who called David B Duncan, Arthur Andersen partner in charge of auditing Enron; Duncan, in e-mail message to senior colleagues at Andersen on Feb 23, 2001, said Causey had asked 'whether these types of commitments will add any formal or informal access to this process'; e-mail message is released by Sen Carl Levin; Levin says Volcker did nothing wrong, since accounting rule makers raise much of their money from corporate contributions; Volcker says Enron had later pledged contribution of $50,000, half amount he had sought as annual contribution, bu t had not sent in any money before it filed for bankruptcy protection; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Search For Quake Survivors Ends
abstract: Search for survivors from earthquake on February 3 in central Turkey is called off as victims are buried and as soldiers and aid workers turn their efforts to providing food and shelter for survivors; photo (S)

headline: An Institutional Group Is Close to Switching Its Stance on Stock Options
abstract: Council of Institutional Investors says it is close to switching its position and backing bill offered by Sens Carl Levin and John McCain to force companies to count stock-option awards as compensation expense; says group responds to adoption of many stock-option plans without shareholder approval (M)

headline: Judge Dismisses Cigarette Suit
abstract: US Judge Nicholas G Garaufis dismisses lawsuit in which European Commission accused Philip Morris Companies and R J Reynolds Tobacco Co of smuggling contraband cigarettes into Europe to evade paying billions in taxes (S)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for JOHN C. WILCOX; Democracy's Corporate Attire
abstract: Interview with John C Wilcox, vice chmn of Georgeson Sharehold

headline: A City, Free of Taliban, Returns to the Thieves
abstract: Jalalabad, Afghanistan, returns to former lawlessness, with people selling everything from what are thought to be terrorist materials taken from Al Qaeda caves in Tora Bora to bootlegged copies of Hollywood blockbusters to hashish to food stolen from aid convoys; city's newly appointed interim mayor Abdul Ghaffar decries rampant corruption; photos (M)

headline: Saudis Haven't Requested Pullout, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: WASHINGTONâ€”  Top U.S. officials said Sunday that they had received no request from Saudi Arabia for a withdrawal of American forces, and Secretary of State Colin Powell went further, describing the U.S. military forces posted in the kingdom as a continuing symbol of American presence and not as a limited-term deterrent aimed at Iraq.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: CenterSpan In Sony Licensing Deal
abstract: CenterSpan Communications Corp, which has developed online music distribution network, signs licensing deal to include artists from Sony Music Corp; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: For Apple, To Be Flat Is a Virtue
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on radical new design of Apple's i-Mac computer, composed of 6-inch-tall dome and thin flat-panel screen; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm Settles Deceptive Ad Charges
abstract: Palm agrees to settle Federal Trade Commission accusations of deceptive advertising over claims that Palm hand-held computers provide built-in wireless access to Internet; FTC says many of Palm's models do not have such access without separate wireless modems or additional software; settlement provides for $11,000 fine for any violation of order (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Monetary Policy Unchanged
abstract: Bank of Japan leaves interest rates unchanged at near zero (S)

headline: Executive Shifts At 4 Companies
abstract: Louis M Schultz, chairman and chief executive at Initiative Media Worldwide, part of Partnership division of Interpublic Group of Companies, is in talks to step down and take another part at Interpublic; Maxxcom, division of MDC Corp, names Harold Reiter president and chief executive, succeeding Beverly Morden, who resigned; Holly Pavlika is named executive vice president and executive creative director at New York office of Grey Direct, succeeding Bob Feinberg, who is retiring; Rodale's president-chief operating officer Steven P Murphy is named president and chief executive; he assumes duties from Ardath Rodale, who continues as chairwoman (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FLEETBOSTON FINANCIAL CORP., Boston, the seventh-largest U.S. bank, has changed the name of its $170 billion asset management unit from Fleet Asset Management to Columbia Management Group Inc.    ELECTRONICS BOUTIQUE HOLDINGS CORP., West Chester, Pa., said it would close its EB Kids unit and sell its BC Sports Collectibles business to focus on its core business, video games. The company will offer jobs to workers displaced by the moves.

headline: Grey Global Involved In U.S. Investigation
abstract: Grey Global Group says it is cooperating with federal investigation of print production industry that resulted in arrest last week of former executive vice president-director Mitchell E Mosallem, who was charged with conspiracy to defraud Grey clients by padding invoices; Mosallem, who resigned in December, allegedly agreed with unidentified co-workers at Grey and employees of at least four outside graphic suppliers from 1991 to 2000 to defraud Grey clients by authorizing 'false and fraudulent invoices relating to its contracts'; Paul B Bergman, lawyer representing Mosallem, says Mosallem intends to fight charges; warrant estimates that from February 1998 to July 2000, fake invoices totaled $500,000 (M)

headline: Tax Surfing
abstract: Traffic to IRS Web site, leading personal finance sites and sites from companies specializing in tax advice surged in Feb; sites seem to be holding up under strain; graph of leading tax information sites; photo (S)

headline: An Especially Rough Year
abstract: Study by Kanon Bloch Carre shows investors holding shares of Janus'sd

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Government Planes To Get Internet Service
abstract: Boeing Co wins contract valued at as much as $112 million equip aircraft for vice president and other officials with two-way Internet, e-mail service and television service (S)

headline: Anti-Trust Officials in Britain to Look at Newspaper Consolidation
abstract: A potential "live and let live" attitude among the big newspaper publishers is being investigated by the competition authorities, who are concerned about a concentration of ownership in Britain's regional press.

headline: NATIONAL STEEL SEEKS BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
abstract: National Steel Corp files for bankruptcy protection because of low prices and weak economy; National Steel is majority owned by NKK Corp of Tokyo (S)

headline: HOSTILE FIRE KILLS FIRST U.S. SOLDIER SINCE WAR'S ONSET
abstract: Army Special Forces sergeant Nathan Ross Chapman, 31, is killed in brief firefight in eastern Afghanistan, first death of US serviceman by hostile fire since war began nearly three months ago; CIA officer is wounded; ambush happens after small team of Americans and Afghans meets with local leaders near Khost and Gardez to try to get information about Al Qaeda locations; Gen Tommy Franks warns much dangerous work remains to be done; US planes bomb Al Qaeda training camp in province; Pentagon reports Al Qaeda regrouping at compound; Khost area is filled with bandits, renegade Taliban and die-hard Al Qaeda; speculation noted about whereabouts of Osama bin Laden (M)

headline: A Rival Offer Is Expected For Global
abstract: Gores Technology Group is expected to bid for bankrupt Global Crossing in competition with Hutchison Whampoa; bid would improve chances company could continue operating (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Listen.com To Announce Licensing Pacts
abstract: Listen.com, an Internet music company, plans to announce today that it has signed licensing agreements with EMI Recorded Music, part of the EMI Group, and BMG, the music arm of Bertelsmann. The agreements will permit Listen.com, based in San Francisco, to sell the labels' music on a streaming basis, which means that Listen.com customers can listen to the music over the Internet. The company said it is making some music available now, and would add more in the coming weeks. However, the deal does not permit Listen .com's subscribers to download the songs onto their own computers or transfer them to mobile devices.   Matt Richtel (NYT)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Japan Premier Faces Major Crisis Over Firing of Foreign Minister
abstract: Japan's reformist prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, faced a major crisis today as voters frowned on his firing of the popular foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka.

headline: As the Web Matures, Fun Is Hard to Find
abstract: World Wide Web loses its luster just 11 years after it was born and about six years after it became popular; many who once raved about surfing from address to address on Web now lump site-seeing with other online chores, like checking In box; length of average online session has decreased, along with percentage of users who say Internet helps them 'a lot' in learning new things; drawing (M)

headline: Charlie Sheen's Redemption Helps a Studio In Its Struggles
abstract: DreamWorks SKG executives hope actor Charlie Sheen's recent Golden Globe Award for his role in Spin City, studio's only lasting television success, will boost teetering show and prevent ABC from cancelling it at end of season; credit his father, Martin Sheen, with helping him recover from substance abuse (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: More Corporate Restructuring
abstract: Munich Re doubles its stake from 5 to 10 percent in Commerzbank and says it is looking to find bank new partner; Munich Re says it wants to secure its interest in consolidation of Germany's banking industry; under new law that took effect Jan 1, companies can sell their stakes in other enterprises without having to pay capital-gains taxes; Munich Re is one of several large German financial institutions that are eager to sell holdings that they acquired decades ago and are now worth billions of dollars (S)

headline: MindShare Selected by Novartis
abstract: MindShare Selected By Novartis Novartis in Basel, Switzerland, which sells products under names like Ex-Lax, Gerber, Maalox and Triaminic, said yesterday that it had consolidated its worldwide media planning and buying assignments at offices of MindShare, part of the WPP Group.

headline: Dot-Govs
abstract: Web sites run by federal government are consistently among most-visited sites; ComScore Networks says traffic to those sites rose 28 percent, Aug-Feb; graph; table of top government sites; photo (S)

headline: U.S.-Style Evangelical Drive Rouses Germany
abstract: American-financed advertising campaign promoting fundamentalist Protestant values and 'power for living' book causes uproar in Berlin, prompting ban on its television spots and some self-searching on part of Germany's established churches; various German celebrities promote campaign on billboards; ads give no clue as to who is behind campaign or book, which is sponsored by Arthur S DeMoss Foundation of West Palm Beach Fla; photo (M)

headline: HEALTHPARTNERS EXECUTIVE TO LEAD KAISER PERMANENTE
abstract: Kaiser Permanente appoints George C Halvorson to succeed David M Lawrence as chairman and chief executive, effective May 1; executive vice president Mary K Brainerd will succeed Halvorson as chief executive (S)

headline: Redefining 'Wholesale'
abstract: reÃ˜

headline: Investing; Now, Futures in a Single-Serving Size
abstract: E-mini futures contracts traded on Globex trading system of Chicago Mercantile Exchange allow individual investors with modest capital to speculate on stock indexes using leverage that magnifies their gains and losses; e-mini on Standard & Poor's 500-stock index costs as little as $3,938, compared with $19,688 for standard futures contract; graph; photo (M)

headline: Dubai's Airline Plans Rapid Growth
abstract: Emirates Airlines is planning rapid growth; in November, airline ordered $15 billion in new jetliners from Airbus Industrie and Boeing; orders will nearly triple Emirates Air's fleet in next decade, to 100 aircraft from 36 today; in 2003, Emirates Air plans to begin flights between North America and its base in Dubai, beginning with daily service from Kennedy Airport and adding Chicago and Los Angeles flights later; top executive Maurice Flanagan comments; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: Tell-All Book Portrays Split In Leadership Of China
abstract: Book supposedly written by someone with remarkable access to inner workings of China's Communist Party denounces leadership of Pres Jiang Zemin and promotes Prime Min Zhu Rongji as under-recognized brains behind brawn of country's central government; book, Zhu Rongji in 1999, was published in Chinese in US last Oct and is being serialized in English in American scholarly journal, Chinese Law and Government; it is latest effort by Jiang's opponents to deflate his reputation before he retires later this year; it is also most powerful attempt by supporters of oft-embattled Zhu to elevate his stature ahead of his own retirement; Andrew J Nathan, political scientist who edited English translation, says author--or authors, he will not say which--hope to ensure that Jiang gives up all his posts rather than continue to exercise influence behind scenes; there is no way to judge book's authenticity or accuracy, but its arrival suggests growing movement among Communist Party insiders to rewrite party history and influence country's future by leaking information to West (M)

headline: Italian Truckers Fight Limits on Crossing Alps
abstract: Hundreds of Italian truckers block Alpine crossings to protest Switzerland's limits on long-distance hauling since accidents caused shutdown of Mount Blanc and Gotthard Tunnels and to press for reopening of Mont Blanc tunnel, which links France and Italy; Mount Blanc has been closed since Mar 1999; trucks are now barred from crossing Switzerland at night to curb noise and pollution in valley that leads to Gotthard Tunnel; photo (M)

headline: An Uneasy Routine at Cuba Prison Camp
abstract: Elaborate system of privileges and rewards for cooperation evolves between American military guards at Guantanamo naval base and their prisoners from Afghan war; photo; prisoners get novels and reading glasses, sweet tea and curried chicken, are allowed to talk with each other and shout out to visiting reporters, and get first-class medical care with specialists flown in; they are also frustrated and angry over uncertain future; Gen Michael R Lehnert says most are high-ranking Taliban or suspected Al Qaeda, although his deputy says some may be 'victims of circumstance' (M)

headline: Audience for Cable News Grows
abstract: Cable and broadcast news networks seem to have held much of very large audiences that tuned in after Sept 11 terrorist attacks; news executives say they are unsure whether growth will hold if domestic terrorism front remains quiet; news audiences are still far smaller than in first weeks after attacks, when up to 50 million people may have watched news; graph of audience gains; photos (M)

headline: For Women in Kabul, This Test Is Welcome
abstract: Hundreds of young Afghan women take exam to attend Kabul University, idea that was anathema to former Taliban rulers; university faces many problems; Dr Aziz Ahmad Rahmand, professor of Afghan history, recalling Taliban repression, says he is thrilled that new day is dawning for education in his country; photos (M)

headline: Economic Scene; If there was a new economy, why wasn't there a new economics?
abstract: Hal R Varian's 'Economic Scene' column cites 1937 work by economist Ronald Coase to explore why advent of Internet has not led to smaller companies even though it has lowered lowered communications costs; photo (M)

headline: Executive Life; Farewell, Six Courses. Hello, Tuna Salad.
abstract: Top executives in New York City are abandoning two-hour business lunch, partly to cut their calorie intake and company's expenses, but mainly to bolster productivity; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Enron Executives Defend Treatment of 401(k) Fund  Enron executives acknowledged that before they temporarily prevented employees from selling company stock in their retirement accounts last fall, they had sharply debated delaying the moratorium because employees could suffer heavy losses from a plunging stock price.    House and Senate lawmakers issued subpoenas to compel the testimony of Enron's former chief executive, Kenneth L. Lay, while Congressional and state officials broadened their inquiries into why state pension funds and agencies invested and did business with Enron as it spiraled downward. [Page A1.]

headline: U.S. Seeks to Stem Optimism on Seizing Bin Laden and Omar
abstract: Pentagon officials said they would stop speculating about the whereabouts of Osama bin Laden and Mullah Mohammad Omar.

headline: Interpublic Board To Add Outsiders
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies says it will substantially remake its board to give greater weight to outside directors by having four inside directors leave; there will be two inside and seven outside directors with arrival of another outside director, Michael I Roth, chief executive of MONY Group, and departures of four inside directors: David Bell, Jim Heekin, Frank Lowe and Brendan Ryan; chairman-chief executive John J Dooner Jr will be one of two remaining inside directors, along with Sean F Orr, executive vice president and chief financial officer (S)

headline: Personal Business; It's 5 P.M. Friday. Know Where Your Weekend Is?
abstract: Weekend is being increasingly colonized by work; at least fourth of nation's 130 million workers toil on Saturdays, Sundays or both for their main jobs and many more not formally scheduled for weekend work are working these days more often; many use technology for work purposes during time off; photo (M)

headline: Start-Ups Tailored to the Times Thrive
abstract: Substantial number of businesses in New York metropolitan areas are thriving despite terrorist attacks and recession, or at least they are weathering these shocks well; some are even hiring workers; these include pharmaceutical companies, munition suppliers, mobile-phone companies, security specialists, bankruptcy-related services, secondary education, fast food, public transportation and other businesses; photo (M)

headline: Bipartisan Outrage but Few Mea Culpas in Capital
abstract: The bipartisan chorus of outrage suggests a business scandal, not a political one.

headline: U.S. and Argentina Fight Over Honey
abstract: US and Argentina are fighting over honey exports as US accuses Argentina of dumping honey on American market; Argentina has become world's leading exporter of honey, selling nearly 90,000 tons per year to foreign markets, with almost half of it going to US; US has placed tariffs of up to 66 percent on Argentine honey, effectively shutting it out of market; decision, which went into effect in November, has dealt serious blow to industry that earned $86.6 million in much-needed foreign exchange in 2000 and provides livelihood to thousands of farmers; officials argue that Argentine beekeepers are being unfairly punished for being more efficient; Argentina's position is largely shared by honey importers in US; Sunland International president Nicholas Sargeantson says Argentine honey is very high quality, adding that some packers prefer it to domestic honey because it is cleaner; adds Commerce Department ruling against Argentina illustrates 'the immense hypocrisy of US trade law' (M)

headline: Ex-Chief Says He Didn't Know About Enron's Accounting Woes
abstract: The former chief executive of Enron insisted today that he knew nothing of accounting tricks meant to conceal losses.

headline: Brazil's Royal Scandal: Prince Is Said to Steal Aunt's Dishes
abstract: Internal problems in Brazil's imperial family are highlighted by theft of porcelain dishware by Pedro Tiago Bourbon Orleans e Braganca that originally belonged to his great-great-grandfather, last emperor of Brazil, and most recently were owned by Tiago's aunt Princess Cristina; Tiago is certain to be indicted and case highlights rift within normally circumspect imperial family (M)

headline: Agent Offers One-Stop TV Production
abstract: Ben Silverman is leaving William Morris talent agency to start company that will create, distribute and own television programming; says company, Reveille, will develop shows with multiple sources of financing, including foreign production companies and advertisers, to avoid usual television industry structure in which studio pays program's costs, receives fee from network that defrays part of cost and covers rest at deficit (M)

headline: Deciphering the Marks In a Web Page Address
abstract: Q. What do the tildes, question marks and equal signs in Web addresses mean?    A. These seemingly random punctuation marks in Web addresses usually have to do with where the Web page is stored on a server or with the steps taken by the server when you request the page from a Web site.

headline: New Hand-Helds With Color To Make a Peacock Blush
abstract: Sony and Casio introduce hand-held computers with color screens, Sony's running on Palm operating system and Casio's running on Microsoft's Pocket PC operating system; photos (S)

headline: Rates Remain High. Blame Bush Budget Or Big Expectations?
abstract: Do budget deficits matter to the economy?    Senator Tom Daschle, the highest-ranking Democrat in Washington, certainly thinks so. Last week, he blamed the Bush administration's fiscal policies for hampering an economic recovery. ''The rapidly disappearing surplus is a key reason long-term interest rates have barely budged,'' Senator Daschle said.

headline: Not in Finland Anymore? More Like Nokialand
abstract: Finns acknowledge Nokia's great contribution to national economy over last decade, but are becoming anxious about size of country's dependence on cellphone giant, especially after Jorma Ollila, chairman and chief executive, wonders aloud about lowering country's relatively high income-tax rate; fear Ollila may be ready to pull out of Finland, jeopardizing tax base that supports state's extensive welfare benefits; see disturbing collision between Finland's traditional, sheltered, high-tax society and harsher global rules by which Nokia is obliged to play; graph; photo (M)

headline: New Economy; A new stock offering should give some signal whether investors have forgiven Internet investments.
abstract: Matt Richtel New Economy column sees initial public offering of Paypal, which provides payment system for goods and services bought over Internet, testing investor appetite for Internet ventures; notes company, like many hot Internet stocks of past, is not profitable yet and faces potentially thorny regulatory obstacles but has potential for fast growth, has dominant position in new market and capitalizes on several commercially successful Internet facets; drawing (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Senate Committee to Vote To Subpoena Ex-Enron Chief  Republicans and Democrats on the Senate Commerce Committee said they would vote today to issue a subpoena to Kenneth L. Lay, the former chief executive of Enron, to compel his appearance.    Mr. Lay, who severed his final tie to Enron by resigning from its board, had infuriated lawmakers by canceling his appearance, saying through his lawyer that a series of Congressional hearings planned for this week had taken on a prosecutorial tone. [Page A1.]

headline: SIX ISRAELIS SLAIN BY ARAB GUNMAN
abstract: Lone Palestinian gunman with semiautomatic rifle opens fire in crowded reception hall in Hadera, Israel, killing 6 people and wounding at least 25; in retaliation, Israeli forces bomb governor's headquarters in Palestinian-controlled town of Tulkarm in West Bank, and Israeli tanks roll through Ramallah, where Israel has confined Yasir Arafat for last month; witnesses to attack in Hadera say assailant's gun apparently jammed, and he was then knocked to ground and beaten; say three police officers arrived at scene and shot him dead; scores of children and adults were in reception hall for bat mitzvah party; assault comes after four days of escalating violence; renewed fighting, following month of relative calm, leaves in tatters latest cease-fire between Israelis and Palestinians; photos; map (M)

headline: BUSH RECONSIDERS STAND ON TREATING CAPTIVES OF WAR
abstract: Pres Bush, following lengthy meeting with national security team, says he is reconsidering whether Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters held at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, should be protected under Geneva Convention, but reiterates that they are 'killers' who will not be granted prisoner-of-war status; says US is adhering to 'spirit' of Geneva Convention; was asked by Sec of State Colin Powell to reconsider decision made on January 18; Powell agrees capitves should not be classified as prisoners of war, but is seeking to have administration affirm that international law of war governs US in its treatment of captives; Bush's unusual request to reverse decision exposes clear split within administration; officials say Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, reflecting concerns of Joint Chiefs of Staff, has moved to support Powell's view; military officials fear by denying capitives protections of Geneva Convention, US is setting precedent that could put future American battlefield captives at risk; Powell's call for review of policy comes after European leaders bluntly criticized American decision; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Old Foe Of Mobutu Seeks Presidency
abstract: Etienne Tshisekedi, longtime opposition leader to late Mobutu Sese Seko, declares his candidacy for presidency of Congo; says he will not take part in national unity government headed by Pres Joseph Kabila and that Kabila should be replaced; photo (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Online travel businesses are finding that there is money to be made offline, particularly in selling expensive vacations.
abstract: Expedia and other online travel companies are slowly growing roots in offline travel world, while also exploring avenues like televised shopping; follow lead of other e-commerce retailers in offering consumers array of shopping options; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Police Arrest Students
abstract: Police in Iran raid Tehran office of country's leading student movement, influential pro-reform group, and arrest 40 members (S)

headline: Broad Support in Pakistan for a Promised Purge of Islamic Militants
abstract: Gen. Pervez Musharraf's pledges in a speech on Saturday to sever links to terrorism in Kashmir appear to have won broad public support.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Risks Persist, Panel Says
abstract: Computer systems in the United States are increasingly vulnerable to attack despite plentiful technology to make them secure, a report published by the National Academy of Sciences says. Citing 10 years of studies, the authors of the report, ''Cybersecurity Today and Tomorrow: Pay Now or Pay Later,'' say that ''our ability and willingness to deal with threats has, on balance, changed for the worse.'' Industry needs to do more to build security directly into new hardware and software, the authors wrote, and policy makers should finance research and consider ''steps that would increase the exposure of software and system vendors and system operators to liability for system breaches.'' The report can be found at http://books.nap .edu/html/cybersecurity.   John Schwartz (NYT)

headline: CNN Headline News Anchor Says She'll Leave Network
abstract: Andrea Thompson, former NYPD Blue actress whose hiring by CNN Headline News last year was panned by critics as extreme example of melding of news and entertainment, is leaving network; comments; CNN says Sophia Choi will take Thompson's place from 6 pm to 10 pm; photo (M)

headline: U.S. PLANS TO ACT MORE RIGOROUSLY IN HOSTAGE CASES
abstract: Bush administration after protracted debate that pitted State Department against Defense Department adopts new policy that requires federal government to review every kidnapping of American overseas for possible action; under new policy, Hostage Subgroup, committee of officials from several agencies led by National Security Agency, will examine every case in which American is taken hostage to assess whether intervention is warranted; new policy envisages wide range of options to save hostages, from providing advice on negotiations to American-led commando raids; will not require government to become directly involved in every kidnapping; opponents of policy, particularly at Pentagon, say approach will build pressure on government to win release of hostages and will give foes of US more incentive to kidnap Americans; photo (M)

headline: In Tehran Visit, Karzai Appeals to Iran and U.S. to Make Up
abstract: Hamid Karzai, leader of Afghanistan's interim government, visits Tehran and appeals to Iran and United States to put aside their differences and help build his war-ravaged country; meets with Pres Mohammad Khatami and praises Iran for assistance it gave Afghanistan against Taliban; urges economic help; Khatami reaffirms his support for Karzai's government; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: First Lady's Nephew Jailed
abstract: Nephew South Korean Pres Kim Dae Jung's wife is jailed on corruption charges; Lee Hyong Tack allegedly conspired to inflate value of company looking for gold on sunken ship (S)

headline: Londonderry Journal; 'Bloody Sunday' of '72: Digging Anew for the Truth
abstract: On Jan 30, 1972, day known since as Bloody Sunday, British paratroopers fatally shot 14 unarmed Roman Catholic civil rights marchers in streets of Londonderry, Northern Ireland; now, 30 years later and just blocks from scene, event is being painstakingly recreated in longest legal inquiry in British history; photos (Londonderry Journal) (M)

headline: Disney Earnings Are Better Than Expected
abstract: Walt Disney Co reports net income of $438 million for its first fiscal quarter in contrast with loss of $36 million in period year earlier, beating Wall Street's expectations; revenue fell 5 percent, to $7.05 billion from $7.43 billion; chief executive Michael D Eisner and president Robert A Iger comment (M)

headline: PÃ´rto Alegre Journal; A Leftist City Makes Money to Its Own Drummer
abstract: World Social Forum is held in Porto Alegre, socialist stronghold in southern Brazil to counter World Economic Forum in New York; meeting, from which World Bank and other pillars of global economic establishment, are excluded affords city leaders opportunity to swap ideas on containing global capitalism with representatives of European and American left; participants run gamut from members of Brazilian fringe groups to polished members of European parliament; maps; photo (M)

headline: Novell Official Says He Sought Microsoft's Aid
abstract: Novell Inc's chief technology officer Carl S Ledbetter says Novell offered two years ago to tell antitrust enforcers that Microsoft Corp altered its behavior in return for help promoting its products, testimony in case involving nine states seeking tougher remedies than those Microsoft accepted to settle federal government's case; Michael Mace, chief competitive officer of Palm, testifies that Microsoft planned to make its .Net Internet software incompatible with Palm devices to bolster its competing product, Pocket PC (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Maker of Crowd Scanner Is on the Defensive Again
abstract: Graphco Technologies' security system, which uses cameras to scan crowds, will not be used during Olympic events at E Center in Salt Lake City; organizers cite technical shortcomings, but company says decision was based on resolved commercial issues (S)

headline: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS
abstract: ANDERSEN LOSES BUSINESS -- Clients of Arthur Andersen are asking questions about its role in Enron's collapse, and the firm is losing business as a result.   BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Looking Ahead Before Stepping Down
abstract: Kenyan Pres Daniel arap Moi addresses Parliament for what may be final time before he is scheduled to leave office after election later this year; photo (S)

headline: Arabs Say Israel Is Undermining Peace Moves
abstract: Top Arab officials warn that Israel's action in West Bank will cause collapse of efforts to renew peace negotiations and will undermine visits of two senior American officials, Gen Anthony C Zinni and Vice Pres Dick Cheney; Amr Moussa, secretary general of Arab League, says Arab countries cannot talk about Saudi proposal to make peace with Israel while Israeli aggression proceeds against Palestinians; photo (M)

headline: Founding Editor of Slate, Online Pioneer, Quits
abstract: Michael Kinsley, pioneering figure in Web publishing, steps down as editor of Slate, online magazine he conceived; Kinsley, who announced in December that he has had Parkinson's disease for last eight years, says decision was not driven by his health, but was influenced by it; deputy editor Jack Shafer will serve as interim editor for six weeks to be followed by Jacob Weisberg for another six weeks; at end of that time, editor will be selected; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: McDonald's Profit Falls
abstract: McDonald's of Japan's second-half profit falls 67 percent as customers shun beef products because of Japan's first cases of mad cow disease (S)

headline: U.N. Pleads for Afghan Aid While U.S. Jets Raid Compound
abstract: UN makes impassioned plea to foreign governments to increase financial donations to interim government in Kabul, Afghanistan, which is unable to pay its workers; says country needs $100 million within few days to pay six months of back salaries, as well as six months of wages to its 235,000 employees; says less than $10 million has been donated; American warplanes bomb al-Qaeda training compound near Pakistani border for 10th time in 11 days; senior Pentagon officials say operation is nearly complete; photo (M)

headline: A Ruling in Auction Houses' Case Is Reversed
abstract: US Appeals Court reverses Judge Lewis A Kaplan's decision and orders additional consideration of class-action lawsuit on behalf of auction house customers who contend that Sotheby's and Christie's colluded to fix fees charged to buyers and sellers in foreign transactions (M)

headline: Sharon Said to Meet Secretly With 3 Aides to Arafat
abstract: Palestinian officials say Prime Min Ariel Sharon met secretly with three Palestinian envoys of Yasir Arafat, Israeli leader's first such meeting since taking office; two sides reportedly restate clashing views; Sharon tells newspaper he will urge Pres Bush to sever ties and 'boycott' Arafat; photos of Sharon and of Palestinians stoning Israeli soldiers in Ramallah (M)

headline: Designers Take Robots Out of Human Hands
abstract: Researchers are working to create independent robots that can cope with complicated jobs on their own; seek to endow robots with enough intellience and versatility to be, in jargon of field, autonomous--able to work out complex problems by computer without help from their creators; photos (M)

headline: Downsizing Videotape, Yet Again
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on Sony's new MicroMV, world's smallest videocassette, and matching tiny camcorder; drawing; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Beauty In The Eye Of The Government
abstract: Vietnam government will recognize and certify for first time winner of Miss Vietnam beauty pageant that has been held every other year since 1988 (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: EMC Falls On Analysts' Comments
abstract: Shares of EMC Corp fall almost 5 percent after Salomon Smith Barney analyst H Clinton Vaughan and Pacific Growth Equities analyst Thomas Mancino say they do not think company will meet estimates (S)

headline: Schroeder and Stoiber Grapple for German Swing Vote
abstract: BERLINâ€”  Like a sash of office, an enormous red banner is suspended diagonally these days from roof to ground level over the facade of the Christian Democratic Union's headquarters building. A white-lettered inscription leaps out from the red background. It asks: "How many more jobless, Herr Schroeder?"

headline: Board Dashes Cold Water On Public Feud at Viacom Between Top Executives
abstract: Viacom board members tell chairman-chief executive Sumner M Redstone and president-chief operating officer Mel Karmazin to end personal conflict between them that has emerged into public view; group of outside directors makes plea in unusual separate meeting that occurs after regularly scheduled board meeting; Redstone and Karmazin are said to have agreed to board's request that they try to resolve their differences; directors tell two executives that they fear that public disagreements between them could have serious impact on company's financial outlook; recent articles in various publications raise possibility that Redstone is preparing to try to force Karmazin out of company; Karmazin's contract ends in May 2003; it appears that directors' action is defeat for Redstone; list of members on Viacom's board (M)

headline: Israeli Efforts To Pressure Arafat Get U.S. Support
abstract: Bush administration, stepping up weeks of pressure on Yasir Arafat, expresses support for Israel's confinement of Palestinian leader to his West Bank compound and says next step in ending violence in region is up to him (M)

headline: Directions From a Device That Knows Which Way Is Up
abstract: Navman GPS, new device for Palm's latest crop of hand-held organizers, uses satellite technology to pinpoint location anywhere on earth with accuracy within five meters; photo (M)

headline: Man in the News; Peronist for the Present; Eduardo Alberto Duhalde
abstract: Biographical sketch of Eduardo Duhalde, Argentina's fifth president in two weeks; he was born Oct 5, 1941; photo (M)

headline: 2 Marines Killed and 5 Injured As Helicopter Crashes Near Base
abstract: Two marines are killed and five injured when their helicopter crashes in mountainous area south of Bagram air base in northern Afghanistan (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Fund Manager Revises Results
abstract: Schroders revises its 2000 profit downward because of accounting error that inflated earnings by about $16 million; says error is related to fees paid by clients; denies overcharging; 2001 pretax profit was as much as 10 percent below analyts' forecasts of about $100 million; graph (S)

headline: German Bank Offers to Buy Kirch Asset
abstract: Bayerische Hypo-und Vereinsbank is offering to pay about $1 billion for Kirch Group's stake in Axel Springer Verlag, Germany's biggest publisher of newspapers and magazines; though cash will not completely solve Kirch Group's problems, it will buy company extra time (M)

headline: Less Than Super
abstract: Super Bowl Sunday tends to have depressing effect on movie business, with movies selling most tickets during that weekend each year tending to be ones least likely to appeal to football fan; major studios did not roll out any new movies for general release this year on Super Bowl weekend; graphs; photo (S)

headline: Showing in Canada: The Mystery of the Falling Dollar
abstract: It's hard to say what they are, but Americans generally love them and Canadians hate them: the mysterious forces that have pushed the value of Canada's dollar relentlessly downward to new lows in recent weeks.    The Canadian dollar -- nicknamed the loonie because of the loon depicted on dollar coins -- has been declining fairly steadily for three decades, a drop that has angered Canadians and puzzled the nation's leading economists. Experts are at a loss to explain why the exchange rate continues to erode even when the economy itself is fundamentally sound.

headline: London Journal; Uneasy Heads in the Palace: Will Jubilee Year Flop?
abstract: Celebration of Queen Elizabeth II's 50th year on British throne gets off to inauspicious start, and there are fears that it might become rerun of botched millennium celebrations; British public has become less deferential to monarchy and less appreciative of royal family since 1977, when queen had triumphant Silver Jubilee; photo (M)

headline: IT GROUP SEEKS CHAPTER 11 AND AGREES TO SELL ASSETS
abstract: Shaw Group agrees to pay $105 million in cash and stock and assume liabilities to buy most of IT Group, hazardous-waste manager, which has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: India Welcomes Pakistani Steps, but Stays Alert
abstract: The Indian government on Sunday welcomed the commitment by Pakistan's military ruler not to allow his country to be used as a base for terrorism.

headline: Thinking the Unthinkable, Again
abstract: News analysis of controversy over whether US would consider pre-emptive nuclear strike to prevent hostile states from obtaining weapons of mass destruction (M)

headline: Italy Cooling On Europe, And 2 Aides Explain Why
abstract: Italy scales back its vision of European integration; will no longer sacrifice national interests in favor of common European agenda; Defense Min Antonio Martino says nation will cooperate mainly on defense and foreign policy, but that anything that can be done better at national level should be; new model within European Union is Britain, historically much more reserved partner; Rocco Buttiglione, minister of European Union policy, says Italy will push not only for less regulation from Brussels, but for overhaul of European institutions that make rules (M)

headline: In a word : When deception is deceiving:false friends and other enemies
abstract: PARISâ€”  One of the more vexing aspects of getting to know a language is the phenomenon described in French as faux amis, or false friends. They could better be described as true enemies.

headline: Tyco Says Expense Prepayment Used in '99 Deal
abstract: Tyco International says it encouraged Raychem, electronic components maker that it bought in 1999, to prepay some expenses before acquisition was completed; Tyco executives have denied that Tyco changes payment practices of companies it buys before takeovers are final; Tyco spokesman Brad McGee says prepayments at Raychem were standard business practices and did not contradict company's earlier statements (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Trade Surplus Grows
abstract: Canada's trade surplus climbed to its highest level in nine months in January, with exports rising at almost twice pace of imports; surplus with US widened to 7.61 billion Canadian dollars ($4.8 billion) from 6.76 billion in December; overall surplus in January was 5.1 billion Canadian dollars, up from 4.5 billion previous month; exports grew to 33.01 billion Canadian dollars from 32.01 billion (S)

headline: A. A. Sommer Jr., 77, Commissioner on the S.E.C. in the 70's
abstract: A A Sommer Jr, corporate and securities lawyer and former SEC commissioner, dies at age 77; photo (M)

headline: CALPINE RECEIVES $1 BILLION LINE OF CREDIT
abstract: Calpine, power plant developer, has been granted $1 billion in unsecured credit, increasing its finances for third time since its credit rating was cut month ago (S)

headline: Hunt for U.S. Reporter Leading to Dead Ends
abstract: Police in Pakistan report that arrest and interrogation of Ahmed Omar Sheikh, chief suspect in kidnapping of American journalist Daniel Pearl, has produced no solid evidence on Pearl's whereabouts or whether he is still alive; Gen Perez Musharraf, in visit to Washington, says he is 'reasonably sure' that Pearl is still alive, and that he regards abduction as retaliation by Muslim extremists to his efforts to crack down on terror; it is unclear whether police found Sheikh or whether he turned himself in as part of arrangement for freeing of relatives and colleagues who have been detained in case; photo (M)

headline: A Nation Challenged: The Afghan Army; In a Land of Warlords, Boot Camp Drills and Big Dreams
abstract: New national army is beginning to take shape in Afghanistan at old Soviet military base in outskirts of Kabul; NATO instructors are training 600 recruits during six-week course of drills familiar to any military recruit; plan is to eventually assemble army of 50,000 to 60,000 troops with modern weapons and loyalty to democratically elected, multiethnic government; hope is that era of warlordism, of thuggish militia bosses who now hold much of Afghanistan in thrall will be history; photos (M)

headline: Auction Losers, Backstage
abstract: Cheryl A Herman letter on March 7 article on Internet auction fraud

headline: Geneva Convention to Be Applied to Captured Taliban Fighters
abstract: President Bush has decided to apply the Geneva Convention to Taliban fighters, the White House announced today.

headline: Pakistani Suspect Tells Court Abducted U.S. Reporter Is Dead
abstract: Ahmed Omar Saeed Sheikh said today that Daniel Pearl was dead. But Pakistani authorities held out hope he was alive.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Fine Living, Los Angeles, named the Los Angeles office of Crispin Porter & Bogusky to handle the creative and media planning duties for the introduction of the Fine Living cable television network, Web site and magazine.

headline: Business; Insurers Find Profit in a New Risk Consciousness
abstract: Insurance companies are doing brisk business in political risk coverage as American companies with overseas operations seek protection against against terrorism, riot, civil war, strikes, coups d'etat, nationalization and government interference with flow of profits back home; terrorism coverage used to be included in general property policies at little or no extra charge, but many property insurers are refusing to provide terrorism coverage that way, forcing companies to buy it separately or as part of political risk package; photo; table (M)

headline: TITAN BUYS A MAKER OF RADAR SYSTEMS FOR THE MILITARY
abstract: Titan Corp acquires Jaycor Inc, manufacturer of radar and communications systems, for $95 million in stock (S)

headline: Wall St. Analysts Tell Congress They Were Misled by Enron
abstract: Analysts told lawmakers today that they were fooled by misleading statements from the company.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Afternoon Trading Resumes
abstract: Philippine Stock Exchange will resume afternoon trading Feb 21 for first time in more than two decades (S)

headline: MCI Names Deutsch For Consumer Ads
abstract: MCI, unit of WorldCom Inc, expands its agency roster by shifting consumer advertising for MCI brand without review to Deutsch; assignment had been held by Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG; billings could reach as much as $100 million (S)

headline: Beijing Journal; Seeking Justice, Clad in the Armor of Persistence
abstract: Thousands of petitioners make way to Beijing each year when China's National People's Congress meets, in hopes of redressing unresolved complaints; must contend with wide dragnet of police officers and officials whose job is to protect city's image of untroubled stability, especially while country's legislators are on show; photos (M)

headline: PAPER AND BOX MAKER DROPS TENDER OFFER FOR RIVAL
abstract: Temple-Inland, a paper and box maker, dropped its $841 million tender offer for a rival, the Gaylord Container Corporation, after the bid failed to attract the minimum amount of shares and notes. The takeover bid drew criticism from some of Gaylord's bondholders, who said the offer was inadequate. Temple-Inland, based in Austin, Tex., offered 87.5 cents on the dollar for the bonds and $1.25 a share. As of yesterday's deadline, only 84 percent of Gaylord's 47.2 million shares were tendered. Temple-Inland will return all Gaylord shares and notes to their holders. Gaylord is based in Deerfield, Ill.

headline: The Fiber Optic Fantasy Slips Away
abstract: Swaps of fiber market access appear to have been important common ingredient in epidemic of accounting fiascos at Global Crossing, Qwest Communications International and Cable and Wireless, and they also seem to have played role in cascading problems of Enron and Tyco International; SEC and FBI are now searching for signs of sham transactions and fraudulent accounting; photos; drawings; graphs (L)

headline: Computers for the People in Brazil
abstract: By last May, with turmoil in Argentina and a homegrown energy crisis sending computer sales plummeting in this country, executives at the Brazilian computer manufacturer Metron L. Indústria Eletrônica were thinking that nothing less than a miracle could salvage the company's revenue.     Help came in the beatific smile of Silvio Santos, the media and finance tycoon who is the host of the ''Show of the Million,'' the extremely popular Brazilian version of the American television quiz show ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire.''

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Citigroup Names New President Amid Talk of More Acquisitions
abstract: Citigroup names Robert B Willumstad president, position unfilled since departure of James Dimon in November 1998; move comes amid talk that chief executive Sanford I Weill is preparing to make more acquisitions; analysts say appointment appears to place Willumstad as leading candidate to succeed Weill and reinforces importance of consumer operation, which accounts for half of Citigroup's profits; FleetBoston Financial is seen as potential takeover target; Fleet spokesman James Mahoney denies that merge is in works; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Some Politicians Give Away Contributions From Enron
abstract: Bulk of money contributed to charitable funds that are helping former Enron employees has come from politicians who are either anxious to purge themselves of guilt for accepting contributions or simply feel it is appropriate to return donations from people who have fallen on hard times; some political contributions noted; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Africa; SIERRA LEONE: REBEL LEADER BARRED FROM ELECTION
abstract: Foday Sankoh, Sierra Leone rebel leader who has been imprisoned for last two years and is now being tried on murder charges, is not eligible to run in presidential election scheduled for May 14 (S)

headline: Trump Hotels Settles Case Accusing It of Misleading Investors
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission, in its first enforcement action involving abuse of so-called pro forma accounting, charges that Trump Hotels and Casino Inc 'recklessly' misled shareholders in 1999; Trump Hotels agrees to settle charges and consents to SEC's cease-and-desist order, acknowledging its findings without admitting or denying them (M)

headline: Republicans Give Bankruptcy Bill a Push
abstract: Congressional Republicans are trying to bring momentum to months of negotiations with Senate Democrats to pass bankruptcy overhaul bill; House Judiciary Committee, in proposal that was made to Senate Judiciary Committee, agrees to kill disputed provision of bill that some lawyers have linked to Enron Corp; proposal would eliminate provision that related to certain asset-backed securities; bill would have made it impossible for assets shifted off company's balance sheet into separate entity to be pulled back into that company's estate after bankrptcy filing; lawyers opposing provision have agreed that Enron made frequent use of this sort of financing; Rep F James Sensenbrenner Jr says bankruptcy bill is alive and well, and its future has never been better (M)

headline: Dead and Missing
abstract: Death toll from Sept 11 terrorist attacks now estimated at 3,062

headline: While Burning Music on CD's, A Drive Also Burns Rubber
abstract: Comment on new internal CE-RW drive made by Philips Electronics; drive can copy recordable discs at speeds up to 32x, burn rewritable CD's at speed up to 10x and read discs at 40x; photo (S)

headline: World Bank, in Report, Defends Its Use of Aid
abstract: World Bank says its aid programs help ease poverty and allow poor people to 'live longer, healthier and more productive lives,' defending its track record against Bush administration charges that it has been ineffective; Pres Bush wants to overhaul World Bank and convert many of its loans into grants; European leaders have resisted, saying real problem is that US devotes too little money to fighting poverty (M)

headline: Korean Unification Minister Is One of 8 Replaced in Reshuffle
abstract: President Kim Dae Jung today dismissed the minister in charge of pursuing peace with North Korea as part of a cabinet shake-up.

headline: NEWS CORPORATION AGREES TO TRADE TELEVISION STATION
abstract: News Corp agrees to exchanges KPTV, its television station in Portland, Ore, for two Meredith Corp stations in Florida, WOFL in Orlando and WOGX in Ocala (S)

headline: Afghan Aid Meeting Ends
abstract: Two-day international donor conference on rebuilding Afghanistan ends in Tokyo with more than $4.5 billion in pledges through 2005; interim Afghan President Hamid Karzai expresses gratitude (S)

headline: In Caucasus, the Peaceful Separatists
