abstract: Profile of Ingushetia, island of relative stability in rough-and-tumble politics of Russia's far-flung republics; Ruslan Aushev, elected in 1993, hs steered republic away from war and toward prosperity while playing host to hundreds of thousands of Chechen refugees and Russian soldiers passing through; Aushev's high-handed ways infuriate critics who charge him with interfering with elections; photos; map (M)

headline: Market Place; New rules help AOL Time Warner, but put it to a test.
abstract: IT sounded like good news for AOL Time Warner, as well as its investors. On Monday the company announced a big charge against its first-quarter earnings to cover the declining values of some assets since the merger of AOL and Time Warner was completed. And the company noted that new accounting rules would free it from having to take similar charges in the future.    Those costs were to be accounted for over decades, resulting in a big hit to earnings each year. But now they would be out of the way, allowing the company to report far better earnings in quarters to come.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Candidate's Husband Target Of Raid
abstract: Brazil's Liberal Front Party threatens to withdraw from governing coalition after police raid business office of husband of its candidate for president Roseana Sarney; police sought evidence of his involvement in corruption scandal (M)

headline: Sotheby's Posts Smaller Losses
abstract: Sotheby's Holdings says fourth-quarter loss fell to $400,000 from $6.5 million year earlier; posts net loss of $41.7 million for all of 2001; announces changes in fees charged to buyers as of April 1; will charge 19.5 percent on first $100,000 of transaction and 10 percent after that (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: Premier Said To Step Down
abstract: Prime Min Jean-Marie Cherestal of Haiti has reportedly resigned; he was about to face no-confidence vote from members of Parliament displeased about country's social and economic woes (S)

headline: Bush Seeks Terror Pledge By Pakistan
abstract: President Bush warned today that the standoff between India and Pakistan remained serious and volatile, and he called on Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's military ruler, to make a clear pledge to crack down on terrorism.    ''I don't believe the situation is defused yet, but I do believe there is  a way to do so, and we are working hard to convince both the Indians and the Pakis there's a way to deal with their problems without going to war,'' Mr. Bush told reporters at the White House.

headline: Mideast Envoy, 'Encouraged,' Calls Meeting
abstract: Anthony C Zinni, Bush administration's Middle East peace envoy, meeets Palestinian officials and pronounces himself encouraged despite debate surrounding Israel's seizure of ship carrying arms that it said were destined for Palestinian Authority (M)

headline: A Nation Challenged: The Combat; U.S. Tells How Rescue Turned Into Fatal Firefight
abstract: United States official describe grueling battle in which American Special Operations forces fought off Al Qaeda ambush in eastern Afghanistan after being trapped by intense fire for 12 hours, unable to evacuate wounded; say American forces returned to site where two helicopters were attacked while touching down after discovering that Navy Petty Officer Neil C Roberts had fallen from helicopter and watching him via airborne surveillance video being dragged off to his death by Al Qaeda fighters; say 7 Americans died and 11 were wounded in ambush of would-be rescuers; say hard-core Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters suffered heavy casualties while putting up surprisingly fierce resistance; senior officers predict remaining Al Qaeda and Taliban will be captured or killed in coming days; photos (M)

headline: Hewlett's Shareholders Meet Today on Compaq Merger
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Corp's shareholders will meet at Flint Center in Cupertino, Calif, to vote on acquiring Compaq Computer Co (M)

headline: European Central Bank President Stepping Down
abstract: European Central Bank president Wim Duisenberg says he will retire in July 2003, opening new phase in what is already tangled succession struggle; announcement does not resolve intensely political question of his successor, issue that French and German leaders thought they had settled more than three years ago; France's Pres Jacques Chirac badly wants next president to be Bank of France governor Jean-Claude Trichet; Trichet remains entangled in criminal investigations of collapse and bailout of French bank Credit Lyonnais in early 1990's; European leaders have not challenged widespread presumption that Duisenberg's successor will be French; economists say succession struggle is unlikely to have any impact on monetary policy or on exchange rate of beleaguered euro; photo (M)

headline: U.S. More Wary on Bailouts Abroad
abstract: John B Taylor, under secretary for international affairs, intends to bring Bush administration's hands-off market-based philosophy to troubled countries around world; in biggest crisis on his watch so far--Argentina's default on much of it debt--Taylor has left American creditors to fend for themselves; Taylor says financial crises are less likely to spread beyond their country of origin because research into creditworthiness of emerging economies has improved; that means rationale for US and other wealthy nations to step in and bail out countries like Argentina has dwindled; Taylor says US and other governments should work to improve flow of information between international borrowers and lenders instead of intervening after crisis; photo (M)

headline: Some Lots of Claritin-D Are Recalled
abstract: Schering-Plough Corp will voluntarily recall some

headline: Ford Mustang Said to Have Failed Company Crash Tests
abstract: Joseph A Fried, lawyer who obtained numerous internal Ford Motor Co documents as part of civil suit, says Ford Mustang repeatedly failed Ford's internal crash tests for fuel tank integrity while it was being redesigned in early 1990's, but it met broader company guidelines and production version later passed government tests; although Ford officials acknowledge that Mustang did fail some tests, they strongly disagree there are any problems with Mustang's design, pointing out that it passed 1996 test conducted by National Highway Traffic Safety Administration; Fried has filed suit for family of Daniele Wright, who died from burn injuries suffered after collision involving her 1996 Mustang convertible (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Jobless Rate Rises
abstract: Brazil's unemployment rate rose to 6.8 percent in January compared with 5.6 percent in December (S)

headline: Filing by Cisco Has New Data On Its Finances
abstract: Cisco Systems file statement with Securities and Exchange Commission that includes new disclosures about its financial positions, development Cisco officials attribute to heightened calls for openness by public companies; Cisco says it reached deals to acquire four private technology companies, but it says purchase prices would depend on whether companies met certain obligations; also explains how it made some financial estimates; controller Dennis P Powell comments (M)

headline: Unhappy With Settlement, Sun Sues Microsoft
abstract: Sun Microsystems, dissatisfied with federal government's antitrust settlement with Microsoft, files private lawsuit accusing Microsoft of 'choking off' Sun's Java programming language through illegal behavior (M)

headline: One of Madison Avenue's oldest and best-known figures is leaving the arena.
abstract: Stuart Elliott profile of Philip B Dusenberry, one of best-known, most honored creative executives in advertising, who is retiring from BBDO, where he has spent lion's share of his careeer; photo (M)

headline: Where Pain of Arthur Andersen Is Personal
abstract: Once-proud founding families of Arthur Andersen & Co are humiliated by Enron Corp debacle; Arthur Edward Andersen III, founder's grandson, has little to say other than 'we have to wait for the facts'; Judith A Spacek, daughter of company's other pioneering executive, Leonard P Spacek, who died two years ago at age 92, says her father emerged as conscience of accounting industry after he retired from Andersen in 1973; Bruce Spacek, Spacek's son, says he is disappointed by what has become of his father's legacy; company's history discussed; photo (M)

headline: Chinese Prosecutors Deal A Full Deck of Warnings
abstract: Prosecutors in Qiuxian, China, distribute to thousands of local officials and police officers decks of playing cards with forbidden messages in crackdown against two main vices; devoting inordinate time to poker games and using official powers for political gain; each card carries legal definition of 'crime of public office' and cartoon depicting illegality; photo (M)

headline: Setting the Time on the Benefits Clock
abstract: Uncertainty about life expectancy can add mystery to retirement planning; some questions answered about how and when to take Social Security and pension benefits; advice on recovering pensions from companies that may have merged with others; drawing; (special section, Retirement) (L)

headline: Rumsfeld Discounts Iraq's Offer to Discuss Pilot's Fate
abstract: Bush administration voices deep skepticism over reported offer from Iraq to discuss status of Lt Comdr Michael Scott Speicher, American pilot shot down during Persian Gulf war in 1991; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says supposed offer was reported only through news media outlets and not through formal channels between both countries, warning Iraqis are 'masters at propaganda;' photo (S)

headline: Drawn to the Hearth's Electronic Glow
abstract: Home theater, composed of television, speakers, receiver, video player and recorder and comfortable seating from which to enjoy it, becomes full-blown marketing concept; prices range from as low as $1,000 for simple setup to $35,000 and up for elaborate systems that closely replicate theater experience; explosion in sales of DVD's is main catalyst for home theater craze; drawing; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: World Briefing

headline: Advanced Micro Makes Pact With Taiwan Chip Producer
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices, maker of microprocessors for personal computers, enters broad manufacturing alliance with United Microelectronics Corp, contract chip maker; companies say they will build chip factory in Singapore, and form joint venture, called AU, to run plant, which they expect to begin full-scale production in 2005; Advanced Micro hires United Microelectronics, which is based in Taiwan, to manufacture some of its personal computer chips (M)

headline: For Those With a Disability, The Word Made Digital
abstract: Bookshare.org, Web database that contains thousands of books, is designed for those with visual or reading disability; photo (M)

headline: GLOBALSTAR FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
abstract: Globalstar files for bankruptcy protection after spending more than $4 billion to build satellite-telephone network that failed to attract enough customers (S)

headline: From the Skin Artist, Always a Free Makeover
abstract: Comment on graphic designers who create online, and freely distribute, skins, graphical interfaces that act as both face and control panel of computer program; rather than settling for manufacturers' often mundane built-in visuals, they make and trade their own; photo of Steve Moss, graphic designer (M)

headline: Enron Ruling By Nominee To U.S. Court Is Being Noticed
abstract: Texas Supreme Court Justice Priscilla Owen who has been nominated by Pres Bush to fill vacant federal judgeship could face fierce Senate confirmation fight because her critics say she once wrote opinion that saved Enron Corp about $15 million after accepting campaign contributions from company; liberal groups plan to use her connections to Enron to try to derail her nomination; in 1996, Owen's critics note she wrote majority opinion in unanimous decision that reversed lower court order and reduced by about $15 million amount of school taxes paid by Enron; Texans for Public Justice study shows that since 1993, Enron has contributed $134,058 to members of state Supreme Court, including donation to Owen; photo (M)

headline: Bamboozling the TV Viewer
abstract: John Burgeson letter derides virtual television newsrooms (March 14 article)

headline: Unease Grows In Philippines On U.S. Forces
abstract: Political firestorm erupts in Philippines over impending arrival of 650 American soldiers dispatched to help battle Islamic insurgency; there are calls for impeachment of Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo; Vice Pres Teofisto Guingona denies rumors that he will resign as foreign secretary, but he has been publicly unenthusiastic; Philippine and American officials, seeking to calm political furor, stress that Filipinos will do fighting and Americans will do advising; newspapers feature banner headlines quoting Sen Sam Brownback of Kansas referring to Philippines as 'the next Afghanistan'; Bownback was discussing American missionary couple being held hostage by Abu Sayyaf insurgents, who are suspected of having links to Al Qaeda (M)

headline: A Naptime Tool for the Visor (No, It's Not a Flannel Blanket)
abstract: Jetlog Corp offers module for Handspring's Visor hand-held computer it says will improve effectiveness of naps by preventing excessively deep or prolonged sleeping; uses alarm with increasing volume to limit naps to optimum 40 minutes; photo (S)

headline: Olympics and a Disputed Land Swap Bolster a Utah Resort's Prospects
abstract: Olympics and a Disputed Land Swap Bolster a Utah Resort's Prospects**R Earl Holding, whose Snowbasin resort will host several Salt Lake City Winter Olympic Games ski events, used Olympic plan as leverage to make disputed 1996 land exchange with Forest Service that added over two square miles to resort's base; has since spent some $100 million on lifts, lodges and snowmaking equipment; land deal has given uneasy prominence to man who has long avoided publicity; photos (M)

headline: A New Scrutiny of Somalia as the Old Anarchy Reigns
abstract: United States has taken new interest in Somalia since Sept 11, believing it may become Osama bin Laden's hiding place, refuge for experienced terrorists and breeding ground for new ones; two governments, two breakaway states, five clan groups and over 30 individual clans are fighting for control within Somalia; country is so fractured that nominal government controls less than half of its capital city and some coastal strips; fear that Americans will bomb or invade has ebbed in last month, but American and European warships patrol coast, looking for ships or planes smuggling in lieutenants of Al Qaeda; photos; map (M)

headline: Market Place; Disclosure Is Now Name Of the Game For More Banks
abstract: Executives at many companies are telling analysts and investors to expect more detailed disclosures in their year-end filings with Securities and Exchange Commission; moves are in response to investor uneasiness after Enron Corp collapse; finance companies, including commercial banks, are expected to be in spotlight because of nature of their business, which involves trades, loans and other dealings on behalf of third parties (M)

headline: Charm and the West Keep Afghan in Power, for Now
abstract: Hamid Karzai, chairman of Afghanistan's interim government installed after Taliban's collapse, has cut dynamic figure in Kabul and West, eclipsing expectations that he was merely stand-in for Western coalition that ousted Taliban; is entering second half of six-month term amid growing signs that government over which he presides is troubled enterprise, sustained almost entirely by his charisma and Western cash; turmoil that could ultimately threaten government, from ethnic strife to battles among warlords, percolates everywhere outside capital, where there seems little evidence of central government at all; government has been unable to provide basic security, and soldiers nominally in its employ are often agents of chaos; civil servants in nearly every province have gone unpaid since Karzai's government took office; taxes, if collected at all, appear only rarely to reach government's coffers; Karzai often appears to be less head of state than mayor; has ventured in three months in office only occasionally into provinces, which seem separated from Kabul by centuries; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: New Chief At Netratings
abstract: NetRatings Inc says William Pulver will become chief executive, replacing Dave Toth, who resigned (S)

headline: A Growing Number of Potential Targets for Lawsuits
abstract: List of deep-pocketed potential targets of civil and criminal lawsuits resulting from Enron Corp collapse grows with each new report of possible misdeeds by professionals who worked for or with company; variety of major companies might just end up paying damages to help compensate victims of Enron's implosion; some creditors are just starting to consider suing (M)

headline: Security Bill for Australia Is Too Broad, Critics Say
abstract: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 9 â€” Australia wants firmer penalties and longer jail sentences for convicted spies and traitors, but broad legislation proposed after Sept. 11 for that purpose could also imprison public sector whistle-blowers and journalists who expose scandals, not state secrets, civil libertarians and legal experts contend.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Ryanair Increases Flights
abstract: Ireland's Ryanair adds 30 daily flights on 10 international routes from its hub in Hahn, Germany; German court on Feb 12 lifted injunction that had been granted to Lufthansa to prevent Ryanair from comparing prices on its advertisements (S)

headline: Business Travel; Here and there, the nation's air-rail links are beginning to look a lot like Europe's.
abstract: Business Travel column on how nation's air carriers and airports are coping with passengers' shifting patterns as more travelers are opting for driving instead of flying on shorter trips or using nation's rail systems; says air-rail links in US are beginning to look a lot like Europe's (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Neo-Nazis? No, Nerds To the Editor:.

headline: Ulster Police Arrest Two in Mailman's Death
abstract: Police in Ulster, Northern Ireland, arrest two men in slaying of Daniel McColgan, Catholic mailman shot dead by Protestant gunmen in northern outskirts of Belfast; Ulster Defense Assn, province's largest Protestant paramilitary organization, claims responsibility for killing; says it was in reprisal for attacks against Protestant communities (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE RESIGNS AND L90 PAYS TO END A MERGER
abstract: L90 Inc Internet marketing company, says chief financial officer Thomas Sebastian has resigned; adds it has paid eUniverse undisclosed amount to end their merger (S)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: U.S. May Regain Human Rights Seat
abstract: US is likely to regain seat on UN Human Rights Commission, now that Italy and Spain reportedly agree to step aside (S)

headline: Darth Vader. Machiavelli. Skilling Set Intense Pace.
abstract: Jeffrey K Skilling, former chief executive of Enron Corp, is expected to paint self-image of visionary but out-of-touch executive who was misled by corrupt subordinates, not deeply involved manager, when he appears before House subcommittee investigating Enron's collapse on Feb 7; Skilling, in New York Times interview several weeks ago, said 'I had no idea the company was in anything but excellent shape'; photo (M)

headline: Powell Lauds Pakistan's Efforts Against Extremists
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell praises Pakistan's efforts to crack down on violent extremists after meeting in Islamabad with Pres Pervez Musharraf and other top Pakistani officials; vows to do all he can to help defuse tensions with India over disputed Kashmir region; repeats that monthlong standoff in half-century dispute can be resolved only with direct discussions by two nations; Powell heads for India, hoping to help end crisis by his sheer presence; situation between India and Pakistan begins to ease; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Molecule-Sized Machines Advance
abstract: Hewlett-Packard and University of California at Los Angeles receive US patent on technology that may prove useful in wiring together molecule-sized switches that many scientists and engineers say may one day lead to new kind of ultratiny electronics; patent is issued to Philip J Kuekes and R Stanley Williams of Hewlett-Packard Laboratories and James R Heath of UCLA (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Royal Exiles Win Round 1
abstract: Italian Senate votes to let exiled male heirs of Vittorio Emanuele III back into country (S)

headline: A Master's Insights Are Undiminished by Time
abstract: Mark Hulbert column on valuable insights into stock market made by James Tobin, late Nobel laureate, particular his Q ratio, which measures relationship between company's market price and replacement value of its assets; graph (M)

headline: 130 FASHION BUGS SCHEDULED FOR CLOSING
abstract: Charming Shoppes, which operates Fashion Bug and Lane Bryant clothing stores, is closing 130 Fashion Bug stores as well as its Added Dimension/Answer chain and its 77 stores; closings will cost $23 million in fourth quarter, which ends Jan 31; will convert 44 Fashion Bug stores into Lane Bryant stores (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; AT&T and AOL are very different and yet very much alike.
abstract: AT&T Corp says revenue at its consumer unit fell by 18.3 percent in fourth quarter, to $3.47 billion from about $4.25 billion year earlier; reports overall revenue of $12.59 billion, down about 9.5 percent from $13.91 billion year earlier; chief executive Charles H Noski comments; AOL Time Warner reports loss of $1.8 billion compared with loss of $1.1 billion year earlier (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Chants of 'Death to America!' Mark March by Millions in Iran
abstract: Galvanized by their anger at President Bush for branding their nation part of an "axis of evil," Iranians marched in a huge nationwide pep rally.

headline: Announcement on a Hepatitis C Drug Is Expected Today
abstract: Vertex Pharmaceuticals and Eli Lilly are expected to announce today that they have developed a drug candidate that can attack the hepatitis C virus in the same way that several drugs attack H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.    The companies say that their compound, which they hope to begin testing in patients in 2003, blocks an enzyme known as a protease, which the hepatitis C virus needs to replicate itself. Protease inhibitors for H.I.V. have had a significant effect in treating AIDS, and many companies have tried to develop one for hepatitis C.

headline: Sri Lanka and Rebels Sign Cease-Fire Agreement
abstract: The prime minister of Sri Lanka and the reclusive leader of separatist Tamil rebels signed a formal cease-fire agreement today.

headline: Big Providian Settlement Is Small Change to Many
abstract: DIARY Â  Big Providian Settlement Is Small Change to Many.

headline: PG&E SAYS IT WILL RECLASSIFY $1 BILLION IN LEASES AS DEBT
abstract: PG&E Corp plans to reclassify as debt $1 billion in 'synthetic' leases on three power plants and will revise financial results dating to 1999; review of leases shows company must add them to its balance sheet (S)

headline: Cuba Trade Helps Texas Port
abstract: Shipments of Texas-grown rice to Cuba under new trade agreement benefits state's oldest seaport, Freeport (S)

headline: Enron Hearings Open, Focusing on Destroyed Papers
abstract: Lawmakers said evidence showed Enron's auditors destroyed documents knowing they might be relevant to investigations.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Jay Bertram was named president at the Toronto office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, succeeding David Fong, who left.

headline: Europe Lists U.S. Imports It Plans to Tax
abstract: European Union draws up list of $2.1 billion in imports from United States to penalize in retaliation for Bush administration's imposition of tariffs of up to 30 percent on some imported steel; wants US to pay compensation for its bid to protect struggling American steel industry; apparently leans toward using World Trade Organization's slower dispute-resolution system rather than rapidly imposing sanctions (M)

headline: Medical First: A Transplant Of a Uterus
abstract: Doctors in Saudi Arabia say they performed world's first uterus transplant, to woman unable to have baby; say transplanted uterus remained healthy for 99 days but then began to deteriorate and had to be removed; American experts are divided on report; some see news as important first step toward making childbirth possible for women who had hysterectomies or uterine abnormalities; say uterus transplants would be temporary, and would be removed once baby is born so mother could stop taking potentially damaging anti-rejection drugs; other experts question ethics of exposing patient to risks of transplant for organ that is not lifesaving; operation is described in International Journal of Gynecology and Obstetrics; authors say uterus transplants would be especially useful in Muslim societies, where religous authorities do not allow use of surrogate mothers and where Islamic law does not permit eggs or embryos to be transferred from one person to another, but would permit uterus transplant (M)

headline: Betrayed by the Bar
abstract: Nontas Konstantakis letter comments on concerns about personal information that is encoded in drivers licenses (March 21 article)

headline: 2 Presidential Hopefuls Keep France Waiting as Vote Nears
abstract: Conservative President Jacques Chirac and Socialist Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, have not declared themselves as candidates even though they will face each other in first round in France's presidential elections in three months; poll indicates 65 percent of citizens want both to declare candidacies, and that 50 percent are unhappy with way campaign is unfolding; 70 percent of respondents say real issues have not been addressed (M)

headline: Market Place; Vivendi Universal, with its complex balance sheet, meets distrust from investors shaken by accounting scandals.
abstract: Geraldine Fabrikant Market Place column on 42 percent fall in stock of Vivendi Universal over last 12 months; says that while chief executive, Jean-Marie Messier, contends shares are 'victim of suspicions and manipulation,' Vivendi's complex balance sheet is notoriously difficult to decipher and that company has made at least a few transactions that might make shareholders understandably skittish; photo; graph (M)

headline: Official Says S.E.C. Is Strained, With Duties Exceeding Budget
abstract: General Accounting Office head David M Walker warns that Securities and Exchange Commission is 'increasingly strained' because it does not have financing to do its job while its workload has been rising, testimony before Senate Banking Committee; Walker says third of SEC's staff departed from 1998 to 2000, who also notes that last year SEC was able to review only 16 percent of annual corporate filings, compared with its goal of 30 percent to 35 percent; SEC chairman Harvey L Pitt agrees that his agency is strained because its financing has not grown commensurate with its workload; committee chairman Paul S Sarbanes urges lawmakers to pass legislation in wake of Enron Corp's collapse to tighten regulation of auditors; federal judge overseeing Enron's bankruptcy proceedings approves plan to distribute extra $5 million in severance pay to workers laid off when company filed bankruptcy protection in December (M)

headline: OUTLOOK: Markets & Investing; Bonds May Have Tougher Time Outperforming Stocks in 2002
abstract: Domestic bonds will have tougher time outperforming stocks in 2002; key variables for volatility and performance are shape of economy recovery that is in consensus forecast for spring and how long Federal Reserve policy makers wait before they decide to push up their short-term interest rate benchmark, federal funds rate on overnight loans among banks; graph (M)

headline: Free Speech and Enron Play in Debate Over Soft Money
abstract: Campaign finance bill supporters argued that big money, symbolized by Enron donations, had cast a shadow over Congress and the White House.

headline: Hippie chic goes to the beach in a splash of color
abstract: LONDONâ€”  If sun worshipers follow the counsel of their favorite ready-to-wear designers, then this summer they'll be decked out in haute hippie looks on beaches from Margate to St. Tropez.

headline: U.S. Labels an Arab Captive A Planner of Qaeda Attacks
abstract: US law enforcement and military officials say terrorism suspect handed over to Americans by Bosnia and Herzegovina is identified as European lieutenant in Al Qaeda terrorist network who was ordered to carry out attacks on American targets in Balkans after September 11 attacks; say intercepted telephone calls and other evidence show suspect Bensayah Belkacem, who is believed to be native of Yemen or Algeria with Bosnian citizenship, had numerous conversations on cellular telephones with leaders of Al Qaeda in Afghanistan (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Believes bin Laden and Omar Are Still in Afghanistan
abstract: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that he believes the elusive Osama bin Laden and Mullah Muhammad Omar are still in Afghanistan.

headline: AT&T WIRELESS REDUCES ITS SALES FORECAST
abstract: AT&T Wireless reduces sales and cash-flo

headline: After January Raid, Gen. Franks Promises to Do Better
abstract: Gen Tommy R Franks, commander of war in Afghanistan, says he ordered top ground officers to tighten coordination with Afghan allies; army is stung by criticism that American commandos might have mistakenly killed anti-Taliban troops in raid last month, and wants to prevent recurrence; Franks says future operations will be fully discussed in advance with interim Afghan government headed by Hamid Karzai; Franks stops short of calling midnight raid a mistake, pending inquiry, but senior American official claims CIA representatives have already paid more than $1,000 to each of families of Afghans killed in raid; photo; map (M)

headline: Sheldon B. Satin, 69, Cable TV Consultant
abstract: Sheldon B Satin, cable tv consultant, dies at69 (S)

headline: For Clothing Makers, It's Cut or Be Cut
abstract: Retailers, forced to offer steep pre-Christmas discounts, are pressuring apparel makers and wholesalers to bear brunt of cuts in forms of concessions; ranks of these businesses are expected to shrink rapidly in coming months, with real trouble to be felt by thousands of midsize and small companies already hurt by low-cost competition from overseas; graphs of personal spending on apparel and of United States apparel output; photos (M)Â

headline: Rite Aid's Loss Grew in Quarter
abstract: The Rite Aid Corp says its loss widened to $112.8 million in fiscal third quarter ended Dec 1 from $105.7 million year earlier; sales rose 5.7 percent, to $3.73 billion (M)

headline: Wall Street Journal Reporter Missing in Karachi for 2 Days
abstract: Daniel Pearl, Wall Street Journal reporter who was in Karachi, Pakistan, reporting on Al Qaeda, is reported missing; he left home where he was staying to meet two people who had presented themselves as sources with contacts in terrorist network (M)

headline: Rehabilitation Joins Retribution in Saudi Drug War
abstract: Drug abuse in Saudi Arabia is serious enough problem that rulers are beginning to deal with it in very un-Saudi way: openly; government treats drug trafficking as criminal activity, but it has begun to regard drug, alcohol and nicotine dependence as treatable illnesses; drugs have increasingly become source of entertainment and escape in country that bans movie theaters, concert halls, discotheques and dating, and where 65 percent of population is under age of 25; country now has four drug treatment centers where patients are offered group therapy, physical therapy and biofeedback; photos (M)

headline: In a Quest for Youth, An Old Pepsi Theme
abstract: Campaign by Pepsi-Cola division of PepsiCo, which begins during ABC broadcast of Academy Awards, will introduce theme 'think young, drink young' for Diet Pepsi; commercials by BBDO New York echo theme used from 1961 to 1964 for company's flagship brand, 'For those who think young' (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * DeLonghi America, Saddle Brook, N.J., a division of DeLonghi that makes kitchen and other appliances, to Earle Palmer Brown, New York, to handle its account, which had been at Stoner Bunting, Lancaster, Pa. Billings were estimated at $6 million to $8 million. Earle Palmer is part of Panoramic Communications.  * Little Tikes Company, Hudson, Ohio, a children's toy and equipment maker owned by Newell/Rubbermaid, to the New York office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, to handle its account, which had been handled by the Cleveland office of the Wolf Group. Billings were estimated at $5 million. McCann-Erickson is a unit of the McCann-Erickson World Group, a division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: U.N. Details Vicious Acts Charged Against Milosevic
abstract: Slobodan Milosevic unleashes another blistering attack on United Nations tribunal that has charged him with gravest of atrocities in three Balkan wars; says he is victim of 'lynch process' and challenges legitimacy of International Criminal Tribunal and of his transfer from Serbia last June; he has not hired lawyers, and is scheduled to give his full opening statement on Feb 14; he is expected to present himself as victim of West who acted only to defend his country as it collapsed into war in early 1990's; he is expected to show videotape about atrocities in Kosovo in 1999 which he hopes will counter prosecution's claim that it was Serbian forces that carried out massacres and deportations there; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Technology Concerns To Aid Foundation
abstract: Markle Foundation and United Nations Development Program to announce they have won support from initial group of technology companies and nonprofit organizations for project aimed at bridging digital divide in developing world; group has pledged to spend about $10 million in cash, resources and labor in next two years on strategies that use technology to improve quality of life in 12 developing nations (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: States Seek Windows Code
abstract: Nine states that oppose proposed Microsoft Corp antitrust settlement have asked judge to let them examine so-called source code of company's Windows operating system; states want to force Microsoft to sell version of Windows without Internet Explorer browser; Microsoft argues that removing Web search program from Windows would destroy system (S)

headline: Salomon Under Inquiry on WorldCom Options
abstract: Salomon Smith Barney is under investigation by New York Stock Exchange for possible violations surrounding firm's handling of number of accounts opened by WorldCom employees to exercise stock options in 1999 and 2000; investigation centers on firm's branch office on Peachtree Road in Atlanta, where as many as dozen brokers opened more than 2,000 accounts for WorldCom employees interested in exercising their options (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Auto Production Rises
abstract: Japan's largest auto makers increase production and exports in January to meet demand in US; Toyota Motor increased worldwide production by 4.6 percent and Honda Motor raised output by 7.4 percent; Mitsubishi Motors and Mazda Motor also had gains (S)

headline: IDENTIX, SECURITY CONCERN, BUYING VISIONICS
abstract: Identix Inc, maker of fingerprint-security devices, agrees to buy Visionics Corp for about $285 million in stock and other obligations; Identix's chief executive Robert McCashin will serve as new company's chairman and Visionic's chief executive Joseph Atick will be chief executive (S)

headline: Commercial Real Estate; Airport Hotels Multiply. Yes, Airport.
abstract: Three new hotels have opened near airports in New York area since Sept 11, and four more are scheduled to open this year, followed by two in 2003 and one in 2004; occupancy rates at hotels around Kennedy, LaGuardia and Newark airports, which were 98 percent on Sept 10, plummeted to average of 66 percent as of Jan 19, while average room rates over same period dropped to $120 from $145; newly opened airport hotels in New York metropolitan area are Wyndham Newark Airport Hotel in Elizabeth, NJ, JFK Airport Hampton Inn and Doubletree Club Hotel near Kennedy Airport; graph; photo (M)

headline: Uncertain Toll in the Fog of War: Civilian Deaths in Afghanistan
abstract: Hundreds and perhaps thousands of innocent Afghans have lost their lives during American attacks, and Pentagon finds itself accused of sometimes relying on faulty intelligence; military has so far made detailed inquiries into only few cases, but now full-fledged investigation by Pentagon's Central Command is under way; most often, Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld and military spokesmen have dismissed accusations of mistakes as enemy propaganda; many mournful Afghan families are demanding reckoning; map (M)

headline: Chrysler Seeks to Revive Line With Convertible PT Cruiser
abstract: Chrysler says it plans to make convertible version of PT Cruiser, which was instant hit when it reached auto market two years ago but whose luster has since begun to face; announcement comes at Geneva International Show, traditionally place where European manufacturers spotlight their most attractive new vehicles; PT convertible will go on sale sometime in 2004; graph; photo (M)

headline: MindShare Selected By Novartis
abstract: Novartis has consolidated its worldwide media planning and buying assignments at offices of MindShare, part of WPP Group; spending estimated at $250 million (S)

headline: VISTEON TO SELL AIR BAG SENSOR UNIT TO AUTOLIV
abstract: Visteon Corp to sell its Restraint Electronics air bag sensor unit to Autoliv Inc for $25 million; says about 1,000 Visteon workers at Markham, Ont, plant will lose jobs and about 200 engineers in Dearborn, Mich, will probably shift to Autoliv (S)

headline: Mareb River Journal; Bridge Over a Troubled Border in Horn of Africa
abstract: Mareb River Bridge joins Ethiopia and Eritrea along one of few uncontested stretches of their border; bridge was heavily damaged when Ethiopia and Eritrea took up arms against each other in two-year war that began in 1998; in recent months, it has been refurbished by United Nations peacekeepers called in to monitor cease-fire; it has become symbol of two countries' difficult search for reconciliation; tensions are especially high now as two countries await ruling from independent commission to settle 620-mile border that was not clearly demarcated when Eritrea gained its independence from Ethiopia in 1993; Prime Min Meles Xenawi of Ethiopia and Pres Isaias Afewerki of Eritrea say they will abide by commission's ruling, but both leaders face political pressures that could grow should ruling lean heavily in other's favor; photos; map (M)

headline: Regulation on Tire Safety Rejected by Budget Chief
abstract: Dr John D Graham, head of White House Office of Management and Budget, takes unusual step of rejecting tire safety proposal made by Bush administration's top auto safety regulators, National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, and says in letter that their analysis is flawed (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Discussing Acquisition
abstract: Egg, Britain's biggest online bank, which is 79 percent owned by insurance company Prudential of Britain, says it is in 'advanced' talks to buy ZeBank of France from Groupe Arnault, which is controlled by billionaire Bernard Arnault; analysts say deal could cost Egg up to $60 million (S)

headline: It's Time for Investors to Start Acting Like Owners
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column praises William H Gross, manager of Pacific Investment Management, on decision not to own General Electric commercial paper for foreseeable future on ground that GE is not disclosing enough about its operations or financing needs to bond investors; says it is about time investors started making demands of their companies; graph (M)

headline: Former Chairwoman Resigns From S.E.C.
abstract: Laura Unger, Securities and Exchange Commission member who was acting chairwoman for six months during 2001, resigns (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Oil Profit Falls
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell reports fourth-quarter profit of $1.91 billion, down from $3.58 billion year earlier (S)

headline: U.N. Inspector Tells Council Work in Iraq Could Be Fast
abstract: Hans Blix, chief United Nations arms inspector, tells Security Council that his inspectors could conceivably accomplish their disarmament tasks in Iraq in less than year once Baghdad gives green light for their return, but only if Iraqis actively cooperate; says once inspections are carried out to his satisfaction, he could recommend council suspend, though not lift, penalties in place since Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990; says continuing inspections would ensure that Baghdad is not secretly acquiring new chemical, biological and nuclear stockpiles (M)

headline: Closed Trial Begins in Tehran For Dissidents Accused of Plot
abstract: Iran's hard-line Revolutionary Court began the trials of 15 dissidents today. Most of them are writers and intellectuals and are charged with plotting to overthrow the Islamic system.    Those men and numerous others have been arrested since last year in what is seen as an effort by hard-liners, who control the judiciary, to weaken supporters of President Mohammad Khatami's agenda for political and social reform. Fourteen other dissidents were tried in November; no ruling has been issued.

headline: U.S. MAY SEND G.I.'S TO EX-SOVIET AREA
abstract: US considers sending 'sizable' number of Special Operations forces to former Soviet republic of Georgia to help train its military in counterterrorism tactics; aim is to prepare Georgian troops to combat foreign fighters who are operating in mountainous region and may have links to Osama bin Laden's network; new front in war against terrorism would build on operations in Afghanistan and involve 100-200 Special Operations forces who would not take part in direct combat but would defend themselves against attack (M)

headline: Ex-Chief of Netscape Criticizes Microsoft's Penalty Proposal
abstract: Netscape Communications' former chief executive James L Barksdale tells Federal Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly that penalties Microsoft Corp has proposed in final phase of landmark antitrust case would allow company to engage in same kind of illegal conduct that helped it quash Internet browser of Netscape in 1990's; Microsoft's lawyer John Warden questions Barksdale on some of more contentious issues in current phase of case (M)

headline: Paris briefed Beijing on deal, report says : Taiwan cites betrayal by France over frigates
abstract: HONG KONG:â€”  An explosive report by the Taiwan government alleges that France betrayed Taiwan's confidence by passing top-secret information to China about the controversial sale of $2.5 billion worth of French frigates to Taiwan in the early 1990s, according to people who have seen the report.

headline: Powell Will Visit India and Pakistan
abstract: State Sec Colin L Powell, seeking to contain tensions between India and Pakistan, says he will visit both nations next week, and possibly others in region; expresses hope Pakistani Pres Pervez Musharraf will act appropriately on India's call for surrender of 20 alleged terrorists (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Modified Seeds Approved
abstract: The Indian government said it would allow commercial planting of genetically modified seeds under certain limits. Three varieties of disease-resistant cotton developed by Mahyco, an Indian affiliate of Monsanto, won approval for three years/

headline: Blue Lights or Not, Martha Stewart Remains Calm
abstract: Martha Stewart appears ready to honor her commitment with Kmart despite its filing for bankrutcy protection; her deal with Kmart is especially sweet, providing special staff and advertising support and guaranteeing her company, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, minimum double-digit annual increase in revenue no matter how her products sell; Stewart and Kmart have both profited nicely from their relationship, but that could change if restructuring forces Kmart to amend some terms of its contract; graph; photo (M)

headline: AETNA SAYS IT WILL RETURN TO PROFITABILITY THIS YEAR
abstract: Aetna Inc chief executive Dr John W Rowe says company will be profitable in 2002 as its restructuring progresses (S)

headline: 2 Canadian Energy Concerns in Merger Talks
abstract: Alberta Energy Co and PanCanadian Energy are discussing merger, which would create Canada's biggest oil and natural gas producer, with market value of $12.5 billion (M)

headline: New Attacks Feared With Afghan Thaw
abstract: The spring thaw in Afghanistan may bring a sharp rise in guerrilla attacks on American and allied troops, American officials say. They say melting snow in mountain passes will make small bands of fighters harder to spot and attack. Article, Page A10.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent Completes Bond Sale
abstract: Lucent Technologies completes private sale of $1.75 billion of 15-year bonds convertible into Lucent stock at $6.10 per share, 24 percent premium over closing price on March 13; bonds carry 7.7 percent dividend; graph (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Euro Zone: Inflation Steady
abstract: Eurostat reports annual inflation in 12-member euro zone remained at 2.1 percent in December; inflation in 15 countries of European Union rose to 2 percent from 1.8 percent in November; initial estimates indicate euro zone had trade surplus in November of 5.5 billion euros ($4.86 billion), down from 9.6 billion euros in October (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Medical Education Acquisition
abstract: Thomson Corp acquires medical education provider, Gardiner-Caldwell Communications Ltd of Britain, for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: After the Snapshot
abstract: Use of photo-editing software and photo Web sites rises with sales of digital cameras; graphs of top software and photo services web sites; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Kirch May Sell Assets
abstract: Kirch Group's deputy chief executive Dieter Hahn says company would be willing to give up control of its pay television network and possibly its broadcasting rights to Formula One races; Kirch is struggling to avoid bankruptcy, but talks about possible bailout have been bogged down in disagreements among Germany's biggest creditor banks; pay television business, Premiere, is believed to be losing more than $700 million per year (S)

headline: Will Florida Be Able to Pay?
abstract: Bob Schaeffer letter, commenting on Fred Brock's March 3 column, says Florida will have to mondernize its tax system to cope with cost of caring for aging population

headline: New Claim by Opponents of Microsoft Pact
abstract: Group of states suing Microsoft Corp, citing recent testimony by Microsoft senior vice president Richard Fade, tells federal court that Microsoft has used Bush administration's antitrust settlement as 'a sword to extract valuable concessions' from personal computer makers; nine states say government's proposed settlement has already been used by company 'to provide net benefit for Microsoft and a net harm to those whom decree is intended to benefit'; Microsoft responds by saying states' claim that company had benefited from settlement with government was 'simply inaccurate' and 'fairly predictable,' given the source (M)

headline: House Subcommittee Hearings
abstract: The following is the full text of Thursday's session of a hearing of the oversight and investigations subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee on the findings of Enronâ€™s special investigative committee as recorded by the Federal News Service.

headline: Merck Intends to Spin Off Unit That Manages Drug Plans
abstract: Merck & Co will spin off part of Merck-Medco, unit that manages drug plans for employers, in initial public offering as early as this summer, and sell remainder of business over following 12 months; chairman-chief executive Raymond V Gilmartin says Merck decided it has reached point where its pharmaceutical operations and prescription management business are worth more to shareholders as two independent companies; chart (M)

headline: At Least 17 Are Killed in Israeli Raid at Palestinian Camp in Gaza
abstract: At least 17 Palestinians die in Israeli military sweep through Jabaliya refugee camp in Gaza in predawn darkness on March 11; scores are injured; tanks also rumble into Ramallah; latest incursions follow similar raids and searches in Bethlehem and Qalqilya; military operation began on March 1 and has included camps in Jenin, Nablus and Gaza Strip; is largest Israeli military operation against Palestinians since 1993 Oslo agreements gave Palestinians control over some of their lands; map; photo (M)

headline: Good (or Unwitting) Neighbors Make for Good Internet Access
abstract: Short-range, inexpensive and often unsecured wireless networks based on Wi-Fi technology are rapidly sprinkling nation with sweet spots of airborne high-speed Internet access; are allowing growing numbers of people with properly equipped laptops to tie into Internet on run, courtesy of others; any computer with receiver in radius of about 300 feet can potentially pick up signal; diagram; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Russian Troops Now Welcome
abstract: Georgia Pres Eduard A Shevardnadze reverses course and tells Parliament that he wants Russian peacekeeping troops to remain in nation's rebel-controlled separatist region, Abkhazia, lest their removal lead to blood bath against ethnic Georgians there; map (S)

headline: Female Bomber Strikes Scarred Shopping District in Jerusalem
abstract: A Palestinian bomber today triggered an explosion that resounded throughout Jerusalem, killing herself and an 81-year-old man and injuring 113, most of them lightly.

headline: Rethinking Dire Warnings By Insurers After Sept. 11
abstract: Commercial insurance costs in general have risen steeply after Sept 11 terrorist attacks, and terrorism coverage, still extremely limited, is particularly expensive; there is growing evidence that American businesses and their insurers are solving their problems without help from Federal government; terrorism coverage, which was unobtainable immediately after attacks, is becoming more widely available and in larger amounts; premiums are falling as more insurers enter market; General Accounting Office, in report requested by Rep Michael G Oxley, author of legislation providing for government assistance that has so far succeeded only in House, cites nine examples across nation of unidentified commercial property owners being unable to get full or partial terrorism coverage or being unwilling to pay what insurers were asking; Congressional hearing on terrorism coverage is scheduled for Feb 27; Congress's interest in issue has generally cooled (M)

headline: Few Crying the Blues for Mariah Carey
abstract: Analysis: few in record industry are saddened over EMI Records' decision to buy out Mariah Carey's $80 million recording contract; most feel she is millions richer for lost contract and still has career (M)

headline: Company Stock in 401(k)'s
abstract: Duncan Van Dusen letter comments on David Leonhardt's Feb 17 article on 401(k) plans; urges creation of totally employer-independent primary retirement savings system

headline: Hi, Old Friend. Help Me Get a Job Like Yours.
abstract: Abby Ellin column on how to respond to friends, friends of friends, acquaintances and strangers when seek advice and assistance in finding a job; drawing (M)

headline: Pressure for Overhaul Builds on Stock Options
abstract: Sens John McCain, Peter G Fitzgerald, Carl Levin and Richard J Durbin, in wake of Enron collapse and widespread worries about quality of financial statements, introduce bill to force companies to deduct from profits estimated cost of stock options they give employees; companies now consider stock options to have no cost, but many receive large tax deductions when employees exercise them, much as corporations do for salaries they pay; corporate executives are expected to oppose measure strenuously (M)

headline: Equity Offerings for Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:     Commonwealth Telephone Enterprises, Dallas, Pa., 3.5 million shares. Morgan Stanley and Goldman, Sachs & Co.

headline: Thatcher Quits Public Life, Citing Health
abstract: Former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is retiring from public life immediately for health reasons, her office announced today.    A statement said that Lady Thatcher, 76, prime minister of Britain from 1979 to 1990 and a baroness in the House of Lords since 1992, would not make any more public speeches because of the strain they put on her.

headline: Letterman Offer Was News to Chief of ABC News
abstract: ABC News president David Westin tells his top executives that his bosses blindsided him, failing to tell him of plan to remove Nightline to make room for David Letterman, whom network hs tried to lure from CBS; photos; Westin is reported 'ashen,' talking of tremendous blow to ABC News from news he learned in call from The New York Times; outcome is unclear with Letterman on vacation; Nightline anchor Ted Koppel declines comment; executives at parent Walt Disney Co insist they will not allow sentimental attachment to 'aging news program' stand in way of corporate ship; Letterman, who has strained relations with CBS Television head Leslie Moonves, has made clear he will not go to ABC if it leads directly to Koppel's departure (M)

headline: Pope, at Ecumenical Meeting, Denounces Violence in Religion's Name
abstract: Pope John Paul II convenes unusual one-day gathering of leaders of a dozen religions, including Muslims, Jews and Christians, to affirm his belief that 'whoever uses religion to foment violence contradicts religion's deepest and truest inspiration,' Assisi, Italy; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Loss For Chemical Maker
abstract: Rhodia, France's largest specialty chemical maker, reports fourth-quarter loss of 213 million euros ($184 million) for 2001 compared with net profit of 216 million euros year earlier; says it will not meet 2003 profit targets; will reduce staff by 6 percent and close 19 sites (S)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: Ex-Broker Is Charged In $68 Million Case
abstract: Enrique Perusquia, former broker at Lehman Brothers Holdings and PaineWebber, is charged with defrauding Mexican client of $68 million by investing his money in gold mining companies from which he was receiving kickbacks; US attorney's office in San Francisco and Securities and Exchange Commission also accuse Perusquia of forging client signatures on investment and legal memorandums, using $1.6 million of client funds for his own purposes and engaging in unauthorized trading on margin from 1992 to 1998; Perusquia is contesting charges (S)

headline: 3 Web Sites Closed in Spam Inquiry
abstract: Federal court orders closing of Web sites of Britain's TLD Network, Quantum Management and TBS Industries that used e-mail messages to sell estimated $1 million worth of nonexistent Web addresses; court's actions come at request of Federal Trade Commission as part of agency's most aggressive move in its campaign against unsolicited commercial e-mail messages, or spam; Thomas Goolnik and Edward Harris Goolnik of London controlled companies deny allegations; British Office of Fair Trading has been cooperating with FTC in investigation; David P Berten, lawyer for Goolniks, says defendants plan litigation (M)

headline: Saudis Warn Against Attack on Iraq by the United States
abstract: Vice Pres Dick Cheney receives unusual public warning from Saudi leadership that Bush administration should put aside any plans for military campaign against Iraq; Crown Prince Abdullah declares it would not be in 'United States' interest, or the interest of the region, or the world's interest, to do so;' Cheney meets with King Fahd and Prince Abdullah; Abdullah condemns terrorism; photo of Cheney and Abdullah (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: World Briefing

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago       Prime rate   4.75   4.75   9.50       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   6.00       Federal funds   1.56   1.61   5.95       3-month T-bills   1.64   1.65   5.08       6-month T-bills   1.72   1.75   4.89       10-yr. T-infl.   3.49   3.48   3.47       10-yr. T-note   5.07   5.05   4.98       30-yr. T-bond   5.52   5.49   5.43       Telephone bd.   7.58   7.55   7.67       Municipal bds.   5.38   5.40   5.25          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Seeking Trade And Support
abstract: Brazil Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso begins state visit to Russia and Ukraine, hoping to interest both in launching satellites from launch base on edge of Amazon; Russia wants to sell jet fighters to Brazil (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Unilever signs multimedia marketing alliance with AOL Time Warner to advertise its brands; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Private Sector; A Spiritual Accounting of Enron
abstract: Kazuo Inamori, founder of Japan's Kyocera Corp and DDI Corp, who retired five years ago to become Buddhist monk, says questionable deals and accounting issues that brought down Enron reflect loss of moral standards; photo (S)

headline: Roy Porter, 55, Historian, 'A One-Man Book Factory'
abstract: Dr Roy Porter, British author, commentator and historian, dies at age 55 (M)

headline: Queen Mother Mourned as Link to British Past
abstract: News of Queen Mother Elizabeth's death at 101, while not unexpected, nevertheless shocks Britons accustomed to her enduring, cheerful presence through good times and bad; photo; royal family gathers at Windsor Castle (S)

headline: DataBank; Investors See Little to Cheer About
abstract: The stock market tumbled for the second week in a row, despite signs that the economy might be turning around sooner than many economists had expected.     Investors had ignored much of the negative news after Sept. 11 and had seemed to assume that a recovery was just around the corner as they pushed stocks higher in the last three months of 2001. Last week some investors appeared to believe that the stock market may have moved a little ahead of the news.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Officials Seize Copies Of Terror Film
abstract: Customs officials in St Petersburg (Russia) seize videos from Parliament member Yuli Rybakov that purport to show Russian intelligence agents engineered terrorist bombings in apartment buidings in Moscow and elsewhere in Russia in 1999; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Vodafone In Deal With Start-Up
abstract: Bytemobile, wireless data start-up based in Mountain View, Calif, reaches deal with Britain's Vodafone to provide technology that improves performance of networks that allow mobile users to send e-mail messages and surf Internet; graph (S)

headline: Israeli Foreign Minister Says Arafat Should Go To Arab Talks in Beirut
abstract: Palestinian officials warn that Arab summit meeting in Beirut cannot make progress on Mideast conflict if Israel blocks Yasir Arafat from attending; Israeli Min Shimon Peres suggests Arafat should be allowed to go, provided he curbs violence; five Palestinians die in clashes in Gaza; two gunmen are killed in attacking Israeli outpost (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Philosophical Call For More Talks
abstract: National League for Democracy, leading opposition group in Myanmar, encourages military government to continue dialogue with party leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Troops Guard Schools
abstract: Nearly 750 police officers and British army troops guard entrances to dozens of schools in northern Belfast because of death threat to teachers and other workers at Roman Catholic schools issued by Protestant paramilitary group, Red Hand Defenders (S)

headline: Ex-Chief of Enron Takes Defiant Tone at Senate Hearing
abstract: Jeffrey K. Skilling said at a hearing that he did not lie to Congress earlier this month about his role in Enron's collapse.

headline: Tribunal: How It Works
abstract: Article describes workings of International Criminal Tribunal for former Yugoslavia (S)

headline: One Rule Of Plastic: Recovery Has A Dark Side
abstract: Robret G Hottensen Jr, specialty financial services analyst at Goldman Sachs & Co, discusses outlook for credit card companies; photo (M)

headline: Polish Priests Press Vatican on Case Against Bishop
abstract: Push by Poznan, Poland, priests for probe of charges that Archbishop Juliusz Paetz made homosexual advances to seminarians as young as 18 described; included affidavits sent to papal nuncio, Bishop Jozef Kowalczyk, who forwarded them to Paetz with recommendation that matter be forgotten, and eventual direct contact with Pope John Paul II that led to Vatican probe; usually cautious Polish daily has published charges in detail; local church is deeply torn and Polish Catholics dismayed; Paetz denies charges; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Top Official's Death Seen As Suicide
abstract: ***Nugzar Sadjaya, close aide to Pres Eduard A Shevardnadze, apparently commits suicide after opposition forces in Parliament accuse him of involvement in series of unsolved assassinations (S)

headline: After Clashes, Minister Quits His Post in Italy
abstract: Renato Ruggiero resigns as Italy's foreign minister over latest disagreement with government of Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi, which he has accused of undermining launch of euro and European unity in general (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Muslim Animal Slaughter Approved
abstract: German high court overturns ban on traditional Muslim slaughter of animals by slitting their throats and letting them bleed to death (S)

headline: Labor Talks At United Air Make Progress
abstract: Progress is reported in talks between United Airlines and union representing its machinists (M)

headline: Television's Interest in Hearing of Taliban Fighter Eclipsed Enron
abstract: Hearings into collapse of Enron Corp open on Capitol Hill, but all-news television channels show little interest, providing only intermittent coverage; instead, CNN, Fox News and MSNBC devoted far more attention to initial court appearance of John Walker Lindh, American accused of acts of terrorism for serving with Taliban in Afghanistan (M)

headline: 'Lone Voice': Excerpts From Testimony of Executive Who Challenged Enron
abstract: Excerpts from testimony of Enron Corp vice president Sherron S Watkins before hearing of House Energy and Commerce subcomittee (L)

headline: When a Buyer for Hospitals Has a Stake in Drugs It Buys
abstract: Article in ongoing series, Medicine's Middlemen, on large purchasing groups that buy medical products for about half of nation's hospitals; examines potential conflicts of interest that exist in worlds of medical-supply commerce, where billions of dollars worth of goods and services change hands each year with buying groups functioning as middlemen in negotiating contracts with suppliers with little public oversight; groups function as middlemen, but unlike most other purchasing agents are not financed by hospitals that buy products, but by companies that sell them; situation raises question about whose interests buying groups serve; activities of two biggest buying groups Premier Inc and Novation and their close ties to medical supply company American Pharmaceutical Partners discussed; photos (L)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sanmina-SCI Buys Alcatel Plants
abstract: Sanmina-SCI Corp, electronic contract manufacturer with more than 100 factories, acquires Alcatel's manufacturing plants in Cherbourg, France, Gunzenhausen, Germany, and Toledo, Spain; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Cambodia 32 years later / 'Life is better' : Revisiting a jungle district where war and terror reigned
abstract: KIRIVONG DISTRICT, Cambodiaâ€”  Motor scooters piled high with black market goods careered along the narrow dirt road from the border. Beyond, the flag of Vietnam, a yellow star on a red field, hung limply in the afternoon sun.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bombardier Disputes Price Of Adtranz
abstract: Bombardier Inc demands 1 billion euros ($870 million) from DaimlerChrysler, contending carmaker overstated value of Adtranz train unit sold to Canadian company last year; says DaimlerChrysler did not disclose 850 million euros in costs from contractual obligations to third parties; DaimlerChrysler board member Manfred Bischoff says contention is 'baseless' (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Falls
abstract: Japan's merchandise trade surplus stood at 6.6 trillion yen ($50 billion) last year, 38 percent lower than in 2000; total export volume fell 15 percent, 12th straight decline (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Telecommunications Loss
abstract: BCE posts net loss from continuing operations of 326 million Canadian dollars ($202.7 million) in fourth quarter compared to earnings of 4 million Canadian dollars year earlier; revenue climbed 8.5 percent, to 5.7 billion Canadian dollars; chairman-chief executive Jean Monty comments (S)

headline: Profile of the Noncommuter
abstract: Census Bureau releases profile of home-based workers; says nearly 9.3 million Americans -- about 7 percent of work force -- worked from home at least once a week during typical week in 1997 (S)

headline: If Not One Problem, It's Another, For the Struggling Giant Qwest
abstract: Qwest Communications International continues to market itself to Wall Street as model phone company of future, but all that investors seem interested in it how voice and data communications giant plans to survive present; faces cash squeeze severe enough to have forced company to draw down $4 billion credit line with banks; is also confronting doubts about its growth prospects and controversy over its accounting practices that has generated shareholder lawsuits; photo of Joseph P Nacchio, chief executive; graph shows decline in share price (M)

headline: Peru Support Of Free Trade Draws Praise In Bush Visit
abstract: Peru's economy is stumbling, Pres Alejandro Toledo's popularity has plummeted and long-dormant rebel group may be restive again, but Pres Bush's visit reflects US support of Toledo as democratic, world away from Alberto Fujimori's authoritarian regime; Toledo's government has made its mark by trying to reform Peru's troubled institutions while sticking to principles of free trade favored by US (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Survey: E-Government Trumps E-Commerce
abstract: University of Maryland survey finds Internet users in US are more likely to visit government Web sites than they are to handle banking or stock transactions online (S)

headline: Executive Life; From the Law Office to the Boardroom
abstract: Lawyers disenchanted with the law are seeking new professions in unprecedented numbers; several who have successfully made the leap from law to business -- Tim and Nina Zagat of Zagat Survey, David Stern, NBA commissioner, and Henry Silverman, chief executive of Cendant Corp -- were able to shed law's ingrained cautiousness and become comfortable with making snap decisions and taking risks; photos (M)

headline: Chrysler withdraws a Jeep ad after deer hunters take offense.
abstract: DaimlerChrysler Jeep ad that showed deer hunter boldly rescuing his prey by fooling his fellow hunters has been taken off air after numerous complaints from hunters; ad was created by PentaMark Worldwide; photo (M)

headline: New Economy; Software that screens trading partners for myriad terror links, as well as for compliance with trade rules abroad.
abstract: Companies in United States and abroad arÂ

headline: Egypt Vows to Press Iraq on U.N. Arms Inspections, Cheney Is Told
abstract: Pres Hosni Mubarak of Egypt tells visiting Vice Pres Dick Cheney that he will press Pres Saddam Hussein of Iraq to readmit United Nations weapons inspectors, to avert American military attack on Iraq; says he has received indications that Baghdad would agree; Mubarak's remarks reflect anxiety among Arab leaders that Bush administration is determined to confront Iraq; possibility that weapons inspectors will return to Iraq offers way out for Egypt, Jordan and other moderate Arab governments worried that American military strike against Iraq could intensify resentment of US, and, indirectly, of Arab rulers who are close to Washington; photo (M)

headline: Software Rage
abstract: It doesn't seem possible, but I may just have found an issue on which every man, woman and child can agree, regardless of politics, age or income: Lousy tech support.

headline: Struggle to Control What Islamic Schools Teach
abstract: Article on Pakistan's Islamic schools or madrasas, where young boys are taught jihad, or holy war, and where studies are limited almost strictly to Koran; effort by Pakistan's Pres Pervez Musharraf to bring madrasas under control in campaign to end flourishing culture of jihad discussed; photos; maps (M)

headline: Colombian Rebels Hijack a Plane and Kidnap a Senator
abstract: Colombian guerrillas hijack domestic flight, forcing it down on remote highway in south to kidnap Sen Jorge Eduardo Gechem Turbay, who had been on board; hours later Pres Andres Pastrana breaks off peace talks with largest rebel group, Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, and gives them deadline to vacate safe haven his government ceded in 1998 for peace talks; many Colombians conclude that rebels have used peace effort to stall, allowing them to fortify their 17,000-member army; Gechem Turbay is nephew of former Pres Julio Cesar Turbay; several members of his family have been killed by rebels in last decade; Pastrana, furious at latest rebel act, threatens to send in troops if rebels do not disperse; photo; map (M)

headline: Israeli Raids Kill 17 Palestinians; In Tel Aviv, 3 Die in a Shooting
abstract: Israel unleashes anger at Palestinians as it buries its dead from weekend of bloodshed in which 22 Israelis died; launches military strikes across West Bank, killing at least 17 Palestinians; helicopters fire shells near Yasir Arafat's headquarters in Ramallah; troops raid Palestinian-controlled sectors of Hebron and Dura; Palestinian gumnan fatally shoots three Israelis in popular Tel Aviv night spot; is shot and killed by police; Aksa Martyrs Brigade claims responsibility; identifies gunman as Ibrahimi Muhammad Hassouni; both sides vow further acts of vengeance; Prime Min Ariel Sharon vows Israel will prevail; says if Palestinins are not being beaten there will be no peace negotiations; Hamas leader Sheik Ahmed Yassin warns Israel will learn price of aggression against Palestinians; Pres Bush reiterates it is up to Yasir Arafat to take measures to curb growing violence; photos (M)

headline: Postal Service Begins a Review to Consolidate
abstract: The United States Postal Service has decided to consolidate most of its advertising assignments, with combined billings estimated at $100 million, and has begun a review to find an agency to handle tasks like mainstream campaigns, media services, direct marketing and promotions.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   8.00       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   4.50       Federal funds   1.75   1.75   5.04       3-month T-bills   1.79   1.82   4.21       6-month T-bills   2.06   2.11   4.11       10-yr. T-infl.   3.33   3.39   3.40       10-yr. T-note   5.34   5.40   5.00       30-yr. T-bond   5.75   5.80   5.46       Telephone bd.   7.84   7.87   7.76       Municipal bds.   5.41   5.42   5.30        (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Interest Rate Steady
abstract: Bank of Canada, citing stronger-than-expected economic recovery, keeps its target for overnight interest rates unchanged at 2 percent (S)

headline: Retrieving a PC's Past With XP's Time Warp
abstract: Q. After making some changes to the settings on my Windows XP system, I didn't like the results, but now I can't get the computer back to the way it was before. What can I do?    A. Windows XP, like Windows Me before it, comes with a built-in safety-net feature called System Restore that can help you undo changes by rolling back your system to a previous state. System Restore also comes in handy when the operating system is damaged by a bad software installation or a system crash. Such events can corrupt files that Windows needs to function properly.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: NestlÃ© Expands Water Business
abstract: Nestle acquires 51 percent stake in Aqua Spring of Greece to expand its mineral-water distribution business (S)

headline: Chrysler to Increase Vehicle Incentive Offers
abstract: Chrysler Group reverses course and says it will increase incentive offers to its customers because of slump in January sales; automaker, unit of DaimlerChrysler, cut back its offer at end of last year; Chrysler executive vice president James Schroer comments (M)

headline: Watchdog? Lap Dog? Why Have To Guess?
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column says trust that investors should have in a company's audited financial statement has been undermined by accounting firms' increasing reliance on other services they provide to companies they audit; notes that fees for nonauditing services, usually consulting, are two and a half times greater than fees for audits; says risk is that audit work, which generates lower fees, could jeopardize by desire to maintain more lucrative consulting relationship; table (M)

headline: A Forum for the Formerly Radical
abstract: Article describes panel discussion on Northern Ireland at World Economic Forum in Manhattan in which participants included former political radicals Irish Deputy First Min Mark Durkan, First Min David Trimble and Gerry Adams, head of political arm of Irish Republican Army; photo (M)

headline: Israel Eases West Bank Blockade as U.S. Envoy Returns
abstract: Israel eases military blockade on parts of West Bank as Bush administration's peace envoy, Gen Anthony C Zinni, returns to region with seemingly modest goal of trying to bring two sides close enough to resume negotiations for cease-fire; Yasir Arafat and other Palestinian leaders call Israeli moves fake withdrawal intended to deceive Zinni; they want blockade and travel restrictions to be lifted completely and permanently; photo (M)

headline: Japan's Debt Under Study For New Cut In Rating
abstract: Moody's Investors Service says Japan's credit rating could be lowered again soon because country is not moving fast enough to deal with deflation and debt; warning increases pressure on government of Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi to come up with substantial measures this week, before Pres Bush arrives on Feb 17, to overhaul stagnant economy and keep prices from falling (M)

headline: 4 Movie Studios to Issue Films in a High-End Video Format
abstract: Movie companies Universal, Fox, DreamWorks SKG and Artisan Entertainment plan to release films on high-definition videocassette to be used with player from JVC; new JVC format, called D-Theater, is designed exclusively for use with high-definition television sets; player, which has been on market since September, is priced at $1,999; JVC is unit of Matsushita Electric Industrial (M)

headline: Farmers in Zimbabwe Brace for Change
abstract: Zimbabwe's white farmers are bracing for major changes expected to follow presidential election; with country's increasingly explosive struggle over land distribution, have become acutely aware of how vulnerable they are; Keith Kirkman, white farmer, comments; photo (M)

headline: Andersen Partners Abroad Are Cutting Ties
abstract: Andero

headline: Trader Is Said to Have Defrauded Irish Bank of $750 Million
abstract: Ireland's largest financial institution said today that a trader for its U.S. subsidiary defrauded it of $750 million and has since disappeared.

headline: Hyundai Gives Carat Its Media Account
abstract: Hyundai Motor Co names Carat North American to handle consolidated media services for an Aemrican account with billings estimated at $450 million to $500 million (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: AMERICAS.

headline: When The Big Paycheck Is Hers
abstract: Ellyn Spragins column on wives who make more money than their husbands; notes many successful women and their husbands are unwilling to talk about resulting strains; notes fiscally unequal couples are common at high-income levels; invites lower-earning men to discuss issues; drawing (M)

headline: A Departure at CondÃ© Nast Prompts a Reshuffling Among Its Publishers
abstract: Peter King Hunsinger, executive vice president and chief marketing officer at Conde Nast Publications, resigns; Richard D Beckman, vice president and publisher of Vogue magazine, succeeds Hunsinger; Thomas A Florio, publisher of GQ magazine, will succeed Beckman; photos (M)

headline: Equity Offerings for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      Coventry Health Care, Bethesda, Md., 7 million shares. Salomon Smith Barney.

headline: U.S. Offers Aid to Turkey To Lead Kabul Peace Force
abstract: Vice Pres Dick Cheney offers Turkey $228 million in aid to seal its agreement to assume command of international peacekeeping force in Kabul, Afghan capital; under new arrangement, Turkey would lead force while German colonel would assume second level of command; Britain now commands peacekeeping force in city and is eager to hand over responsibility; US has no interest in command; photo of anti-American protest in Ankara hours before Cheney's arrival (M)

headline: Consumers Have Saved The Day. Well, Maybe.
abstract: Louis Uchitelle column on consumer spending as driving force behind economic recovery; graph (M)

headline: Israeli Woman Stabbed to Death in a Wave of Violence
