abstract: Group of Arab youths stab to death Israeli woman, 24, who was walking in park between Jewish and Arab areas of Jerusalem; police report catching four of masked Palestinians spotted running away; say one died at scene, without being shot or wounded; plan autopsy; thousands of supporters of Islamic group Hamas rally, Gaza Strip; watch performers act out rocket attack on Jewish settlement; Hamas leader Dr Abdel Aziz Rantisi speaks in first public appearance since he agreed with Palestinian Authority to submit to house arrest in Dec; deal, together with limited cease-fire set by Hamas, seems to have collapsed; Rantisi says suicide attacks will continue; Palestinian leadership again calls for cease-fire; map; photo (M)

headline: GQ steps out of its pages and opens a lounge, trying to put advertisers and consumers together.
abstract: Conde Nast Publications is 'opening' lounge next week on behalf of GQ, its monthly men's lifestyle magazine; Sunset Room in Hollywood will be renamed for almost one month as GQ Lounge, redecorated to reflect tone of magazine and promote products sold by 22 GQ advertisers; project is example of increasing efforts by marketers to offer consumers what they call tangible brand experiences that move beyond traditional methods like store promotions or product sample handouts; photo (M)

headline: GENCORP DELAYS ITS RESULTS TO REVIEW ACCOUNTING ITEMS
abstract: GenCorp Inc delays release of its fourth-quarter and full-year financial results for review of accounting items and costs at two auto parts plants (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Analyst Talks Of Bankruptcy, And Kmart Takes a Plunge
abstract: Prudential Securities analyst Wayne Hood's negative report sends price of Kmart Corp shares plunging 13.2 percent, to $4.74, in heavy trading; Hood slashes his per-share earnings estimate for fourth quarter by more than 50 percent and predicts loss for year; urges investors to sell; says he would not be surprised if company were to file Chapter 11 bankruptcy if trends do not improve; Kmart spokesman insists that everything at company is progressing normally; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Strike Spreads To Vehicle Makers
abstract: Strike of workers at government-owned South Korean corporations spreads to automobile industry, jeopardizing government's plan to sell stake in money-losing companies; more than 50,000 workers are idle (S)

headline: Shell Plans to Triple Its Stake in China
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group chairman Philip Watts says company plans to triple its investment in China to over $5 billion by 2005 as it helps build natural-gas pipeline across nation with PetroChina (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A white-collar criminal adds conviction No. 7 to his record.
abstract: Article on white-collar criminal career of Lionel Reifler, who pleads guilty to conspiring to rig price of FinancialWeb.com stock traded on over-the-counter bulletin board (Market Place column) (M)

headline: A Marvel Of Science, Hawking Turns 60
abstract: There is no crying in physics, where even the best of friends can call each other's work rubbish, and the most beloved theories are coolly thrown out when experiments contradict them.    But there was emotion tonight in the high-ceilinged hall of Gonville and Caius College here when a butler opened a door and a Marilyn Monroe impersonator slithered in, wearing a pink dress and singing ''I Want to Be Loved by You'' in a whispery voice to Dr. Stephen Hawking, the Cambridge University cosmologist and best-selling author. Dr. Hawking was lolling in a wheelchair, his face split by a huge grin, while some 200 hard-core physicists, their families and friends roared and cheered with laughter, and then joined in singing ''Happy Birthday.''

headline: EMC's Loss in 4th Quarter Was Not as Deep as Feared
abstract: EMC says it lost $70.2 million in fourth quarter on revenue of $1.51 billion; company earned $562.9 million on revenue of $2.62 billion year earlier (M)

headline: Bush, in Monterrey, Speaks of Conditional Global Aid
abstract: Pres Bush calls for 'new compact' for global development by insisting that rich nations give foreign aid to poor nations only if poor nations undertake broad range of political, legal and economic reforms, speech to conference on global aid to developing world, Monterrey, Mexico; photo; 171 nations sign 'Monterrey Consensus,' accord committing them to goals of doubling development to poor and halving world poverty by 2015 (M)

headline: Chicken Well Simmered in a Political Stew; Tyson Fosters Ties to Officials But Is Unable to Avoid Scrutiny
abstract: Tyson Foods, nation's largest meat processor, is badly battered by authorities despite its ties to influential politicians and generous support of Bill Clinton and George W Bush; over last few years, federal officials have accused Tyson of violating labor, environmental and civil rights laws and of making illegal gifts to cabinet secretary; federal grand jury recently indicted Tyson and six employees on charges of conspiring to smuggle illegal immigrants into United States to work at company's processing plants; Tyson insists it has been target of overzealous investigators and crusading special interest groups; company largely denies wrongdoing, even in cases it paid to settle years ago; photo of John H Tyson, 48-year-old scion and chief executive (M)

headline: IVAX CLEARED TO KEEP SELLING GENERIC CANCER DRUG
abstract: FDA will allow Ivax Corp to keep selling generic version of cancer drug Taxol after Ivax signs licensing agreement with Bristol-Myers Squibb Co, original manufacturer, settling patent suits between them (S)

headline: Stocks Flex Some Muscle, Ending Week With Big Gains
abstract: Stock markets surge, ending higher for week, as technology shares post sharp gains and better-than-expected data provide evidence that economy appears to be recovering; investors also seem encouraged by report showing rebound in manufacturing, as factories increase production for first time in 18 months; Nasdaq composite index closes at 1,802.74, up 4.53 percent for week; Dow Jones industrial average rises 262.73 points, to 10,368.86; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 25.05 points, to 1,131.78; graph; chart; table (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar falls against Japanese yen and euro; in New York, dollar settles at 131.96 yen, down from 132.24 yen; euro trades at 89.41 cents, up from 89.25 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Premier Names Deputy
abstract: Canadian Prime Min Jean Chretien names Foreign Min John Manley as deputy prime minister; photo; drops public works minister, Alfonso Gagliano, who has been embroiled in corruption controversies; changes follow surprise resignation of industry minister, Brian Tobin (S)

headline: Univision bets on a new Spanish-language network, TeleFutura.
abstract: TeleFutura, new Spanish-language network of Univision Communications, can be seen on 42 stations and hundreds of cable systems nationwide, making it accessible to about 80 percent of Hispanic population; Univision says TeleFutura will generate $100 million in revenue and break even in its first year; photo (M)

headline: Once again, 20 questions on campaigns, marketing, the media and popular culture.
abstract: Advertising column asks 20 questions about advertising, marketing, media and popular culture (M)

headline: Russian Court Orders Closing Of Nonstate TV
abstract: Moscow court abruptly orders shutdown of Russia's last independent television network, TV-6, which has battled for months against what managers allege is Kremlin-inspired vendetta; similar battle over NTV, independent station absorbed by government-controlled natural gas company Gazprom recalled; both networks were largely owned by tycoons who are political enemies of Pres Vladimir V Putin; they live in exile because of allegations of financial crimes; international organizations and US, among others, have warned legal battles raise questions about Putin's commitment to free speech and independence of Russia's courts; Kremlin insists it has played no role in what it says are ordinary business disputes (M)

headline: Behind India's Brinkmanship: Ominous Preparations to Follow Through
abstract: Analysis: Indian Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee's determination to wage what he has called decisive last battle against terrorism is driving India's increasingly explicit threats of war; Vajpayee is outraged at Dec 13 attack by suicide squad that tried to shoot its way into Parliament, and blames attack on Islamic groups and their sponsors in Pakistan's military intelligence; senior Western diplomats worry that India is dead serious about conlfict that could explode into full-scale war; many fear possibilty of ruinous nuclear exchange; photo (M)

headline: Though France Booms, Voters Find Politics Blah
abstract: France has undergone remarkable economic and social transformation in last few years, but political scene remains largely unchanged; this year's presidential election shapes up to be rerun of 1995 race, between conservative President Jacques Chirac and Socialist Prime Minister Lionel Jospin; rematch has left most French voters cold; opinion polls indicate that vast majority want new faces in race, and suggest that abstention rate this year may be higher than ever before; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Two Women, an Israeli and a Palestinian, Give Birth After Being Shot at Checkpoints
abstract: Two pregnant women, one Palestinian, the other Israeli, give birth after being shot and wounded in separate attacks across their political divide, as violence proceeds unabated day after Israel decides to keep Yasir Arafat confined to West Bank city of Ramallah; in Tulkarm, 15-year-old Palestinian girl leaves suicide note, picks up knife, and runs yelling at soldiers at Israeli army checkpoint, where she is shot dead after refusing to stop; along with violence, new proposal for peace floated by Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia shows signs of gathering momentum; Abdullah's overture comes as Palestinian militants seek to focus international attention and Israeli fear on occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip; militants step up attacks in West Bank, on soldiers and settlers but in particular on Israeli checkpoints; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nokia Introduces Global Phone
abstract: Nokia introduced a mobile phone yesterday that permits users to roam across different wireless communications standards in the United States, Europe and elsewhere. The new phone, the Nokia 6340, will work on the Global System for Mobile Telecommunications networks, the most widely used global standard, as well as the Time Division Multiple Access standard, used primarily in the United States. Global System has about 500 million users worldwide and is used in more than 70 percent of the world's digital wireless market. Nokia said the new phone also comes equipped with a digital wallet that permits quick wireless transactions. Nokia shares fell 85 cents, to $25.30.     Andrew Zipern (NYT)

headline: Week's Schedule Of Equity Issues
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      American Mortgage Acceptance, New York, 3.5 million shares. Friedman, Billings, Ramsey.

headline: Personal Business; Pink Slip? Gold Handshake? Buyouts Can Bridge the Gap
abstract: Employees who are offered buyout packages by companies that are downsizing are encouraged to try to negotiate best deal possible; photo (M)

headline: Palestinians Reclaim Homes In Battered Neighborhoods
abstract: Israeli Army's withdrawal from Bethlehem brings tentative calm, but Kamel Hmeid, local leader of Fatah movement, warns that quiet cannot last without political gains for Palestinians; Palestinians reclaim houses and neighborhoods, cleaning up wreckage left by soldiers and paying condolence calls to families whose members were killed (M)

headline: LAY SOLD SHARES FOR $100 MILLION
abstract: Enron discloses that Kenneth L Lay sold $100 million in Enron stock last year, including $20 million sold after he was warned by Sherron S Watkins that company might collapse 'in a wave of accounting scandals'; it is not clear how much profit Lay made on sales, many of which came while he was encouraging Enron employees to buy shares; Lay previously disclosed selling $29.9 million in shares in public markets from Jan through July; new disclosures show he took in $70.1 million from selling Enron stock back to company from Feb through Oct; spokeswoman for Lay says sales were unrelated to developments at Enron, including Watkins letter; despite sales, family members say Lay faces serious financial difficulties as he struggles to repay loans taken out to make investments, many of which have lost value; time line matches events at Enron last year with Lay's sales of company stock (M)

headline: Hill, Holliday Ending Cisco Ties
abstract: San Francisco office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos is ending its relationship with Cisco Systems by declining to take part in review that Cisco began last week for its advertising account; Cisco spent $22.7 million for first nine months of 2001 (S)

headline: 3 Colombian Rebels Included in Drug Charges by U.S.
abstract: Federal grand jury, Washington, DC, indicts seven men, including three Colombian guerrillas, on charges of conspiring to smuggle planeloads of cocaine from Colombia to US; indictments are first felony narcotics charges brought against members of rebel government; one defendant identified as Tomas Molina Caracas (S)

headline: Investing; A Foul-Weather Bet Has a Following
abstract: Shares of coal producers like Peabody Energy, Arch Coal, Consol Energy, Massey Energy and Canada's Fording Inc are languishing well below their highs of last May, but some analysts and fund managers say investment in coal will be profitable over long term; they say regulatory climate in Washington has become more favorable to coal under Pres Bush; photo; graph (M)

headline: The Increase In Chip Speed Is Accelerating, Not Slowing
abstract: Stress at International Solid State Circuits Conference, set to open, San Francisco, will be on blinding computer speed, suggesting that increases in desktop PC performance of last two years will accelerate; chip speed are doubling even faster than every 18 months forecast by Intel co-founder Gordon Moore in 1965 now that industry is able to shrink physical gate length, key dimension of modern computer chips (M)

headline: As Zinni Heads for Mideast, Sharon and Arafat Are Far Apart
abstract: Israeli officials say Prime Min Ariel Sharon will press Yasir Arafat to take tougher action against militants before Israel will return to peace talks; stand comes as Gen Anthony C Zinni, Pres Bush's envoy, heads back to region to try to revive talks; Israel says it eases blockades on some West Bank and Gaza Strip villages as good will gesture, with more pullbacks planned; Palestinians say they see no change at major choke points blocking their travel between cities and into Israel; Israel arrests Palestinian human rights activist Dr Mustafa Barghouti as he leaves East Jeruslem news conference with European activists for entering country illegally from West Bank, frees him and briefly arrests him again at border checkpoint for allegedly disrupting traffic (M)

headline: Greenspan Says Recession May Be Abating
abstract: The Federal Reserve chairman signaled today that the central bank may not cut interest rates when it meets next week, telling Congress that the economy appears to be on the brink of recovery.

headline: Mistissini Journal; Will the Flood Wash Away the Crees' Birthright?
abstract: Nomadic customs of 13,000 Cree Indians in snowy northern woods of Quebec are about to be disrupted as Rupert River is flooded by dams and dikes of huge hydroelectric project; photos; map; Crees, resigned to project, have signed agreement with provincial government that will open vast territory, one third of province, to development; Crees are dropping $3.6 billion in environmental claims in return for 50-year financing and thousands of jobs; agreement is first in Canada recognizing full autonomy of any Indian people as 'native nation,' but secret negotiations by chiefs have shocked Quebec's nine Cree communities (Mistissini Journal) (M)

headline: US Airways Account Goes to Baltimore
abstract: US Airways will name Eisner Communications to handle its domestic advertising account, with billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million; account had been handled by McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising (S)

headline: Problems Preceded A Move to Eckerd
abstract: TO two people who witnessed J. Wayne Harris's performance on his previous job, it comes as no surprise that Eckerd has taken a more aggressive tack on his watch. These people, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said aggressive and dubious practices characterized Mr. Harris's almost three years as chief executive of the Grand Union Company, the supermarket chain.    One of these people was a lender to Grand Union and a major shareholder; the other a large shareholder. Both were intimately familiar with Mr. Harris's management.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Shelley Eudene Lanman, executive vice president and executive creative director at the New York office of Draft Worldwide, was promoted to senior executive vice president and chief creative officer.

headline: DUPONT CANADA WILL BUY LIQUI-BOX
abstract: DuPont Canada Inc will buy Liqui-Box Corp for $333 million (S)

headline: Israel Hits Police Site After Palestinian Rocket Attack
abstract: Wave of Israeli warplanes strike Palestinian security compound in Gaza City after Palestinian rocket attack on February 10 that Israeli officials call escalation of conflict; strike other sites in Gaza Strip; rockets launched by radical group Hamas toward communities in southern Israel landed in fields; no injuries reported; photos (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  Balance of Trade: Jan.    WEDNESDAY  Housing Starts: Feb.  Federal Budget: Feb.

headline: Amid Growth-Fund Slide, A Manager Departs
abstract: Putnam Investments dismisses Steven Kirson as co-manager of its lagging Putnam OTC Emerging Growth fund; Merrill Lynch is folding Premier Growth and Mid-Cap Growth funds into Large-Cap Growth fund (S)

headline: Economy's Rock: Homes, Homes, Homes
abstract: Housing has emerged as key pillar of support in shaky economy; housing market is less volatile and less prone to oversupply than before; prices have been increasing faster than general inflation for several years, accelerating in recent months to fastest real rate of gain in decades and helping to bolster consumer spending; Federal Reserve is using market as its main lever for reviving economy, supporting demand for housing by driving down mortgage interest rates; graphs of interest rates and home prices; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Old Bomb Found In Berlin
abstract: Unexploded World War II bomb is found buried beneath lower rung of seats of Olympic Stadium in Berlin, Germany; 550-pound British bomb is defused by explosives experts (S)

headline: Bedside Visits, on the Telephone
abstract: Milt Freudenheim column on growth of disease management companies, which work with health insurers to provide information and advice over telephone to patients with serious medical conditions, especially those with multiple maladies; say approach has antagonized some doctors but two sides are making effort to cooperate; drawing (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: COGENT COMMUNICATIONS GROUP, Washington, a provider of Internet access, said it would acquire the United States assets of PSINet Inc., Ashburn, Va., a bankrupt Internet access provider. Terms were not disclosed.    DRS TECHNOLOGIES INC., Parsippany, N.J., a maker of military computer displays, said it had agreed to a $28 million contract to make equipment for U.S. Army vehicles.

headline: Eye on Profits, Murdoch Focuses on Details
abstract: Article in The Media Giants series profiles Rupert Murdoch's empire, which encompasses broadcast, cable and satellite television, movies, books and newspapers; Murdoch says his focus today is not on further acquisitions but on improving operational details and lifting operating income; says company has weathered current downturn better than the last because it moved debt from short-term bank debt to long-term bonds; graphs; photos (L)

headline: Judge Grants A Suspension Of Lawsuit On Napster
abstract: Federal Judge Marilyn Patel grants request by four of five major record companies to suspend their three-year-old lawsuit against Napster; order grants only 30-day suspensions, but it underscores turnabout in strategy by music companies and possible shift in momentum in their case; industry might have requested suspension because of fears that some aspects of case are going against it; record companies involved in decision are AOL Time Warner, BMG, Vivendi Universal and Sony Corp (M)

headline: AFGHANS' LEADER BLAMES OFFICIALS IN KILLING OF AIDE
abstract: Afghanistan's interim leader Hamid Karzai says killing of aviation and tourism minister Abdul Rahman was personal vendetta carried out by other senior government officials, including intelligence chief, Gen Abdullah Jan Tawhidi and senior defense official, Gen Qalander Beg; both men are believed to be in Saudi Arabia; they are senior figures in dominant political faction in Northern Alliance, anti-Taliban coalition that forms core of Karzai government; Karzai says he has asked Saudi government to arrest them; assassination of Rahman, followed by outbreak of violence in Kabul, seems likely to stir new anxiety about fragile situation facing government; fear is that government itself could be torn apart by old enmities based on ethnic, tribal and political divisions that underlay miseries of past; photos (M)

headline: HERSHEY FOODS TO INTRODUCE MORE CHOCOLATE PRODUCTS
abstract: Hershey Foods Corp chief executive Richard H Lenny says company plans to introduce more products this year in effort to bolster nonholiday sales; some new products noted (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Brokerage Firm Sells Unit
abstract: Bipop-Carire, whose shares have lost about 75 percent of their value this year, agrees to sell its Azimut fund management unit to Apax Partners of Britain for 418.5 million euros ($370 million) (S)

headline: Mexico's Supreme Court Demanding Inquiry Into '68 Massacre
abstract: Mexico's Supreme Court orders government of Pres Vicente Fox to investigate 1968 massacre of student demonstrators by government troops in Mexico City; neither government nor military has ever officially acknowledged gravity of killings and no one has every been charged; official history texts used in Mexico's schools erase event; historians and human-rights activists say 300 people died and 1,000 were injured when plainclothes government snipers fired on crowd of peaceful demonstrators (M)

headline: Judge Says Ruling on Microsoft Won't Come Quickly
abstract: Bush administration and nine states urge Federal Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly to approve their settlement of Microsoft Corp antitrust case swiftly and reject complaints by rivals and consumer groups; Kollar-Kotelly says case's many complexities require her to spend time examining all isues and that her decision will not be imminent; among those participating in daylong meeting are Kenneth W Starr, representing Microsoft, and Robert H Bork, representing industry groups critical of Microsoft; photo (M)

headline: Denunciation Of Mugabe By Europeans Intensifies
abstract: Euroepan leaders step up denunciations of recent Zimbabwe elections, with Germany following Canadian lead in vowing to cut off aid to Robert Mugabe's government (S)

headline: SCHERING FILES SUIT TO BLOCK GENERIC FORMS OF CLARITIN
abstract: Schering-Plough files lawsuits to block McNeil Consumer Healthcare, unit of Johnson & Johnson, and Whitehall-Robins Healthcare, unit of American Home Products, from selling generic versions of Claritin, its top-selling allergy drug (S)

headline: Board Member Of Tyco Unit Owed Millions To 2 Executives
abstract: As Tyco International was negotiating last year over how much it would pay to buy out public shareholders of its fiber optic division, independent director of unit owed Tyco's two top executives $14.1 million; neither Tyco nor fiber optic division, TyCom, ever publicly disclosed that TyCom director Warren V Musser and wife Hilary Grinker Musser borrowed money from Tyco's chairman L Dennis Kozlowski and chief financial officer Mark H Swartz in December 2000; Mussers were in financial distress at that time; Tyco went on to buy public shares of TyCom, repurchasing stake that it had sold in initial public offering in July 2000; deal proved profitable for Tyco, although not not TyCom shareholders; price of $864 million in stock that Tyco paid for TyCom in October 2001 was half what it had sold shares for 15 months earlier (M)

headline: In Shock, and in Charge
abstract: Fran Keeth, president of Shell Chemical LP, writes The Boss column, telling how she took charge of Shell Oil's tax and finance department in 1970's, when she was in her 20's, only woman and most junior staff member; photo (M)

headline: Colombia and Its Rebels Agree to Talks, Reviving Peace Effort
abstract: Colombian government and country's largest rebel group agree on timetable for reaching cease-fire agreement, raising hopes that country's troubled peace efforts might at last make headway under three fitful years; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Compulsory Military Service Ends
abstract: Spain, after 200 years, ends compulsory military service for young men; change is step toward professionalizing armed forces (S)1

headline: APPELLATE COURT EASES LIMITATIONS FOR MEDIA GIANTS
abstract: Washington, DC, federal appeals court, in major victory for nation's largest television networks and cable operators, rules government must reconsider sharp limits on number of stations network can own and strikes down regulation that restricted cable operators from owning television stations; ruling would remove significant impediments that have prevented companies from merging with broadcast networks that own TV stations; would permit big broadcast networks, which have bumped up against station-ownership limits, to continue buying stations unimpeded; is setback for smaller owners of broadcast stations and consumer groups advocating more diversity in media since it could open door for new wave of megamergers in entertainment and media industries and continued concentration of power among biggest media companies; executives at large media companies laud ruling; consumer groups express alarm; ruling, based on consolidation of five separate cases in which Federal Communications Commission sought to defend ownership regulations, discussed; photo; chart (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Another Warning From Cable And Wireless
abstract: Cable and Wireless delivers its third warning in last year that sales and profits will be lower than forecast; says sales at its global division will be down 10 percent in year through March 31, compared with earlie rforecat of 5 percent fall; graph (S)

headline: Afghan Flag Is Unfurled As Dark Threats Swirl
abstract: A NATION CHALLENGED: RECONSTRUCTION: Afghan Flag Is Unfurled As Dark Threats Swirl**Afghan government holds flag-raising ceremony at old royal palace in Kabul, where Hamid Karzai, interim leader, speaks of Afghanistan's yearning to rejoin 'civilized world'; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says US is sending small team of military advisers to assess proposals for building new multiethnic army for Afghanistan; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: BMW Predicts Growth
abstract: BMW expects its sales and profit to grow further this year; they expect vehicle sales to rise 10 percent at least and top one million cars, up from 905,700 in 2001 (S)

headline: U.N. Demands That Congo Rebels Withdraw From Seized City
abstract: United Nations Security Council demands that Congolese Rally for Democracy, rebel force, withdraw immediately from Moliro, major port town that it has captured on Lake Tanganyika; calls on Rwanda, which has backed force, to use its influence to make rebels withdraw (M)

headline: At Rights Meeting, Anxiety That Terror Fight Takes Lead
abstract: UN Commission on Human Rights opens meeting in Geneva amid concern that invoking terrorism allows countries with questionable rights records to escape condemnation; Comr Mary Robinson warns rights could be undermined in aftermath of Sept 11 attacks; US, which was voted off last year, takes exception to contention that fighting terrorism is tied to correcting problems like poverty and discrimination (M)

headline: Rains Help Australia Turn Corner on Worst Wildfires in Years
abstract: Heavy rains douse most of last of forest fires still burning outside Sydney, Australia; many residents are angered that arsonists helped spread fires and are determined to punish culprits (M)

headline: U.N. Reviews Plans to Protect Its Offices Around the World
abstract: Sec Gen Kofi Annan releases report on increasing security at UN offices around world (S)

headline: VAIL RESORTS TO BUY HEAVENLY SKI FOR $96 MILLION
abstract: Vail Resorts Inc acquires Heavenly Ski Resort near Lake Tahoe from American Skiing Co for $96 million to $99 million in cash (S)

headline: Private Sector; Funny Lady, Serious Woman
abstract: Profile of actress and comedian Whoopi Goldberg, focusing on her success as film producer; photo (M)

headline: In Siberia, Serious TV News Fights to Survive
abstract: Aleksandr Karpov's Afontovo television station, which introduced Western style of TV news to Krasnoyarsk, Russia, is struggling to survive; offers balanced and polite news coverage; is losing viewers to scandal-mongering rival station; plight is typical of some 600 local stations across Russia's provinces, which must chose between staying afloat or staying honest; state takeovers of two countrywide networks that supplied many regional stations with free programming have made survival harder; map; photos (M)

headline: Tyson Foods Reports Surge in Net Income
abstract: Tyson Foods Inc says fiscal first quarter net income rose to $126.9 million compared with $27 million year earlier; revenue rose to $5.86 billion from $1.77 billion (S)

headline: GOODYEAR'S TIRE SHIPMENTS LAG THOSE OF RIVALS
abstract: Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co says shipments to retailers in North America lagged rivals for first two months of year as dealers sold fewer tires than expected; company's shares fall $2.55, or 9 percent, to $25.40, biggest one-day drop since Sept 17 (S)

headline: Private Sector; Just a Friendly Competition
abstract: Adidas-Salomon chief executive Herbert

headline: Arabs Deploy New Explosive Against Tank; 3 Israelis Die
abstract: Palestinian militants destroy Israeli tank for first time, using mine underneath that kills at least three soldiers and lightly wounds fourth; tank was responding to coordinated attack on settlers' convoy in Gaza; Hamas and Fatah faction claim responsibility; Israel sees escalation to conventional warfare; Israeli raids in Gaza and West Bank and killings of several Palestinians also noted (S)

headline: Ex-Leader of Belarus Challenges a Punishment by Pension
abstract: Former Belarus Pres Stanislav Shushkevich is suffering inventive punishment at hands of current Pres Aleksandr Lukashenko, political enemy who is refusing to have Shushkevich's pension indexed for inflation; Shushkevich says inflation has left monthly pension worth about $1.80, enough for four loaves of excellent brown bread or bottle of vodka, but not both (M)

headline: A Management Revolution Still in the Making
abstract: Steve Lohr reviews Frances Cairncross's The Company of the Future, book on how Internet promises to transform corporate management; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: When Are Media Not Media?
abstract: Former Vice Pres Al Gore speaks at India Today news magazine conference in India after barring reporters from attending; photo (S)

headline: In Polish Trip, Putin Talks Of More Trade And New Ties
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin ends two-day trip to Poland, and he and Pres Aleksander Kwasniewski vow to let renewed trade and pragmatism warm frost off Polish-Russian troubled past; Putin, seeking to make gestures to ease Poles' anger at Russia, stops unexpectedly at monument to nearly 50 victims of revolt in Poland in 1956, one of first major demonstrations in Eastern Europe against Soviet rule; Poles seem to regard his visit with mix of hope, curiosity and admiration for Putin himself (M)

headline: Foreign students on rise : Enduring allure of a U.S. diploma
abstract: WASHINGTONâ€”  Marga van der Werff had the typical priorities in mind when she went looking for a graduate program in businessaffordability and a challenging curriculum. But for the 28-year-old Dutch woman, the most important factor was location.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Ryanair Posts Profit
abstract: Ryanair announces 35 percent increase in after-tax profits for three months ended in December, to 28.8 million euros ($32.5 million), while passenger numbers rose 30 percent, to 2.7 million; operating costs rose more slowly than revenue, at 15 percent; chief executive Michael O'Leary comments; photo (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; In 30 months, two top executives at Tyco made hundreds of millions of dollars selling the stock.
abstract: Tyco International Ltd's chairman-chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski and chief financial officer Mark H Swartz have made more than $500 million in profits by selling Tyco shares since July 1999; Kozlowski has netted at least $330 million while Swartz has made at least $180 million; shares of Tyco have fallen 40 percent since July 1999, lowering its market value by tens of billions of dollars; Tyco spokesman Brad McGee says stock sales were to pay taxes and for tax planning (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Europeans Turn to the W.T.O. To Battle U.S. Tariffs on Steel
abstract: European Union responds to Pres Bush's imposition of new tariffs on steel from certain countries by filing two-part complaint at World Trade Organization; union fears it will be hurt by flood of cheap steel diverted from American market to Europe by tariffs; European Central Bank president Wim Duisenberg denounces tariffs as 'deplorable action'; European Union maintains that American steel industry's failure to consolidate and restructure is source of its problems, not unfair competition from imports (M)

headline: Dead and Missing
abstract: Estimate of number of people killed or missing and presumed dead as result of attacks on Sept 11 stands at 3,119 (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: MIDDLE EAST.

headline: Suspect, Changing Story, Says American Reporter Is Dead
abstract: Ahmed Omar Sheikh, chief suspect in kidnapping of American journalist Daniel Pearl, says in Pakistani court that reporter is dead and that he had carried out abduction three weeks ago 'under my own free will'; photo; authorities and Wall Street Journal say they believe Pearl is still alive; wife issues new plea; Pres Pervez Musharraf says in Washington extremists may have sought to destabilize his government, but also suggests Pearl got 'overintrusive in whatever he was doing' (M)

headline: Predictable Password Use
abstract: David Hanuer letter on Dec 27 article on computer passwords cites human tendency to leave passwords where intruder could find them

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Hearing Dropped In Patent Fight
abstract: International Trade Commission decides to eliminate closing arguments in closely watched patent dispute over Gemstar-TV Guide International's interactive program guides; closing arguments were scheduled for Feb 20, and ruling was expected by March 21; Gemstar-TV brought lawsuits against EchoStar Communications, Scientific-Atlanta, SCI Systems and Pioneer for importing cable and satellite television set-top boxes with interactive program guides; Gemstar says guides violate its patent portfolio (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Pipeline Strategy
abstract: Malaysia's state oil company, Petroliam Nasional, warns again that it might reroute natural gas pipeline to exclude neighboring Thailand, where political opposition has delayed construction; photo (S)

headline: Moody's Raises Debt Rating Of South Korea by 2 Notches
abstract: Moody's Investors Service upgrades South Korea's sovereign debt rating two notches to A3 from Baa2; change puts rating one notch below where it was before 1997 economic crisis; Kim Yi Tae, deputy director of finance ministry's international finance division, says Korean companies will be able to borrow more easily and cheaply overseas, saving about $5 billion per year in interest; Finance Min Jin Nyum dismisses concerns voiced in some quarters that Korean economy, which grew 3.7 percent in fourth quarter of 2001, might be doing almost too well; Bank of Korea reports exports were 16.8 percent lower in February 2002 than in February 2001, and that industrial output was 2.6 percent lower; imports fell 17.8 percent; trade surplus grew to $440 million for month (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Economic Growth Expected
abstract: Min German Gref predicts Russia's economy will expand by average of 3.5 percent from 2002 to 2005 if export price for its crude oil is $18.50 a barrel; says gross domestic product probably rose 3.1 percent to 3.2 percent in first quarter (S)

headline: More Departures From Fidelity
abstract: More Departure

headline: 13 Stripes, 50 Stars, 800 Tired Workers
abstract: update: annin & comp

headline: Argentine Peso Sinks to New Lows as Crisis Continues
abstract: Argentine peso plunges to 1.85 to US dollar as Argentine central bank tries for second time to stabilize its value by selling dollars; demonstrations and rioting continue across country over economic crisis and over continuing restrictions on Argentines' access to their bank accounts; International Monetary Fund says it will postpone for year debt of $993 million that Argentina was due to pay Jan 17; economists say peso will continue to slide until government puts in place credible fiscal and monetary policies that can begin to rebuild confidence in country's economy (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; History Shows First 5 Days Can Put Bulls On Right Path
abstract: One of Wall Street's most noted indicators--first five days of January--has sent its signal, and it says that this will be good year for stock market; John McGinley, editor of newsletter Technical Trends, says when market goes up during first five days, it almost always indicates that market will go up for the year; indicator was invented for Dow Jones industrial average, but it has also worked for Standard & Poor's 500-stock index; during first five trading days of 2002, through Jan 8, Dow rose 1.3 percent, Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 1.1 percent, and Nasdaq composite index rose 5.4 percent; there have been 16 years since 1972, first full year of Nasdaq composite index, when all three indexes rose during first five days; graph (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Ford Lost $5.4 Billion in 2001 After Charge for Revamping
abstract: Ford Motor Co reports $5.45 billion net loss for 2001, first annual loss since 1992; company had net profit of $3.47 billion in 2000; reports net loss of $5.07 billion in fourth quarter compared with net profit of $1.08 billion year earlier; chief financial officer I Martin Inglis comments; Delphi Automotive Systems, supply company spun off from General Motors in 1998, reports net loss for 2001 of $370 million, in contrast to net profit of $1.06 billion year ago (M)

headline: Briton Gives Testimony On Warning To Milosevic
abstract: War crimes trial of Slobodan Milosevic moves into new phase as first Western politician appears to testify against him, The Hague; Paddy Ashdown, former member of British Parliament, acccuses Milosevic of using 'outrageous and excessive force' as his forces looted, burned and shelled villages in Kosovo in 1998 and forced starving inhabitants to flee (M)

headline: Investing; Seeking Buried Treasure, The Old-Fashioned Way
abstract: Investors show renewed interest in small mining exploration companies, particularly gold ventures, sector that has been troubled recently by slumping metal prices and Bre-X Minerals scandal; analysts comment on industry as a whole and individual companies (M)

headline: Enron Fights U.S. Ban Affecting Utility
abstract: The Enron Corporation will try to remove its Portland General Electric unit from a list of businesses now barred by the General Services Administration from doing new business with the federal government for 12 months.    ''We do not understand why P.G.E. was included, but we will be taking the necessary steps to remove them from the G.S.A.'s list,'' an Enron spokesman, John Ambler, said today.

headline: EX-CHIEF OF AREMISSOFT INDICTED ON FRAUD CHARGE
abstract: AremisSoft Corp's former chairman-co-chief executive Roys Poyiadjis is indicted for fraud; charge comes to light in case filed March 22 in which prosecutors say they are seeking to seize $175 million in illicit profits diverted to two overseas banks by Poyiadjis and his co-chief executive Lycourgos Kyprianou (S)

headline: Women Take Command in Internet Shopping
abstract: DIARY Women Take Command In Internet Shopping.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   9.50        Discount rate   1.25   1.25   6.00        Federal funds   1.81   1.78   6.20        3-month T-bills   1.55   1.53   5.72        6-month T-bills   1.58   1.58   5.05        10-yr. T-infl.   3.37   3.34   3.56        10-yr. T-note   4.83   4.87   5.23        30-yr. T-bond   5.34   5.37   5.60        Telephone bd.   7.42   7.42   7.82        Municipal bds.   5.27   5.29   5.24          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: More Connecticut Records About Enron Deal Emerge
abstract: Connecticut Attorney General Richard Blumenthal releases documents that he says provides additional proof that $220 million paid to Enron Corp by quasi-public agency in late 2000 was 'illegal, unsecured loan' and not legitimate energy transaction, as agency has maintained; documents consist of three loan amortization schedules that listed dates and amounts of monthly payments Enron would make to agency, Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority, starting in February 2001 (M)

headline: Justices to Review Copyright Extension
abstract: US Supreme Court agrees to decide whether 1998 law, Sonny Bono Copyright Term Extension Act, that extended duration of existing copyrights by 20 years is constitutional; court's action takes copyright holders and users by surprise and holds potential of producing most important copyright case in decades; issue is whether Constitution's grant of authority to Congress to issue copyrights and patents 'for limited times' to 'promote the progress of science and useful arts' contains any real limitatation on how that power is to be exercised; that quesion has implications for future cases as battle over ownership of intellectual property focuses on Internet; consequences could be enormous, both for those with stakes in copyrights that are running out and for growing community of people, represented by plaintiffs in case, trying to use Internet to expand boundaries of public domain; if 20-year extension is unconstitutional, early Mickey Mouse depictions could no longer belong exclusively to Walt Disney Co, although Disney would retain trademark protection of character; two lower federal courts had rejected arguments by coalition of publishers and individuals that latest extension of copyright protection defeated original intent of Copyright Clause; initial Copyright Act, which Congress amended only once in 150 years, provided for 14-year term, with 14-year renewal only if author was still alive; plaintiffs' Supreme Court appeal, filed by Prof Lawrence Lessig of Stanford Law School, garnered support from concerned groups including American Library Association and other libraries (M)

headline: BUSH SAYS THE U.S. PLANS NO ATTACK ON NORTH KOREA
abstract: Pres Bush says US has no intentions of invading or attacking North Korea and that his goal on Korean peninsula is peace, news conference, Seoul; acts to soothe fears of South Koreans following State of the Union address, in which he accused North of being part of 'axis of evil' with Iran and Iraq that sponsors terrorism; says he fully supports so-called sunshine policy of negotiations with North embraced by South Korean President Kim Dae Jung; says dialogue with North is not inconsistent with his tough 'axis of evil' talk; says he is deeply concerned about plight of North Koreans, who live under regime that is closed and nontransparent; says US offer for talks in June 2001 has not been answered by North Korea and that contact between both countries is up to Pres Kim Jong Il; visits demilitarized zone; photos; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Moody's Forecasts Bank Losses
abstract: Moody's Investors Service says Argentina's banks face losses of $54 billion and may be taken over by government to avert financial collapse; says banks probably will default on all international dollar obligations (S)

headline: Ford's Bet on Metals Prompts a Lawsuit
abstract: Ford Motor Co is hit will class-action lawsuit that accuses it of not disclosing early enough that it made large, unhedged bets on palladium; lost $1 billion trading palladium after price fell and technical advance with catalytic converter reduced its need for metal (S)

headline: Craving Walls in an Office Tundra
abstract: Lisa Belkin column compares working in cubicle to having own office; notes cubicle occupants often try to create space that feels like it has walls out of desire for privacy and comfort; drawing (M)

headline: SHARES OF STATION CASINOS RISE ON LAS VEGAS OUTLOOK
abstract: Shares of Station Casinos Inc rise 12 percent after owner of Las Vegas-area casinos says its first-quarter and 2002 earnings will beat analysts' estimates; chief financial officer Glenn Christenson comments (S)

headline: Audit Papers Usually Held For Years, Accountants Say
abstract: Documents related to corporate audit, such Arthur Andersen's audit of Enron Corp, are generally maintained for years by accounting firms, although there are no hard and fast rules governing how soon they can be destroyed; only some audit papers are maintained, however, and accounting firms have long held that less important papers can be destroyed as soon as an audit is completed; lawyers and accountants agree that all relevant documents must be preserved once auditor learns of government investigation related to audit, even if it would have been permissible to dispose of them before that; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Problem At Nuclear Plant
abstract: Nuclear power station in Temelin, Czech Republic, is shut down because of generator problem just hours after being powered up for tests; Austria, whose border is 35 miles from plant, has repeatedly threatened to block talks on Czech entry into European Union unless Prague guarantees safety of plant; map (S)

headline: Volcano-Scorched Congo City, Ground Shaking, Returns to a Nervous Kind of Normal
abstract: Goma, Congo, struggles to return to normal in aftermath of eruption of volcano on Mount Nyiragongo that has left widespread destruction and people desperate and starving; death toll remains unknown; maps (M)

headline: Napster Wins One Round In Music Case
abstract: America's major record companies, which successfully sued to shut down online music-swapping service Napster, suffer serious setback as Federal Judge Marilyn Patel allows Napster to seek evidence that record companies colluded to monopolize digital music market; Patel writes that if Napster shows record labels were involved in illegal collusion, it could invalidate their lawsuit; decision is potential turnaround in case that has helped define how copyrighted material is distributed over Internet, who will profit from such distribution, and whether and how much consumers will pay; Napster says it is pleased by decision (M)

headline: Another Round Of Layoffs Are Planned At First Boston
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston plans another round of layoffs at its investment banking group; Adebayo Ogunlesi, new head of investment banking group, announces his intention to begin new round of job cuts, focusing on senior executive positions; photo (M)

headline: Cohen Is Appointed Times Foreign Editor
abstract: Howell Raines, executive editor, announces appointment of Roger Cohen as foreign editor of The New York Times; Cohen has been acting foreign editor since Sept (S)

headline: Man Charged With Lying About Radio Device in Room
abstract: Abdallah Higazy, Egyptian student staying in hotel room with view of World Trade Center on Sept 11, is charged with lying to federal investigators about aviation radio found in room's safe; he was arrested Dec 17 after he returned to Millenium Hilton Hotel to collect his belongings; Judge Frank Maas orders him held without bail; Higazy's lawyer, Robert S Dunn, says Higazy is son of former Egyptian diplomat who was educated largely in United States; says client does not know how aviation radio got into safe in his hotel room (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Saving Sturgeon, And Caviar
abstract: Russia and three other countries on Caspian Sea, facing possible UN ban on caviar exports, reportedly survey sturgeon stocks and set fishing quotas; map (S)

headline: Bigger Crowd Urges a Focus On Social Ills
abstract: Thousands of most vocal critics of globalization are in Porto Alegre, Brazil, at World Social Forum, counterweight to World Economic Forum discussions being held in New York; photo (M)

headline: Labor Brings Witnesses to Tell Of a Harsher Side to Growth
abstract: World Economic Forum serves as foremost intellectual seminar about globalization; unions, recognizing this, seize on occasion to try to get across their take on globalization; AFL-CIO campaign to make global economy friendlier to workers includes flying in garment worker from Guatemala to tell corporate chiefs attending forum about harsh conditions for factory workers in her country who make clothes for American companies; many corporate leaders argue that moving operations to low-wage countries is good for those countries and their workers (M)

headline: Merck Says AIDS Vaccine Shows Promise in Human Trial
abstract: Merck & Co scientists reports promising findings from first human tests of its experimental HIV vaccine, which some experts consider best hope in effort to slow AIDS epidemic (M)

headline: Police Say Former Enron Executive Committed Suicide
abstract: The body of a former Enron executive who resigned after voicing concerns about the direction of the company was discovered early this morning after he apparently killed himself.

headline: Merger Business Plunges for Investment Banks, but Underwriting Is Up
abstract: Wall Street bankers have tough time trying to do anywhere amount of business they did in 2000; business has dropped off about 15 percent; most lucrative business, advising companies on mergers and acquisitions, falls by slightly more than half, to $1.71 trillion from $3.47 trillion in 2000; however, business of underwriting stocks and bonds climbs about 24.7 percent in 2001, buoyed in part by raft of interest rate cuts; table shows performance of leading underwriters (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Expedia Buys a Tour Company
abstract: Expedia agrees to buy Classic Vacation Group Inc unit called Classic Custom Vacations for $82 million in cash, stock and assumed liabilities (S)

headline: Senate Issues 29 Subpoenas In Inquiry on Enron Collapse
abstract: Senate committee looking into Enron Corp's collapse issues 29 subpoenas seeking information from company, its accountant, Arthur Andersen, and board members about communications they had with White House and several government agencies on energy policies and related matters (S)

headline: Vietnam's determined war on poverty
abstract: THACH TUONG, Vietnam:â€”  Several dozen farmers crowded into a small concrete hut the other afternoon in this village at the end of a valley full of rice and sugar fields. They came by motorbike and on foot to get advice on how to apply for a bank loan to increase farm production and income.

headline: Limbs for Afghans
abstract: Sara Nicoll letter on Jan 3 article on Curtis Grimsley's escape from World Trade Center; urges prosthetic legs be offered to land mine victims

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Profit Falls At Health Care Group
abstract: Roche Holding posts 4 percent decline, to $2.8 billion, in its net profit for 2001 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Petroleum Merger
abstract: Indian conglomerate Reliance Group says its Reliance Industries, India's biggest petrochemical company, and Reliance Petroleum, country's largest privqte oil refining company, will merger; Anil Ambani's family will own more than third of new company (S)

headline: Drugs: More Important, More Costly
abstract: Importance of prescription drugs to older people is one of most significant changes in medicine in recent decades; drugs have allowed people to live longer and stay healthier; drug costs have soared, spurring almost universal support for some form of Medicare coverage; Pres Bush's proposal discussed; photo (special section, Retirement) (M)

headline: U.S. and North Korea Hold High-Level Discussion
abstract: Bush administration envoy Charles Pritchard meets with North Korea's UN Amb Pak Gil Yon in highest-level bilateral talks since Pres Bush denounced North Korea as part of 'axis of evil' (S)

headline: Drug Maker Issues Earnings Warning
abstract: The Andrx Corporation said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit was ''significantly lower'' than the 35 cents a share it earned in the third quarter as sales of some products fell while its generic versions of blockbuster drugs were delayed.     The company, a generic-drug manufacturer, did not give specifics on fourth-quarter earnings. It was expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call to earn 26 cents a share. Andrx earned 25 cents a share in the quarter a year earlier.

headline: Profit at EBay Increased 8% Last Quarter
abstract: EBay Inc says fourth-quarter net income rose to $25.9 million from $23.9 million year earlier; sales rose to $219.4 million from $134 million year ago (M)

headline: New Economy; Many midsize companies find that 'defensive publishing' is a quick and cheap way to protect intellectual property.
abstract: IP.com allows small and midsize companies to protect intellectual property by posting descriptions of their ideas on site, thus establishing legal existence of their ideas; 'defensive publishing,' as practice is called, means that competitors have access to ideas, but many companies say competitive risk is outweighed by benefit of making it difficult for someone else to win patent without having to go through time and expense of obtaining patent; drawing (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: AOL Moviefone, New York to Gotham, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle the creative and media duties for brand advertising.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: NIIT LTD., New Delhi, a software maker and computer training company, said it had bought Osprey Systems, Charlotte, N.C., a provider of management software services, for $3 million in a bid to increase sales.    ZEBRA TECHNOLOGIES CORP., Vernon Hills, Ill., which makes bar code printers, ended its planned $104 million purchase of Fargo Electronics Inc., Eden Prairie, Minn., a maker of products to personalize plastic identification cards, because the Federal Trade Commission was unlikely to approve the deal.    PACIFIC TEXAS CORP., Phoenix, a closely held pipeline company, said it would build an 800-mile $1.3 billion natural gas pipeline from West Texas to Arizona's border with California. The line is expected to carry up to one billion cubic feet of gas a day by 2004.

headline: For Outsiders in Saudi Arabia, Worship Comes With a Risk
abstract: Article describes risks non-Muslims face in attempting to practice religion in Saudi Arabia, where Islam is only religion officially allowed and where all citizens must be Muslims; Constitution consists of Koran and teachings of Prophet Muhammad, and proselytzing is punishable by prison sentence (M)

headline: Car Bomb Kills Former Chief of Christian Militia in Lebanon
abstract: Lebanon relived a moment drawn from its brutal civil war today when a bomb detonated in a Beirut suburb, assassinating Elie Hobeika.

headline: Executives Nominated To Lead Ad Group
abstract: American Association of Advertising Agencies nominates executives to serve as officers for 2002-2003 year; nominees noted; members of association will vote at conference and business meeting to be held April 17-20 (S)

headline: CNN to Hire Connie Chung From ABC, TV Executives Say
abstract: CNN plans to hire Connie Chung in what would be its highest-profile move since the network announced that it was seeking bigger names for its programs.

headline: Jennings Contract Seen as a Bellwether for ABC News
abstract: Next sign of how serious Walt Disney Co is about cuts at ABC News division will come during contract talks with anchor Peter Jennings; question is whether Disney will hold tough line against Jennings, who is said to earn more than $10 million per year and sits atop pay scale at ABC News; his contract is up in midsummer (M)

headline: Compressed Data; No Uniform Policy For Sprint's Cards
abstract: Sprint Military Miles, prepaid calling card sold online, is marketed as being open to family and friends of the military but is not restricted to military personnel; nonexclusivity and e-mail delivery of access codes allow anyone to send gifts of calling time to those in military; photo (M)

headline: The Geneva Convention on P.O.W.'s
abstract: Here is a summary of some main provisions of the Third Geneva Convention and the Additional Protocols to it, which define the conduct of combatants and the protection of prisoners of war:

headline: Beauty Care for the Macho Man
abstract: LONDONâ€”  Will beauty products and treatments, even cosmetics, ever become guy things? The companies that make them are gambling that they will. Leading manufacturers of beauty products, such as Clarins and Lancome in France, are introducing ranges for men that go beyond the usual hair and shaving supplies.

headline: U.S. Joins Council Vote Telling Israel To Withdraw
abstract: US joins other UN Security Council members in resolution calling on Israel to withdraw troops from Ramallah and other Palestinian cities (M)

headline: Most Recent E-Mail On Seized Reporter Sends Grim Message
abstract: Fate of Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl, abducted in Pakistan, remains unknown after telephone demand for $2-million ransom is followed by e-mail message saying Pearl has been executed; message says body is in Karachi graveyard, prompting police search (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: Spain Decides to Fine Deloitte Over Audit of Failed Concern
abstract: Spain's Institute for Accounting and Auditing, regulatory body, fines accounting firm Deloitte & Touche 540,000 euros ($473,000) in connection with collapse last summer of one of its audit clients, Gescartera SA, Madrid brokerage firm; Deloitte's Spanish office says it stands by its work on Gescartera's books (M)

headline: For Gap Shoppers, A Question of Age
abstract: Jo Landau letter on Feb 25 article suggests Gap stores bring back classic apparel to win back over-30 shoppers; photo

headline: BANK OF NEW YORK AGREES TO BUY A UNIT OF WEISS, PECK
abstract: Bank of New York agrees to buy stock-and-bond clearing unit of money manager Weiss, Peck & Greer for undisclosed amount; Weiss, Peck is unit of Rabobank Group of Netherlands (S)

headline: Study Said to Show Added Benefit of Genentech Breast Cancer Drug
abstract: Study by Harvard Medical School and Massachusetts General Hospital Dr Rakesh K Jain and four colleagues shows that Herceptin, breast cancer drug from Genentech, not only blocks factor that promotes tumor growth but also slows flow of blood tumors need to grow; Herceptin generated revenue of $346.6 million in 2001 (M)

headline: DRILLING CONTRACTOR TO SPIN OFF OIL AND GAS BUSINESS
abstract: Helmerich & Payne, US-based drilling contractor, will spin off subsidiary that produces oil and natural gas; new company called Cimarex Energy Co will acquire Key Production Co of Denver in $220 million transaction (S)

headline: Two Senior Al Qaeda Fighters Captured
abstract: Two senior Al Qaeda fighters were among 14 suspected terrorists detained by United States forces in eastern Afghanistan, a top Pentagon official said today.

headline: Job Data May Show a False Positive
abstract: Comment on how 'seasonal adjustment' factor affects employment figures, in light of official tally of jobs in New York City, scheduled to be released in March, that is likely to show increased employment in stores, finance, maybe even all over, 'after adjustments for seasonal factors'; graphs (M)

headline: Leonid Ozernoy, 62, Dissident And Soviet-Era Astrophysicist
abstract: Dr Leonid M Ozernoy, Soviet-born astrophysicist and dissident whose campaign to emigrate to United States in 1980's drew international attention, dies at age 62 (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Gas Executive Freed
abstract: Vyacheslav Sheremet, executive of Sibur, gas-processing company that is partly owned by Russian gas monopoly Gazprom, is released after his arrest as part of investigation into disappearance of Sibur assets valued at $85 million; two other Sibur executives are still being held (S)

headline: Art's Message to World: Simply, Eat the Riches
abstract: Diary column on World Economic Forum in New York City; Mimi Oka and Doug Fitch, whose 'art' involves provocative food presentations, prepare event for 35 people that features pasta sheets printed with $100 bills and gold-flecked meatballs(M)

headline: 8 European Air Treaties In Jeopardy
abstract: Antonio Tizzano, top adviser to European Court of Justice, says eight European countries are breaking European Union law by negotiating civil aviation treaties directly with US; Tizzano's opinion may form basis for court ruling in coming months, which could back campaign by European Union's executive arm to negotiate these treaties on behalf of all 15 member states; transfer of power to European Union could topple 50-year-old system that regulates international air traffic rights; under that system, European nations have individual bilateral trans-Atlantic agreements with US, spelling out which airlines can fly into US from which airports; analysts say overturning those agreements could have effect of liberalizing European aviation and pave way for consolidation; British Airways could have most to lose if changes become reality (M)

headline: 37% Raise Proposed By Panel in Dispute At United Airlines
abstract: Presidential panel suggests that mechanics at United Airlines should receive 37.3 percent pay increase this year because their wages lag industry; board says 10,600 mechanics should have their top pay rate increased to $35.14 an hour, up from $25.60, upon signing new contract; United says it has serious reservations about some of recommendations and will discuss issue with its board's labor committee (S)

headline: Europeans Give Bush Plan on Climate Change a Tepid Reception
abstract: European Union gives tepid welcome to Pres Bush's new proposals, strictly voluntary, to address climate change (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Rebel Merger Angers Government
abstract: Government of Sudan condemns two rival groups of rebels that have agreed to merge, saying they are hindering efforts to end country's long civil war (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Dominican Republic: Visit By Haitian Leader
abstract: Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide of Haiti arrives in Dominican Republic to discuss, among other things, extradition of Guy Philippe, former Haitian police official accused of plotting failed coup attempt last month; Dominican officials have said they would deport him, but to third country rather than hand him over to Haiti; photo (S)

headline: India and Pakistan Pave Way for Talks
abstract: Indian and Pakistani foreign ministers, in Nepal for regional summit, privately discusse terms for talks to defuse dangerous confrontation along border; photo of Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee and Pres Pervez Musharraf at royal dinner; map; compromise would assure India that Pakistan is cracking down on terrorism while allowing Pakistan, smaller and more insecure, to save face; India also wants US to see that Pakistan cuts off support to Islamic groups waging war in Jammu and Kashmir (M)

headline: U.S. Is Studying DNA of Dead Combatants
abstract: Forensic experts begin testing DNA of human tissue found in battlefield around Shah-i-Kot Valley in Afghanistan to determine whether any senior leaders of Al Qaeda or Taliban were killed in 13 days of fighting there; Maj Gen Franklin L Hagenbeck says he does not believe Osama bin Laden was in valley, but that interrogations of captured fighters suggest 'second- and third-tier' Al Qaeda and Taliban leaders were among those killed; photo; map (M)

headline: 12 Iranians Turned Over to Americans
abstract: Twelve Iranians apparently seeking to secure allegiance of commanders in western Afghanistan are seized by Afghans and handed over to American military officials in Kandahar; Iranian government makes no public statement about matter; officials with Red Cross, which monitors status of detainees, have not been notified of Iranians' presence at base, which suggests they are not being treated as official detainees or prisoners of war; Iranians' capture complicates life for interim government and its leader Hamid Karzai, who for weeks have played down accusations of Iraniann influence-buying (M)

headline: Walker to Be Moved From Ship to Airport Camp
abstract: Pentagon says it will soon move John Walker, American captured with Taliban soldiers in Afghanistan, from Navy ship to detention camp in Kandahar and on to United States to face criminal charges (M)

headline: Russia Steps Toward Banking Overhaul
abstract: Analysts and investors say when Russian Parliament votes this week to confirm Sergei Ignatyev to run central bank, it will also be voting to begin long-delayed transformation of Russia's financial system into one that can serve modern economy; Pres Vladimir V Putin's choice of Ignatyev won widespread approval when it was announced late last week; Ignatyev will succeed Viktor Geraschenko; Ignatyev is expected to bring spirit of coopertion with government in modernizing Russian banking and finance (M)

headline: Sharon Tells Bush He Expects Creation of Palestinian State
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon of Israel tells Pres Bush that 'Israel is committed to peace' and that he expects to see Palestinian state at end of Middle East peace process; two hold 45-minute meeting at White House, at which Bush says United States will keep up pressure on Yasir Arafat to crack down on violence; American and Israeli officials say Sharon's words about Palestinian state, made with American president at his side, are sign of his willingness to move toward negotiations with Palestinians, and reflects slight warming in his hard-line appraoch (M)

headline: 'This Chip Will Explode in 5 Seconds': Imagining the Uses
abstract: Lab accident at University of California at San Diego has alerted researchers to potential power source or tool for chemical analysis; silicon chip being scribed with diamond cutter exploded, leading chemists to conclude that exploding chips could be used to develop new types of portable chemical analyzers for biowarfare or allow computers containing highly sensitive commercial government data to self-destruct if they fall into wrong hands; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Aircraft Order
abstract: The easyJet Airline Company, one of Europe's leading budget airlines, said it was talking with Boeing and Airbus about buying as many as 75 planes, an order that would more than double its fleet. Passenger traffic at easyJet and other no-frills European airlines has increased after national flag carriers cut back flights and routes after the Sept. 11 terror attacks. EasyJet now owns 27 aircraft, all Boeings, and will add 23 Boeing planes by May 2004; the new order, for either Boeing 737-700's or Airbus A319's, would be for delivery through 2007, easyJet said.   Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

headline: WHAT THEY'RE READING
abstract: Advent Soft8

headline: Hollywood Watches Ovitz Star In Tale of Thwarted Ambition
abstract: Michael S Ovitz's Artists Management Group is in financial turmoil with withdrawal of Vivendi Universal, major investor in film unit, from their joint venture; Vivendi's internal audit of unit has cast shadow; company faces threat of suit by at least six dismissed workers seeking back pay; Ovitz, once Hollywood's top talent agent, has had trouble with bid to become entertainment mogul; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Second Runway For Narita Airport
abstract: Japan's Transport Ministry approves use of second runway at Tokyo International Airport at Narita, ending three-decade fight to expand facility (S)

headline: COCA-COLA BOTTLER REPORTS LOSS FOR QUARTER
abstract: Coca-Cola Enterprises reports loss of $36 million in fourth quarter compared with net income of $16 million year earlier; sales rose 11 percent, to $3.97 billion (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Environment Officials Approve Kyoto Pact
abstract: European Union's 15 environment ministers agree that their countries will be bound by Kyoto Protocol on global warming (S)

headline: Moscow Journal; Putting Sholom Aleichem on a Belated Pedestal
abstract: Moscow Journal on Moscow's belated unveiling of statue to Sholom Aleichem, chronicler of 19th-century Jewish life in Pale and long something of nonperson in his native land; photos (M)

headline: Rebels or Drug Rings Suspected in Colombian Prelate's Killing
abstract: Assassination of Archbishop Isaias Duarte Cancino of Cali, Colombia, after officiating over group wedding in poor neighborhood, stuns country already deep in conflict; Colombian law enforcement officials hint rebels are most likely responsible, while church officials say narcotics traffickers may have killed him; his excommunication of rebels for kidnapping civilians and his castigation of drug-tainted candidates in recent congressional elections noted; his involvement in country's civil war and his help in arranging secret meetings between government officials and outlawed rightist paramilitary group responsible for thousands of killings discussed; government offers $483,000 reward for information leading to arrest of killers; thousands show up at Cali's cathedral to pay respects; he is mourned by Pope John Paul II, who issues statement lauding him as generous and valiant pastor; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sales Of Chip Gear Off 41% In 2001
abstract: Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International says worldwide sales of semiconductor equipment tumbled 41 percent last year, to $28 billion from nearly $48 billion in 2000; graph (S)

headline: DEFIANT, MILOSEVIC BEGINS HIS DEFENSE BY ASSAILING NATO
abstract: Defiant Slobodan Milosevic blames everyone but himself for decade of carnage in Balkans, telling war crimes tribunal that charges against him are 'all lies'; photos; ousted Serb leader, in dramatic and tense four-hour statement, seems to seize new political mission of defending himself and fellow Serbs by attacking NATO and casting himself as antiglobalist hero who fought 'terrorists'; Milosevic denies his troops killed thousands of civilians in Kosovo in 1999, blaming ethnic Albanian rebels or NATO bombs and presenting ghastly photos and videos of mangled bodies; he expresses contempt for indictments accusing him of genocide against Bosnian Muslims and other crimes in Croatia and Kosovo; first part of trial relates to Kosovo, giving Milosevic chance to focus his attack on NATO and play to Serb audience by charging tribunal indicts entire nation; he also says he condemned Bosnian Serb shelling of Sarajevo and was lied to about concentration camps there (M)

headline: Britain May 'Own' the Elgin Marbles but Greece Wants a Loan
abstract: British Museum resists bid by Greece to borrow relics British know as Elgin Marbles and Greeks call Parthenon Marbles for display in Athens during 2004 Olympic Games; over 90 British lawmakers and actors have opened drive to have marbles, removed from Athens's Acropolis almost 200 years ago, returned to Greece; other European museums have agreed to loan antiquities to Greece for Games (M)

headline: A Cup of Memories, With Matching Saucer
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on dish-replacement services online that will sell subsitutes to match broken china and also act as sleuth to help hunt down most obscure patterns imaginable; drawing (M)

headline: Nonstate TV In Russia Wins License To Broadcast
abstract: Team of Russian journalists win right to continue broadcasting on national television after being shut off airwaves in January in bankruptcy proceedings they say were rigged; government commission votes unanimously to award five-year broadcasting license to Media-Sotsium, nonprofit group that includes former Russian Prime Min Yevgeny M Primakov, business magnate Arkady Volsky and some of country's most critical journalists; supporters are doubtful about how much control journalists wil have over how station will be run (M)

headline: AD MARKETER SAYS PROFIT WILL MEET REDUCED FORECAST
abstract: The R. H. Donnelley Corporation, an advertising marketer, plans to cut 100 jobs and says 2001 profit was at the lower end of its reduced forecast. Profit for the year was $2.35 to $2.37 a share, excluding $30 million in pretax fourth-quarter costs, partly related to eliminating the 100 jobs, at its Raleigh, N.C., publishing plant, Donnelley said. In October, the company lowered its forecast for the year to $2.35 to $2.40 a share from  $2.40. The company said it would report final results in mid-February. Donnelley's advertising sales have been hurt as companies have curtailed spending in a slowing economy. The company, based in Purchase, N.Y., named David Swanson its chief executive on Monday, He will start in May, succeeding Frank Noonan.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; What's Good For the Country Is Good for G.M.
abstract: General Motors Corp, citing stronger-than-expected outlook for domestic auto sales, raises its estimate for first-quarter earnings, increases production and sets aggressive profit goal for middle of decade; chief financial officer John Devine comments; company also releases details of its off-the-balance-sheet activities in effort to be more transparent and head off financial concerns that other companies have faced since Enron bankruptcy; one additional hurdle for GM is possibility of more stringent fuel-economy standards, being debated in Senate; GM, along with United Automobile Workers, organizes rallies of its worker at several plants against tougher fuel standards being considered; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Five public relations executives are opening the Vistance Group, which will specialize in corporate communications, in New York. The executives, all principals at Vistance, are Jack Gutt, Joshua Hochberg, Derwin Johnson, Adam Segall and Ed Trissel. They held posts at the New York offices of Fleishman-Hillard, owned by the Omnicom Group, and Hill & Knowlton, owned by the WPP Group.  * EUniverse, Los Angeles, an online entertainment company, agreed to acquire L90, Marina del Rey, Calif., an online advertising and direct marketing company, for about $55 million. L90 is to operate as a separate brand under the aegis of eUniverse.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Yen rises against dollar after Japanese economic minister says yen is near levels justified by economy; table; graph (S)

headline: 2 Clothing Retailers Post Gains
abstract: Limited Inc and its majority-owned Intimate Brands Inc say profits rose in fiscal fourth-quarter ended Feb 2; profit gain of 35 percent at Intimate Brands bolstered Limited's net income by 37 percent, to $326.5 million; Limited's sales fell 11 percent, to $31.4 billion (M)

headline: A Shuffle at the Top For Homestore.com
abstract: The Homestore.com company announced today that its chairman and chief executive, Stuart Wolff, had resigned less than a week after the company  said it had overstated revenue in the first nine months of 2001 by as much as $95 million.    Shares of the company, based in Westlake Village, fell $1.19, to $2.46, in afternoon trading after an eight-day halt.

headline: Bank Inquiry Not Expected To Pinpoint Trader's Help
abstract: Allied Irish Banks' internal investigation of Baltimore currency trader John Rusnak, who lost $691 million, is not expected to provide definitive answers about whether Rusnak had help inside or outside bank in hiding losses; because bank allowed just one month for investigation, inquiry concentrated on transactions made by Rusnak, how he hid losses and why they were not detected earlier by Allfirst Financial, Rusnak's bank in Baltimore; investigation report will say Allied Irish's chief executive Michael Buckley did hear unspecified report of big currency trades at Allfirst last May and called executive at bank about them; Rusnak's name was not mentioned and Buckley was apparently satisified with explanation from Allfirst executive (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Bond Default
abstract: Fujian International Trust and Investment Corp, which was closed by China's central bank in December, says it will default on 14 billion yen ($104 million) of bonds (S)

headline: 'You'll PurÃ©e Because I Said So'
abstract: Voice control is being incorporated into more and more mundane household devices and appliances, including clock radios, MP3 players, television remotes, telephones, coffee makers and light switches; teaching device how to respond to commands typically involves saying keyword three or four times until device is satisfied that it can pick it out in noisy room; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Rebel Tactics Intimidate Colombia Candidates
