abstract: Political candidates in Colombia are abandoning or sharply curtailing their campaigns, concerned that they could be kidnapped or killed either by leftist rebels or right-wing paramilitary groups; five members of Congress have been kidnapped by rebels, and at least three candidates have been killed by paramilitaries; elections are scheduled to take place Mar 10; government has been unable to do much to contain threats and violence against candidates; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Equality For Women
abstract: Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil signs new civil code making women equal to men in eyes of law (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online On the Rails
abstract: Amtrak, with help from Yahoo and Compaq Computer, begin offering free wireless Internet service on some of its trains (S)

headline: Kidnapped Brazilian Ad Executive Is Freed in a Police Raid
abstract: Police squad in Sao Paulo, Brazil, raids deserted home in capital and rescues kidnapped advertising executive Washington Olivetto, bringing end to highest-profile case in recent wave of abductions; arrests six suspects, who may be linked to guerrilla organizations in neighboring countries; rescue ends nearly two months of captivity for Olivetto, one of Latin America's leading advertising executives (M)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: MONDAYNone.

headline: Merrill Lynch Posts $1.3 Billion Loss
abstract: Merrill Lynch reports record $1.3 billion loss in fourth quarter. compared with profit of $422 million year earlier; net revenue declined 24 percent, to $4.8 billion (S)

headline: Euro Is a Hit in Montenegro (Yes, Montenegro)
abstract: Euro, Europe's new currency, is official money of only 12 European Union countries, but it has quickly become de facto currency in Montenegro and in other parts of former Yugoslavia; photo; map (M)

headline: Airlines Shy Away From Loan Guarantees by U.S.
abstract: Nation's airlines, which pleaded for federal bailout package to help them survive impact of Sept 11 terrorist attacks, are shying away for now from applying for government loan guarantees after seeing stringent requirements placed on first recipient, America West Airlines; Northwest Airlines says it will not submit application soon to federal Air Transportation Stabilization Board, which gave tentative approval to America West's application after exacting option to buy up to one-third of carrier's equity; US Airways says it has no plans to file application for loan guarantees (M)

headline: As Trials Lag, Death May Save Khmer Rouge From Justice
abstract: Cambodians are slowly realizing that no one may be brought to justice for deaths of more than million people under Khmer Rouge rule from 1975 to 1979, in wake of decision by UN to withdraw from negotiations on structure of international tribunal after five frustrating years of talks with Cambodian government; Sec Gen Kofi Annan says provisions of new Cambodian law to set up tribunal and government's refusal to modify them make it impossible to hold trial that would meet international standards of justice; impasse revives heated debate over whether flawed trial is better than no trial at all, and whether UN should bend to allow one to go forward before aging Khmer Rouge leaders die; photos (M)

headline: Frozen by Violence: An American Mission Waits for Its Opening
abstract: News analysis of outlook for US diplomacy in Middle East as Israeli-Palestinian violence intensifies; unrelenting violence seems all but certain to bolster Bush administration's position that meaningful engagement will have to wait; has left Bush administration stymied and efforts at meaningful diplomacy stalled (M)

headline: A Fog Over Enron, And the Legal Landscape
abstract: Legal scholars say fundamental question about sprawling Enron Corp scandal is whether it is case of strong laws being violated by bad people, or weak laws rendering such violations necessary; Richard C Breeden, former chairman of Securities and Exchange Commission, says if company this size, advised by top-tier accountants and law firms, could conclude that our laws permit some of what happened here, then our laws are inadequate; quandry is particularly acute in case of Enron's partnership called LJM2, because it seemed to thrive on arrangements that were actually intended to protect investors; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LOCKHEED MARTIN CORP.,  Bethesda, Md., the military contractor, said it had signed a $50 million contract with the Egyptian government to build a 13-vessel search-and-rescue system with specialized electronic equipment for the Gulf of Suez.    SCIENCE APPLICATIONS INTERNATIONAL CORP.,  San Diego, the largest employee-owned research and engineering company, said it had won a $360 million contract to provide BP, London, the oil company, with information technology services at its units in Houston for four years.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DIVINE INC., Chicago, an Internet software maker and consultant, said it had acquired closely held Northern Light Technology, Cambridge, Mass., an Internet search engine, in an all-stock transaction.    PUBLIC STORAGE INC., Glendale, Calif., the largest owner of self-storage properties, said it would pay $155.4 million for the 70 percent of a development joint venture that it did not already own. The venture owns 47 properties in 18 states.

headline: Briefly Noted; TERROR LINK
abstract: Prosecutor at Phoenix trial says Faisal Michael al Salmi, charged with lying to FBI about contacts with Sept 11 hijacker, repeatedly changed story about Hani Hanjour during ten hours of questioning (S)

headline: First 'Unlawful Combatants' Seized in Afghanistan Arrive at U.S. Base in Cuba
abstract: Twenty prisoners from war in Afghanistan arrive in Cuba, some of them shackled at legs and all of them manacled; some of them resist their American captors and are pushed to their knees on tarmac before rising and being taken to individual wire cages; Gen Richard B Myers, chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff, says this first batch of prisoners is considered most dangerous; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Catholic Bishop Arrested
abstract: Cardinal Kung Foundation says Roman Catholic Bishop Julius Jia Zhiguo, previously jailed for insisting on loyalty to Vatican, has been arrested in central China; dozens of other Catholic leaders are in jail or under virtual house arrest for refusing to accept authority of government-affiliated Catholic church (S)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: For Women, to Soar Is Rare, to Fall Is Human
abstract: Carleton S Fiorina, who has staked her future as Hewlett-Packard's chief executive on winning shareholder approval of merger with Compaq Computer, could provide test for women chief executives if she fails and is forced to leave, but is still viewed as chief executive material and can go on to top post at another company, just as a man would in her place; sheer scarcity of women as chief executives guarantees them enormous attention when they are hired and even more when they are fired; photos; graphs show that gains by women in such fields as medicine, law and higher education are not matched in business (L)

headline: Mourning the Magic Of Markdowns Past
abstract: Michelle Slatalla column on shopping for post-Christmas bargains online; notes observation by Paco Underhill, consultant and author, that retailers have so overused markdown that they have destroyed its usefulness as marketing tool (M)

headline: AT&T Offers a Flat-Rate U.S. Calling Plan
abstract: AT&T Corp will allow its residential long-distance customers to place unlimited domestic calls to one another at flat rate of $19.95 per month; chief executive Betsy J Bernard comments (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint Offers Bullish Forecast
abstract: Sprint Corp says it will meet its 2002 profit forecast and that its Sprint PCS Group wireless unit will add as many as 750,000 customers this quarter (S)

headline: Hyundai Narrows List of Sites for U.S. Plant
abstract: Hyundai Motor Co narrows list of sites for its first American plant to Montgomery, Ala, and Glendale, Ky, eliminating Ohio and Mississippi from consideration; also says that plant might have decent shot at being first US auto assembly plant solely owned by foreign manufacturer to be organized by union (M)

headline: Screen Actors Guild Agrees to New Rules for Talent Agencies
abstract: Screen Actors Guild and associations representing talent agents reach tentative agreement on pact that allows talent agencies to be owned in part by other companies and permits them to become more economically involved in production companies; agreement will allow talent agency to invest up to 20 percent--increase of 10 percentage points--in independent production company and allows advertisers or independent production companies to buy as much as 20 percent of agency over two years; movie studios and television networks--as well as their parent companies like Viacom Inc, AOL Time Warner and Walt Disney Co--remain barred by industry agreement from such investments (M)

headline: Fox News Hires Van Susteren From CNN, Filling the Zahn Slot
abstract: Fox News Channcel strikes back at CNN, hiring away one of CNN's longtime anchors and correspondents, Greta Van Susteren, and handing her same 10 pm Fox talk show, The Point, that Paula Zahn had until she was hired by CNN in September; photo (M)

headline: KIMBALL SAYS IT LAID OFF 300 ADDITIONAL WORKERS
abstract: Kimball International laid off 300 workers in its fiscal second quarter ended Dec 31, bringing job cuts last year to 2,300 as customers reduced purchases of desks, chairs and office cubicles; net income in quarter dropped to $6.5 million from $12.4 million year earlier; sales fell 11 percent, to $296.6 million from $332.8 million (S)

headline: Thomas Losee Jr., 62, Executive At Several Magazine Publishers
abstract: Thomas P Losee Jr, longtime exec for several large national magazine companies in New York, dies at 62 (S)

headline: North Koreans Who Sought Refuge in China Head for Seoul
abstract: 25 North Koreans who ran into Spanish Embassy in Beijing to demand asylum leave China for Manila, taking indirect route to South Korea to avoid offending North Korea; photo; Premier Zhu Rongji announces resolution of standoff; photo(S)

headline: EMI to Revamp and Cut Its Work Force 20%
abstract: EMI Group announces sweeping restructuring of its operations that will eliminate 20 percent of its work force; measures are second in series of steps that new chief executive Alain Levy is taking to create slimmer, more efficient recorded music division; EMI will take $343 million one-charge to cover cost of jobs cuts--which Levy says will total 1,800 by time he is finished--and streamlining of major music labels, Capitol and Virgin; Levy comments (M)

headline: Excerpts From House Subcommittee Hearings on the Enron Collapse
abstract: Excerpts from House Energy and Commerce subcommittee hearing on Enron Corp collapse; witnesses--Jordan Mintz, Jeffrey McMahon, Robert K Jaedicke, Herbert S Winokur Jr and Jeffrey K Skilling--are questioned by Reps Bart Stupak, James C Greenwood, Cliff Stearns, Diana DeGette, Richard M Burr, Chris John and Billy Tauzin; photos

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: White House Is Ordered To Keep Records of Enron  The Justice Department ordered the White House to preserve records of contacts between government officials and Enron executives over the last three years, a sign that federal prosecutors have broadened their criminal inquiry to the company's ties in Washington.    The request, made in a letter to the White House counsel, prompted the administration to order all agencies not to destroy any records related to Enron. [Page A1.]

headline: Market Place; It's Now Time For Rolling Up Disney's Sleeves
abstract: The new year got off to a rough start for Robert A. Iger, president of the Walt Disney Company.    First, Mr. Iger was summoned home from a sailing trip last Monday to try resolving a very public spat with the satellite television company EchoStar Communications, which is threatening to drop Disney's ABC Family channel.

headline: Enron Shows a Need For Strong Oversight
abstract: Claude M Gruener letter says Enron collapse proves need for strong government oversight

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Haider Apologizes To Jewish Leader
abstract: Jorg Haider, far-right Austrian politician, issues written apologies to Ariel Muzicant, leader of country's largest assn of Jews, and withdraws derogatory remarks about him; photo (S)

headline: Peso Down Steeply, Argentines Strengthen Currency Curbs
abstract: Argentine government imposes strict new controls on foreign exchange market; it is unable to halt panicky flight to dollar by savers and investors; measures come in response to heavy trading on March 22, when peso fell nearly 18 percent against dollar; peso settles in New York late March 25 at 3.30 to dollar, or 30.3 cents; under new regulations, individuals can purchase no more than $1,000 in American money each day; registered companies are limited to $10,000; currency exchanges may operate for only three and half hours per day instead of seven; government also puts new limits on amounts of dollars that banks and businesses can hold, and restricts ability of investors and brokerage houses to shift money abroad through stock purchases in US; photo (M)

headline: Afghan Refugees Are Likely to Reject Australian Resettlement Plan
abstract: Immigrants and their advocates say Australian government's plan to offer Afghan immigrants money to return to their homeland would not be accepted by many of eligible asylum seekers and could be premature; within Australia opposition is building to government's policy of mandatory detention for all unauthorized immigrants (M)

headline: Final Item On Agenda: Slow Down
abstract: Jim Dwyer's Diary column describes seminar held for participants in World Economic Forum in Manhattan on how to repair frayed lifestyles (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Aluminum Unit For Sale
abstract: Corus Group will sell profitable aluminum business worth estimated $1.3 billion to reduce its $2.2 billion debt; French group Pechiney says it is interested in buying company; will cut 4,000 of its 52,000 jobs (S)

headline: G.E. Faulted For Strategy On Growth
abstract: William Gross, manager of Pimco Total Return mutual fund, sharply criticizes General Electric, saying that GE is using acquisitions to drive its growth rate and is relying too much on short-term financing; says GE's strategy reminds him of that used by failed conglomerates in 1960's, like LTV; says Pacific Investment Management Co, his fund group, will no longer buy short-term GE debt; faults GE for making acquisitions with commercial paper, inexpensive form of short-term financing used by big companies; adds because GE's cost of capital is so low, company can easily add to its profits by making acquisitions whose earnings outstrip its interest costs; says though strategy appears promising in short run, it increases risks for GE investors in long run; says if interest rates rise or GE loses access to commercial paper market, company could wind up paying much more in interest, sharply cutting its profits; GE's chief financial officer Keith S Sherin says company is moving to rely less on commercial paper (M)

headline: 2 Companies Form Database To Pinpoint Human Genes
abstract: Oxford GlycoSciences and Marconi prepare to unveil Protein Atlas of Human Genome, which they say will definitively pinpoint human genes and help clear up mystery of how many genes there are; database starts with human proteins, then works backward to determine genes that encoded them; Confirmant Ltd, joint venture created to develop and market database, expects to have 10,000 genes in its database by time it begins selling subscriptions in June and to complete database by middle of 2003 (M)

headline: Private Sector; Led by Horses to the Bulls and Bears
abstract: Stagecoach will carry Wells Fargo chief executive Richard M Kovacevich and New York Stock Exchange chairman Richard A Grasso to exchange for Kovacevich to ring closing bell; stunt will mark bank's 150th anniversary; photo (M)

headline: Relic in a Cave: But What War?
abstract: Pentagon says global positioning device found in Afghanistan cave had been lost by pilot who served there; device's markings has prompted some speculation that it had belonged to one of 18 American soldiers killed in Mogadishu, Somalia, in 1993; American officials have long sought to determine whether soldiers in Mogadishu were killed by militiamen with links to Al Qaeda (S)

headline: He Said. She Said. It Just Gets Uglier.
abstract: Proxy contest at Hewlett-Packard over its proposed acquisiton of Compaq Computer has escalated into bitter battle between chief executive Carleton S Fiorina and shareholder Walter B Hewlett, who opposes deal; contest is marked by its level of acrimony and high $100 million-plus cost; drawings; photo (M)

headline: Qaeda Suspect's Bosnian Wife Says He's No Terrorist
abstract: Bosnian Muslims are angered over arrest and deportation of six Algerians, alleged operatives of Al Qaeda in Europe who were turned over to American authorities and flown to prison at US naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba; question why US acted so quickly against accused but lag in cases against Radovan Karadzic, Bosnia's wartime leader, and Ratko Mladic, top Bosnian Serb general who remain at large though they were indicted in 1995 for war crimes against Bosnian Muslims; Anela Belkacem, wife of Bansayah Belkacem, who is among those accused, denies husband is terrorist; photo (M)

headline: Solo Journal; A Rebel's Opera: Muslims Meet Cowboy George
abstract: Interview with Sardono Kusumo, choreographer in Solo, Indonesia, who is testing new artistic freedoms by staging avant-garde production of 'Opera Diponegoro'--opera based on 19th-century warrior Prince Diponegoro; map; photo (M)

headline: Stocks Gain on Signs Of Quicker Recovery
abstract: Stocks rallied powerfully amid signs that the economy is recovering more quickly and strongly than investors had expected.    Economic growth appears to be accelerating, and investors are snapping up stocks in the belief that corporate profits will soon follow. At least for the moment, the economy's recovery has overwhelmed concerns about corporate accounting as well as worries that stocks remain expensive by many historical benchmarks.

headline: FORD PLANS TO CUT 35,000 EMPLOYEES AND SHUT 5 PLANTS
abstract: Ford Motor Co announces most sweeping cutbacks in two decades, terminating 35,000 workers, closing five plants and dropping four models, including Lincoln Continental and Ford Escort; cuts North American capacity by nearly million cars and trucks a year; William Clay Ford Jr, who took over as chief executive 10 weeks ago, says company underestimated its competitors and effects of recession, and reached too far beyond business of making cars and trucks; analysts are divided over whether cutbacks would be enough to restore Ford's competitiveness; note that cuts in North America, of 21,500 workers, are smaller than reduction of 26,000 workers announced by Chrysler last year, and smaller than huge cutbacks by General Motors in early 1990's; other Ford cars to be retired are Mercury Cougar and Mercury Villager; plants to be closed are in Edison, NJ, Brook Park, Ohio, Oakville, Ontario, Hazelwood, Mo, and Dearborn, Mich; photo; graph; chart detailing cutbacks (L)

headline: Prediction of Failure For Airline Contract
abstract: International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers president Thomas Buffenbarger says mechanics with United Airlines will probably reject contract recommended by presidential board that fails to guarantee pay and benefits; rejection of contract would give airline and machinists week to reach another agreement before workers would become free to strike on Feb 20, assuming no further government intervention (S)

headline: Sydney De Haan, 83, Creator Of the Budget Package Tour
abstract: sydney de haan, 83, creator o

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: Whalers Allowed A Bigger Catch
abstract: Officials in Norway increase quota of minke whales for 2002 hunt by 23 percent, to 674; Norway resumed whaling in 1993, defying ban by International Whaling Commisssion (S)

headline: For America's Captives, Home Is a Camp in Cuba, With Goggles and a Koran
abstract: Washington ponders fate of prisoners being held at Guantanamo Bay Naval Station, and their legal limbo lengthens; they are not being interrogated and have not had access to lawyers; nor have they been charged with crime; in last week 110 men have been flown in from Afghanistan, and room is being made for 1,900 more; they live in 8-by-8-foot chain-link cages with roofs made of wood rafters and corrugated metal tops; their treatment is drawing increased scrutiny from human rights groups and allied governments; conditions at camp described; photo; map (M)

headline: Bush Policy on Releasing Records Differs in Case of Clinton Ones
abstract: Rep Henry A Waxman, ranking Democrat on Government Reform Committee, says Bush administration policy on confidentiality of executive branch records is inconsistent; Pres Bush and Vice Pres Dick Cheney have refused to give Congress information about administration's contacts with energy industry executives based on executive branch's fundamental right to receive 'unvarnished' advice from people outside of government; but two months ago, Bush administration authorized release to Congress of thousands of e-mail communications by senior White House officials in Clinton administration, including messages sent by outside advisers and senior aides to Vice Pres Al Gore; on five other occasions, National Archives and Records Administration released records of contacts with outside parties seeking to influence Clinton's last-minute pardon decisions, including transcript of conversation between Clinton and Israel's Prime Min Ehud Barak relating to pardon application of billionaire fugitive Marc Rich; Bush administration raised no objection; White House spokeswoman Anne Womack says Clinton administration documents were released to Congress because Clinton did not object to their release; says it is unfair to compare release of Clinton administration documents and Bush administration's stance on energy task force records; photo (M)

headline: Chief Is Out As Kmart Tries To Get Footing For Comeback
abstract: Kmart Corp announces chief executive Charles C Conaway's departure after board vote; James B Adamson, board member who took Conaway's spot as company chairman on Jan 18, four days before Kmart filed for bankruptcy, will replace Conaway; Julian C Day is named president and Albert A Koch is appointed chief financial officer; Adamson comments; photo (M)

headline: A Country in Chapter 11? Yes, but . . .
abstract: Argentina's creditors face

headline: Afghans Grapple With Earthquake's Toll, and Face More Misery
abstract: Afghan hamlets lay in ruins following earthquake in Nahrin; estimated 7,000 families are homeless; villagers rifle rubble with their hands, searching for living and dragging out the dead; relief workers pour into area, as aftershocks continue to rock area; photos; map (M)

headline: White House Seeks to Ease Rules Put on I.R.S. Workers
abstract: Bush administration wants to ease some of 10 rules that require dismissal of Internal Revenue Service employees for acts like filing their personal income tax returns late, even if refund is due; rules were enacted in 1998 after Senate hearings on accusations that IRS employees had abused taxpayers; Pres Bush's budget recommends that Cognress revise parts of 10 rules and calls for sweeping reduction in penalties and way most other complaints are handled; Colleen M Kelley, president of National Treasury Employees Union, says she hopes Congress will move quickly to eliminate overly harsh rules (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Extending Law To Chad
abstract: Belgian investigators go to Chad for inquiry into allegations of atrocities against former dictator Hissene Habre; victims are suing under Belgian law that allows crimes against humanity to be prosecuted there, regardless of where they were committed (S)

headline: Arrests Rattle a British City Hailed for Diversity
abstract: Officials in Leicester, England, say Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda terrorist network may have exploited city's reputation for tolerance and diversity to implant secretive network of Algerian militants that blended easily among Muslims of many backgrounds; 17 people have been arrested in recent days and charged with violation of terrorism and immigration laws; with over third of its people drawn from Britain's ethnic minorities, compact city in English Midlands projects itself as model of harmonius diversity; map; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nissan Expects Record Profits
abstract: Nissan Motor Co president Carlos Ghosn says company will post record profits for second straight year; photo (S)

headline: A Surprise From Amazon: Its First Profit
abstract: Amazon.com made its first quarterly profit, $5 million, validating at least in part its strategy to grow rapidly first and worry about profits later.

headline: Ovitz Film Unit Loses Partner, Putting Future In Some Doubt
abstract: Vivendi Univer

headline: A Faster Line Of Computers From Apple
abstract: Apple Computer says for first time it has broken 1 gigahertz mark in single-processor performance in its personal computer product line, introducing new high-end desktop system priced at $2,999; also says it has begun shipping its flat-panel-display iMac G4, and that it has received more than 150,000 orders for new system since it was introduced three weeks ago (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Secret Files On Public Display
abstract: Central archives of former East Germany secret police agency will be opened to public on regular basis; visitors can view shelves of files gathered by agents on six million peope--more than third of population at the time (S)

headline: A Trial by Snowstorm, and It's Not on Court TV
abstract: A Trial by Snowstorm, And It's Not on Court TV Â When the weather is so bad that it nearly shuts down the Weather Channel, that could become cause for alarm. But executives at the channel, based in Atlanta, said they were never in any danger of going off the air from the snowstorm that hit the South last Thursday. Ultimately, they got more for less.

headline: Compressed Data; A Small Fortress for Companies' Web Sites
abstract: Clarence Briggs comments on theft deterrents at his Advanced Internet Technologies Fayetteville, NC, site to prevent competitors from stealing server computers or data from company, host for clients' Web sites; says firm deals with several attempted network hacker attacks a day; says it plans to offer security service for corporations, modeled on its mix of physical and electronic security; photo (M)

headline: Andersen Chief Quits in Effort To Rescue Firm
abstract: Arthur Andersen chief executive Joseph F Berardino resigns in effort to save firm; acts after Paul A Volcker, who heads special Andersen oversight committee, proposed management shake-up; lawyers say it is unlikely that resignation or Volcker's proposal will lead Justice Department to drop criminal case against firm for shredding documents related to Enron audit; Volcker says resignation will not affect his plans for firm, phone interview (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Parolees and Security To the Editor:.

headline: Harry Keefe Jr., 79, Innovator In Investments in Bank Stocks
abstract: Harry V Keefe Jr, founder of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods brokerage firm and later manager of investment fund, dies at age 79; photo (M)

headline: White House Could Be Sued On List Access
abstract: David M Walker, comptroller general of US, says General Accounting Office is prepared to file lawsuit against Bush administration to turn over names of industry executives who advised Vice Pres Dick Cheney on national energy policy during spring of 2001 if administration does not provide information within a week; Cheney met with Kenneth L Lay, former Enron chairman, during that time, and Enron executives met with Cheney's staff four times; some Republicans think Cheney's refusal to divulge names of executives he met with is contributing to public's perception that administration is not telling all it knows about Enron; Cheney photo (M)

headline: Baker Hughes Is Target of U.S. Investigation
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission and Justice Department probe charges in suit by former Baker Hughes employee Alan Ferguson that oilfield services company paid kickbacks to win contract with Royal Dutch/Shell Group unit in Nigeria and fired him for objecting; company says it began own probe and cooperates with investigators (S)

headline: Once Again, Japan's Fix Is Short Term
abstract: It is an old ritual here by now. As the fiscal year nears its close on March 31, fears of a financial meltdown reach fever pitch. Alarmed investors head for the exits, raising even more worries that the nation's banks will collapse after lop

headline: Argentine Default Reopens 'Dirty War' Wounds
abstract: Families of 30,000 Argentines who disappeared during country's 'dirty war' of 1970's are bearing uniquely painful burden as nation suffers through it's worst economic crisis ever; government, after admitting responsibility for deaths and promising to pay sizeable indemnity, has broken its word by freezing bank accounts and suspending payments on its debts; photos (M)

headline: Miramax Films Cuts 75 Jobs After Some Recent Setbacks
abstract: Miramax Films, movie studio run by Harvey Weinstein and owned by Walt Disney Co, notifies 75 employees that they are either being laid off or that their contracts will not be renewed; it is first time in studio's 22-year history that it has laid off so many employees at one time, bulk of whom worked in publicity, production and marketing; majority are based in New York, although several are in Los Angeles and overseas; total comes to about 15 percent of worldwide work force of 500; John Dreyer, spokesman for Disney chairman Michael D Eisner, says Eisner is not involved in decision to trim Miramax's staff; photos (M)

headline: S.E.C. Chief Strikes Back At His Critics
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission chairman, Harvey L Pitt, lashes out at critics who say that agency's response to Enron debacle has been weak and that accounting industry has had greater influence in shaping agency's policies than consumer and investor groups, testimony before Senate Banking Committee; accuses media of 'deliberately mischaracterizing recent meeting he had with top executives from Big Five accounting firms in which he said he had urged them to come up with their own reforms or face tougher rules from regulators, Congress and courts; sys it was 'petulant' for Public Oversight Board, accounting review board run by prominent group of experts, to have resigned in protest after his recent proposal to overhaul organization in way that group said would give accounting industry more control (M)

headline: Working to Unite Stars and Factions at ABC News
abstract: ABC News president, David Westin, is attempting to instill team spirit in his anchors and producers, whom his predecessor, Roone Arledge, encouraged to fight with one another for exclusive news; has told Barbara Walters and Diane Sawyer to stop undermining each other; has teamed, Walters, who represents the more entertainment-minded wing of newsroom, with John Miller, a hard-news investigative correspondent, as co-anchor of 20/20 program; photos (M)

headline: HarperCollins To Junk Copies Of a New Book Cited as Libel
abstract: HarperCollins is taking rare step of destroying its inventory of Nicholas W Maier's book Trading With the Enemy that attacks journalist and former hedge fund manager James J Cramer after threat of libel suit; HarperCollins vice president-general counsel James A Fox concedes in letter to Cramer's lawyer that three pages of book contain false assertions that Cramer traded on insider information about Western Digital Corp; HarperCollins spokeswoman Lisa Herling says company will pulp about 4,000 copies of bok that it has in stock; publisher shipped 10,000 copies beginning in middle of February; will send errata notice to bookstores and reviewers correcting text and will reprint new copies without erroneous pages; Herling says HarperCollins stands by remainder of book and plans to continue promoting it as soon as new copies become available; Maier contender Cramer used his media connections to manipulate stock prices and on other occasions traded on insider information for his own financial advantage; photo (M)

headline: Big Board Is Approached About Amex
abstract: New York Stock Exchange says it has been asked to look at books of American Stock Exchange, whose owner, National Association of Securities Dealers, is looking for buyer; NYSE spokesman Robert Zito says Big Board has not yet seen any books and that no negotiations have been held (S)

headline: Skilling Disputes Testimony on Reasons for Enron's Demise
abstract: Jeffrey Skilling, Enron's former chief executive, and Sherron Watkins, a vice president, offered lawmakers differing views today about the company's collapse.

headline: Business Travel; Despite federal rules, the airlines are still finding ways to speed favored passengers to their flights.
abstract: Airlines are still finding ways to speed favored passengers to their flights despite new federal rules; all of major airlines have notices on their Web sites assuring elite passengers that nothing has changed (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: U.S.-China Tensions Ease Before Bush Trip
abstract: Chinese-American relations remain unusually relaxed on eve of two-day visit to Beijing by Pres Bush; neither side expects big advances nor ugly encounters during visit, despite disagreements on many major issues; some problems ripe for discussion noted (M)

headline: Despite Signs of Recovery, Greenspan Says Economy Remains at Risk
abstract: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the economy is not yet out of danger, injecting a note of caution into a growing consensus the recession almost over.

headline: Getting Himself Out of Hot Water
abstract: Ex-Pres George Bush has upset Marin County, Calif, residents with recent comments describing John Walker Lindh, American accused of fighting with Taliban, as 'misguided Marin County hot-tubber'; County Supervisor Steve Kinsey deplores prejudice against progressive community; Bush apologizes (S)

headline: From Old Files, a New Story Of U.S. Role in Angolan War
abstract: US involvement in Angola from 1970's reviewed (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Napster Testing Pay Service
abstract: Napster, hoping to evolve from record industry nemesis to for-profit music exchange, plans to begin test version of its new subscription service; service will be available to 20,000 Internet users, who will be able to download music from Napster and to exchange music with each other from their home computers; photo (S)

headline: Publishing Executive To Head TV Group
abstract: Peter O Price is expected to be named president of National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences (S)

headline: World Briefing | World: Ban On Young Soldiers
abstract: UN says global ban on child soldiers has gone into effect; treaty bars recruitment of children under 18 by armies and militias, practice that affects estimated 300,000 children (S)

headline: Executive Life; Hard Times Prompt an Entrepreneurial Itch
abstract: Interview with Scott Allison on his recent decision to start his own public relations firm when he saw he might be laid off; about 20 percent of all employees at big public relations firms have reportedly lost their jobs in last six to eight months; photo (M)

headline: Error Possible In Attacks, Rumsfeld Says
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld acknowledges for first time that American troops in Afghanistan might have mistakenly killed or wounded friendly Afghans in raids on two compounds north of Kandahar in January; previously dismissed claims by Afghan villagers that American airstrikes or raids had erred; says US forces may have been fired on first, then returned fire; says incident reflects often confusing situation on ground with uncertain loyalties and imperfect intelligence posing huge challenges for American troops (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Workers Stage Protest
abstract: About 5,000 workers from China's six recently bankrupted state factories demonstrate in Liaoyang, complaining that they were owed year or more's wages and accusing officials of corruption (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Jet Controversy
abstract: French aircraft manufacturer Dassault Aviation and other companies involved in building of Rafale jet fighter respond angrily to indications that Boeing Co will win $4 billion contract to produce 40 fighters for Korean air force (S)

headline: RCN Cut 50 Jobs in 2001
abstract: RCN Corp eliminated 50 jobs last year as it consolidated network operations centers (S)

headline: Official Arrested as Zimbabwe Election Ends
abstract: Police in Harare, Zimbabwe, arrest Welshman Ncube, an opposition leader, and detain four American diplomats observing presidential election, which ended after court denied opposition request to extend vote after third day of sometimes chaotic balloting; developments draw strong protest from US State Department, which calls it 'totally unacceptable;' photo (M)

headline: Last Year Was Slow For Capital Gains
abstract: Mutual funds distribute only $72 billion in taxable capital gains to shareholders in 2001, down from $326 billion in 2000 and lowest level since 1995 (S)

headline: EMMIS COMMUNICATIONS TO SELL 2 DENVER RADIO STATIONS
abstract: Emmis Communications Corp sells Denver FM radio stations KALC and KXPK for $135.5 million; sells KALC to Entercom Communications Corp for $88 million and KXPK to Entravision Communications Corp for $47.5 million (S)

headline: A hydro megaproject / Banking on investors : In its water, Laos sees power to cut poverty
abstract: BAN NONG BOUA, Laosâ€”  As head of this poor village in central Laos, Sombon Sisavang says he dreams of a better future if a group of international investors and the Laotian government go ahead with a plan to build a big hydroelectric power project near where he lives, at an estimated cost of $1.2 billion

headline: Technology Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fashion House For Sale
abstract: Holding di Partecipazioni Industriali is talking with several groups to sell its fashion house, Valentino; unit's chief executive Fabio Giombini says revenue grew about 10 percent last year, but does not say whether concern earned profit; Valentino lost money in 2000 (S)

headline: Thomas F. Leahy, 64, Ex-Leader of CBS TV
abstract: Thomas F Leahy, former president of CBS television network, dies at age 64 (S)

headline: With Talk magazine defunct, its top executive returns for a third stint at CondÃ© Nast.
abstract: Ronald A Galotti returns to Conde Nast Publications as president and publisher of GQ magazine, effective Feb 18, after three and half years at Talk magazine, which folded; photo (M)

headline: Teachers Seeking Better Pay Stage Rare Protest in Tehran
abstract: Thousands of teachers stage protest in Tehran, Iran, for second time in week despite police ban to demand pay raises and better working conditions (S)

headline: Independent Voice Hurt by a Culture of Secrecy
abstract: As Ireland rocketed through the economic and cultural booms of the last decade, few institutions could guide its transformation as The Irish Times did.    With an nonpartisan and unbiased approach, The Times pushed issues to the fore with a progressive, literate, pro-European voice.

headline: Others Endure Complications In Telephone Bankruptcy
abstract: Bankruptcy proceedings of Global Crossing are becoming far more contentious and potentially disruptive for its creditors, customers and business partners than previously expected; complications include competing interests of Global Crossing's bank lenders -- a group of about 20 Wall Street firms led by J P Morgan Chase -- and company's other creditors and fact that most valuable of company's physical assets appears to be network links owned by Asia Global Crossing, in which Global Crossing has controlling stake but is not only big shareholder; complications may make it impossible for company to emerge from bankruptcy as viable company or be acquired, leaving liquidation as only option; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Faults 3 Nations on Anti-Drug Efforts
abstract: Officials say Pres Bush determined that Afghanistan, Haiti and Myanmar 'failed demonstrably' in fight against drugs over last year, but that he decided not to impose penalties on Afghanistan, where 4,000 American troops are stationed, or on Haiti, Western Hemisphere's poorest nation; Mayanmar remains inteligible for most forms of United States aid anyway; findings are first under new procedure that allows administration to deliver annual report card on countries it says are most egregious cases of noncooperation (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: AMERICAS.

headline: France Fines General, 83, for Memoir Justifying Algerian War
abstract: French court convicts Paul Aussaresses, former French general who admitted in memoirs that he tortured and executed dozens of Algerians during France's brutal colonial war, of trying to justify war and fines him $6,500; convicts president and senior editor of his publishing house of same crime and fines them $13,000; all plan appeal; Aussaresses was pursued not for acts themselves, long covered by amnesty, but for telling unapologetic version of events; photo (M)

headline: Ukraine's Leader Struggles to Go Quietly
abstract: Pres Leonid D Kuchma of Ukraine is nearing end of his political career and fighting for safe exit from public life in upcoming parliamentary elections; natiowide balloting will determine whether he can galvanize new majority that would enable him to pick his own successor to run in 2004 presidential elections, when he is barred from seeking another term; his approval ratings have sunk to record lows, with United States distancing itself from him while supporting development of democratic institutions and Western investors shunning Ukraine because of corruption and scandals surrounding Kuchma; American officials are pressing for full investigation into deaths of journalists in Ukraine, and Bush administration, along with NATO is trying to stop flow of weapons from Ukraine to Macedonia, Africa and perhaps Iraq; photos (M)

headline: In Georgian Region, Race To Recover Nuclear Fuel
abstract: International team of experts flies to former Soviet republic of Georgia to try to recover two highly radioactive objects thought to be abandoned Soviet nuclear batteries; they were found near mountainous Abkhazia region controlled by Muslim rebels; three woodsmen who recovered them soon developed radiation burns; one is now fighting for his life; during cold war, American and Soviet military forces used nuclear batteries to power satellites in space and spy devices; recovery team from International Atomic Energy Agency is eager to keep them out of hands of terrorists; photo; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Bank Raises Executive Pay
abstract: World Business Briefing: S

headline: Steel Users Campaigning Against Curbs on Imports
abstract: Coalition of manufacturing companies that rely on steel imports begins lobbying Bush administration and Congress to reject proposed restrictions on foreign-made steel, arguing that protecting ailing steel makers will cost consumers far more than it helps producers; group steps up its campaign ahead of pending administration decision on whether to enact what could be most sweeping controls on steel imports since 1980's; Pres Bush must decide by March 6 whether to impose tariffs and quotas on wide range of steel products; corporate members of Emergency Committee for American Trade, umbrella group that works to dismantle barriers to open trade in steel and other goods, met with administration officials in recent days to fight industry's push for high tariffs; antitariff lobbyists release study by two economists at Institute for International Economics that says highest tariffs and tightest quotas under consideration could cost domestic steel users and foreign steel companies $34 billion over four years (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: Russians Make No Promises To OPEC Officials on Oil Cuts
abstract: Russia makes no promises to OPEC leaders, who travel to Moscow in hopes of persuading country's oil industry to continue to hold back exports of crude; OPEC's secretary general Ali Rodriguez and its president Rilwanu Lukman meet with Prime Min Mikhail M Kasyanov and executives from private Russian companies; officials ask Russia to extend cuts in oil exports through second quarter (M)

headline: Britain Proposes Changes in Asylum Process
abstract: Britain proposes that future immigrants would have to demonstrate language skills and knowledge of British values to obtain citizenship; Home Secretary David Blunkett issues broad program to be submitted to Parliament that seeks to speed up asylum process, deport more rapidly those who do not meet requirements for residence and speed new arrivals' identification with their adopted country; Blunkett argues that credible asylum policy would rob white supremacist groups of issue to exploit (M)

headline: To Shrink the Pay Gap, Turn Up the Volume
abstract: Deborah A Ellis letter comments on Jeffrey Seglin's March 17 column on widening pay gap between men and women who are managers

headline: Times Somber, Ads Follow in Tone and Topic
abstract: Collapse of Enron Corp is hastening seas change in way American business talks to consumers in its advertising; change has been under way as rsult of dot-com bust, terrorist attacks and economic slowdown; all those dislocations have led Madison Avenue ad agencies to discontinue campaigns that celebrated how young business upstarts took risks, broke rules and thought 'outside the box'; successor campaigns are more serious and measured, focusing on topics that had been considered boring, like community, experience and customer service; some specific ad campaigns noted; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Auditors Find Things Are Different in Russia
abstract: Current and former employees of Big Five US accounting firms say auditors, in their competitive rush for foothold in Russia, lent their reputations to practices that in West would be regarded as unethical if not illegal; most attention in Russia has focused on PricewaterhouseCoopers, which has been accused by minority shareholders and regulators of failing to look critically at pattern of Gazprom, giant gas monopoly; in chaotic years of new Russian capitalism, accounting standards in Russia were poorly suited to market economics; they were built around reporting to tax authorities, not gauging company's financial health for investors; oversight was all but nonexistent and legal system was undeveloped, leaving room for manipulation and theft (M)

headline: The Body May Creak, but the Brain Hums Along
abstract: Article profiles four distinguished octogenarians, none of whom appear to have considered retiring: author Saul Bellow, television correspondent Mike Wallace, producer David Brown and chef and cookbook author Julia Child; photos (special section, Retirement) (L)

headline: Neal W. O'Connor, 76, Executive at Ad Agency
abstract: neal w. o'co

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: F.T.C. Cites 'Spam' Scheme
abstract: Federal Trade Commission settles charges against seven people for operating illegal e-mail schemes that promised quick and easy money; defendants sent chain letters with slight variations of same message: $46,000 or more within 90 days; FTC messages, which claimed to be legal, drew in more than 2,000 people from nearly 60 countries; FTC chairman Timothy J Muris comments; photo (S)

headline: Debt Offerings Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills today and a four-week bill tomorrow.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.75 percent; the six-month issue was 1.96 percent; and the four-week bill, 1.72 percent.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Rate Action Unlikely
abstract: Park Seung, set to become Bank of Korea governor, says South Korea's economy shows signs of overheating, but sees no reason for acting against slowly rising prices; is not expected to raise interest rates (S)

headline: Indonesian Troops Kill Leader of a Province's Separatist Group
abstract: Indonesian troops shoot and kill Tengku Abdullah Syafei, commander of separatist Aceh Liberation Movement in raid on his jungle headquarters in Aceh; increasingly violent fighting in province has alienated ordinary Acehnese from Indonesian armed forces (M)

headline: Lorillard Tobacco threatens legal action against a foundation for its tough antismoking campaign.
abstract: Lorillard Tobacco is formally threatening legal action against American Legacy Foundation; Lorillard charges that American Legacy, which was created as part of 1998 settlement between tobacco companies and 46 states to run antismoking ads, has exceeded its mandate under settlement by disparaging tobacco industry (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Andersen Knew in August About Enron Concerns  Arthur Andersen knew in mid-August of a senior Enron employee's concerns about improprieties in the company's accounting practices and sought guidance from the firm's lawyers about how to respond, Congressional investigators studying Enron's collapse said.    The disclosure that the Enron employee called a former colleague at Andersen on Aug. 20 raised fresh questions about Andersen's decision to stand by Enron's financial reports until early November, when the company -- by then under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission -- restated five years of results and erased almost $600 million in reported profits. [Page A1.]    Using 881 subsidiaries in tax-haven countries and other techniques, Enron paid no income taxes in four of the last five years, an analysis of its financial reports shows. [A1.]

headline: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Energy Crisis
abstract: North Korean government says acute power shortage has afected nearly every aspect of economy and everyday life; cites natural disasters; blames United States for delays in construction of two nuclear actors under 1994 accord under which Korea agreed to freeze nuclear arms program (S)g

headline: Russia's Latest Export: Bad Jokes About U.S. Chickens
abstract: Russian Agriculture Min Aleksei V Gordeyev stops issuing permits for imports of American chicken, single most popular item from US; cites American use of hormones, antibiotics and preservatives, but Russian farmers are also battling deluge of cheap American chicken thighs; National Chicken Council explains that Americans prefer white meat, so dark meat is often exported (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Teenager Drew 1,000 Investors And the S.E.C. With His Plan
abstract: The Internet stock bubble may have burst, but the dream of getting rich quick lives on.    How else to explain the success of Cole Bartiromo, a California teenager who raised more than $1 million from investors late last fall by guaranteeing returns of up to 2,500 percent? In less than two months, Mr. Bartiromo, 17, persuaded more than 1,000 people to send him money by promising to make risk-free bets on sporting events, according to a complaint yesterday from the Securities and Exchange Commission. Then he transferred much of the money to an account he held at a casino in  Costa Rica.

headline: World Briefing | World: Unions Hope To Recruit Women
abstract: International Confederation of Free Trade Unions and AFL-CIO announce campaign to double number of women belonging to unions worldwide to 128 million (S)

headline: Pakistan to Cut Islamists' Links To Spy Agency
abstract: Pakistan signals significant change in course, disbanding two major units of its powerful intelligence service that had close links to Islamic militants in Afghanistan and Kashmir; officials describe move as one of most significant shifts emerging from country's decision to align itself with West during crisis in Afghanistan and to reduce ties with Islamic militants there and in Kashmir; say move will result in transfer of perhaps 40 percent of forces assigned to secretive InterServices Intelligence Agency, which draws most of manpower from military; organization is one of country's most powerful forces, and requests by US government and forces within Pakistan for its reform have previously been rebuffed; photos (M)

headline: Waste Management Executives Are Named in S.E.C. Accusation
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission files civil complaint against six former officers of Waste Management Inc, providing new details of accounting fraud behind government's criminal action against Arthur Andersen; complaint portrays multiyear effort to inflate reported profits at Waste Management using accounting tricks that allowed company to hide about $1.7 billion in expenses from 1992 through part of 1997; complaint says Arthur Andersen accountants complained about efforts but still approved company's financial statements when their objections were effectively ignored; Thomas Newkirk, associate director of SEC's enforcement division, says 'complaint is a catalog of ways to cook the books'; Arthur Andersen, which complaint contends played central role in allowing accounting fraud to continue, paid $7 million fine last year and accepted injunction against future misdeeds as part of settlement of its role in Waste Management case; complaint names Waste Management founder-former chairman Dean L Buntrock, Philip B Rooney, who served as president, chief operating officer and later chief executive during part of relevant period, and James E Koenig, former chief financial officer; others named are Thomas C Hau, former chief accounting officer, Herbert A Getz, former general counsel, and Bruce D Tobecksen, former vice president for finance; chart; photo (M)

headline: Conducting Diplomacy With Flair And a Cape
abstract: Hamid Karzai, Afghanistan's interim leader, has been photographed wearing number of richly layered outfits during his visit to United States; Afghan observers say garments he chose are carefully assembled collection of regional political symbols, combined in way that might look swashbuckling to West, but could be read as something else by anyone back home; one Afghani living in US says Karzai's message is that Afghanistan is one nation, and will have solidarity; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Mozambique: Opposition Supporters Sentenced
abstract: Judge in Mozambique sentences 14 supporters of opposition party, Renamo, to prison terms ranging from three months to eight years for their roles in riots that killed at least 41 people in November 2000 (S)

headline: Shares Rally After Optimistic News About the Economy
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average climbs 144.62 points, or 1.5 percent, to 9,762.86; Nasdaq composite index advances 20.45 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,913.44; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 12.93 points, or 1.2 percent, to 1,113.57; graph; chart (M)

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Travel Curb On Bankers
abstract: Judge investigating allegations that Argentine banks illegally exported assets before last month's 50 percent devaluation bars nearly 20 bank executives from leaving country (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil falls on expectations that US inventories will stay abundant; in New York, crude oil for February delivery falls 79 cents, or 4 percent, to $18.89 per barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Scene Shifts in Fight Against British Testing Lab
abstract: Future of Britain's Huntingdon Life Sciences has moved from demonstrations over its treatment of animals in its drug-testing business to financial front; Huntingdon is seeking to move its stock market listing from London to Nasdaq, using quirks of American securities regulations to shield its investors from protesters; Huntingdon on Jan 24 plans to cease trading on London Stock Exchange, where years of protests have hammered its stock price down to equivalent of about 6 American cents per share from $3 or more in early 1993; to evade protesters, company will be take over by Life Sciences Research, shell company set up by Huntingdon and incorporated in Maryland, where investors holding less than 5 percent of company's stock need not disclose their identities; photo (M)

headline: Court Rejects Any Liberty For Milosevic, Citing Threats
abstract: Judges at Slobodan Milosevic's war crimes tribunal turn down his repeated requests to be temporarily released from jail to organize proper defense; say in effect that he cannot be trusted to appear for trial if released; say also that if he were released, he could pose threat to others, including victims or witnesses (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: New doubts over Russia's commitment to OPEC's planned supply cutbacks pushes down price of crude oil; graph; table (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Advertising Hall of Fame, administered by the American Advertising Federation, named four additional members to be honored for lifetime achievement. They are: Katharine Graham, the late former chairwoman and chief executive of the Washington Post Company; Charles D. Peebler Jr., chairman emeritus of True North Communications, which was acquired last year by the Interpublic Group of Companies; Hal Riney, chairman and chief executive at Publicis & Hal Riney, San Francisco, part of the Publicis Groupe; and John Smale, former chairman and chief executive of the Procter & Gamble Company, Cincinnati. They will be inducted at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York on March 19.

headline: Andersen Labors to Recover Enron-Related Documents
abstract: Arthur Andersen & Co court filing says it may be months before it can collect and sort all documents that its employees generated in course of working for Enron Corp; Andersen is storing documents under 24-hour guard in Houston and Chicago (M)

headline: Male Aspiration to the Fore In Lauren's European Debut
abstract: MILAN â€“ After a decade of dressing down, casual Fridays, sloppy sportswear and designer stubble, men's fashion has returned to an old ideal: aspirational attire.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago       Prime rate   4.75   4.75   9.00       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   5.50       Federal funds   1.62   1.68   5.92       3-month T-bills   1.58   1.59   5.08       6-month T-bills   1.65   1.66   4.89       10-yr. T-infl.   3.43   3.43   3.52       10-yr. T-note   4.88   4.93   5.16       30-yr. T-bond   5.36   5.40   5.55       Telephone bd.   7.54   7.60   7.79       Municipal bds.   5.29   5.28   5.23          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Enron Bankers Felt Pushed To Invest in Partnerships  Bankers for Enron told a top executive of the company that they had been led to believe that they could obtain lucrative business from Enron if they agreed to invest money in outside partnerships controlled by Andrew S. Fastow, the chief financial officer, according to records of interviews with the executive.    The statements raise the specter of improper activity in the solicitation of partnership stakes, legal experts said. [Page C10.]

headline: A Reminder: Risks Persist
abstract: Military analysis: major military offensive mounted near Gardez to wipe out last major pocket of Al Qaeda resistance is graphic reminder that war in Afghanistan is hardly over; amid talk of where next stage of Bush administration's campaign against terrorism should be, there is much unfinished business in Afghanistan; Pentagon, in sending in several hundred soldiers, may have learned lesson of what can happen when US relies too heavily on proxy force, as it did in Tora Bora, and may be determined not to repeat that mistake (M)

headline: In London, putting touch of whimsy into jewelry
abstract: LONDONâ€”  I wanted to created something that was pure, yet totally luxurious," says the young British designer Russell Sage of the transparent twists of glass jewelry he created for his recent autumn 2002 London show. Known for using delicate fabrics such as antique French and Gainsborough silks, this season Sage is concerned with the more exclusive aspects of fashion. "Now it's time to concentrate on luxury and quality," he says.

headline: After Filing Taxes, Keep Those Records
abstract: Advice on keeping tax records after filing federal income tax return (S)r

headline: German Immigration Bill Wins Disputed Vote
abstract: Upper house of German Parliament passes immigration law that would open gates to greater number of skilled foreign workers; center-right Christian Democratic Union denounces outcome as unconstitutional and vows to appeal to Germany's high court; even before vote, law had become election-year battle between Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, Social Democrat who supports new law, and his conservative challenger, Bavarian premiere, Edmund Stoiber, who opposes it; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: ASIA

headline: Meet the E-Mail Daemon, Always Eager to Pitch In
abstract: Q. What is a mailer daemon and how did it get that name?    A. Most e-mail users have probably noticed the words ''mailer daemon'' in the header of an automatic reply or a message that bounced back from an intended recipient's mail server because of a misspelled address or technical problem. A daemon (pronounced DEE-muhn or DAY-muhn) is a program or process that runs in the background while a computer performs other duties.

headline: Computer Security Experts Warn of Internet Vulnerability
abstract: Defense Department-backed computer security group CERT Coordination Center, asserting that companies did not heed its warnings, warns of security flaw that would make computers across Internet and within company networks vulnerable to being controlled or shut down by malicious hackers; says it decided to publicize flaw because word of its existence has begun leaking out to potential intruders, who security experts feared might soon exploit it; says among roughly 250 companies with products that are vulnerable are Microsoft Corp, Cisco, 3Com and Hewlett-Packard Co (M)

headline: Bush to Unveil Plan To Protect Investors
abstract: Responding to the Enron debacle, President Bush will unveil proposals today to protect investors better through faster and more complete disclosure of information, improved auditing rules and new requirements for executives, officials said.    Separately, Thomas E. White, a former Enron executive, held options to buy 665,000 shares until early this year despite promises to give up any financial interest in Enron when he became secretary of the Army.    Business Day, Page C1.

headline: SMARTFORCE BUYS CENTRA SOFTWARE FOR $260 MILLION
abstract: SmartForce, educational software maker, acquires Centra Software for $260 million in stock (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Disney To Supply Content
abstract: Walt Disney Co has agreed to provide content from various Disney businesses to BellSouth Corp's Internet service in hopes of making money from subscribers to fast World Wide Web services; BellSouth deal is first agreement Disney has made where it is paid per subscriber (S)

headline: A Dutiful Recruit's Notebook: Lesson by Lesson Toward Jihad
abstract: Article on captured notebook of Al Qaeda recruit in Afghanistan which describes his preparation and schooling in training camps for jihad; photos (M)

headline: Mitsubishi And Hitachi Talk About Chip Merger
abstract: Hitachi Ltd and Mitsubishi Electric Corp are in talks to merger their system chip businesses; Micron Technology announces tentative agreement to take over memory chip making operations of Hynix Semiconductor, vaulting it to first place in field ahead of Samung Electronics (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Internet Magazine Closes
abstract: CMP Media's Internet Week, weekly print magazine that reported on Internet business and strategy, stops publishing; company says layoffs are inevitable but some workers will probably find jobs at company's 30 or so other technology publications (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Premier Sees Taxi Conspiracy
abstract: Thailand Prime Min Thaksin Shinawatra is concerned about organized campaign to spur taxi drivers to discredit him (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Enron Chairman Contacted Top Officials About Collapse  The White House disclosed that Kenneth L. Lay, the chairman of Enron and one of President Bush's biggest political contributors, called two Cabinet officers last fall, and one of them said Mr. Lay had sought government help with its dire financial condition.    Attorney General John Ashcroft recused himself from all matters involving Enron because of campaign contributions he received from it. And later in the day, the entire United States attorney's office in Houston recused itself from the investigation. [Page A1.]

headline: For ImClone Drug Entrepreneur, A Past of Celebrity and Notoriety
abstract: Article on flamboyant life style of Dr Samuel D Waksal, chief executive of ImClone Systems, which is at center of controversy over whether company misled investors about reasons Food and Drug Administration rejected company's application to market new cancer drug Erbitux; says some investors and associates have long been concerned that Waksal is too promotional, that his celebrity chasing and numerous outside business ventures divert his attention from ImClone and that he has used company loans as vehicle to finance his opulent life; House Energy and Commerce Committee will investigate company's conduct, including fact that Waksal and his brother, Dr Harlan W Waksal, company's chief operating officer, sold more than $150 million worth of shares at peak prices in months before drug agency's rejection; photo of Dr Samuel D Waksal with rock star Mick Jagger (M)

headline: Hindu Rioters Kill 60 Muslims in India
abstract: Hindu mobs rampage through Ahmedabad, India, killing more than 60 Muslims in their homes and shops day afer Muslims kill dozens of Hindus by setting fire to train in nearby Godhra; central govenrment sends 1,000 paramilitary troops to Gujarat State in response to most serious religious violence in years; Hindu nationalists call for nationwide strike and curfews are declared in 30 villages, towns and cities; photos; map (M)

headline: Bin Laden's Trail Is Lost, but Officials Suspect He Is Alive
abstract: US officials, month after expressing confidence that they had cornered Osama bin Laden in mountains of Tora Bora, Afghanistan, now acknowledge they have lost track of terrorist leader and are increasingly frustrated over virtual absence of intelligence on whereabouts (M)

headline: Kmart's Credit Rating Cut For Second Time in a Month
abstract: Moody's Investors Service downgrades Kmart's credit rating for second time in less than a month, citing concerns about operating performance of company and uncertainty about success of its business strategy (S)

headline: Secretary Powell to Visit Afghanistan Next Week
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell to visit Kabul, Afghanistan, to meet with country's new interim leaders, review nation's reconstruction needs and pledge American assistance for rebuilding (S)

headline: One China? Perhaps Two? Little Things Mean a Lot
abstract: Chinese leaders seem less agitated about nettlesome issue of Taiwan than thay have been for some time; Prime Min Zhu Rongji, speaking at opening of Parliament, repeats offer to resume negotiations between China and Taiwan; does not raise prospect of using military force against Taiwan, which Beijing regards as rogue province; this is second major address by Chinese official recently that does not contain customary warning; as China appears to be standing down, Taiwan's leaders are stepping up; critics say Pres Chen Shui-bian is edging toward independence, not with single defiant proclamation but in small ways intended to widen gulf between Taiwan's 23 million people and mainland; Chen has pledged not to declare Taiwan a separate state, but he seems to feel obliged to mollify pro-independence factions in his party; photo (M)

headline: Donations Returned
abstract: Enron Corp was prolific contributor to candidates and causes, with almost $6 million given since 1989; increasing number of politicians and political groups say they are returning company's money in wake of inquiry into its collapse; National Republican Congressional Committee is returning $100,000 donated by Enron (S)

headline: Andersen Wins An Early Trial As Date Is Set For May 6
abstract: Federal Judge Melinda Harmon rules that trial will begin May 6 on felony charge that Arthur Andersen & Co obstructed justice in Enron Crop investigation; ruling puts Andersen case on one of fastest tracks ever for white-collar criminal prosecution; Harmon says trial might last long hours on weekdays and continue on Saturdays; scheduling stuns former prosecutors and some legal experts; decision comes hour after Andersen enters plea of not guilty to felony charge; hundreds of Andersen employees show up outside courthouse to cheer on firm's lawyers as they arrive; prosecution is handled by Samuel W Buell, assistant US attorney from Boston who is on task force investigating Enron collapse; defense team is led by Rusty Hardin; photo (M)

headline: When PC Still Means 'Punch Card'
abstract: EVERY day more than 23,000 employees of the Los Angeles County Department of Health Services come to work and punch in -- literally. Their timecards are good old-fashioned punch cards that are collected, sorted and used to generate the biweekly payroll.    The county's timecard system, in place since the 1960's, survives because to upgrade it would require the rewiring of too many hospitals and local clinics for data transmission and would be too costly. And because it still works.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Call For Modernization
abstract: North Korean Prime Min Hong Song Nam calls for economic modernization and joint ventures with other countries; will meet with Indonesian Pres Megawati Sukarnoputri, who will then go to South Korea (S)

headline: India's Leading Hindu Party Suffers Losses in State Elections
abstract: Hindu nationalist party that leads India's governing coalition suffers string of losses in state election results; costliest defeat is in Uttar Pradesh, India's most populous state and powerhouse in country's politics; state's chief minister Rajnath Singh resigns once extent of loss becomes clear; party's leadership of governing coalition is not threatened by election results, but its credibility has been damaged; losses may also embolden party's allies at national level to demand greater share of power and weaken it for national elections in 2004; no changes are expected in government's popular hard-line stance on Kashmir and Pakistan (M)

headline: Agency Differs With U.S. Over P.O.W.'s
abstract: International Committee of Red Cross says it differs with United States on how to decide whether to grant prisoner of war status to captives in Afghanistan; says person captured in international conflict is presumed to be prisoner of war unless competent tribunal decides otherwise (S)

headline: The News Media; Sports Reporting: Rules on Rumors
abstract: News coverage of disputed Olympic pairs skating event has shown great deal of reliance on unnamed sources, speculation and rumors; rigorous attribution rules observed in other fields appear to become relaxed when journalists turn to sports; photo (M)

headline: The Happy Talk Is Still Flowing From Wall Street
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column on Lehman Brothers analyst Holly Becker's buy recommendation for Alloy Inc, which came three weeks after Lehman managed Alloy stock offering; holds Wall Street analysts remain wildly bullish on companies that benefit them and their firms; notes Becker hails Alloy's profitable business model, without mentioning that firm has yet to earn profit; graph (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: ScreamingMedia Names New Chief
abstract: ScreamingMedia names Kirk M Loevner as president and chief executive, succeeding Kevin Clark, who continues as chairman (S)

headline: Vatican Says Jews' Wait for Messiah Is Validated by the Old Testament
abstract: Vatican issues document that explicitly says Jewish wait for Messiah is not in vain; scholarly work, signed by pope's theologian, Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, in effect rejects and apologizes for way some Christians have viewed Old Testament; oddest thing about document from Jewish perspective is that it is so quietly released; Tullia Zevi, longtime Jewish commentator, suggests church is trying to avoid criticsm within its own ranks (M)

headline: Chief Resigns at Analogic After a Year
abstract: The Analogic Corporation, which makes fetal monitors and electronic parts for magnetic resonance imaging systems, said yesterday that the chief executive, Thomas Miller resigned on Friday after a year in the job.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Loan Loss Provisions
abstract: TD Bank Financial Group to increase its estimated loan-loss provisions by 35 percent, to 1.1 billion to 1.2 billion Canadian dollars ($689 million) for fiscal year, which ends Oct 31; bank says it had exposure of $175 million in Argentina (S)

headline: World Briefing Asia: Cambodia: Government Foes Sentenced
abstract: Twenty people, including one Cambodian-American, are sentenced to prison for links with United States-based group that attacked government buildings in Nov 2000 (S)

headline: A Divide-and-Conquer Strategy Comes Back to Haunt
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column on significant and deleterious share inflation at largest corporations that could lead to disappointing per-share earnings growth; notes stock splits were major force behind big increase in share counts; graph of growth in shares outstanding (M)

headline: Text of Morning Session of Hearing on Enron
abstract: The following is the text of the morning session of a hearing of the oversight and investigations subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee on the findings of Enronâ€™s special investigative committee as recorded by the Federal News Service.

headline: QAEDA STILL ABLE TO STRIKE THE U.S., HEAD OF C.I.A. SAYS
abstract: George J Tenet, director of central intelligence, tells Congress that Al Qaeda is trying to reconstitute itself and remains capable of another large-scale attack against United States; says nearly 1,000 Al Qaeda operatives have been arrested or detained since Sept 11 in about 60 countries, but that many leaders are still at large; says number of Al Qaeda plots have been disrupted, but that American intelligence officials know that it has considered attacks against high-profile landmarks, government targets, airports, bridges, harbors and dams; says network has plans to attack American and allied targets in Europe, Middle East, Africa and Southeast Asia; stresses that 'Al Qaeda has not yet been destroyed'; says United States recovered documents in Afghanistan showing that Osama bin Laden was pursuing sophisticated biological weapons research program; says he is uncertain whether bin Laden is still alive, but that CIA thinks Taliban leader Mullah Muhammad Omar is alive; says some Al Qaeda members are seeking refuge in Iran, while others, along with some Arab fighters, continue to threaten Afghanistan's interim government; photo (M)

headline: ALLSTATE SAYS LAWSUIT AND REVAMPING WILL CUT PROFIT
abstract: Allstate Corp says fourth-quarter profit will be cut by $108 million for costs related to overhaul and settlement it had made with plaintiffs in Georgia lawsuit (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Wall Street Role Examined In the Rise and Fall of Enron  The collapse of the Enron Corporation promises to keep investors, lawmakers and corporate executives mesmerized for months to come.    While the spotlight is now trained on the nation's capitol, the story of Enron's rise and almost instantaneous fall inevitably leads back to Wall Street and the obsession with stock market gains that characterized the late 1990's. News Analysis. [Section A.]

headline: Chirac sees hope for Mideast
abstract: PARIS:â€”  President Jacques Chirac, striking a surprisingly pro-American tone before the French presidential election this spring, said he believed that new U.S. and Arab initiatives had created a "rarely seen" opportunity for peace in the Middle East.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank's Outlook Slips
abstract: Germany's biggest bank, Deutsche Bank A.G., said that bad loans would continue to overcast its profit outlook when it publishes its annual report today. The bank released last year's main figures in January, posting a 9 percent decline in p2

headline: Mutual Fund Growth Was Slack Last Year
abstract: Investment Company Institute says investors added $3.04 billion to stock funds in December, pushing total for year to $32.3 billion; in 2000, investors added record $309.4 billion to equity funds; stock funds held $3.41 trillion at end of 2001, 14 times $239.5 billion they held in 1990 (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA.

headline: For Gap Shoppers, A Question of Age
abstract: Jodie Corngold letter on Feb 25 article suggests Gap stores stop playing loud, pounding music to win back over-30 shoppers; photo

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Not Gone, Not Forgotten
abstract: Rule change will allow statue of former Prime Min Margaret Thatcher to take its place in House of Commons at end of 2002; photo (S)

headline: American Mission Takes to the Air, and the Airwaves
abstract: Pentagon is using Commando Solo aircraft to fill airwaves over Afghanistan each day with 5 to ten hours of traditional Afghan music sprinkled with bluntly pro-Western, anti-Taliban and anti-Al Qaeda messages; broadcasts have become part of broader debate over Pentagon's use of information and psychological operations to promote US interests, although team is required to be truthful in broadcasts (M)

headline: Echoes of an Era: Pershing Was Here
