abstract: History hangs heavy over coming use of American military advisers in operations against Abu Sayyaf rebels who are holding American missionary couple and Christian nurse from Philippines hostage in Basilan, island between Zamboanga and Jolo; Jolo was site, in 1913, where United States Gen John J Pershing mounted Philipine-American military expedition against seafaring Muslim rebels who had kidnapped Christians for ransom and refused to disarm; in weeklong siege, 1,000 Muslims, largely women and children, were killed; photos; map (M)

headline: The World According to Enron's Ex-Chief
abstract: Analysis of Enron Corp former chief executive Jeffrey K Skilling's testimony before Senate committee; says Skilling did not offer his opinion as to who perpetrators were and recurring theme in his testimony was that he is not an accountant; holds Skilling has not picked up much in way of humility since Enron Corp, blaming banks for Enron's collapse because they were not willing to keep lending billions; photo of Skilling with Enron president Jeffrey McMahon and Skilling's lawyer Bruce Hiler (M)

headline: Lawyer Known for Class Actions Will Lead the Enron Plaintiffs
abstract: William Lerach is named to lead tangle of securities fraud cases against Arthur Andersen and former executives and directors of Enron Corp; selection practically guarantees his firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, largest share of any legal fees, which could amount to hundreds of millions of dollars; Lerach is flamboyant class-action lawyer well known in world of shareholder litigation; photo (M)

headline: Contracts So Complex They Imperil The System
abstract: Complexity of derivatives and lack of transparency in derivatives market create potential for kind of abuse uncovered at Enron and put financial system at risk; when companies that rack up huge hidden debts and traders that illicitly amass mountains of risk are exposed, banks and other big financial institutions rush to cut their losses and collect on their debts; such rush might result shortage of cash and paralyze financial system; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Air Traffic Recovering
abstract: BAA, which runs Heathrow in London and six other British airports, says decline in airline passengers seems to be slowing, suggesting that travelers are beginning to recoever from impact of Sept 11 terrorist attacks; BAA says eight million passengers used its airports in January, fall of 3.9 percent compared with level year earlier; decline in December was 6.4 percent (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo Starting Fee-Based Search Service
abstract: Yahoo plans to introduce fee-based search service called Premium Document Search that will let users search for articles and other documents from more than 7,100 newspapers, trade journals and other sources (S)

headline: Saudi Idea for Peace Prompts An Outburst from Qaddafi
abstract: Libyan leader Muammar el-Qaddafi seeks to upstage Saudi peace plan for Middle East, first threatening to quit Arab League in protest then consenting dramatically to hold off and attend key summit later in month; Syria registers unease with plan, which offers Israel normal relations with Arab world in exchange for withdrawal from land captured during 1967 war; proposal makes no mention of resettling millions of Palestinian refugees spread across region nor mentions any Israeli return of Golan Heights to Syria--two points that Damascus has always insisted on (M)

headline: In Upheaval Within Bayer, Chief Resigns At Drug Unit
abstract: The head of Bayer's worldwide drug operations resigned today during a strategic upheaval intended to allow the company to reshape itself through joint ventures.    The resignation of Dr. David R. Ebsworth, 48, after slightly more than two years in his current post, surprised analysts, who said he was highly regarded despite a string of high-profile disasters at Bayer's drug unit.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Travelocity Starting Site For Asia
abstract: Internet travel agent Travelocity. com will start site with 17 airlines to sell air travel to and from Japan and other Asian destinations; financial term undisclosed; site will begin operation on March 26 and is joint venture among Travelocity.com, Japan Airlines, All Nippon Airways, Japan Air Systems and 14 other Asian and US carriers (S)

headline: Appointment at Sony
abstract: Sony Corp of America names Robert Wiesenthal to new post of chief financial officer and executive vice president (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Pet Food Deal Cleared
abstract: Mars Inc, maker of Pedigree pet foods, wins European antitrust approval to buy Royal Canin SA of France for $1.3 billion after offering to give up some brands to offset competition concerns (S)

headline: Labor Dept. Reviews Ban On Stock Sale
abstract: Labor Department is reviewing whether Enron Corp acted properly when it told its employees they could not sell Enron shares in their retirement accounts at time when shares' value was evaporating; Ann L Combs, assistant secretary of labor in charge of Pension and Welfare Benefits Administration, says 20,795 Enron employees held $2.1 billion in company's 401(k) plan at end of year 2000, 63 percent of which was in Enron stock (M)

headline: Nortel Says Orders Are Slow and Key Product Is Delayed
abstract: Nortel Networks says demand for its telecommunications equipment has been softer than expected and that delivery of new optical telecommunications switch, known as HDX, is about six months behind schedule; optical equipment market is cornerstone of Nortel's recovery strategy; Terry G Hungle, chief financial officer who resigned after disclosure of suspicious stock trades in his 401(k) retirement account, expresses regret for 'a serious error in judgment'; denies taking advantage of insider information; Nortel posts loss of $1.83 billion for fourth quarter and $27.3 billion for year; fourth-quarter revenue of $3.46 billion was 58 percent below previous year; chief executive Frank A Dunn comments; photo (M)

headline: STORE CHAIN WILL CLOSE THREE OF ITS LAZARUS STORES
abstract: Federated Department Stores will close three Lazarus stores in Indiana and Ohio, affecting 190 jobs (S)

headline: U.S. Eases Some Curbs On Exporting Technology
abstract: Bush administration loosens limits on exporting high-performance computers and microprocessors, saying move is aimed at helping change nation's export controls to focus on 'truly sensitive goods and technologies'; under new guidelines, American companies will be required to notify Commerce Department of proposed exports of computers to certain restricted countries when systems are faster than 100,000 Mtops (S)

headline: U.S. Confident of Suspect's Extradition From Pakistan
abstract: Bush administration is convinced that Ahmed Omar Sheikh, militant accused of killing Daniel Pearl, will eventually be handed over to United States even if Pakistani government follows through with its plan to try him for crime in Pakistan; photo (M)

headline: How Qaeda Linked Up With Malaysian Groups
abstract: Recent investigations suggest that Al Qaeda may have used young Malaysians for broader purposes than stated, support for armed Muslim militants in Indonesia and Philippines; some of men attending meetings, arrested last year and interrogated after botched bank robbery, led to larger network and plot to blow up American and Israeli embassies in Singapore; one of Indonesian clerics who lectured Malaysian youths reportedly called Osama bin Laden his friend (M)

headline: 'Cheese!' To 'Print,' In One Step
abstract: David Pogue column assesses printers that can print images directly from digital camera's memory card, without computer; drawing; photos (M)

headline: Trying Not to Be the Next Enron, Companies Scrutinize Practices
abstract: Enron's colossal collapse prompts growing number of corporations to take hard look at financial and accounting practices and relationships with auditors and others that might create similar problems for them; many are adopting policies against buying consulting services from auditors and looking anew at their own boards; executives and boards are also thinking about risks and how well they know what lurks on and off their balance sheets (M)

headline: Fourth-Quarter Profit Fell 16% at Safeco
abstract: Safeco Corp says net income fell to $8.6 million from $10.2 million year earlier; revenue was little changed at $1.67 billion (S)

headline: New Le Monde for a New France
abstract: Le Monde's editors say they intend to brighten paper's staid look with more photographs; say they will step up their coverage of European institutions, finance and stock market in light of euro replacing franc; says when ad market revives, paper also plans increased coverage of sports and cultural events and new weekend magazine; cost of changes will be $5 million to $7 million (M)

headline: Syria Repackages Its Repression of Muslim Militants as Antiterror Lesson
abstract: Syria is seeking to repackage its experience in eliminating Muslim extremism as textbook anterroprism campaign in aftermath of September 11 terrorist attacks against US; is exuding sense of vindication that brutal suppression of Muslim Brotherhood in city of Hama, once viewed as human rights horror, might help improve long-troubled ties with Washington; massacre of estimated 10,000 Muslims in Hama in February 1982, arrests and disappearance of thousands of others and leveling of entire neighborhoods to quash Islamic insurgency described; country remains on State Department's list of nations that support terrorism and has been mentioned as possible target because of support for groups that Washington labels terrorists; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   8.00       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   4.50       Federal funds   1.69   1.74   4.94       3-month T-bills   1.79   1.82   4.18       6-month T-bills   2.05   2.07   4.15       10-yr. T-infl.   3.38   3.40   3.25       10-yr. T-note   5.39   5.36   4.80       30-yr. T-bond   5.81   5.78   5.31       Telephone bd.   7.99   7.85   7.65       Municipal bds.   5.41   5.40   5.24          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Irishman To Lead Parliament
abstract: Pat Cox of Ireland, Liberal Democrat, is elected president of European Parliament and promises to make body more relevant to alienated voters (S)

headline: Liberty Media Backs Away From Kirch Deal
abstract: Liberty Media, cable television holding company controlled by John C Malone, says it no longer wants to buy stake in Premiere, German digital pay-TV service of Kirch Group (M)

headline: People
abstract: Ronald Rosen is named executive creative director and executive vice president at DCA Advertising, succeeding Steve Penchina, who resigned (S)

headline: In Manila, Trading Words Over Rates
abstract: Clubby Philippine banking industry is pitted against central bank governor Rafael Buenaventura, who has accused some bankers of breaking promise to lower their interest rates in step with cuts in benchmark rate, rate at which central bank lends to them; many banks are still charging loan customers as much as 20 percent while overnight rate is 7.5 percent; while Buenaventura says bankers agreed to keep lending rates no more than five percentage points above yields on government three-month Treasury bills, now about 7 percent, executive director of bankers' association, Leonilo Coronel, remembers it differently, saying 'there is a gentleman's agreement, but it covers prime clients without any weaknesses'; Buenaventura says bankes are being 'intellectually dishonest'; analysts have tended to side with banks, saying banks are in no position to ease credit terms; photo (M)

headline: Airlines and hotel chains are spending plenty to revive travel, especially business travel.
abstract: Airlines, hotel companies and others involved in travel have introduced advertising campaigns in recent weeks to encourage more travel; many new campaigns are directed at business travelers; specific campaigns noted (M)

headline: A Wealth of Information Inside a Magnetic Strip
abstract: Q. What information is on the magnetic strip on the back of credit cards, and what is transmitted back and forth when a card is swiped?    A. The magnetic strip on the back of your A.T.M. or credit card has three tracks for storing data.

headline: Son of the Chairman Prepares for Leadership
abstract: Lachlan Murdoch, 35-year-old son of Rupert Murdoch, is being groomed by his father to take over control of News Corp, but people close to company say that if Rupert Murdoch were to step down suddenly or be incapacitated at any time in next few years, top job would first fall to Peter Chernin, president and chief operating officer, in order to Lachlan Murdoch more time to prepare himself; photo (M)

headline: Optimism Weakens On Accounting Worries
abstract: UBS Paine Webber survey finds investor optimism declined sharply in Feb, largely because of concerns about accounting problems raised by Enron Corp collapse; finds investors now expect average stock market returns of 9.5 percent over 12 months, down from 10.2 percent in Jan (M)

headline: Adviser for Italian Labor Reform Is Killed
abstract: Marco Biagi, economist and top adviser to Italy's labor minister, Roberto Maroni, is shot dead by two gunmen outside his home in Bologna, and police believe killing is political assassination; Biagi has been helping center-right government draft proposed changes to Italy's labor law, changes that would make it easier to fire workers; photos (M)

headline: Pakistani Trying to Redefine the Nation
abstract: Analysis of Pakistani Pres Pervez Musharraf's speech sees him confronting challenges, both foreign and domestic, in ambitious style; cites his effort to redefine Pakistan's sense of itself after two decades of drift into lawlessness and violence; holds he plots daring course, setting forth vision of tolerant and progressive Islamic nation; it is uncertain whether he can overcome threat of violence from militant groups and Islamist sympathies in government and military; he strikes balance, particularly in remarks aimed at India, between conciliation and warnings of Pakistan's readiness to defend self (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Write-Offs At Bank
abstract: Bank of Nova Scotia has taken write-offs totaling 540 million Canadian dollars ($340 million) on its business in Argentina, trimming net income for quarter ended Jan 31 to 52 million Canadian dollars, compared with 510 million Canadian dollars year earlier (S)

headline: Faded Memories Revived With a Scanner's Magic
abstract: Ian Austen reviews four flatbed scanners priced under $150 that can read photographic slides and negatives; they are from Epson, Hewlett-Packard, Acer and Canon; photos (M)

headline: Patents; Recognition for canine breath freshener with a special, head-scratching, ingredient: garlic.
abstract: Joan Lewandowski patents garlic-based product to combat bad breath in dogs; she comments, interview (M)

headline: Conduct of War Is Redefined By Success of Special Forces
abstract: American Special Operations forces in Afghanistan are reshaping warfighting doctrine; many in military have been surprised by how much these forces have accomplished against Taliban and Al Qaeda despite facing many obstacles, including foul weather, strange allies and friendly fire; use of small, highly trained units to accomplish large, strategic missions by exploiting every's weakness has been talked about for years, but tried with mixed success in past; maps illustrate Special Forces combat picture in Afghanistan, week by week; photo (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SERVICEMASTER CO., Downer's Grove, Ill., a commercial landscaping provider, said it would acquire the minority interest in ServiceMaster Home Service Center held by Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers.    TEACHERS INSURANCE & ANNUITY ASSOCIATION-COLLEGE RETIREMENT EQUITIES FUND, New York, acquired a three-building, 547,000-square-foot office complex in Wilton, Conn., for $135.5 million, or about $250 a square foot.

headline: Economic Scene; Investor behavior clouds the wisdom of offering wider choice in 40l(k)'s.
abstract: Hal R Varian's 'Economic Scene' column on whether wider choice in 401(k) retirement plans is beneficial; says behaviorial economists have identified several reasons that more choice can make consumers worse off, reasons that affect everything from marketing strategy to pension policy; research of Sheena S Iyengar and Mark R Lepper and behviorial economists Shlomo Benartzi and Richard Thaler discussed; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Secret Files On Kohl To Stay Secret
abstract: Berlin court rules that files compiled by East German secret police on Helmut Kohl must not be released to journalists and historians; new ruling will be precedent for other cases involving files of public figures; photo (S)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: MONDAYNone.

headline: On Oscar Night, They Can't Lose
abstract: Profile of R S Owens & Co, small, family-owned company in Chicago that makes Oscars and several other prestigious awards; photo (M)

headline: Steelmaking nations warn of retaliation; battle likely at WTO : U.S. tariffs draw fire from Asia to Europe
abstract: SEOUL:â€”  Steel-making countries edged closer to a possible global trade war Wednesday as they announced plans to appeal President George W. Bush's decision to impose tariffs to the World Trade Organization.

headline: Russia Rejects U.S. Plan to Store Warheads
abstract: Russia strongly criticizes Bush administration plans to store rather than destroy decommissioned nuclear warheads; suggests plan would undermine credibility of any new arms control accord aimed at eliminating thousands of nuclear weapons; says reductions of nuclear arsenals must be irreversible; testiness of tone of Russia's statement indicates depth of feeling there that Washington is seeking to orchestrate longterm advantage in nuclear weaponry (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Electricity Contract Awarded
abstract: Singapore's Keppel Corp wins $400 million contract to supply electricity in Northeastern Brazil; unit, Keppel Fels Energy and Infrastructure, will build power plant at Port of Aratu to begin supplying electricity from June until end of 2004 to Comercializadora Brasileira de Energia Emergenical (S)

headline: Arab Leaders Warn Israel Over Arafat
abstract: Arab leaders gathering in Beirut, Lebanon, for Arab League summit warn Israel could miss opportunity to achieve enduring cease-fire if it insists that Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat cannot attend; say Arafat's presence at summit is crucial since it is in Israel's interests that Saudi peace initiative, which commits all Arabs to normal relations with Israel, roll forward in Beirut; photo (M)

headline: Pakistani Aides Voice Confidence U.S. Reporter Is Still Alive
abstract: Pakistan's interior minister said today that he was optimistic that Daniel Pearl, a correspondent for The Wall Street Journal, would be found alive.

headline: Citigroup Raises $4 Billion In Travelers Stock Offering
abstract: Citigroup, taking advantage of likely boom in profits at commercial insurance companies, sells 21 percent of its Travelers Insurance unit in largest initial public offering this year; sale of 210 million shares at $18.50 raises $3.89 billion, making it biggest initial public offering of insurance company; investors react with enthusiasm to opportunity to invest in established company with strong earnings record (M)

headline: Asians take a closer look at Islamic schools
abstract: SINGAPOREâ€”  Without warning, a phalanx of riot police and plainclothes officers descended on a school for about 200 young children in a lush oil palm estate in the southern Malaysian state of Johor, adjacent to Singapore. The raid, on Jan. 3, led to the closure of the Islamic school, or madrasa, which Malaysian authorities say was linked to a group of Muslim extremists.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Construction Merger
abstract: Japan's Mitsui Construction and Sumitomo Construction say they will merge in one to two years in push to cut costs and cope with shrinking demand; company will cut combined 500 jobs, or 9.7 percent of their work forces, before joining operations (S)

headline: Amazon Ships to a Sorting Machine's Beat
abstract: Amazon.com has improved efficiency at its

headline: Impasse Ends Over Top Post At Bookseller
abstract: Barnesandnoble.com names president and chief operating officer Marie J Toulantis to added post of chief executive, effectively succeeding acting chief executive Stephen Riggio; move signals end of two-year stalemate between company's major shareholders, Bertlesmann AG and Barnes & Noble; chairman and founder Leonard Riggio comments; photo (M)

headline: A Crucial Record on Contributions to I.R.A.'s
abstract: Taxpayers who have nondeductible IRA's as well as traditional deductible IRA's need to know how much was contributed to each kind over the years because contributions to nondeductible IRA's are deducted from amount to be taxed (S)

headline: Justice Dept. to Form Task Force To Investigate Collapse of Enron
abstract: Justice Department, widening potential scope of criminal probe, will form special task force of prosecutors from across nation to probe Enron Corp and its eventual collapse; move will reduce burdens going forward on Enron, which has been struggling with demands from multiple civil and criminal probes; Robert S Bennett, Enron's lawyer, lauds decision (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Rebel May Boycott Talks
abstract: Jean-Pierre Bemba, leader of Uganda-backed rebels who control about one-third of Congo, says he will boycott scheduled peace talks in South Africa because of selection of political foes who will take part (S)

headline: After the Attacks, A Lasting Change
abstract: Forty-five percent of executives questioned in recent survey report that there have been changes in ways they do business since Sept 11 terrorist attacks, slight changes for 31 percent of them and large changes for 14 percent (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Credit card companies go to great lengths online to develop products that will corral teenage consumers.
abstract: Credit card companies are struggling to formulate product to spur Internet shopping by teenagers, huge but currently inaccessible market; issuers favor format in which parents or others put cash value into account teenagers can draw on using debit card; remaining issues involve fees and marketing of cards; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: New Package From Linux Distributor
abstract: Red Hat, distributor of Linux operating system, introduces package for computer servers and says that more than 20 software developers have agreed to support it (S)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: Federal Judge Deals Setback To Microsoft In Private Suits
abstract: Judge J Frederick Motz rejects proposed settlement of more than 100 private class-action suits against Microsoft Corp, saying settlement plan appears to be insufficiently financed and could well have anticompetitive effect of unfairly increasing Microsoft's market position in schools, one of Apple Computer's remaining bastions of strength; under proposed settlement, Microsoft agreed to donate $500 million in cash, in addition to computers and software, to thousands of public schools in low-income neighborhoods (M)

headline: Reviving Argentina: The Trouble With Taxes
abstract: Argentina, having stopped payments on its public debt of $132 billion, sits mired in enormous crisis of economic confidence; there is no easy way out in short term; but to help long-term stability, country might start by fixing its tax system; one analyst contends Argentina's failure to balance spending with tax revenue lies at heart of its travails (News Analysis) (M)

headline: Who Brings Home The Most Money?
abstract: Barbie O'Connor letter on Jan 6 article on men whose wives earn more money than they; drawing

headline: Fighting Nazis
abstract: Tim Holt letter on Jan 3 comment on Nazi symbols in video games

headline: Chip Makers In Japan See Only Trouble
abstract: Japan's Toshiba Corp and Fujitsu, leading computer chip makers, are scheduled to announce results for third fiscal quarter ended Dec 31 and both are expected to be downbeat; Toshiba is expected to lower its outlook sharply for coming year; analysts predict downbeat news will set off wave of lowered forecasts from rivals over next few weeks; Japanese manufacturers that once dominated semiconductor industry have lost ground in recent years to more efficient producers in South Korea (M)

headline: Desperation in a Job Hunt
abstract: Thelma Philipson Plesser letter on Feb 10 article holds people who are hiring should be compassionate toward desperate job seekers

headline: ABB Seeks Return of Some Severance Benefits
abstract: ABB, Swiss-Swedish power and technology group plunged into red ink by huge charges for restructuring costs and asbestos liability exposure, wants former chief executives Goran Lindahl and Percy Barnevik to give back some of their combined $138 million in severance and pension benefits; company puts net loss for 2001 at $691 million, its first annual loss ever, and says it will not pay dividend for year (M)

headline: Tanqueray and Stolichnaya start intense efforts to gain in the ''white goods'' liquor market.
abstract: Stolichnaya vodka and Tanqueray gin are emerging with campaigns from new advertising agencies intended to help them keep up in highly competitive 'white goods' category of American liquor market; Tanqueray importer, Schieffelin & Somerset Co, plans to spend about $20 million on humorous campaign that seeks to offer new twist on celebrity endorsement, while Stolichnaya importer, Allied Domercq, plans to spend about $30 million; Stolichnaya campaign was developed by BBDO Worldwide; Tanqueray campaign is by J Walter Thompson; photos (M)

headline: Pakistani Gang Said to Kidnap Children to Be Sold Abroad
abstract: Gang of kidnappers in Pakistan has been buying children from desperately poor parents, and then smuggling them to Malta, where they are resold at substantial profit (S)

headline: OUTLOOK: Round Table; Wall Street's Prescriptions in a Convalescing Economy
abstract: Excerpts of interviews with Abby Joseph Cohen of Goldman, Byron R Wien of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Charles I Clough Jr of Clough Capital Partners on direction of economy and stock markets in 2002; say recovery in profits and stocks is coming, but it will be weak and slow; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Chip-Plant Deal Near
abstract: Hanvit Bank president Lee Duk Hoon says negotiators from Micron Technology are on track in talks with Hynix Semiconductor for Micron to take over all or some of its memory-chip factories; Micron is reported to be willing to pay only $2 billion for seven plants (S)

headline: Even a Watchdog Is Not Always Fully Awake
abstract: California Public Employees' Retirement System, usually formidable advocate for good corporate governance, did not confront Enron's board after it was alerted by advisers in Dec 2000 about serious and potentially embarrassing conflicts inherent in one of web of private partnerships set up by Enron chief financial officer Andrew S Fastow; Calpers, major Enron shareholder, declined to invest in partnership, LJM3, kept silent and continued to reap profits on its other deals with Enron-linked partnerships until early last summer; some institutional investors say Calpers had no responsibility to challenge board or make its concerns public; photo (M)

headline: Investing; Leaving Home, Without Its Umbrella
abstract: Outlook for investing in Travelers Property and Casual

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CUSHMAN & WAKEFIELD INC., New York, the second-largest commercial real estate broker, said it would form alliances with six independent real estate companies in the Southeast U.S. and Southern California to build its business in industrial warehousing and distribution space.

headline: INTIMATE BRANDS TO REVIEW OFFER FROM THE LIMITED
abstract: Intimate Brands Inc says that, pending review, it is unable to decide on unsolicited offer of Limited Inc to buy back 16 percent stake of Intimate brands it does not already own; Intimate Brands says it has formed three-member committee of independent directors to consider $1.49 billion offer, scheduled to expire on March 11 (S)

headline: A Rebound for Hedge Funds
abstract: Net inflows to hedge funds around the world reach record $31 billion in 2001, compared with only $8 billion in 2000 (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Bush Orders Review Of Contracts in Enron Case  The White House ordered federal agencies to consider dropping contracts worth more than $60 million a year with Enron and Arthur Andersen, saying the accusations swirling around the companies raised doubts about whether they should be receiving taxpayer money.    The order continued a pattern by the Bush administration of trying to distance itself from a corporate meltdown whose aftershocks have been felt in both the political and business worlds. [Page A1.]

headline: MARRIOTT POSTS QUARTERLY LOSS AS TRAVEL DECLINES
abstract: Marriott International Inc posts fourth-quarter loss of $116 million compared with net income of $149 million year earlier; revenue fell 10 percent, to $2.87 billion (S)

headline: New Economy; I.B.M. and Steelcase lay out their vision of the office of the future.
abstract: Claudia H Deutsch New Economy column on 'smart-office' designed by IBM and furniture company Steelcase; office represents their joint vision of how technology might solve myriad frustrations of daily work life; embodies their notion that line between inanimate furniture and dynamic devices will soon blur; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Women Protest Election
abstract: Hundreds of women march through Lusaka, Zambia, to protest recent election of Pres Levy Mwanawasa; election was marred by charges of vote rigging; photo (S)

headline: Compressed Data; DVD Copyright Case Grinds Through Courts
abstract: Update on Electronic Frontier Foundation's litigation alleging that 1998 copyright law violates First Amendment; Kathleen Sullivan is handling appeal without fee, because Martin Garbus's firm proved too costly for foundation; Garbus photo (S)

headline: Bush Declares Free Markets Are Essential For Americas
abstract: Pres Bush cautions Argentina against using its economic crisis as excuse to backtrack on free-market reforms or return to era of protectionism; speaks at Washington headquarters of Organization of American States, hoping to send strong message to Pres Eduardo Duhalde, who has said his country's economic crisis is caused in part by American led 'model' of economic development, particularly rapid market openings and deregulation (M)

headline: Career Management Company Fights Complaints
abstract: Hundreds of dissatisfied customers of Bernard Haldane Associates, business that describes itself as nation's oldest and largest career-management company, have filed complaints about company's practices to 11 state attorneys general, including those in California New York and Texas; Kansas is investigating nearly 100 consumer complaints; some customers paid as much as $20,000 in fees; Haldane says some complaints are to be expected given its history of serving more than 600,000 customers over 53 years; Haldane faced similar complaints in 1982 and 1993; Michael Gonzales, aerospace engineer who turned to Haldane for job opportunities, says Haldane provided useless data, much of which could have been obtained on Internet; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Refugee Camp To Stay Open
abstract: French court rejects Eurotunnel plea to close refugee camp near Channel Tunnel that is being used as staging point for illegal immigrants trying to get into Britain(S)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: ASIA JAPAN: MONETARY POLICY UNCHANGED With rates already near zero, the Bank of Japan left monetary policy unchanged at its two-day meeting. The bank said it would keep up to 15 trillion yen ($114 billion) available in the money markets for companies to borrow and promised to add liquidity if there was a

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: MONDAYExisting-Home SalesJan.

headline: Drug Kingpin, Long Sought, Is Captured By Mexicans
abstract: Mexican authorities announce arrest of Benjamin Arellano Felix, chief of nation's most powerful and violent drug gang; Asa Hutchinson, head of United States Drug Enforcement Administration, hails arrest as 'incredible victory'; Mexican authorities say that under interrogation, Arellano Felix confirmed death of his brother Ramon, cartel's notorious enforcer; say death of one brother and capture of another represent one of biggest breakthroughs for law enforcement in Mexico's long history of drug wars (M)

headline: NATO Raid Fails to Catch Former Bosnian Serb Leader
abstract: NATO troops mount their first major operation to arrest Radovan Karadzic, former Bosnian Serb leader indicted for war crimes; they raid remote Bosnian village but fail to find him; Karadzic is accused of committing genocide against Muslims in war in Bosnia; he was first indicted 7 years ago; his freedom as fugitive has long been criticized as failure of resolve on part of Western leaders; also, his freedom, along with that of Bosnian Serb military commander Ratko Mladic is considered obstacle to international efforts at rebuilding Bosnia after four years of ethnic warfare; photo (M)

headline: A European Hand-Held to Teach Americans to Say 'TrÃ¨s Cool'
abstract: Nokia 9290 Communicator, hand-held computer popular in Europe, is expected to be available in America by summer 2002; has full-color screen, standard keyboard and is priced around $800; photo (M)

headline: Mortgage Applications Up
abstract: Mortgage Bankers Association of America's mortgage applications index increased 4.9 percent ended March 22, to reading of 494.8 and first increase in three weeks; refinancing index rose 3.2 percent, to 1,450.6 (S)

headline: JUDGE RULES IN G.M.'S FAVOR IN TRADEMARK DISPUTE
abstract: Federal Judge Robert Miller Jr rules grille of Hummer H2, made by General Motors Corp, does not violate trademark design of DaimlerChrysler's Jeep vehicles; DaimlerChrysler sued GM last year, saying grille was too much like Jeep grille; Hummer H2 is scheduled to go on sale in July (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: More Labor Leaders Detained
abstract: Three leaders of labor protests in Liaoyang (China) are detained as workers continue to demonstrate at city offices, claiming they have not received back pay and pensions or adequate benefits (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: U.S. Decision On Taiwan Condemned
abstract: Chinese government condemns Bush administration's decision to allow Taiwan defense minister to attend conference sponsored by American arms makers (S)

headline: Hans-Georg Gadamer, 102, Who Questioned Fixed Truths
abstract: Hans-Georg Gadamer, leading figure of 20th century philosophy, dies at age 102; photo (M)

headline: House Panel's Investigation Of Global Crossing Is Started
abstract: House Energy and Commerce Committee begins investigation into accounting practices and executives' sales of company stock at Global Crossing; company faces accusations that it used sham transactions to increase revenue and that it misled investors about its financial health (M)

headline: Families Try to Trace Thousands of Missing Taliban, Many Forced to Fight
abstract: Thousands of Afghan Taliban conscripts are still being held in detention in grim, even life-threatening conditions in north, where anti-Taliban feeling runs high among ethnic minorities; in southern Afghanistan, people are too frightened to travel to north to search for relatives, afraid of being accused of being Taliban by authorities now in power there; Red Cross has only just begun registering prisoners and helping families trace them; it estimates that 5,000 prisoners, mostly Afghan Taliban fighters, are still being held around country; photo (M)

headline: Solid Consumer Spending Bolsters Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft Corp reports second-quarter revenue of $7.74 billion, increase of 18 percent from $6.55 billion year ago; operating income was $2.84 billion, up from $2.62 billion year ago (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BANK OF NEW YORK CO., New York, the financial holding company, increased its quarterly dividend to 19 cents from 18 cents, payable on Jan. 31 to holders of record as of Jan. 18.    BEAR STEARNS COS., New York, the securities broker-dealer, said its board had authorized a buyback of up to $1.2 billion of company stock to offset the dilutive effect of the company's stock award plan for employees.

headline: BUSH WELCOMES SAUDI'S PROPOSAL ON MIDEAST PEACE
abstract: Pres Bush, thrusting himself into Mideast peace effort, calls Saudi Crown Prince Abdullah and praises his proposal for Israel to withdraw completely from West Bank and Gaza in return for full normalization of relations with all Arab countries; others in administration are less enthusiastic, undertain how Prime Min Ariel Sharon will view long-term plan at time of intensifying violence; Javier Solana of European Union reports Sharon says idea is interesting; also discusses concept with Yasir Arafat, who sends team to Tel Aviv to discuss curbing violence; some Israeli ministers are heartened by what seems to be first concrete peace signal in 17 months of unmitigated violence (M)

headline: Germans Say Goodbye to the Mark, a Symbol of Strength and Unity
abstract: Germans, set to exchange marks for euros, will bid reluctant farewell to currency that has been icon of strength and stability, rebirth and reunion; Germans are not so much giving up mark as exporting it since laws that underlie euro and European Central Bank are in large part reflection of German monetary policies; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Digital Media Hub Planned
abstract: Digeo, interactive television company started by Microsoft Corp co-founder Paul Allen, plans to release cable boxes this year that can serve as digital home media hubs; devices, called broadband media centers, will offer services like wireless home networking, telephone and digital media; Charter Communications, part owner of Diego, will make it available later this year (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Internet executives take a look at a moving target, the college student, in hopes of fostering future spending.
abstract: E-commerce businesses seek to raise online spending by college students in hopes that they will become lifetime customers; only $1.4 billion of $100 billion in discretionary cash at disposal of college students is spent online each year; vastly diverse interests among college students make them elusive marketing target; photo (M)

headline: Concerns About Accounting Cause Losses Once Again
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 98.95 points, to 9,903.04; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 12.30 points, to 1,104.18; Nasdaq composite index falls 38.17 points, to 1,805.20; 10-year Treasury note rises 22/32, to 100 5/32, with yield falling to 4.86 percent; price of 30-year bond rises 20/32, to 100 4/32, and its yield falls to 5.37 percent; table; graph (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Setbacks For Satellite Services
abstract: Orbital Sciences says it expects its auditor PricewaterhouseCoopers to attach note to its 2001 results questioning its ability to avoid bankruptcy; Orbital says it must refinance $100 million in debt due in October to show it can start generating more cash than it is using to meet concerns of auditor; says sales rose more than 80 percent in fourth quarter, to $121 million, but it lost $31.7 million; Lockheed Martin says in regulatory filing that its contract to build four satellites for Astrolink International LLC has been canceled; graph (S)

headline: Israel's Tactics Prompt a Fiery Disagreement in the Cabinet and Censure Abroad
abstract: Israel's defense minister Benjamin Ben-Eliezer reportedly threatens to resign over extent of army's continuing invasion of unofficial Palestinian capital of Ramallah; Terje Roed-Larsen, United Nations envoy in Jerusalem, warns that struggle has reached its lowest point; his growing anger said to have fed unusually tough speech by Secretary Gen Kofi Annan on Mar 12; Israeli officials defend army's tactics and its overall mission as necessary to stop Palestinian terrorism; Prime Min Ariel Sharon said to scorn Ben-Eliezer's resignation threat and to propose cabinet vote on invasion tactics that defense minister would surely lose; photo (M)

headline: World Economic Forum Plays Down the Scandal
abstract: Enron scandal is barely mentioned at World Economic Forum. where thousand corporate chief executives have gathered for meetings during last four days; executives are resistant to linking Enron to corporate fraud and political connections (M)

headline: Ikea Names Crispin To Handle Account
abstract: Advertising: Ikea Name

headline: Bombardier Net Off 34%
abstract: Bombardier says income totaled 229.6 million Canadian dollars ($144.9 million), down from 348 million year earlier; revenue in period, which ended Jan 31, climbed 41 percent, to 7.8 billion Canadian dollars (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank's Profit Falls
abstract: HSBC reports 14 percent decline in pretax profit, to $8.8 billion, compared with $10.3 billion last year, as it wrote down $1.12 billion in Argentine investments after that country's currency was devalued (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: 2 Safe Ways to Drive Like a Maniac
abstract: Game Theory column evaluates auto racing games for Playstation2; Burnout, developed by Criterion Games, is published by Acclaim Entertainment; Star Wars Racer Revenge, developed by Rainbow Studios, is published by LucasArts; photos (M)

headline: Spyros Kyprianou, 69, Former President of Cyprus, Dies
abstract: Spyros Kyprianou, former president of Cyprus who refused to compromise with island's breakaway Turkish minority, dies at age 69; photo (M)

headline: Executives Beyond Enron Took Months To Report Sales
abstract: Loophole in federal securities regulations allow corporate executives to put off public disclosure of their sales of their own companies' stock for 13 months if buyer is company itself; Kenneth L Lay used loophole while heading Enron Corp; executives at Colgate-Pamolive, Procter & Gamble and Tyco International also sold their holdings without investors' knowledge (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: COPPER LEAPS. Copper gained on expectations that a recovery in the United States will increase demand. In New York, copper for March delivery rose 4.05 cents, or 6 percent, to 71.5 cents a pound.

headline: TROUBLES IN ARGENTINA TO REDUCE EARNINGS AT DIAL
abstract: Dial Corp says devaluation of peso in Argentina, company's biggest international market, will reduce earnings this quarter (S)

headline: GLOBAL CROSSING STOCK SOARS ON GRACE PERIOD FOR DEBT
abstract: Shares of Global Crossing Ltd rise nearly 38 percent after company reports receiving more time from bank lenders to meet borrowing conditions (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Growth Outlook Brightens
abstract: Singapore's Prime Min Goh Chok Tong predicts economy will grow from 1 to 3 percent this year; officials had forecast 2 percent growth to 2 percent contraction; photo (S)

headline: Reports of Hackers Are on the Rise
abstract: Number of reported incidents of computer hacker attacks is on rise; public awareness about security issues is factor; graph (S)Ã»

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WHIRLPOOL CORP., Benton Harbor, Mich., the appliance maker, said it would buy Polar S.A., Poland's largest appliance maker, from the former Moulinex-Brandt Group, France, for $43 million in cash and assumed debt.    HAWTHORNE FINANCIAL CORP., El Segundo, Calif., a savings and loan, said it would buy First Fidelity Bancorp Inc., for $68 million.

headline: Nortel C.F.O. Forced to Resign
abstract: The chief financial officer of Nortel Networks was asked to resign today after the company said it had notified regulators of suspicious trades in his 401(k) retirement account.

headline: Two agencies are in a review dispute over the Pennsylvania state lottery's lucrative account.
abstract: Dispute has erupted between advertising agencies Tierney Communications and Marc USA over lucrative account of Pennsylvania state lottery; centers on review for contract; account, with annual billings estimated at $18 million, has been handled for last 25 years by Tierney, which is protesting review of account; lottery awards contract to Marc USA, which has been taking part in review (M)

headline: Fresh Interest in a Global Crossing Bid
abstract: Platinum Equity, buyout firm, is considering bidding for assets of Global Crossing, fiber optic cable company that has filed for bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: West Wayne Promotes President
abstract: West Wayne names president Jeffrey L Johnson to added post of chief executive, succeeding Ben West, who continues as chairman (S)

headline: Cheney, at Marine Base, Reinforces Bush's Stand On War Against Terror
abstract: Vice Pres Dick Cheney opens four-day campaign-style swing through California by underscoring America's resolve to stop Iraq, Iran and North Korea from continuing to develop or pursue nuclear, chemical or biological weapons; address at Marine Corps Air Station in Miramar defends Pres Bush's decision to single out three nations as an 'axis of evil,' defining new phase in Washington's war against terror; photo (M)

headline: In a Surprise, Report Says U.S. Economy Grew in Fourth Quarter
abstract: Fueled by government spending and a rise in automobile sales, the economy experienced some unexpected growth.

headline: Tentatively, North Korea Solicits Foreign Investment and Tourism
abstract: Foreign investment, trade and tourism has been filtering into North Korea over last 18 months; although Pres Bill Clinton eased most restrictions on trade and investment with North Korea in June 2000, large American companies shied away from conducting business after efforts to establish diplomatic ties foundered at end of Clinton administration; although Americans are free to travel to North Korea, Pres Bush has taken hard line, arguing that nation's missile exports and biological warfare capabilities are threat to US; specific tourist and foreign investment projects detailed; map; photo (M)

headline: Enron's Former Chief Will Face Congress
abstract: Kenneth L. Lay, who resigned last month as the chairman and chief executive of Enron, is expected to provide his first public explanation of what went wrong at the company and to describe his role in its collapse in a scheduled appearance tomorrow before a Senate subcommittee.

headline: Records Indicate a Lack of Direction for Executives in Deal-Approval Procedures
abstract: Records of investigation by Enron Corp's outside law firm show Enron's approval process for deals involving partnerships controlled by chief financial officer Andrew S Fastow was so haphazard that important people involved in procedures had limited grasp of their responsibilities; records include notes of interviews with Richard Causey, former chief accounting officer and one of executives with primary responsibility for reviewing partnership transactions; records of interviews also show that several senior executives, including former chief executive Jeffrey K Skilling, were frequently consulted on issues related to partnership transactions (M)

headline: Fund Manager Moving to New Role at Janus
abstract: DIARY Fund Manager Moving To New Role at Janus Â The Janus Capital Corporation, whose stock mutual funds plummeted after the Internet bubble burst, has appointed James Goff, a fund manager, to the vacant position of director of research.

headline: James Tobin, Nobel Laureate in Economics and an Adviser to Kennedy, Is Dead at 84
abstract: Dr James Tobin, economist who was top adviser in Kennedy administration, dies at age 84; photo (M)

headline: Loquacious Disney Fan, Aspiring Firefighter, Young Spirit, Happy Host
abstract: Portraits in Grief, profiles of 14 victims of Sept 11 attack on World Trade Center

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Pension Payback
abstract: Former ABB executive Percy Barnevik will return $53 million in pension benefits and his successor, Goran Lindahl, agrees to pay back $27.8 million after company went public with complaints that two men received sums without express approval of company's board (S)

headline: Understanding Enron
abstract: Not long ago, the Enron Corporation's name was part of the lexicon of corporate and political power. The company's contacts and influence in the White House and Congress bred envy among competitors. It was a driving force behind a radical shift in the nation's energy policy, and its fortune seemed guaranteed for years.

headline: Commercial Real Estate; Designed to Stand Out in a Crowd
abstract: Article on design of new Westin Hotel at Eighth Avenue and 43d Street in Manhattan, which will open in November; $300 million 860-room hotel, designed by Arquitectonica and owned by Tishman Realty and Construction, will be operated by Starwood Hotels and Resorts; photo (M)

headline: Bush Says U.S. and China Want to See Koreas Unified
abstract: Pres Bush and Pres Jiang Zemin of China say they will work together on reunification of North and South Korea, and that peace in region is crucial to both them and world, joint news conference in Great Hall in Beijing; Bush says he asked Jiang to help him make contact with North Korean leader Kim Jong Il, and to tell Kim that Bush is serious about his offer to sit down with Kim for talks; Bush is in China on last leg of his six-day Asian tour; he hopes to negotiate deal with Jiang's government on controlling proliferation of Chinese missile and nuclear technology to nations like Pakistan, Iran and North Korea; photos (M)

headline: AIRLINE TO RESUME FLIGHTS FROM REAGAN NATIONAL
abstract: US Airways Group will resume daily nonstop flights between Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington and six destinations; Reagan Airport was closed by Transportation Department after Sept 11 attacks; carrier says it will also offer online discount fares from $112 to $160 for round-trip service to six destinations (S)

headline: Retirements Delayed By Losses, Survey Says
abstract: Survey finds that 13 percent of investors will have to delay retirement because of stock losses, more than 22 percent in case of respondents in 55-to-64 age group (S)

headline: New Plan: Join the Fray
abstract: News analysis of new American-led offensive south of Gardez, Afghanistan, aimed at cutting escape routes for Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters; military may to have learned 'bitter lessons' from earlier battle at Tora Bora, where overreliance on Afghan proxy forces and small teams of Special Operations troops to prevent foe from escaping led to muddled results; current markedly different offensive reflects thinking that Americans are needed to cut off escape routes and to keep Afghans focused on mission (M)

headline: In Musharraf's Words: 'A Day of Reckoning'
abstract: Following is the full text of a speech today by Gen. Pervez Musharraf, as translated by the Pakistani government.

headline: Britain's Quandary: Hoping the Euro Neither Succeeds Nor Fails
abstract: Britain watches with decidedly mixed feelings as Europeans begin using euro currency; Prime Min Tony Blair has given himself until June 2003 to decide whether euro is successful enough to merit calling referendum on British participation (M)

headline: Toyota Names New Line of Cars 'Scion'
abstract: Toyota Co names new line of vehicles for young buyers 'Scion,' as in descendant, offspring or heir (S)

headline: BORGWARNER TO WRITE OFF $19 MILLION FOR ACQUISITIONS
abstract: BorgWarner Inc., a leading maker of automatic-transmission parts, expects costs of about $19 million in the fourth quarter to write off the value of assets and other expenses. Excluding the cost of 72 cents a share for the write-offs, the company will earn $3.10 to $3.20 in 2001, a spokeswoman, Mary Brevard, said. Analysts surveyed by by Thomson Financial/First Call had forecast BorgWarner would earn $3.15 a share.  The costs are mostly related to businesses BorgWarner bought the last few years to broaden its product range. BorgWarner is writing off environmental costs and expenses to combine headquarters of three units at a site in Auburn Hills, Mich.

headline: Doubted as Business, Valued as Asset, Network News Will Be Hard to Displace
abstract: ABC's bid to lure David Letterman from CBS to replace Ted Koppel's Nightline has rallied television journalism's defenders; has also raised questions about fate of network news business; host of market forces and demographic changes are working against network news, but its dismantling will not be simple; investors are pressing networks to find better business models for their news divisions; graphs of dwindling audiences for network evening news shows and of growing audiences for main cable news networks; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Trip To Jerusalem Barred
abstract: Egyptian court rejects attempt by Coptic Christian to overturn ban issued by Interior Ministry against his traveling to East Jerusalem to pray at Christian sites; cites danger created by Israeli occupation of Palestinian land and notes that Coptic patriarch, Pope Shenouda III, banned faithful from praying in East Jerusalem while it remained under Israeli control (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Linda Kaplan Thaler, chief executive and chief creative officer at the Kaplan Thaler Group, was named advertising woman of the year for 2001 by the Advertising Women of New York.

headline: Many May Be Surprised To Be Enron Investors
abstract: More than 50 mutual funds and insurance companies in last year invested in Osprey Trust created by Enron Corp in 1997 to finance operations of several of company's shadowy partnerships; many individual investors--through these funds--unwittingly owned piece of entity that was used to finance some of partnerships that contributed to Enron's failure; in September 2000 trust raised $2.4 billion from institutional investors in so-called private placement of notes due in January 2003; within last year, mutual fund financial services companies like Putnam Investments, Vanguard Group, Travelers and Prudential have bought Osprey debt; Osprey seems to have been central fund-raising entity for several of Enron's partnerships, including LJM and Whitewing LP; list of some major holders of Osprey debt (M)

headline: Loans From Parents Hide Assorted Strings
abstract: Ellyn Spragins article on emotional issues raised by loans from parents to adult children; drawing (M)

headline: In 401(k) Plans, a New Rush to Diversify
abstract: Growing number of people are seeking help of brokers and financial advisers on how to diversify their 401(k) retirement plans in wake of Enron Corp collapse; many Enron employees lost their retirement savings when Enron collapsed; photo (M)

headline: Sterner U.S. Policy Toward North Korea Causes Debate in South
abstract: United States policy toward North Korea has become a source of deep disagreement between President Kim Dae Jung and the man likely to succeed him in elections this year.

headline: Do You Look Best Wearing Envious Green?
abstract: Abby Ellin column says that in trying to assess one's life, there are dangers in making comparisons with others; says comparisons are useful if they provide motivation; photo (M)

headline: After Musharraf's Speech, Indian Officials Respond Cautiously and Only in Private
abstract: Indian officials, poised for war with Pakistan, delay any official reaction to Pres Pervez Musharraf's speech, carried live in India on several television stations; diplomats, scholars and analysts are hopeful speech contained enough positive signals to buy time for further diplomatic efforts to defuse crisis; photo (M)2

headline: In Rite of Past, Afghans See Way to Forge Future
abstract: The meeting stretched over 11 days, filled with passionate argument, flowery oratory, political intrigue and legal maneuvering. In 1964, Afghanistan adopted a new constitution, but not before the assembly of politicians, royalists and tribal, ethnic and religious elders had reshaped it in ways large and small.    Once again, the loya jirga -- a Pashto phrase meaning great meeting or grand council -- had helped determine the structure of Afghanistan's government and the course of its history.

headline: You Can Take It With You
abstract: Colin Ferenbach is moving from Haven Capital Management, where he has managed $78.5 million midcap Haven Fund, to Tocqueville Capital Management, and fund will go with him and be renamed Tocqueville Alexis (S)

headline: Investors and Local Broadcasters Watch Growth of Satellite Radio
abstract: During this holiday season, the latest consumer electronics gadget was not a digital TV recorder or a new hand-held organizer but a new twist on an old technology: the radio.     Since its national debut in mid-November, XM Satellite Radio has sold 25,000 to 30,000 subscriptions to its new national radio service, XM Radio. In the same period, consumer electronics stores sold nearly an equal number of the specialized radios necessary to receive the signals, making national satellite radio one of the fastest-growing new products the audio industry has seen in years.

headline: Viacom Radio Executive Resigns Unexpectedly
abstract: Farid Suleman, chief executive of Viacom Inc's Infinity Broadcasting, stuns colleagues and Viacom president Mel Karmazin with his resignation; Suleman is leaving Infinity to become chief executive of Citadel Communications and special limited partner at Forstmann Little, leveraged-buyout firm that owns Citadel; Karmazin will assume Suleman's duties on interim basis; move comes amid recent speculation that Viacom's chief executive Sumner M Redstone may not renew Karmazin's contract in 2003 (M)

headline: Lawyers Say Board Report Has Limited Value for Them
abstract: Lawyers for investors and former employees of Enron Corp say company-sponsored report detailing its manipulation of numerous investment partnerships will provide only limited support to lawsuits; say investigators failed to cover range of company activities that will figure prominently in many suits; say they ignored foreign operations, accusations of insider trading, company's role in California's energy crisis year ago and possible mishandling of employee pensions; sat they lacked access to several crucial Enron managers and members of Enron audit team at Arthur Andersen, or enough time to delve deeply into investment partnerships that were focus of inquiry; express misgivings that there was no mention of investment bankers and consultants they suspect played role in constructing financial house of cards (M)

headline: Vera Wang, the celebrity designer, is extending her brand, first with a fragrance.
abstract: Celebrity designer Vera Wang is introducing perfume with print-only advertising drive stressing bridal magazines; fragrance is aimed at future brides in 25-to-35-year-old range; photo (M)

headline: In Death, Alliance Leader's Stature Only Grows
abstract: Reporter's Notebook column describes some behind-the-scenes events related to US war against terrorism in Afghanistan; photos (M)

headline: Magazines; Those Jaunty Issues Of the New Economy Take a Sober Turn
abstract: Spate of magazines that lived off Internet boom struggle for survival and for compelling story; find fizzy vocabulary of little use in reporting on debacle; Red Herring magazine has shrunk from 552 ad-stuffed pages in Sept 2000 at height of boom to scant 100 pages; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Hard-Liners Block Budget
abstract: Iranian Council blocks Pres Mohammad Khatami's budget plan, which was approved by Parliament, finding conflict with Islamic law (S)

headline: Company Buys Canadian Rival For $6 Billion
abstract: PanCanadian Energy agrees to buy Alberta Energy Co for $6.1 billion in stock, creating Canada's largest producer of oil and natural gas; combined company, called EnCana, will form serious competitor to American energy concerns amid rash of takeovers of smaller Canadian oil and gas producers by US companies (M)

headline: James J. Dunn, 81, Ex-Publisher of Forbes
abstract: James J. Dunn, the publisher of Forbes magazine for 20 years, died on Monday at his home in North Palm Beach, Fla.     He was 81 and formerly lived in Greenwich, Conn.

headline: A Sept. 11 Survivor Is Hurt as Man Dies In Jerusalem Attack
abstract: Suicide bomber sets off explosion in central shopping district in Jerusalem, killing herself and 81-year-old man and wounding 113 others; wounded include 43-year-old New Yorker Mark Sokolov, who survived September 11 terrorist attacks against World Trade Center; wife and two children suffer slight injuries; attacker is first female suicide bomber to strike in Israel since such attacks began in 1994; is identified by Hezbollah as student from Al Najah University in Nablus; scene of destruction on Jaffa Road described; Jerusalem Mayor Ehud Olmert blames Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat; accuses him of inspiring atmosphere of terrorism; photo (M)

headline: OUTLOOK: Markets and Investing; Individual Investors, While Chastened, Are Not Giving Up
abstract: Some individual investors are not giving up on stocks despite declines in prices for two consecutive years; Pittsburgh residents David J Sunseri and Kay Barry comment; photos (M)

headline: Cancer Drug Company's Board to Meet on Partner's Threat to Walk Away From Deal
abstract: Board of ImClone Systems is expected to meet to respond to ultimatum from Bristol-Myers Squibb that it restructure companies' $2 billion deal and temporarily remove its two top executives; ImClone sends signals that it would reject those demands, which it sees as eviserating its potential profits on cancer drug Erbitux; Bristol-Myers wants Samuel D Waksal and Harlan W Waksal to step aside until drug receives approval and to let Bristol-Myers handle all tests of drug on people and dealings with Food and Drug Administration (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Case On Far-Right Party Postponed
abstract: Germany's highest court postpones hearings on government proposal to ban far-right National Democratic Party after learning from interior ministry that leading party member due to testify in case has been informer for domestic intelligence service; Interior Min Otto Schily says government stopped using Wolfgang Frenz as informer in 1995 (S)

headline: Commission Concludes That Swiss Policies Aided the Nazis
abstract: Independent historians' commission, wrapping up five years of research into Switzerland's wartime past, concludes that country's neutrality was twisted to justify policies that helped Nazis; finds that Swiss authorities in World War II knew that turning back Jewish refugees meant likely death; concludes that authorities cooperated unduly with Nazis and failed to return assets to their rightful owners when war ended (M)

headline: ADVENT, A SOFTWARE MAKER, BUYS KINEXUS FOR $68 MILLION
abstract: Advent Software Inc, maker of software to automate securities trade orders, agrees to buy closely held Kinexus for about $68.5 million; Kinexus provides reports to financial advisers for wealthy investors (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Enterasys Fires 3 Over Accounting Lapse
abstract: Enterasys Networks Inc, under investigation by Securities and Exchange Commission, fires three senior employees in its Asian unit after doctored sales contract was given to auditors (S)

headline: 7 Taliban Officials Surrender to a Governor and Go Free
abstract: Seven high-ranking Taliban government officials, including Mullah Nooruddin Turabi, former justice minister who played leading role in Taliban's repressive laws and destruction of Buddha statues at Bamian, surrender to Kandahar Province governor Gul Agha and are freed; interim central government says it was not consulted on amnesty and was informed day later; expresses concern about release of Turabi and of former security chief Abdul Haq; cites determination to bring to justice Taliban leaders who committed crimes against Afghan people or were accomplices of Al Qaeda terrorists; seeks to impose order in Kabul, ordering soldiers and paramilitary troops to turn in weapons or report to barracks; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Sulzer's Shares Surge
abstract: Sulzer Medica shares rise 21 percent after company and parent Sulzer agree to $1 billion settlement of faulty hip and knee implant claims; graph (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Slashdot's Editor Proves Even Nerds Fall in Love
abstract: Rob Malda, founder and editor of Slashdot.org, community news site for software developers, uses site to propose marriage to Kathleen Fent, who accepts (S)

headline: Saving for College Yet?
abstract: Morgan Stanley survey finds that more than half of American families who plan to send their children to college have not started saving to pay for it (S)

headline: Gigha Journal; Scottish Islanders Wake Up As Lairds of All They Survey
abstract: Isle of Gigha, which its 110 residents bought for $5.8 million in Oct, is leading way to land reform in Scotland; half of Scottish land is in private hands, belonging to just 350 lairds, in feudal system set up in 12th century; residents of Gigha got most of money from National Lottery-financed Scottish Land Fund, and benefited from benevolent laird who turned down several higher bids in belief that islanders should have chance to run their island; members of Scottish Parliament, legislature created in 1999, has set land reform as its principal early objective; photos; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Migrants Stifle Channel Traffic
abstract: Hundreds of immigrants try to board trains to go from France to England but are stymied by increased security at Channel Tunnel; virtually all freight service to Britain through tunnel is suspended (S)

headline: Treating Analysts' Scuffed-Up Image
abstract: Interview with Sallie Krawcheck on questions being raised about Wall Street's sell-side analysts; photo (M)

headline: Units of WPP Group Get Lego Toy Account
abstract: Lego Co has consolidated worldwide advertising account of its Lego brand of construction toys, with billings estimated at $35 million, at units of WPP Group (S)

headline: Nation's Unemployment Rate Rises to 5.8%
abstract: Nation's Unemployment Rate Rise

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Publisher Considers Unit Sale
abstract: Pearson appoints Lazard to advise it on its business publishing division, FT Business, for which it has received several expressions of interest; graph (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Drug Maker's Profit Rises
abstract: Novartis says net profit climbed 8 percent, to $4.1 billion, and its sales over all were up 10 percent over previous year, to $19 billion; graph (S)

headline: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; AIRSTRIKE IN EASTERN AFGHANISTAN
abstract: US warplanes strike twice in eastern Afghanistan after forces come under attack at roadblock (S)

headline: AT&T Moves Its President Closer to the Top Position
abstract: By all appearances, David W. Dorman would have to do something shocking to avoid becoming AT&T's next chief executive.    That became clear yesterday as AT&T named Mr. Dorman, the company's president, to the board. It has been clear for at least a year that Mr. Dorman was the favorite to become the chief executive once the company sold or spun off its cable television operation. With yesterday's announcement, the favorite became all but a shoo-in.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Network Associates To Shut Unit
abstract: Network Associates plans to close its PGP software encryption division after failing to find suitable buyer (S)

headline: QUEST TO BUY AMERICAN MEDICAL FOR $340 MILLION
abstract: Quest Diagnostics, which provides medical laboratory tests, acquires American Medical Laboratories for $340 million and assumption of $160 million in debt (S)

headline: MILACRON, EQUIPMENT MAKER, PLANS TO CLOSE 14 PLANTS
abstract: Milacron Inc, maker of equipment used to mold plastics, will eliminate about 1,150 jobs, or 11 percent of its work force, and close 14 plants because of falling demand; says fourth-quarter loss narrowed to $21.9 million, from $22 million year earlier; sales fell 21 percent, to $305.5 million from $388.8 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: SMITH & NEPHEW AGREES TO BUY ORATEC FOR $310 MILLION
abstract: Smith & Nephew, Europe's largest maker of hospital supplies, acquires Oratec Interventions, which develops medical devices to treat spine and joint disorders, for $310 million (S)

headline: Swiss Block Accounts
abstract: Switzerland's largest bank said that it has blocked accounts it suspects contain money belonging to the family of a late Nigerian dictator.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Business Digest column

headline: Thirlspot Journal; Where Foot-and-Mouth Raged, Hikers Now Roam
abstract: Hundreds of walkers return to England's Lake District since foot-and-mouth disease restrictions are eased; at height of epidemic Britons were denied access to forests, trails, canal towpaths, national parkland and most agricultural land; worst-hit area was Cumbria, which encompasses Lake District, one of country's msot beautiful scenic attractions; area seems to have rebounded from 12 months ago, when businesses were forecasting bankruptcy; photo; map (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH/W. George Greig; William Blair International Growth Fund
abstract: Carole Gould profile of $425 million William Blair International Growth fund and W George Greig, manager, who says he is emphasizing more investments in emerging markets of Asia; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Moldova: Opposition Politician Missing
abstract: Moldova police ask Interpol for help in finding missing opposition politician Vlad Cubreacov (S)

headline: Excerpts From Testimony Before House Subcommittee on Enron Collapse
abstract: Excerpts from statement by William C Powers Jr and testimony by Chmn Harvey L Pitt before House commitee probing Enron collapse (M)

headline: Srinagar Journal; Left Orphaned by War: The City and Its Children
abstract: Bloody 12-year guerrilla war in Kashmir has left great many children fatherless and destitute; orphans are one of many examples of conflict's toll on Srinagar, where paramilitary forces are bunkered on every other block; map; photo (M)

headline: Investing; A Winter of Turmoil Could Make Irish Stock Exchange a Target
abstract: Usually sleepy Irish stock exchange has been rocked by accounting questions at Elan Corp and currency trading woes at Allied Irish Banks that have dragged down exchange's benchmark index nearly 12 percent since Jan; two company's market capitalization has plunged from 35 percent of entire market few months ago to 24 percent, reviving longstanding concerns about viability of independent Irish exchange and making it possible merger target; stock price graph; photo (M)

headline: 5 Years and $15 Billion Later, A Fiber Optic Venture Fails
abstract: Global Crossing Ltd, which spent five years and $15 billion to build worldwide network of high-speed Internet and telephone lines, files for bankruptcy after failing to find enough customers to make network profitable; had attracted many notable business and political figures, including Democratic National Committee chairman Terry McAuliffe, former Pres George Bush, Tisch family and former ARCO chairman and big Republican fund-raiser Lodwrick Cook; chairman Gary Winnick could lose control if bankruptcy plan is accepted, but blow would be softened by stock deals that reaped him more than $730 million; company shares have fallen more than 99 percent, to 13.5 cents, in over-the-counter trading after being de-listed by New York Stock Exchange; traded for more than $60 as recently as March 2000; company has never reported annual profit since creation in ambitious plan to extend its sole resource--fiber-optic cable traversing Atlantic Ocean--into 100,000-mile network connecting 27 countries in Americas, Asia and Europe; has $22.4 billion in assets and $12.4 billion in debt, making filing largest bankruptcy by telecommunications company; graph; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Tight Race For Party Leadership
abstract: Beatriz Parades and Roberto Madrazo seem to be in virtual tie in nationwide vote to choose new leader for Mexico's Institutional Revolutionary Party (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil Exports To Be Reviewed
abstract: Russian government next week will decide whether to extend cuts in oil exports as OPEC has requested; Russia's production has been rising as its oil industry is upgraded, creating tension with OPEC (S)

headline: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; PROTEST IN NEW JERSEY
abstract: About 50 of 100 people jailed in Middlesex County, NJ, on immigration charges refuse to eat some meals, protesting length of their detentions and inadequate medical treatment (S)

headline: Larger Minority Role Sought In Managing Retirement Funds
abstract: Rev Jesse Jackson says minority-owned firms should receive 10 percent of asset-management fees for managing corporate pension and 401(k) money, setting goal far higher than what such firms now receive, address to annual Wall Street Project Conference; in 2000, minority-owned firms collected 0.2 percent of total fees paid for asset management by top 200 companies in Fortune 500; Wall Street Project is Jackson's initiative to press corporations to open their boardrooms and capital to minority groups (M)

headline: Suicide Threat By 9 Refugees Held in Camp By Australia
abstract: Nine teenage Afghans seeking asylum are threatening to kill themselves unless they are freed from Australian camp where hundreds of illegal immigrants have been on hunger strike for two weeks to protest their detention; immigrants are protesting conditions at camp and government's policy of detaining all illegal immigrants while their applications for asylum wind through bureaucracy, which can take years; detainees at other centers across Australia have joined protests; some have sewn their mouths shut and others have harmed themselves or attempted suicide; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: England: Higher Interest Rate Possible
abstract: World Business Briefing: Eng

headline: DELTA CHIEF'S CASH COMPENSATION FELL BY 72 PERCENT
abstract: Delta Air Lines proxy statement filed with Securities and Exchange Commission shows chief executive Leo Mullin's total cash compensation fell 72 percent in 2001, to $596,250 from $2.145 million in fiscal 2000; Mullin gave up his salary for last three months of year (S)

headline: International Troops Help Bring Order to Kabul's Streets
abstract: For the past six weeks, Maj. David Buckingham of Manns Choice in southwestern Pennsylvania has been wearing the dark red beret of a British paratrooper, living by kerosene lamp in a wrecked Kabul high school and trying, as best he and the British troops can, to bring security to a quarter of a million people in a war-shattered district in the western part of this capital.    Not many months ago, Major Buckingham was serving in the United States with the 101st Airborne Division. But now he spends his days in Kabul on an exchange with the Parachute Regiment, one of the British Army's most decorated combat units, as part of the force supporting the new post-Taliban government.

headline: DOW CORNING TO SELL LOW-COST SILICONE OVER INTERNET
abstract: Dow Corning Corp, which makes silicone-based products including lubricants and sealants, plans to sell low-cost silicone products over Internet as it prepares to emerge from bankruptcy protection next year (S)
