headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Audit Clears Bank Executives
abstract: National Australia Bank chairman Charles Allen says independent review by Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz of bank's write-down of $2 billion related to its mortgage unit, HomeSide Lending, has cleared directors and executives of bank; bank discloses summary of review because of legal action involving three Homeside executives who were fired when write-downs were disclosed (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  Factory Orders: Dec.

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE TRADE: W.T.O. RESOLVES DISPUTE Member countries of the World Trade Organization resolved a dispute on how to structure negotiations on a new round of talks aimed at opening global markets. The 144-member group agreed that the body's director general, Mike Moore, should head the committee overseeing the three-year negotiations, rejecting a proposal to have their Geneva- based delegates take over the job. The European Union trade chief, Pascal Lamy, issued a statement welcoming the move as a

headline: PG&E REVIEWS CLASSIFICATION OF POWER PLANT LEASES
abstract: The PG&E Corporation, whose California utility filed for bankruptcy protection last year, delayed reporting fourth-quarter earnings yesterday as it reviewed whether to reclassify power plant leases as debt on financial statements dating back to 1999. The company may add $1 billion to total assets and liabilities, a move that would not affect net income, a spokesman, Greg Pruett, said. PG&E executives and auditors from Deloitte & Touche discovered the possible overpayments Wednesday night, Mr. Pruett said. The review related to so-called synthetic leases, which were used for two power plants. PG&E set up partnerships to finance the $1.15 billion cost of building the plants. Outside investors held 3 percent of the trusts. PG&E is now investigating whether the deal met the qualifications for synthetic leases, which are allowed under generally accepted accounting principles.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bid For Packaging Concern
abstract: Anglo American's Mondi International paper subsidiary begins unsolicited cash bid for French packaging company, Rochette, valuing company at about 298 million euros ($270 million) or 11.6 euros per share; offer could start bidding war since Saica of Spain bought 22 percent of Rochette in late December for 10.9 euros a share; Anglo American also offers about 60 million euros, or $54 million, for Rochette's convertible bonds (S)

headline: A Gadfly Who Raised Some Early Questions
abstract: Suspicions of serious corporate governance problems at Global Crossing should have been raised in early 2000 when Web site run by Nell Minow criticized its board of directors on terms of contract given to Robert Annunziata, chief executive; she recalls that posting provoked hostile e-mails from investors and employers and that institutional investors were equally dismissive; rephoto (M)

headline: In Shift, British Airways Looks to Coach
abstract: British Airways says it will try to compete with Europe's booming budget airlines by offering cheaper travel over Internet to passengers in coach; carrier has catered to more wealthy business traveler for years; move comes eight months after British Airways sold its budget airline, Go, only to see rivals like Ryanair and EasyJet add routes, passengers and profits; also announces additional 5,800 job cuts in effort to return to profitability; measures are intended to save $930 million per year by March 2004; chief executive Rod Eddington says airliner will end flights on 10 routes, sell some airplanes and try to lure budget passengers onto its European networks (M)

headline: Man in the News; Pressing the President -- David Michael Walker
abstract: Profile of General Accounting Office Comptroller Gen David M Walker, who is suing Bush administration for disclosure of documents about how administration formulated its energy policy; Walker says he will file lawsuit to force Vice Pres Dick Cheney to turn over papers White House has refused to provide Congress; chart; photo (M)

headline: Greenspan Reports Signs of Stability but 'Significant Risks'
abstract: LONDONâ€”  Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said Friday that he saw tentative signs of stabilization in the U.S. economy, although he warned that "significant risks" remained in the near term.

headline: Peacocks Of Palmtops, In 3 Breeds
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column appraises three new hand-held organizers with color screens: Sony Clie PEG-T615C, Palm m515 and Palm m130; photos (M)

headline: LVMH Avoided Loss for '01 With Gains on Gucci Shares
abstract: LVMH reports operating income fell 20 percent in 2001, to 1.56 billion euros ($1.38 billion); reports group net income fell to 10 million euros, down from 772 million euros in 2000, after charge of 769 million euros; chairman Bernard Arnault says he is not ready to sell money-losing units; photo (M)

headline: Lawmakers In Britain Pursue Fox Hunters
abstract: Fox hunting plunges British Parliament into snarly family fued for fourth year; issue may seem arcane and quaint to outsiders, but in Britain it involves notions of personal liberty, rights of embattled minorities and sanctity of countryside; choice before legislators is whether to ban fox hunting outright, or to permit it to continue but under strict new system of licensing (M)

headline: The Collections / Paris: Young designers show few sparks of innovation
abstract: PARISâ€”  In these days of task sharing, women may be out of the habit of spring cleaning: Three 30-something designers who were brought in to dust off Paris couture houses made a poor job of it Wednesday.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   8.50        Discount rate   1.25   1.25   5.00        Federal funds   1.68   1.68   5.48        3-month T-bills   1.78   1.79   4.40        6-month T-bills   1.95   1.99   4.28        10-yr. T-infl.   3.37   3.38   3.32        10-yr. T-note   5.26   5.31   4.82        30-yr. headline: A Call for U.S. to Get Out of Terror Insurance for Airlines
abstract: American International Group chief executive Maurice R Greenberg, who is strong advocate of government help in providing general terrorism coverage, urges that Federal government get out of business of providing terrorism coverage for US airlines for damage on ground; Greenberg says his company and other private insurers, which refused to sell coverage after Sept 11 terrorist attacks, are now willing to do so; says for government to continue subsidized insurance program for airlines would only stymie full development of commercial insurance market; private insurers have continued to provide full coverage for passengers and $50 million for ground damages, far short of $1 billion minimum required by lenders and many national regulators; Greenberg sends his proposal to Transportation Sec Norman Y Mineta; Air Transport Association says it is too soon to end government program because private coverage is not yet being offered at prices that are 'commercially reasonable'; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: Janus Capital Lays Off 222
abstract: Janus Capital, whose mutual funds have performed poorly since end of Internet boom, lays off 222 more employees, 15 percent of its work force (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Xbox Hits Europe
abstract: Microsoft Corp will begin selling its inaugural video game console, Xbox, in 16 European countries and Australia (S)

headline: On the Trail of a Cure For the Common Cold
abstract: Profile of ViroPharma Inc, small company based in Exton, Pa, which has developed drug that it says can reduce length and severity of common cold by attacking rhinovirus; drug, called plecoaril, trademarked as Picovir, also reduces so-called viral shedding, making cold less contagious; graph; photo of Michel de Rosen, chief executive (M)

headline: Angry at Vote, Commonwealth Bars Zimbabwe
abstract: Commonwealth suspends Zimbabwe for year to punish Pres Robert Mugabe for his stewardship of elections, which were widely criticized outside Africa as rigged; move, while less than expulsion, still deepens Zimbabwe's diplomatic isolation; means that Zimbabwean officials will be barred from meetings held by Commonwealth, organizaton that carries some cachet as important club bridging north-south divide; Prime Min John Howard of Australian makes announcement flanked by Pres Thabo Mbeki of South Africa and Pres Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria, who are torn between solidarity with fellow African leader who was crusader against colonialism and their commitment to democratic standards as part of African economic regeneration (M)

headline: Israel Says It Seized Ship Carrying Arms to Palestinians, Who Deny It
abstract: The Israeli Army announced today that it had seized a ship in the Red Sea carrying 50 tons of arms intended for the Palestinian Authority, but the Palestinians said that assertion was false.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Human Rights Problems
abstract: Oleg Mironov, Russia's human rights commissioners, say Russians still feel 'absolutely helpless' if pursued by police, prosecutors or courts; says police still manipulate courts and beat people; scores as human rights violation cutting off of heat and electricity in winter in regions where officials have not paid utility bills (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Skater Sarah Hughes is being featured on boxes of Wheaties cereal, sold by General Mills; company says she will be only American medal winner to be on Wheaties packages after Winter Games (S)

headline: Powell Leaves India
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell ended his South Asian cross-border diplomacy saying he had received strong signs from India and Pakistan that tensions were decreasing. But he reached no concrete agreements on easing their military standoff.    Article, Page A6.

headline: Pakistani Schools: Meager Fare for Hungry Minds
abstract: Financial and curriculum limitations at Government Muslim High School in Rawalpindi, one of Pakistan's finest and oldest public schools, raise question of how any serious learning is possible there, and illustrate why so many families turn to private schools, if they can afford them, or to madrasas, Islamic religious schools that feed children while giving them very limited education; barely third of Pakistan's population is literate, at least 30 million children are not in school and 6 million of 8 million primary-school-age children not in school are girls; education spending is now barely two percent of GNP, compared with 17 percent in Bangladesh and more than 20 percent in Iran and Turkey; 40 percent of Pakistan's budget goes to pay staggering $38-billion foreign debt, although Canada is swapping some of debt for spending on education and infrastructure (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: William F. Gloede was named editor at Cable World magazine, New York, part of the Media Central division of Primedia Business-to-Business.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; In trying to acquire all of Travelocity, Sabre finds itself in a struggle to regain what it once had.
abstract: Market Place column on prospects of Sabre Holdings acquiring 30 percent of Travelocity.com it does not own; says Travelocity's independent directors want more than $23 per share offered, and some speculators are betting that they will get it (M)

headline: Pakistani Police Make Little Progress in Search for Reporter
abstract: Police in Pakistan make little progress in search for missing Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl; reportedly find no solid evidence linking any of suspects to crime; photo (M)

headline: Stephen King's new collection of short stories is on the beam, literally, to would-be buyers.
abstract: Simon & Schuster, publisher of Stephen King's book Evertying's Eventual, is teaming up with Viacom Outdoor and company called Streetbeam to promote book on telephone kiosks in New York City that allow would-be reader to download sample of book; photo (S)

headline: Private Sector; Her Early Call on Qwest Was 'Sorry, Wrong Number'
abstract: Shares of Qwest Communications International are selling for half of what they were four years ago, when Joan Lappin, president of Gramercy Capital Management, said stock was worth only half its price; she says it is still selling for twice what it is worth; photo (S)

headline: New Luxury Project in Works
abstract: PARISâ€”  Just as French high fashion had seemed burnt out, with the retirement of Yves Saint Laurent, a phoenix may be rising from the ashes.

headline: TRW May Not Bite, Even at a Sweetened Deal
abstract: Analysis: Northrop Grumman is in for tough fight in its bid to acquire TRW Corp; its all-stock offer of $47 per share, or $5.9 billion, seems to low to dissuade TRW from defending itself against Northrop's unwanted advances; Northrop's chances of winning contested takeover battle are undeniably slim: Ohio's new antitakeover laws make it almost impossible to oust board; TRW is considering plan to sell its automotive unit to increase value, taking wind--and value--out of Northrop's plan to do same thing (M)

headline: Chechens and Russians Start Informal Discussions, Hoping Leaders Will Meet for Talks
abstract: Russian lawmakers open new dialogue with Chechen political figures after more than two years of civil war in breakaway province in hopes of setting terms for direct talks between President Vladimir V Putin and rebel leaders he has branded as terrorists; failure of fall 2001 peace initiative by Putin noted (M)

headline: Treasury Finds $410 Million in Fake Bids
abstract: Treasury Department says it has uncovered $410 million in bogus auction bids placed over Internet for next week's auction of two-year notes (S)

headline: Ad sales for the home-court Olympic Games happily surprise NBC.
abstract: Three NBC networks carrying Winter Olympic Games have run up surprisingly robust $750 million on sales for commercial time during 375.5 hours of coverage from Salt Lake City; some major advertisers noted; photos (M)

headline: $1.5 Million Penalty For Knight Trading
abstract: The securities arm of the Knight Trading Group agreed to pay $1.5 million to settle regulatory charges of violations in market-making and trading, the National Association of Securities Dealers said today.    Knight Trading, based in Jersey City, committed numerous violations of federal securities laws and N.A.S.D. rules from July 1997 to May 2001, a period of rapid expansion for the firm, the association said.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Loss Grows At XM
abstract: XM Satellite Radio Holdings says its fourth-quarter loss increased to $143.9 million from $14 million in year-earlier quarter; sales were $532,000; graph (S)

headline: DRUG BOAT INVESTIGATED
abstract: Intelligence officials investigate possible Al Qaeda or Taliban links to drug shipment intercepted off coast of Pakistan by Canadian naval officers; boat contained two metric tons of hashish or opium; two men jumped from boat into speedboat and escaped (S)

headline: U.S. MAKES PLEDGE FOR $300 MILLION IN AID TO AFGHANS
abstract: United States pledges to provide nearly $300 million for initial reconstruction efforts as representatives of more than 50 countries and organizations gather in Tokyo to discuss rebuilding of ravaged country; Sec of State Colin L Powell, addressing opening session, says that first-year contribution--close to one-fifth of $1.7 billion United Nations has estimated will be needed in first year--will be used for programs including agricultural, health, security and counternarcotics efforts a well as refugee assistance; photo of Powell with Hamid Karzai, Afghanistan's interim leader (L)

headline: Builders Flourished In Bad Times. Now What?
abstract: market insight: builders

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix Expects Profit
abstract: Hynix Semiconductor reports operating profit for January and February as result of rising prices worldwide for memory chips; company lost record $3.8 billion last year but expects net profit for first quarter 2002; Hynix chairman Park Chong Sup leaves for another round of talks with Micron Technologies, which wants to take over company's memory chip operations (S)

headline: W.T.O. Pact Would Set Global Accounting Rules
abstract: Little-known global agreement that places untested new requirements on domestic regulation of professional services like accounting is quietly advancing, with help of firms like Arthur Andersen, Enron Corp's much-criticized auditor; new rules would give World Trade Organization oversight on domestic regulation of accounting; any new national regulation could be challenged by other countries as unfair if it is 'more trade restrictive than necessary'; critics say such standard could hobble government's ability to regulate many services; American officials say requirement will prevent governments from setting up discriminatory rules, limitations and quotas that would interfere with right of foreign service companies to enter their markets (M)

headline: Pakistan to Announce New Steps to Combat Islamic Militants
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain met with Pakistan's President Pervez Musharraf, who said he would spell out steps Pakistan plans to take to fight extremists in a speech in the next few days.

headline: I.R.S. to Seek Visa Card Data
abstract: Federal judge authorizes Internal Revenue Service to get records from Visa International of offshore accounts held by Americans suspected of tax evasion as part of widening probe of people who hide their incomes in offshore banks and live off credit cards in United States; MasterCard International has already turned over records involving 230,000 accounts and American Express Co has agreed to turn over similar records; IRS estimates up to two million Americans have offshore card and bank accounts (M)

headline: Verizon in Vermont Bid
abstract: Verizon Communications asks Federal Communications Commission to let it sell long-distance service in Vermont, market valued at $200 million annually (S)

headline: Pashtuns, Once Favored by Taliban, Now Face Retribution in Afghanistan's North
abstract: Article on members of Afghanistan's Pashtun ethnic group in northern Afghanistan who were once favored by Taliban, but who have become victims of reprisals from other ethnic groups that suffered under Taliban rule; map (M)

headline: White House Wants Chief of Chemical Arms Group to Resign
abstract: Bush administration publicly calls for resignation of Jose Bustani as director general of Organization for Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, international organization charged with stopping spread of chemical weapons; says he has mismanaged organization, undertaken ill-considered initiatives and demoralized its technical staff; has sought Bustani's resignation through quiet diplomacy for several weeks to no avail (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Gypsies Sue I.B.M.
abstract: Gypsy International Recognition and Compensation Action sues IBM for its leasing of punch-card tabulating machines to Nazis, which helped regime identify and kill at least 600,000 Nazis (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: 'Mlife' Draws Super Bowl Traffic
abstract: Annual analysis by Jupiter Media Metrix of Web site traffic surrounding Super Bowl shows big increases for site of advertisers AT&T Wireless and site set up by Yahoo and Pepsi-Cola division of PepsiCo (S)

headline: Italians Hope Blair Visit Helps Berlusconi's European Image
abstract: Many Italians hope British Prime Min Tony Blair's upcoming visit will help end Italy's current isolation within Europe, 'reinvent' Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi and reposition Italy in new alliance with Britain and Spain on economic and European policy (M)

headline: Enron's Lay Is to Appear Before Panel
abstract: Sen Byron L Dorgan says he expects Enron Corp former chairman Kenneth L Lay to appear under subpoena and testify before Senate subcommittee probing Enron's collapse; Lay aide says he weighs his options; photo (M)

headline: Guerrilla Attacks May Rise In Warmer Days, U.S. Says
abstract: Bush administration officials fear approach of warmer weather in Afghanistan may signal sharp rise in guerrilla attacks on American and allied troops; suspect significant numbers of Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters are regrouping in mountains along Pakistan border and that other scattered cells of adversaries remain in south and west; note small clusters of fighters are hard to detect, track and attack (M)

headline: State Farm Insurance Loses $5 Billion
abstract: State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Co

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Executive Payback
abstract: Percy Barnevik and Goran Lindahl, former ABB Ltd executives, may return part of $137 million they received in severance; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Large Screen On New Sony Laptop
abstract: Sony Corp introduces laptop computer that it says is first notebook personal computer to come with 16.1-inch display; most expensive model will cost about $3,000 and least expensive $2,100 (S)

headline: Saying Battle Is Reaching End, U.S. Sends Troops Back to Base
abstract: American commanders, while not declaring victory, cautiously declare crux of battle against Al Qaeda ad Taliban fighters in much of Shah-i-Kot Valley in Afghanistan effectively is over; order about 400 soldiers back to base but say say fresh troops may be rotated into battle to eliminate remnants of enemy; Joint Chiefs of Staff Chmn Gen Richard B Myers says remaining Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters are widely dispersed; hints battle has opened way to eventual end of American combat operations in Afghanistan; jubilant returning soldiers from 10th Mountain Division in Fort Drum, NY, express confidence battle will mark decisive moment in successful war; maps; photos (M)

headline: For IDT, the Big Flameouts Light Its Fire
abstract: IDT, wholesale long-distance and prepaid calling card company, is making something of speciality of capitalizing on collapse of once-high-flying telecommunications companies, like Winstar Communications, which had market value of $11 billion in fall of 2000, when IDT's was $1 billion; acquired Winstar out of bankruptcy for $42.5 million in October; has more than $1 billion in cash, $1.2 billion in annual sales and no debt and is thus well positioned to take advanage of depressed valuations in industry; Howard S Jonas, founder and chairman, and James A Courter, chief executive; comment (M)

headline: Arab Woman's Path to Unlikely 'Martyrdom'
abstract: Central, violent role of woman in suicide bombing in Jerusalem seen as sign of growing desperation of Palestinians, and growing willingness of Palestinian militants to deploy women who can slip past Israeli security; Wafa Idris, woman who blew herself up, killing Israeli, appeared motivated more by nationalist fervor than by religion; relatives recall her saying she would like to be a martyr; her eldest brother is Fatah leader wanted by Israelis; life in refugee camp seems to have bred deep anger in her; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Andersen to Reject Plea; Bidders End Merger Talks  Talks about a possible sale of Arthur Andersen all but collapsed, even as senior executives of the accounting firm decided that it would not plead guilty to charges of obstruction of justice in the Enron case, according to people close to the firm.    The aggressive posture was taken before a government-imposed 9 a.m. deadline today in which Andersen had the choice of pleading guilty or risking indictment. [Page A1.]    Documents obtained by Congressional investigators indicate that lawyers for Enron may have been aware of some of the most crucial facts about a partnership that played a significant role in the company's collapse. [C4.]

headline: A Battle of Titans, or Just a 'Silly Sideshow'?
abstract: Media analysts are split as to whether alleged conflicts between Viacom Inc chairman-chief executive Sumner M Redstone and president-chief operating officer Mel Karmazin are real or silly sideshow; Merrill Lynch media analyst Jessica Reif Cohen says company's future, and success of its stock, depends greatly on two men's reconciling, or at least pretending to do so (M)

headline: Goldman Names 3 Executives To Share Vice Chairman Post
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group names Lloyd C Blankfein, Robert K Steel and Robert S Kaplan as vice chairmen, title that was held only by Robert Hurst; J Michael Evans, Eric Mindich and Eric Schwartz will succeed Steel, who has run stocks division since 1998 (M)

headline: Qwest Is Planning Account Consolidation
abstract: Qwest Is Planning Account Consolidation Qwest Communications is planning to consolidate its account and is beginning a review to seek one agency to handle the assignment, said advertising executives who were told of the decision. Billings were estimated at $100 million.

headline: DataBank; Confidence Is Up. But the Market Isn't.
abstract: Stocks fall modestly for the week on investors' fear that continuing improvement in economic data will result in spike in interest rates; charts and graphs (L)

headline: John Robson, 71, Longtime Official Who Led U.S. Export-Import Bank
abstract: John E Robson, whose leadership as president and chairman of Export-Import Bank of United States helped shape Bush administration's trade and foreign policy agenda, dies at 71 (S)

headline: Kmart's Debt to Sara Lee
abstract: Sara Lee Corp, in Securities and Exchange Commission filing, says Kmart Corp owed it $40 million at time discount retailer filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last month (S)

headline: The Mystery of the Disappearing Jobs
abstract: WHERE did all the jobs go - and why?      That was the puzzle last week after the New York State Department of Labor revealed that 132,400 jobs vanished in New York City last year, many of them well before Sept. 11. The new job loss tally is one-third higher than the numbers crunchers had estimated as recently as January.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Croatia: General Denies War Crimes
abstract: Croatian general, Mirko Norac, pleads not guilty to murder of Serb civilians in Gospic in 1991 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bridgestone Profit Slips
abstract: Bridgestone Corp says profit fell 6.9 percent in last six months of 2001; Bridgestone/Firestone Inc, US unit, lost $201 million in half-year, almost twice as much as in 2000 period; Bridgestone earned pretax profit of 42.9 billion yen ($320 million) (S)

headline: His Thoughts About Her Earning Their Keep
abstract: Ellyn Spragins column gives sampling of e-mail she received from men whose wives earn more than they do; their feelings run the gamut, with some men citing issue as major factor in fragile marriage or in breakup of one and others amazed that higher-earning wife could possibly cause problems in this day and age; drawing (M)

headline: Auditor Proposes Changes
abstract: Ernst & Young said it would stop selling information services to clients and quit being internal accountant and external auditor. Page C1.

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: Second Act for Hong Kong Billionaire
abstract: Pacific Century CyberWorks chief executive Richard Li, whose rose and fell faster than perhaps any Internet executive in Asia, has adopted new vocabulary that stresses responsibility, patience, even dash of humility; company, which nearly sank under weight of its $28 billion acquisition of Hong Kong's local telephone company in 1999, reports profit of $243 million for 2001, compared to loss of $886 million in 2000; Li says he wants to offer array of information technology services to large companies in mainland China; photo (M)

headline: Sun Aims to Extend a Lead
abstract: Sun Microsystems plans ambitious effort for wireless Internet, market in which its Java programming language is already widely used; will roll out new set of Web services standards intended as alternative to Microsoft's .Net and announce wide range of alliances with global lineup of wireless carriers and handset makers; at stake is potentially huge market for interactive mobile services; photos (M)

headline: Dialing, Without Fingers
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column assesses voice-dialing products for home developed by Siemens, ArialPhone and Digital Acoustics; drawing; photo (M)

headline: U.N. to Open Rights Review With U.S. On Sidelines
abstract: United Nations Human Rights Commission is set to begin annual review of abuses worldwide amid concerns that international commitment to human rights is being eroded by war against terrorism; human rights campaigners have accused United States, Russia, China and other countries of adopting security measures that jeopardize basic rights (M)

headline: Questions Arise on Law School Dean's Enron Duties
abstract: William C Powers Jr, dean of University of Texas Law School, has sat on board of Enron Corp since October 2001 and heads internal investigation of partnerships that hid company's losses, and critics say he should consider giving up one or the other position, especially in view of other close ties between law school and Enron; Powers argues that none of his relationships with company and its executives affect his impartiality; photo (M)

headline: Investing; Optimism Returns For Airline Stocks
abstract: Many analysts are recommending airline stocks despite lingering effects of Sept 11 and economic slowdown; some favor no-frills carriers while others find more potential -- with more risk -- in major, established lines; graph (M)

headline: A Gesture by Pakistan's President Is Not Enough for India
abstract: Pakistan's military ruler, Gen Pervez Musharraf, offers his hand to Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee at summmit meeting of South Asian leaders in Katmandu, Nepal, and Vajpayee shakes it but says he he has had enough of symbolic gestures from Pakistan and expects Pakistan to halt terrorist acts against India carried out by groups operating from Pakistan; Musharraf condemns terrorism but does not claim any responsibility on Pakistan's part for Islamic groups waging 'holy war' against India in Kashmir; photo (M)

headline: Land O' Lakes Ordered to Pay Inventor
abstract: Land O' Lakes Inc is ordered to pay more than $3 million for infringing Dr William Pordy's patent for low-fat dairy coffee creamer (S)

headline: Europe Seethes as the U.S. Flies Solo in World Affairs
abstract: Europe's unconditional solidarity with Bush administration, declared in shock of Sept 11 terrorist attack on US, is fading in face of Pres Bush's desire to expand war on terrorism to Iraq; Europeans thought Washington's work to build vast international coalition against terrorism meant new willingness to work more closely with allies; European officials now sense they must shout to be heard in warlike, messianic Washington; Europe is regional power with global ambitions that have more to do with civilian power, aid and trade, than military might (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: G.A.O. Sues Vice President, Seeking Energy Records  The General Accounting Office, an arm of Congress, sued Vice President Dick Cheney to try to force the White House to reveal the identities of energy industry executives who helped the administration develop a national energy policy last year.    It was the first time in the G.A.O.'s 80-year history that the agency had filed suit against a member of the executive branch for failing to turn over records to Congress. [Page A1.]

headline: Shell Oil To Acquire Pennzoil
abstract: Shell Oil Co, US affiliate of Royal Dutch/Shell, agrees to acquire Pennzoil-Quaker State Co for about $1.8 billion in cash; offer, which translates into $22 per share, amounts to 42 percent over $15.49 closing price on March 25; Shell will also assume about $1.1 billion in Pennzoil debt (M)

headline: U.N. Takes Swing at Crooks Who Steal Aid for the Poor
abstract: Leaders of UN conference on aid and economic development in Monterrey, Mexico, say corruption among governments, politicians and businessmen is endangering world's efforts to ease poverty; say untangling criminal webs that cripple aid efforts will take years (M)

headline: Lucent Finally Chooses a Chief Executive
abstract: Lucent Technologies, the troubled telecommunications equipment giant, ended its long search for a chief executive yesterday by naming Patricia F. Russo, who was a top executive at the company before leaving 17 months ago.    By rehiring Ms. Russo from Eastman Kodak, where she was president and chief operating officer, Lucent sent a clear message: the company does not plan a major departure from its current management policies as it tries to return to profitability. Lucent lost more than $16 billion and cut or spun off more than 70,000 jobs in the last year and a half.

headline: U.S. MIGHT PURSUE QAEDA AND TALIBAN TO PAKISTAN LAIRS
abstract: American forces in Afghanistan might cross border into Pakistan to capture or kill Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters thought to have found sanctuary there; Maj Gen Franklin L Hagenbeck, commander of American forces, says such an effort would be 'last resort' carried out with approval of Pakistani leaders; American troops are attacked from several directions just 20 miles from border with Pakistan, near Khost; Hagenbeck says it is not clear whether Americans were caught in fighting between Afghan factions or had come under attack from Taliban or Al Qaeda fighters; one American soldier is injured; photo (M)

headline: Did NBC Let Lay's Wife Get Around Hard Issues?
abstract: Article on whether NBC News correspondent Lisa Myers got around hard issues when she interviewed Linda Lay, wife of former Enron Corp chief executive Kenneth L Lay; questions whether Myers shirked her duty by failing to grill Mrs Lay on details of where all money went during interview on Today show (M)

headline: Intel Names Heir Apparent For Chief Executive Position
abstract: Intel Corp names Paul S Otellini as president and chief operting officer, grooming him to take over company as chief executive when Craig R Barrett retires within three years (M)

headline: NEWPORT, AN EQUIPMENT MAKER, BUYS MICRO ROBOTICS
abstract: Newport Corp plans to acquire Micro Robotics Systems for $55 million to $65 million in cash and stock; Micro Robotics makes assembly and dispensing systems for fiber optic communications (S)

headline: When He Talks For Mexico, Washington Pays Attention
abstract: Article profiles Mexico's influential Foreign Minister Jorge G Castaneda, who has helped improve Mexico's political stature in its dealings with US and who is being counted on by Pres Vicente Fox to win gains for Mexico at upcoming summit with Pres Bush in Monterrey; photo (M)

headline: I.B.M. to Expand on 2001 Annual Report
abstract: IBM will give investors 'road map' to explain data in its 2001 annual report, as company answers requests for more detail in financial statements (S)

headline: Captured Fugitive Charged in Tax Case
abstract: Justice Department charges Keith Anderson, leader of Anderson's Ark & Associates, with helping as many as 2,000 people cheat government out of $30 million in taxes from 1998 to 2001; Anderson was arrested on Feb 9 in Costa Rica on money-laundering charge more than 11 months after 14 Anderson's Ark offices were raided in largest criminal enforcement action ever conducted by Internal Revenue Service (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Jordan: Unrest In Southern City
abstract: jordan:

headline: Not Wanted: '02 Graduates Seeking Jobs
abstract: When the millions of students who are set to graduate from college this spring started out in the late 1990's, the stock market was on a bull run and the dot-com frenzy was in full swing. At colleges across the country, career-services offices fashioned makeshift interview booths to accommodate the companies on a hiring binge.    Fresh-faced 22-year-olds commanded signing bonuses of $10,000 or more. People with bachelor's degrees in engineering or computer science often had a dozen job offers, some with six-figure salaries. Liberal arts majors found plenty of opportunities, too, working for Internet companies and consulting and financial firms.

headline: OUTLOOK: Markets & Investing; Initial Public Offerings in 2001
abstract: Most of initial public offerings outperformed benchmark indexes like Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq composite index in 2001; list (M)

headline: FORSTMANN LITTLE TO SELL PART OF STAKE IN CANDLE MAKER
abstract: Forstmann Little plans to raise about $200 million by selling one-third of its stake in Yankee Candle Co (S)

headline: Brazil's Prized Exports Rely On Slaves and Scorched Land
abstract: Brazil, last country in Americas to abolish slavery, is relying increasingly on forced labor to exploit and develop Amazon's vast agricultural frontier, in part to supply foreign markets with two prized goods, namely, timber and beef; government authorities admit, despite federal crackdown announced seven years ago, contemporary forms of slavery in which workers are held in unpaid, coerced labor continue to flourish; reasons range from ranchers in cahoots with corrupt local authorities to ineffective land reform policies and high unemployment; photos; charts; maps (L)

headline: Big Builder In Germany Is Bankrupt
abstract: Germany's Philipp Holzmann construction conglomerate declares bankruptcy; Chancellor Gerhard Schroder calls up top bank executives to push for bailout, but he stays in background and refuses to offer any government money to help bring deal together; Deutsche Bank is only big German bank supporting rescue because it has most to lose (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Air Traffic Picks Up
abstract: Singapore Airlines says one-third of its seats were vacant in November, compared with nearly 37 percent in October; number of passengers carried in November was 12.9 percent lower than same month in 2000; amount of cargo fell 8.5 percent in same period; airline will cut costs by offering buyouts and early retirement to workers other than air crews; graph (S)

headline: Promotions at Federated
abstract: Terry J Lundgren, president of Federated Department Stores, is promoted to chief operating officer; James M Zimmerman's contract as chief executive is extended by at least a year (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: AMERICAS.

headline: In Other Cities, the Grass Is Browner
abstract: New York City's big job losses in wake of Sept 11 terrorism discussed in context of national recession; some of job losses linked to terrorism may be temporary; losses elsewhere have been in industries involved in making things; map (M)

headline: Parolees and Security
abstract: Robert P Weiss letter opposes satellite tarcking for parolees (Jan 31 article)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Big Arms Sale To Malaysia
abstract: Malaysia reports bu

headline: One Chief Will Resign At Verizon
abstract: Charles R Lee is stepping down as co-chief executive of Verizon Communications, accelerating process to make Ivan G Seidenberg only chief executive (M)

headline: Viacom Has Loss but Sees Hope
abstract: Viacom Inc reports fourth-quarter loss of $42.5 million in contrast to net income of $30.4 million year earlier; revenue fell 5 percent, to $6.04 billion; says it has agreed to buy KCAL-TV in Los Angeles from Young Broadcasting Inc for $650 million in cash (S)

headline: Group Will Finance Public Service Effort
abstract: Direct Marketing Association will lead effort to raise money to help pay production costs for public service campaign to promote freedom, effort coordinated by Advertising Council in New York; association selects ad agency Wunderman to develop marketing campaign (S)l

headline: West Bank Suicide Bombing Kills 2 Israelis and Hurts 30
abstract: Suicide bomber detonates explosive package in outdoor food court of West Bank settlement of Karnei Shomron, killing himself and two Israelis and injuring 30 others; bombing follows already deadly day in West Bank and Gaza Strip; Palestinian militants are testing new tactics in stepped-up exchange of attack and retaliation and Israeli Army is searching for new ways to strike back; Israeli soldiers in Gaza kill three Palestinians in gun battle; leader of Hamas in West Bank city of Jenin dies in explosion that Palestinians say is Israeli assassination; Palestinian militants fire rockets into Israeli Army base in northern Gaza Strip, damaging building; Hamas militants fire rockets from Gaza into Israel, injuring no one but drawing new warnings of retaliation for what Israeli officials consider marked escalation in fighting; photo (M)

headline: Study Puts Finland First, and U.S. 51st, in Environmental Health
abstract: New study of 142 countries ranks Finland first in world in environmental health, followed by Norway, Sweden, Canada and Switzerland; US ranks 51st; five worst are Haiti, Iraq, North Korea, Kuwait and United Arab Emirates; study by Yale and Columbia environmental centers for World Economic Forum notes that although economic wealth does not necessarily correlate with healthy environment, level of corruption does (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Mobile Phone Growth
abstract: International Telecommunications Union says number of mobile phones worldwide grew 40 percent in 2001 and will soon outstrip 1.045 billion fixed lines (S)

headline: Scrambling To Regain Its Cool
abstract: Alex Berenson column says Enron scandal may cloud prospects for stock market recovery for some time, citing parallels with 1973 case of Equity Funding Corp of America; says scandal should move regulators to force companies to report cost of executive stock options as real expense (M)

headline: Accounting Worries Hurt European Phone Stocks
abstract: Concerns over questionable accounting practice spread to European telecommunications stocks, causing some to tumble; practice, in which telecommunications companies swap capacity on each other's networks and record deals as revenue even when no cash changes hands, has come under scrutiny in Washington, where Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating how Global Crossing accounted for $100 million of such deals with Qwest Communications International; Europe's Cable and Wireless and KPNQwest have been criticized for using swap transactions (M)

headline: Tyco Shares Plunge On Growing Worries Of a Cash Squeeze
abstract: Tyco International shares fall sharply after company loses access to commercial paper market, major source of financing for big companies and Fitch Ratings and Standard & Poor's cut Tyco's bond ratings; chairman L Dennis Kozlowski says Tyco arranged added $1.5 billion credit line two weeks ago and decided to draw it down last week to ensure it would have adequate cash (M)

headline: Pope Accepts Polish Archbishop's Resignation
abstract: Pope John Paul II accepts resignation of Archbishop Juliusz Paetz, high-ranking Polish prelate accused of molesting young seminarians; pope bows to pressure to resolve sex scandal that has torn church in intensely Catholic Poland; Paetz repeats his denial of any wrongdoing; holds that his words and gestures were misinterpreted; tells priests and lay people in cathedral in Poznan that his resignation is result of his desire for 'unity and stability' among Polish Catholics; this is second time this month that pope is obliged to accept resignation of senior prelate accused of sexual molestation; in earlier case, he accepted resignation of Bishop Anthony J O'Connell of Palm Beach,, Fla (M)

headline: Enron Sought To Raise Cash Two Years Ago
abstract: Former Enron Corp say company might have been able to avoid bankruptcy if it had completed deal in summer of 2000 to sell bulk of its international energy holdings for about $7 billion to group composed primarily of wealthy Middle Eastern investors; note that deal was was being negotiated at time when Enron was desperate for cash; say negotations broke down after Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al-Nahayan, president of United Arab Emirates and crucial foreign backer of proposed transaction, was hospitalized with kidney problems; say it was after this deal was terminated that executives gave task of improving company's finances to Andrew S Fastow (M)

headline: AES Says It Will Sell Assets And Cut Capital Spending
abstract: AES Corp, electricity producer

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Compaq Introduces New Server
abstract: Compaq Computer introduces its smallest server computer called ProLiant B e-Class, or blade server, to compete for sales of low-end systems (S)

headline: Taliban and War Deliver a Double Blow to Villagers
abstract: Shah-i-Kot, collection of mountain villages in eastern Afghanistan that is scene of fierce fighting between US-led forces and those of Al Qaeda and Taliban, is dealt double blow; residents were forced to leave by Taliban who favored it as place to make last stand; was home to mujahedeen base in 1980's during war against Russians, and is considered hallowed ground; is currently being destroyed by bombs dropped by US warplanes; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: 2 Companies Announce Services Deal
abstract: IBM announces seven-year agreement to manage computing systems of American Express; deal is valued at more than $4 billion (S)

headline: India Reacts With Anger To a Speech By Pakistani
abstract: Recent speech by Pakistan's President Gen Pervez Musharraf heightens doubts about whether Pakistan will end its support for Islamic groups waging guerrilla war against India in Kashmir; Musharraf portrays Kashmir as representing struggle of indigenous freedom fighters battling Indian oppression and state terrorism; Indian officials react harshly; Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee declares that India will not give up Kashmir, and hawkish Home Minister L K Advani says Musharraf's renewed promise of diplomatic and political support to rebels in Kashmir is 'smoke screen' to aid and abet cross-border terrorism aimed at India (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Economy Slumps
abstract: Taiwan's gross domestic product fell 1.9 percent in fourth quarter of 2001, third consecutive decline; economy shrank 1.9 percent for all of 2001 (S)2

headline: Gap Has Loss; Federated Net Off
abstract: Gap Inc reports fourth-quarter loss; Federated Department Stores says earnings dropped 23 percent; Gap had loss of $34.2 million in quarter ended Feb 2 compared with net income of $271.8 million; sales at stores open at least year dropped 16 percent; announces it plans to sell $1 billion of convertible bonds in effort to improve results; Federated had profit from continuing operations of $310 million; sales at stores open at least year fell 6 percent (M)

headline: A Contract Dispute Keeps NBC Viewers Waiting for Naught
abstract: Entertainment deals are often made on the basis of a handshake, but NBC and its latest late-night star, Carson Daly, were mostly shaking fists at each other Monday night over an unsigned contract that resulted in a last-minute pre-emption of the premiere of Mr. Daly's show.    The move left more than a million viewers befuddled, wondering what had happened to a show that NBC promoted heavily for weeks. Mr. Daly has gained fame as the host of MTV's popular afternoon music and interview program, ''Total Request Live,'' and on Monday he taped his first NBC program, with the singer Alicia Keys as the guest.

headline: Keen Rivalry By Consultants Expected After Auditors' Shift
abstract: The shift away from consulting by big accounting firms is likely to lead to new and intense competition over clients as independent firms aggressively pursue companies that have bought consulting services from their auditors in the past.    Those firms could be joined by consulting businesses that are being spun off from two of the Big Five. But the soon-to-be-independent firms face a very poor market, analysts say, in part because accountants' consulting units have been indirectly tainted by the collapse of Enron, whose auditor, Arthur Andersen, also sold the company consulting services. In addition, the consulting industry has been in a slump for more than a year because of the recession, making the businesses even more unattractive.

headline: Partner Is Expected to Resist Bristol
abstract: ImClone Systems is expected to reject demands of Bristol-Myers Squibb to restructure their $2 billion partnership because it would eviscerate profits ImClone would receive from its cancer drug, Erbitux; Bristol-Myers has demanded that ImClone change deal announced last September in which it paid $1 billion for 19.9 percent stake in ImClone and agreed to pay $1 billion more for rights to sell Erbitux; ImClone's application for drug was rejected by Food and Drug Administration in December (M)

headline: WHIRLPOOL LASHES OUT AT SPECULATION ON ITS EARNINGS
abstract: Whirlpool Corp affirms accuracy of its quarterly earnings and says it is considering legal remedies after its shares dropped 9.7 percent on Feb 6 on report by Briefing.com that stock traders speculated company's earnings included 'nonoperating items' (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: S.& P. Cuts Hewlett Rating
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp lowers Hewlett-Packard Co's credit rating, saying falling profit and planned purchase of Compaq Computer Corp puts company at financial risk (S)

headline: Panel Finds Rush to Hide Losses and Enrich a Few
abstract: NewsAnalysis.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Liechtenstein: Money Laundering Cases Increase
abstract: Authorities say tougher enforcement in Liechtenstein resulted in doubling of reports of suspected money laundering by banks last year; new watchdog agency was set up after Liechtenstein was listed on international roll of countries that failed to adequately fight corrupt money flow; it has since been dropped from list (S)

headline: Liberty Ready for Rejection from Germany
abstract: Liberty Media has begun to scout for new acquisition targets in Europe, having all but given up on hopes of receiving regulatory clearance for its proposed $4.8 billion acquisition of German cable assets.

headline: In Unusual Deal, Chile Will Buy Advanced U.S. Fighter Jets
abstract: Government of Chile says it will buy 10 F-16 fighter jets from United States, with blessing of Bush administration, in sale valued at $660 million; sale represents first time in two decades that Washington has approved transfer of sophisticated weapons to Latin American country; Clinton administration lifted ban on such sales in 1998, saying it would consider them on case-by-base basis (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: REED SMITH, Pittsburgh, an international law firm with more than 700 lawyers, merged with Parker Duryee Rosoff & Haft, New York, a law firm with 26 lawyers.    JAKKS PACIFIC, Malibu, Calif., a toy maker, acquired closely held Kids Biz, Ewell Village, England, a toy maker and distributor, to expand its sales in Europe. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Dispute Involving Indian Businessman Tarnishes Blair's Image
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair is defending self-proclaimed reputation for clean government from attacks by opposition Conservatives and in media over July 2001 letter to Romanian government backing sale of steel company there to Lakshmi Mittal, London-based businessman who weeks before donated $180,000 to Blair's Labor Party; denies any wrongdoing; says he was unaware of donation when he signed letter and would have taken same action even if he had known; government is under fire over reports that Mittal's companies gave $600,000 to American group lobbying Bush administration to impose 40% tariff on overseas steel imports, move British steel industry vigorously opposes; central feature of Blair's 1997 campaign that returned him to power was repeated claim that Conservatives were party of 'sleaze' and that his government would be 'whiher than white' if re-elected; photos (M)

headline: Trend-spotting:new spins on old techniques
abstract: PARISâ€”  Not that long ago, one of the thrills of traveling abroad was to shop for something distinctly different from what one could find at home. But no longer. Today the only difference between a pair of jeans bought in New York, Sydney or London is the price.

headline: Riyadh Journal; Taking a Rare Peek Inside the Royal House of Saud
abstract: Saudi crown prince Abdullah Bin Abdul Aziz al-Saud receives more than 300 intellectuals and clerics at royal palace in Riyadh to open annual two-week folklore extravaganza; reception described; photo (M)

headline: Differences In Congress On Fuel Use
abstract: Sen John Kerry, who is presiding over Senate Commerce Committee hearings on auto fuel-economy standards, supports tax credits for consumers who buy vehicles powered by hybrid gasoline-electric engines; Democratic Congressional aides say Kerry will press to apply more stringent requirements than those passed by House to determine which vehicles receive credits; House energy bill includes tax credits ranging from $250 to $4,500 (M)

headline: Public Funds Say Losses Top $1.5 Billion
abstract: Pension funds for union members, teachers, government employees and other workers across US have lost more than $1.5 billion because of sharp decline in their Enron holdings; in Ohio, state's two pension funds for government employees lost $114 million, while California's pension fund for teachers lost $49 million and New York City's firefighters, police officers, teachers and other workers lost $109 million; fund managers have reacted to losses with mixed message; they are outraged at Enron, accusing it of fraud, yet at same time are ressuring retirees and workers that losses are such small part of their multibillion-dollar portfolios that pension payments will generally not be affected (M)

headline: Japan Economy Contracts for 3rd Consecutive Quarter
abstract: Japan's economy contracted sharply in fourth quarter of 2001, by 1.2 percent; for all of 2001, economy contracted 0.5 percent; most economists expect Japan's economy to go on shrinking in 2002, though not so rapidly, and for growth not to resume until 2003; yen rallies to nearly 127 to dollar; Nikkei stock index gains 2.6 percent, to 11,648.34; Japan's house approves $630 billion federal budget, which is 1.7 percent smaller than last year's and smallest since 1998 (M)

headline: Will Autos Be a Part Of the Future For Fiat?
abstract: Article on whether automobiles will be part of future of Italian conglomerate Fiat SpA; says speculation got boost from news reports that members of Angelli family, Fiat's principal shareholders, were complaining that losses at car division were draining resources from more lucrative investments; holds Fiat, under chairman Paolo Fresco, has been evolving into modern conglomerate (M)

headline: Architects fear boutique craze is going too far
abstract: WASHINGTONâ€”  Fashion's flirtation with architecture has led to a new generation of over-the-top boutiques. But the design elite is still struggling to embrace the shop-til-you-drop movement.

headline: F.C.C. to Refund Wireless Auction Money
abstract: Verizon Wireless and other mobile phone carriers will receive $2.8 billion from Federal Communications Commission, portion of what they paid year ago for disputed airwaves held by NextWave Telecom; FCC says it will refund 85 perent of down payments carriers made after $15.9 billion sale of licenses last year; agency is contesting court decision that overturned auction and gave licenses to NextWave, which is in bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: Enron Selling Wessex Water for $777 Million
abstract: Enron Corp agrees to sell Wessex Water, British utility, to YTL Corp, Malaysian energy and construction company, for $777 million in cash (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: EMI Expects Lower Profit
abstract: EMI Group says full-year profit will fall 42 percent; pretax profit will be about 150 million pounds ($214 million), down from 260 million pounds year earlier; names Roger Faxon as chief financial officer; David Munns will be chief executive of EMI Recorded Music North America; graph (S)

headline: Active Investors Take European Boards to Task
abstract: LONDONâ€”  With the Enron affair throwing a spotlight on how companies are managed, European stockholders, long considered more docile than their American counterparts, are mounting a vigorous quest for improved accountability.

headline: Mexican Leader Visits Castro to Repair Damaged Ties
abstract: Pres Vicente Fox of Mexico meets with Cuba's Pres Fidel Castro in Havana in effort to restore century-old diplomatic relationship, built on shared history of popular revolutions but damaged in recent years as Mexico began transition to multiparty democracy; cordial 24-hour visit focuses on Mexico's desire to improve commercial ties with Cuba, which ruptured in early 1990's with enactment of new trade restrictions against Cuba in US; photo (M)

headline: Army Official Kept Options On Enron Stock Until January
abstract: Thomas E White, former top executive of Enron Corp who is now Army secretary, promised to give up any financial interest in Enron when he became Army secretary, but held options to buy 665,000 shares until early 2002; letters released by Senate Armed Services Committee show after he became secretary in May 2001, White provided only fragmented disclosures about his stock options to Army ethics officials; show he sought and received extension to dispose of his stock, but even after he sold 380,000 Enron shares for more than $10 million, he continued to hold options, without approval of ethics officials; White forfeited his options on an 17 after discussion between Army's general counsel and staff members for Armed Serices Committee; Sens Carl Levin and John W Warner have criticized White's handling of options, as well as $688 per month annuity White received from Enron in exchange for turning in stock he had held in retirement plan; chart; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: North and South Korea to Resume Dialogue
abstract: North and South Korea, in surprise effort to resume long-stalled dialogue, will exchange high-level envoys and initiate series of other political contacts beginning in April 2002; Lim Dong Wan, special presidential adviser for diplomacy and national security, leaves for North Korea as special envoy (S)

headline: Grand Jury Being Misused As Investigator, Andersen Says
abstract: Lawyers for Arthur Andersen file motion seeking to block prosecutors from using federal grand jury to continue investigating document destruction that led to Andersen's indictment on charge of obstruction of justice; lawyers argue that federal prosecutors have improperly begun using grand jury to gather evidence to bolster their prosecution of Andersen, which they say is impermissible after filing of criminal indictment; filing contends Justice Department interviewed potential witnesses from Andersen before filing indictment; papers say prosecutors failed to compel testimony before grand jury from any of those witnesses (M)

headline: New Life for Networks
abstract: Analysis of Federal appeals court decision that could lead to reduction, or end, of limits on ownership of television stations; says this is latest positive turn for network television, industry that has had seven-year streak of improving regulatory conditions; says heavy lobbying and easing of fears about network monopolies have chipped away at generation of regulations imposed as far back as 1940's; recalls that only decade ago networks were being compared to dinosaur (M)

headline: After a Long Dry Spell, A Change at Invesco
abstract: Invesco Funds Group will replace Trent May and Douglas McEldowney as managers of $850 million Invesco Growth fund, which has had some of worst returns of diversified stock funds; Putnam Investments, which has been overhauling its fund lineup and stock-selection process in response to dismal performance of several of its growth funds in 2001, plans to shut one of its 66 funds and merge 10 others (S)

headline: India's Tea Industry Battles the Blues
abstract: Tea industry of India, world's leading producer, is suffering from glut in global tea production and slump in tea exports, which are result of global economics as well as inability to lure new, younger drinkers; prices are low even for premium Assam and Darjeeling tea crop, most of which is exported; producers are looking for new markets, even sending delegation to Afghanistan; quality of India teas has dropped considerable in last five years, as rising labor costs and declining yields have driven producers to trade quality for quantity, losing customers across country; photo (M)

headline: Leaner Factories, Fewer Workers Bring More Labor Unrest to China
abstract: Overhaul of China's moribund state industries enters decisive phase and public protests by displaced workers are becoming larger and angrier than ever; disputes over money and benefits, often peppered with charges of official corruption, have become frequent as China seeks to streamline or shed bloated state-owned factories; millions of middle-aged workers in particular say they feel betrayed by system that long gave them honor and security, if little money, and now seems intent on discarding them; unrest has not threatened rule of Communist Party, but growing disaffection has become major preoccupation; demonstrations over past month by tens of thousands of irate workers at Daqing oil field discussed; workers charge officials with deceit and betrayal, in what some experts say is largest protests over labor issues since Communiost Party took power in 1949; photos (M)

headline: Private Sector; A Dinner Honoring a Statue
abstract: Lower Manhattan dinner and auction will raise money for increased maintenance and security for New York Harbor and Statue of Liberty, closed since Sept 11 terrorist attacks; artist Peter Max, who donated painting to auction, comments; photo (S)

headline: Dollar Peg Nearing End In Argentina
abstract: Argentina's decade-long defense of fixed parity between its peso and US dollar appears to collapse, as country's new president, Eduardo Duhalde, signals that Argentina will soon officially devalue peso and as central bank stops requiring nation's banks to honor one-for-one exchange rate; Duhalde hopes to make Argentine goods more competitive abroad and end three-year recession; for borrowers, central bank's action effectively devalues peso by as much as 40 percent (M)

headline: Grimly, Palestinians Stay Tuned to News
abstract: Palestinians in Shatila refugee camp in Lebanon anxiously watch television news of violence in West Bank; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Siemens Posts Profit
abstract: Siemens AG earned 538 million euros ($477 million) in three months ended in December compared with 1 billion euro profit in quarter year earlier; chief executive Heinrich von Pierer; photo (S)

headline: An Eye on Derivatives
abstract: Accounting Standards Board advisory panel member Ira G Kawaller letter on Feb 24 article on derivative contracts that helped conceal Enron's problems holds derivatives are transparent unless used in special purpose vehicles or by subsidiaries

headline: Andeans Find Wreck of Jet; All 92 On Board Are Dead
abstract: Searchers in southern Colombia find wreckage of Ecuadorean airliner that crashed on Jan 28; Tama airline officials say all 92 people on board Boeing 727 were killed, revising earlier figure of 94 people on board; map; photo (M)

headline: Briefly Noted; ANTHRAX EXPOSURE?
abstract: Building at Army Reserve Command headquarters in Fort McPherson in Atlanta is evacuated after powder on mailed package tests positive for anthrax; package is taken to Centers for Disease Control for further tests (S)

headline: EQUIFAX CUTS 700 JOBS AND TAKES $37 MILLION CHARGE
abstract: Equifax Inc, consumer-credit reporting company, has eliminated 700 jobs, or about 12 percent of its work force, and has closed offices after July spinoff of payment-processing business, Certegy Inc (S)

headline: COMPUTER PART MAKER TO CUT 1,250 JOBS AFTER LOSS
abstract: Read-Rite Corp, maker of computer disk-drive parts, will lay off 1,250 workers in US and Thailand, 11 percent reduction; reports loss of $4.49 milion in fiscal first quarter ended Dec 31, compared to profit of $12.5 million year earlier; sales fell 28 percent, to $136.9 million from $190 million (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Dutch Ruling In Kazaa Case
abstract: Dutch appeals court overturns lower court ruling that prohibits distribution of popular computer program called Kazaa Media Desktop, which is used to trade music and movies over Internet; court rules that distributor Sharman Networks is not liable for unauthorized copies of material made by people who use software (M)

headline: Singapore Stunned as Ordinary Men Are Tied to Terror
abstract: Focus on Singapore's arrest of 13 men as members of clandestine Islamic Group organization, which allegedly has links to Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda terrorist network; many citizens are unsettled to find that accused are fellow Singaporeans and that extreme radicalism has flourished in sanitized and efficient city-state (M)

headline: Man Who Fatally Shot 8 French Officials Jumps to His Death
abstract: Richard Durn, man arrested in shooting rampage that killed eight local officials in Paris suburb of Nanterre, kills himself by jumping from fourth-floor window of police interrogation room; police say they were unable to prevent his fall; judicial investigation is ordered into circumstances of his death, amid questions of how Durn, with known history of mental illness and with stated wish to die, was allowed enough freedom of movement to open window and thrust himself through (M)

headline: Do Stock Options Buy Silence?
abstract: Jeffrey L Seglin column notes that there were only a few whistle-blowers among Enron's 20,000 employees and suggests reason may be that around 60 percent of company's rank-and-file employees held stock options; says role of stock options in improving employee performance can also be questioned; cartoon (M)

headline: Disney Is Said to Balk At Promise to Koppel
abstract: Ted Koppel wants ironclad and lasting commitment for future of Nightline at 11:35 pm; Walt Disney Co, ABC's parent, is not yet ready to give it; climate inside news division remains tense after David Letterman announces his intention to remain at CBS; some people at ABC News say they are concerned that angry statement issued by Koppel and his producers after Letterman's announcement is warning shot that threatens larger confrontation should Disney fail to guarantee that program will remain in its time slot for substantial period of time; they believe Disney is not ready to make that kind of commitment (M)

headline: Foreign Followers of Falun Gong Held by Police in Beijing Protest
abstract: More than 40 Western followers of the outlawed movement were detained today after they staged protests on Tiananmen Square.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Loss At Telekom
abstract: Deutsche Telekom reports loss of 3.5 billion euros in 2001, in contrast to profit of 5.9 billion euros year earlier (S)

headline: Council Leader Says Euro Is Just a Start
abstract: Rodrigo Rato, Spain's economic minister and new chairman of European Union's council of finance ministers, says European Union countries must seize 'great opportunities' for economic growth and put structural changes in place if they want to compete with US; Rato hopes to get governments to commit themselves to concrete targets and deadlines for change at union's summit meeting in Barcelona in March; putting pressure on Argentina to come up with credible plan to address its fiscal crisis is also high on Rato's agenda; says euro's continuing weakness against dollar is sign that 'markets think that the US economy's ability to grow is still superior to that of European economy, and that therefore economic recovery in US will be stronger and more durable'; photo (M)

headline: Legacies, Left Unsaid
abstract: AARP reports that people who want to leave an inheritance often fail to develop asset inventory and discuss plans with heirs (S)

headline: Israelis Exploring Market for Security Services in U.S.
abstract: Israelis offering security technology and services have been pouring into US looking for new clients, investors and partners; airline-security specialists from Israel have begun to advise American airports on how to protect against terrorist attack; veterans of Israeli military, intelligence and security forces have formed consulting groups, hoping to find work with government agencies and corporations in US; Israeli government will introduce about 40 of country's security and technology companies to few hundred potential customers in US at conference in New York; Ehud Barak, former Israeli prime minister, will address conference; Beth-El Industries is dominant Israeli producer of systems that detect biological or chemical weapons; photo of Beth-El Industries general manager Albrecht Fuchs demonstrating filtration device; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Dominican Republic, Haiti: Development Plan
abstract: Dominican Republic and Haiti agree to joint economic development projects aimed at providing jobs for Haitians living on countries' common borders (S)

headline: U.S. Rules Out Training Indonesia Army, but Will Aid Its Antiterror Police
abstract: Bush administration decides against sending troops to Indonesia, world's most populous Muslim nation, because of concerns about anti-American backlash; say best way to pursue terrorists operating from Indonesia is to work through law enforcement agencies; American intelligence officials believe Indonesia is fertile breeding ground for Al Qaeda, and that country is center of operations for group that has planned attacks on American targets throughout Southeast Asia; US policy toward Indonesia is being closely watched around world; Indonesia presents test case of how administration handles presence of terrorist cells in nation opposed to American military intervention (M)

headline: Thousands of Jobs Expected to Be Cut At G.M. and Ford
abstract: The two largest American automakers are expected to announce the elimination of at least 15,000 jobs this week.    General Motors plans to offer buyouts to about 5,000 white-collar workers as part of continuing belt-tightening in an automotive industry reckoning with recession. Later this week, analysts expect that Ford Motor will cut more than 10,000 jobs as part of a major restructuring plan. Ford officials declined to comment today on reports that as many as 20,000 jobs would be eliminated.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: New Interest In Hynix
abstract: Germany's Infineon Technology may be competing with Micron Technology in bid to take over Hynix Semiconductor (S)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Kelly Apostolidis, manager for national media outreach at the Advertising Council, New York, was promoted to director.

headline: Belgium Seeks Arms Dealer With Suspected Qaeda Ties
abstract: Belgian authorities issue arrest warrant for Victor Bout, former Soviet air force officer and one of world's most notorious arms traffickers, who is suspected of supplying weapons to Taliban and Al Qaeda and pouring huge arms shipments into Africa's civil wars (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: *Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Company Town Keeps Indians at Home
abstract: Catalytic Software is developing New Oroville, township of dome-shaped dwellings near Hyderabad, India, to keep Indian software developers working in India instead of migrating to United States; township offers many Western comforts; US-based Catalytic maintains small sales, marketing and training force in US and will develop software mainly in Oroville; chief executive Swain Porter comments; map; photo (M)

headline: Giving the Internet A Run for the Roses
abstract: Online Shopper describes shopping online for flowers; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Visit By Japanese Leader
abstract: Japanese Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi visits South Korea in bid to promote good will before World Cup soccer finals, which two nations will host; will meet with Pres Kim Dae Jung; photo (S)

headline: Networks Erroneously Report U.S. Reporter's Death
abstract: ABC News and Fox News Channel erroneously report body of Daniel Pearl, Wall Street Journal reporter kidnapped in Pakistan, was found dumped on roadside in Karachi (M)

headline: Executive Life; To Foster Your Star Quality, Get an Agent
abstract: Some senior corporate executives are hiring agents to keep their careers on track and negotiate deals; most agencies are one- or two-person shops catering to executives at medium-sized firms; some experts say using agent could backfire by creating doubt in prospective employers' minds about depth of candidate's commitment; photo (M)

headline: Japan Food Company Battles New Scandal
abstract: Japan's Snow Brand Milk Products is scrambling to find rescuer before it collapses in wake of two major scandals involving its products in 18 months; says it hopes to conclude deal by end of its fiscal year on March 31; Moody's Investors Service downgrades company's rating; Snow Brand's meatpacking subsidiary was accused last month of illegally repackaging imported beef to make it appear to be domestic and qualify for special government subsidies; criminal investigation has begun; president Kohei Nishi says he is aggressively seeking alliances and that foreign companies are being courted; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Democrats Try to Surpass Bush In Tough Post-Enron Fraud Laws
abstract: Senate Democrats try to draw sharp contrast with Pres Bush's response to collapse of Enron Corp, proposing laws that would increase criminal penalties for certain coporate wrongdoing and give state attorneys general new powers to sue companies; Senate majority leader Tom Daschle says Bush's proposals offer 'only the illusion of reform' and 'lacked any kind of new punishment for corporate fraud, even the kind of corporate fraud that cost thousands of people their life savings or their retirement security'; specifics of Democrats' proposals outlined (M)

headline: Compressed Data; In France, Scents Waft Over the Web
abstract: Burgundy wine industry's association introduces at Paris agricultural fair virtual Web tour of Burgundy region, complete with smells; project is showcase for France Telecom software for diffusion of odors over network; uses diffuser unit triggered by computer to pump out fragrances; drawing (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: TELECOMMUNICATIONSQWEST DROPS PLAN TO USE CUSTOMER DATA Qwest Communications, the big telecommunications company, said it would shelve a plan to share customer information among its divisions. At the beginning of the year, the company sent its customers a pamphlet describing new ways that it planned to make commercial use of its customers' records and data. Privacy advocates strongly objected, saying they did not want more promotional mail from Qwest affiliates.

headline: Egypt Hopes for Free Trade Pact With U.S.
abstract: Egypt wants free trade agreement with US; Egypt's economy has taken beating since last year's terrorist attacks, mainly from sharp falloff in international tourism; Egypt says it needs help to help build up trade with US beyond fairly modest $4.2 billion in volume recorded last year; American officials say odds remain long of such pact, and Egypt is not yet in shape to reap full benefit of trade deal (M)

headline: Teachers flee poverty and repression : Zimbabwe brain drain
abstract: According to an old African proverb, knowledge is like a garden:

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Network Makes Bid for Spinoff
abstract: Network Associates Inc makes unsolicited $248 million bid to reabsorb its spinoff, McAfee.com Corp; Network Associates, which sells antivirus software in stores under McAfee brand, spun company off in 1999 to test waters for selling software online; graph (S)

headline: Archbishop of Canterbury to Retire
abstract: The Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. George Carey leader of 73 million Anglicans across 160 nations, announced today that he will step down this fall.

headline: Colombian Troops Begin Retaking Rebel-Held Territory
abstract: Elite government troops in Colombia land in Florencia in swath of southern jungle that Pres Andres Pastrana ceded to Marxist rebels three years ago so peace talks could take place; soldiers are retaking land now that Pastrana has broken off talks in furious reaction to recent rebel hijacking of domestic airliner and kidnapping of senior senator on board; Secretary of State Colin L Powell tells reporters that Washington supports Pastrana's decision to retake rebel zone; photos; map (M)

headline: U.S. Broadens Terror Fight, Readying Troops for Yemen
abstract: Pres Bush has approved plans to send as many as 100 troops, mostly Special Forces, to train Yemeni military to fight terrorists, specifically Al Qaeda fighters hiding in country; increasingly broad campaign stirs Democratic complaints that administration demands virually unlimited funds without answering to Congress; latest operations aim to crush isolated but potent Islamic insurgents; Special Forces would be limited to training and equipping nations requesting help, but not calling in air strikes; Americans will be discouraged from even firing weapons except in self-defense; Yemen is key center of support for Osama bin Laden, home to well-armed tribal forces, at least 20 senior Qaeda officials and scores of fighters trained in Afghanistan (M)

headline: Pakistani Says Bin Laden May Be Dead Of Disease
abstract: Pakistani Pres Pervez Musharraf says Osama bin Laden may have died of kidney failure in Afghanistan cave or been killed by American bombing or may be alive in Afghanistan, Pakistan or elsewhere; Pakistani officials say bin Laden's Dec videotape showed he was seriously ill; United States officials are skeptical (M)

headline: A Glowing Delphic Orb Says 'Buy,' 'Hold' or 'Panic'
abstract: Ambient Devices in Cambridge will introduce its first product, Stock Orb, glowing colored globe that receives wireless information and changes hue and intensity depending on movement of Dow Jones industrial average; photo (S)

headline: A Yawn, a Grumble, and After All It's Just Not Europe, Is It?
abstract: Coverage of World Economic Forum in Manhattan by European media discussed (M)

headline: Jospin Faces an Epidemic of Unrest by Health-Care Workers
abstract: PARISâ€”  With hospital workers, nurses and general practitioners either walking off their jobs Monday or announcing strikes, this was not a good week to fall ill or have an accident in France, and the unrest also bode ill for the Socialist government as it prepares to fight a presidential election less than 100 days from now.
