headline: In Footsteps of Evita: Argentina's New First Lady
abstract: Hilda Duhalde, Argentina's new first lady, has established herself as what local press calls country's 'de facto vice president' and 'superminister' in charge of all social programs; balks at any comparison to her idol Eva Peron, but others say she has revived style of country's beloved Evita; photos (M)

headline: Blazing a Trail Before a Single Tree Falls
abstract: Global Positioning System, computers and other technology are being used to design ski trails; before first tree is cut, planners using mathematical model can calculate number of skiers per hours a particular lift and trail network will accommodate; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Unemployment Rises
abstract: Britain's unemployment rate remained close to 26-year low at 3.2 percent in December (S)

headline: Tenet Testimony: 'A Nation at War'
abstract: Excerpts from Central Inelligence Agency Director George J Tenet to Senate Select Intelligence Committee (M)

headline: HUBBELL TO BUY LIGHTING UNIT OF U.S. INDUSTRIES
abstract: Hubbell Inc, which makes outdoor and commercial lighting, agrees to buy LCA Group lighting unit of US Industries for $250 million (S)

headline: Founder of Barnes & Noble to Step Down as Chief Executive
abstract: Leonard Riggio, founder, chairman and chief executive of the Barnes & Noble, is stepping down as chief executive and naming his brother, Stephen Riggio, to succeed him.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Leader Faces Special Protest
abstract: German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder faces very personal criticism for his new legislation ending tax breaks for single parents; half-sister Ilse Brucke and hundred other single parents file complaint with court in Karlsruhe seeking to restore tax relieg which was abolished in January (S)

headline: OUTLOOK: Markets & Investing; Strong Dollar Erodes Global Investments
abstract: Strong US dollar eroded global investments in 2001 and investors cannot expect much help for their foreign investments from dollar in 2002; 5.5 percent decline in euro against dollar turned 19.8 percent fall in Germany's benchmark DAX stock index into drop of 24.1 percent and changed 26.2 percent plunge in Italy's MIB30 index into 30.2 percent fall; 16 percent decline in Brazilian currency magnified loss in country's main stock index, Bovespa, from 11 percent to 24.9 percent; 8.7 percent rally of dollar against yen since terrorist attacks has made loss for American investors in Nikkei 225 stock index 33.6 percent decline, rather than 23.5 percent drop for Japanese; rally against Mexican peso increased 12.7 percent gain in Bolsa stock index to 18.5 percent return for American investors; Larry Kantor, global head of foreign exchange strategy at J P Morgan, forecasts direction of dollar for 2002; graphs (M)

headline: CONCERNS ON COMPETITION HURT KINDER MORGAN SHARES
abstract: Shares of Kinder Morgan Inc fall to 15-month low on concern company faces competition for assets and on investor wariness about its partnership arrangements; chief executive Richard D Kinder denies speculation that company faces cash squeeze or regulatory inquiry on its finances (S)

headline: Treasury to Shorten Time It Takes to Make Securities Deals
abstract: The Treasury said yesterday that it wanted to shorten the time it takes to process the auctions of its securities to two minutes.    That is good news for the government, which hopes to save money. But it could be bad news for Wall Street dealers, who will have to live with their mistakes, beginning with the next quarterly auction of Treasury securities in February.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Tuberculosis 'Epidemic'
abstract: Ukrainian tuberculosis institute warns nearly 700,000 people in nation have disease, despite government control efforts; warns of epidemic, with many new cases resisting standard drug treatment (S)

headline: Should Men Prowl the Catwalk?: When Less Is More
abstract: MILANâ€”  "Why can't a woman be more like a man?" has been a modern mantra. And vice versa.

headline: U.N. Ends Cambodia Talks On Trials for Khmer Rouge
abstract: UN pulls out of talks on setting up special tribunal to try former leaders of Cambodia's Khmer Rouge; photo of Pol Pot; UN concludes, after nearly five years of often testy negotiations, that Cambodian procedures would not guarantee independence, impartiality and objectivity (M)

headline: Excerpts From Testimony Before Senate Panel Investigating Enron
abstract: Excerpts from testimony of Enron vice president Sherron S Watkins, Jeffrey McMahon, formerly treasurer and now president, and former chief executive Jeffrey K Skilling before hearing of Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: AOL To Use Inktomi Product
abstract: Inktomi, maker of Internet search and content delivery software, says America Online agreed to use its new software that is intended to speed delivery of Web pages by about 30 percent; graph (S)

headline: SKIPPER TIES CARGO TO ARAFAT'S GROUP
abstract: The captain of a ship seized last week by Israel as it smuggled tons of weapons said in jail-house interviews today that he had taken his orders from a weapons agent of Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority and that his deadly cargo was meant to arm Palestinians.    The Palestinian Authority, which governs Palestinians in parts of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, denies any connection to the ship, the Karine A. The Israeli government contends that Mr. Arafat himself was behind the smuggling mission.

headline: Squabbles at the Start for World Trade Talks
abstract: Squabbles break out that threaten to undermine World Trade Organization talks, Geneva; wrangling is about procedural issue: who will head trade negotiations committee, which will oversee mechanics of how to fulfll mission of talks--reducing trade barriers for industrial goods, agriculture and services worldwide; developing countries want chairmanship to rotate among 144 member nations, while industrialized countries want WTO director general to lead talks; photo of WTO director Mike Moore with China's Sun Zhenyu (M)

headline: LIN TV BUYS 6 STATIONS AND FILES FOR STOCK OFFERING
abstract: LIN TV Buys 6 Stations and Files For Stor

headline: Amid Riches, Angola's Poor Consider Their Future
abstract: Angola, which is rich in natural resources, is rife with disease, malnutrition and violence of war; Jonas Savimbi, who became embodiment of 27-year civil war that made Angola one of most desperate places in world, is now dead; with him gone, nation's poor and weak wonder what is next for them; Pres Jose Eduardo dos Santos is scheduled to visit Pres Bush at White House this week; photo; map (M)

headline: Boosted by Spending, Economy Stronger Than First Thought
abstract: Robust spending pushed the economy to grow at an annual rate of 1.4 percent in the final quarter of 2001, according to a new report.

headline: Looking for a Few Good Eggs
abstract: American per capita egg consumption is expected to hit 260 in 2002, up from 234 in 1991, thanks to American Heart Association's revision of its recommendation on intake of egg yolks; is still down from high of 402 in 1945; graph (M)

headline: A Compact-Size Music Player In the Subcompact Class
abstract: New MP10-DMK player from Digital Global Network is so tiny that most of its 88-millimeter length is taken up by single AAA battery that powers it for 10 hours; sells for $209; drawing (S)

headline: DVD RENTALS HELP BLOCKBUSTER REDUCE LOSS
abstract: Blockbuster Inc says fourth-quarter loss narrowed to $4.5 million from $24.6 million year earlier; sales rose 1.3 percent, to $1.36 billion (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Dentsu acquires minority stake in Prophet for $8.3 million (S)

headline: Executive Life: The Boss; A Pioneer at the Marina
abstract: Katrin Theodoli, president and owner of Magnum Marine, writes The Boss column on running luxury boat company; photo (M)

headline: Choose Your Enemy: Monsters or Mathematics?
abstract: Review of new video gamnes Final Fantasy X, and Schizm: Mysterious Journey; photos (M)

headline: Colombian Rebels Sabotage Peace Hopes
abstract: Colombians know that recent hijacking and kidnappings mean intensification of 38-year civil war; most cast blame squarely on rebels, whose string of bombings, kidnappings and other violations eventually led Pres Andres Pastrana to break off negotiations; process that Pastrana began with high hopes in 1998, ceding vast region to rebels as venue for talks, began to unravel almost from beginning; photos; map (M)

headline: A Sharper Picture Of What Ails the Body
abstract: a

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Ask Jeeves Buys Software Company
abstract: Ask Jeeves, online question-and-answer service, acquires Octopus Software (S)

headline: Deals With Son Of an Executive Raise Questions On Governance
abstract: Global Crossing made at least two business deals last year with Internet company Withit.com by Joseph Perrone Jr, son of Global Crossing's executive vice president Joseph Perrone; analysts say business that Global Crossing sent to Perrone's son could have gone to any number of Internet companies that might have been better equipped to handle work; there is no evidence deals were not legitimate; dealings with Withit.com raise further questions about business practices of Perrone and decision making at Global Crossing; Perrone, former Arthur Andersen executive who was in charge of auditing Global Crossing before joining company in early 2000, played important role at company in overseeing accounting methods that are subject of investigations by Securities and Exchange Commission and FBI; among concerns about Global Crossing's board was Maria Elena Lagomasino's position with major creditor J P Morgan Chase; J P Morgan Chase spokeswoman says Lagomasino's efforts on Global Crossing board could not influence or be influenced by Morgan's lending or investment banking interests; Lagomasino resigned from board late last year; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Air Force Boss Steps Down
abstract: Gen Anatoly Kornukov retires as Russian air force commander; Vladimir Mikhailov will succeed him (S)

headline: After Sharing Highs and Lows, a Goodbye
abstract: Patri

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Rights Inspector To Go To Iraq
abstract: Iraq says UN human rights investigator will be allowed to visit for first time in decade (S)

headline: DVD Players Under $100: What Price A Bargain?
abstract: David Pogue column evaluates DVD players available for under $100; drawing; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Leader Nears A Second Term
abstract: Hong Kong chief executive Tung Chee-hwa wins support of majority of island's influential election committee, virtually assuring him of second term in office; will likely run unopposed in election; photo (S)

headline: Beirut Journal; TV Chef Adds World of Flavors to Arab Cuisine
abstract: For their annual feast marking the end of Ramadan, the Teffaha household boldly decided to defy tradition, scratching stuffed lamb off the menu and penciling in a roast turkey.    The problem was how to cook it. Riffling through old Lebanese cookbooks failed to unearth a recipe. No one in their building had ever tried to cook a bird. Then an excited neighbor called one day at noon and yelled that they should turn on the television immediately, because Chef Ramzi was preparing that very thing.

headline: Food Aid for Afghans Way Short of Need, U.N. Agency Says
abstract: World Food Program director Catherine Bertini says despite pledges from many nations to help people of Afghanistan, governments have given agency barely 5 percent of $285 million in emergency aid it needs for rest of year; agency estimates nine million Afghans need food through end of July, with more than five million needing help through end of 2002; US says it will allocate $44.5 million for fund, but agency officials say it would still leave three-quarters of need unmet (M)

headline: Verizon Wireless Will Lay Off 1,000
abstract: Verizon Wireless plans to lay off 1,000 employees in reorganization in next few weeks; cuts amount to less than 2 percent of company's work force (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Deutsche Bank Names Executives
abstract: Deutsche Bank names Michael Philipp and Jurgen Fitschen to help oversee company as Josef Ackerman becomes chief executive in May, replacing Rolf Breuer, who is retiring; photo (S)

headline: Need to Fix a Computer? Ask Another Computer
abstract: Handspring utilizes unusual software program from TuVox to address customer service needs; program uses artificial intelligence and speech recognition to talk Handspring's callers through repairing errors, crashes and other troubles that afflict hand-held personal digital assistants; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Sierra Leone: No Freedom For Rebel Leader
abstract: Sierra Leone government says Foday Sankoh, leader of rebel group responsible for killing and mutilating thousands of civilians, will not be freed even after state of emergency is lifted across country (S)

headline: Slow Recovery for Black-Car Drivers
abstract: Home Front column on plight of New York City 'black car' drivers, independent contractors who ferry mostly corporate clients; so many drivers quit after Sept 11 attacks caused business to plunge that dispatchers are searching for replacements, even though business is still down by over 20 percent from year ago; those that are still working are struggling to cover costs; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Chechnya: Rebels Kill 6 Russian Soldiers
abstract: Separatist rebels in Chechnya kill six Russian soldiers in one of largest single-day losses; UN urges Russia to reduce military presence in province (S)

headline: Mixed Blessings of Canada's Currency
abstract: Decline in Canadian dollar's value against American dollar is mixed blessing for Canadian exporters; weak Canadian dollar has been benefit for Krave's Candy Co of Winnipeg, Manitoba, which exports about half of its candies to US; Nova Chemicals of Calgary, Alberta, which ships big fraction of its polyethylene output to US, has been hammered by same exchange-rate trend; photo (M)

headline: Are the Bulls Starting a Run As the Economy Gathers Steam?
abstract: Stocks rise to end week higher, second consecutive strong week for markets; S&P 500 rises 6.77 points, to 1,164.31, while Nasdaq composite index jumps 48.04 points, to 1,929.67; Dow Jones industrial average climbs 47.12 points, to 10,572.49; rally comes on heels of unexpected surge in economy that has caught all but most optimistic analysts by surprise; graph; tables (M)

headline: Afghan Says U.S. Posture Led to Delay By Zahir Shah
abstract: Afghan official blames United States's reported stand that Italy, not US, should provide security for former Afghan king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, led him to delay his return to Afghanistan from in exile in Italy; US denies Pres Bush expressed reluctance to protect king in phone call to Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi asking Italy to continue to contribute to Afghanistan effort; delay apparently embarrasses interim leader Hamid Karzai, royalist who played key role in persuading Zahir to return; photo (M)

headline: PPG INDUSTRIES PLANS MORE JOB CUTS AND PLANT CLOSINGS
abstract: PPG Industries, maker of paints, specialty chemicals and glass products, says it plans to reduce its work force and close plants; reports net income in fourth quarter fell to $83 million from $126 million year earlier; sales fell 7 percent, to $1.91 billion from $2.05 billion (S)

headline: Reviving an Aging Playboy Is a Father-Daughter Project
abstract: Interviews with Playboy Enterprises founder Hugh M Hefner and chairwoman and chief executive Christie Hefner on magazine he still edits and her efforts to restore profitability and boost share price; graphs; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GEORGIA-PACIFIC CORP., Atlanta, the producer of forest products, said it would sell a wallboard paper mill in Delair, N.J., to the closely held National Gypsum Co., Charlotte, N.C., a maker of building products, to pay debt. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Letterman Will Remain In CBS Slot
abstract: David Letterman says he will keep his late-night talk show at CBS, spurning strong bid from ABC that would have displaced that network's highly regarded news program Nightline; Letterman makes his decision official in statement he delivers after start of taping of his Late Show; Letterman tells his audience that he appreciates generosity of offer from ABC, but that he has decided to stay at CBS and that he hopes ABC will continue with Nightline and its anchor Ted Koppel; Koppel and his staff issue sternly worded statement that says network has damaged Nightline and hurt its staff members and that it is network's obligation to repair damage; senior ABC executive who was involved in talks defends network's effort to win Letterman as 'sound business reasoning'; Rob Burnett, president of Worldwide Pants, Letterman's production company, praises ABC's effort; CBS Television president Leslie Moonves says he is thrilled at Letterman's decision; photo (M)

headline: Hotel Discounter's Stock Soars
abstract: Hotel Reservations Network says net income fell more than 6 percent in fourth quarter, to $4.81 million from $5.15 million year earlier; sales rose almost 42 percent, to $141.7 million from $100 million (S)

headline: Israel Takes Control of West Bank Town
abstract: The Israeli army seized control of the Palestinian city of Tulkarm today, sending troops door-to-door in a hunt for militants and weapons.

headline: Enron Pensions Still Under Old Management
abstract: Rep George Miller says Enron Corp's retirement plans are still being supervised by executives who did little when Enron stock plummeted last year despite agreement three weeks ago to replace executives with independent official; Labor Department officials say they are working to secure independent fiduciary who can take over three pension plans and provide company employees and retirees confidence that their interests will be protected (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Loss At Telecom Concern
abstract: Telecom Italia posts its first loss in two decades after writing down 3.8 billion euros ($3.3 billion) in 2001; sales rose 13 percent, to 30.8 billion euros ($26.7 billion), and operating profit increased 4.7 percent, to 6.7 billion euros ($5.8 billion) (S)

headline: House Panel Voices Doubts On Skilling
abstract: House Energy and Commerce Committee sends letter to former Enron Corp chief executive Jeffrey K Skilling, saying that recent interviews with other Enron officials 'appear to raise serious questions' about whether Skilling told truth before Congress last month; January interviews with three Enron accounting executives concern how much Skilling knew about and approved of restructuring of four partnerships known as Raptors year ago that essentially allowed Enron to delay disclosure of hundreds of millions of dollars in losses; photo (M)

headline: Worried About Portfolios But Reluctant to Sell
abstract: Survey by Penn, Schoen & Berland Associates for Eaton Vance finds 53 percent of respondents who ever worked for public company now hold that company's stock or stock options; overwhelming 87 percent say it is too risky to have large percentage of their personal assets invested in stock of any single company; 49 percent of respondents expect Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to rise this year, down from 62 percent year ago; most people are not taking any steps to lessen risk; they have not diversified their holdings, increased allocation of bonds in their portfolios or reduced their exposure to stock (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global Job Cuts At Gemplus
abstract: Gemplus, maker of chip-embedded smart cards, to cut up to 1,200 jobs globally, 18 percent of work force (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Uruguay: Trade Pact Sought
abstract: Pres Jorge Batlle meets with Pres Bush to push for free-trade agreement between US and Uruguay (S)

headline: Jihad Seethes, and Grows, on Indonesian Island
abstract: Intractable communal war between Muslims and Christians in Poso, on Sulawesi island, is sign of turbulence and lawlessness that have swept Indonesia; over 10,000 buildings have been destroyed, 80,000 people have fled and some 500 have been killed; context has broadened since Sept 11 terrorist attacks as United States seeks to root out worldwide terror network and neutralize sites of such conflicts that could serve as refuges and staging grounds for terrorism; some 500 members of Laskar Jihad, holy warriors from Java, fight on Muslim side; unchecked fighting and Laskhar Jihad presence show how difficult such conflicts are to manage, even when they are blanketed, as in Poso, by huge national police and troop deployment; map; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Level 3 To Carry Sony's Screenblast
abstract: Level 3 Communications becomes primary broadband provider for Screenblast interactive Internet site of Sony Pictures Digital Entertainment (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: MIDDLE EAST.

headline: Compressed Data; Pentagon to Receive Novel Toilet Paper
abstract: Consumers Insterstate, which makes toilet paper imprinted with face of Osama bin Laden and words 'Wipe Out Terrorism,' sends two hundreds rolls to Pentagon; photo (S)

headline: DataBank; Enron's Fallout Dampens Stock Prices
abstract: Stocks fell last week over concern about Enron Corp's flawed accounting procedures; graphs (M)m

headline: The demand drains market : Going, going, gone:art's disappearing act
abstract: LONDON:â€”  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED Wednesday, March 27, 2002 :

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: INTERNET`MLIFE' DRAWS SUPER BOWL TRAFFIC The annual analysis by Jupiter Media Metrix of Web site traffic surrounding the Super Bowl showed big increases for the sites of two advertisers. One was AT&T Wireless, which promoted a site (www.mlife.com) related to a campaign,

headline: PRESIDENT ASSAILS PALESTINIAN CHIEF ON ARMS SHIPMENT
abstract: Pres Bush, in his harshest comments yet on Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, suggests he enhances terror with boatload of smuggled arms intended for use against Israel; meets with top aides to weigh steps to isolate and punish Arafat; White House official later says Bush does not accuse Arafat of personal role in smuggling; holds his Palestinian Authority ordered arms; says he must crack down on terrorism (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: More Trouble At Foreign Ministry
abstract: Japanese Foreign Ministry admits Parliament member Muneo Suzuki exerted improper influence over ministry's policies and bidding for government contracts (S)

headline: For 'A Team' In Kandahar, New Mission Is Defensive
abstract: The mission assigned to the Army Special Forces, whose rules of war are written in mud and sand and sometimes in blood, is in transition across Afghanistan as the character of the American campaign shifts.    Since late October their job was to infiltrate Afghanistan, organize feuding militias of Taliban opponents and, under a withering air campaign, take the offensive on the ground.

headline: Capitol Scorn: Communists to Accountants
abstract: Floyd Norris comment how Congress humiliated fired Arthur Andersen auditor David Duncan by bringing him before Congressional committee in Enron Corp case knowing Duncan would invoke his rights under Fifth Amendment; says Congress displayed similar conduct in past, most notably questioning of suspected Communists before House Un-American Activities Committee in early 1950's; says real answers about who, if anyone, acted badly at Andersen will come from Securities and Exchange Commission and Justice Department investigations, with little help from what went on on Capitol Hill; says other members of Big Five accounting firms need to take clear steps to distinguish themselves from Andersen; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Banking Law Passed, I.M.F. Aid To Follow
abstract: Turkish Pres Ahmet Necdet Sezer signs new banking law, sought by IMF in exchange for $16 billion in loans, after Parliament passes legislation for second time (S)

headline: Business Travel; The Concorde can still turn heads after 25 years in the air.
abstract: Article on popularity of Concorde airplane, which resumed flights in November; says British Airways Concordes have been flying about 75 percent full; British Airways chief Concorde pilot Capt Mike Bannister comments; photo (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: When Nerds Collide: Bots in the Ring
abstract: Fighting robots spawn several television programs, BattleBots, Robotica and Robot Wars, as well as almost 60 live competitions; making robots that fight is irresistable to their builders, some of whom claim it has educational component; provides guilt-free violence that plays on love-hate relationship consumers have with technology; photos (M)

headline: Northern Trust Will Write Off $20 Million of Its $43.5 Million in Enron Loans
abstract: Northern Trust Corp, money management and financial services company, reports weaker-than-expected profits and announces it will write off about $20 million in loans to Enron Corp; Northern Trust, which handled Enron's 401(k) pension plan until October, also discloses that it made total of $43.5 million in loans to Enron over last few years (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Executive Leaving
abstract: Amazon.com's chief financial officer Warren Jenson plans to resign later this year; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: 46th Death In Hunger Strike
abstract: Turkish woman is 46th person to die in hunger strikes by leftists to protest prison conditions; government refuses to negotiate with them, saying they are terrorists (S)

headline: Sassy Ads Enliven Soda War In India
abstract: Article on advertising and marketing war in soft drink industry in India to attract young consumers; Coca-Cola Co and PepsiCo Inc are leading campaign to gain market share in India's $1.2 billion soft drink market (M)

headline: Koppel's 'Nightline' Caught in Cross-Fire
abstract: Staff of Ted Koppel's Nightline program reportedly is devastated by ABC's efforts to replace news program with David Letterman's talk show or another entertainment program; Koppel appears stoic; many at ABC News division hope he will strike blow for quality news coverage against corporate pressures for profits with defiant stance (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Debt Rating Is Raised
abstract: Standard & Poor's gives Mexico investment-grade rating on long-term foreign currency credit, giving nation chance to get new foreign capital and obtain cheaper borrowing (S)

headline: Institutions Turn to Hedge Funds
abstract: Survey by Goldman Sachs Group and Frank Russell Co finds 24 percent institutional investors in United States and Europe plan to invest in hedge funds in 2002, up from 16 percent in 2001 (S)

headline: Leader Plans Open Election For Pakistan In October
abstract: Pakistan's military leader, Gen Pervez Musharraf, announces plan to allow free elections for national and provincial assemblies in October; he also says he expects to remain in power for as long as five years after assembly is seated, to watch for signs of corruption and chaos that led to military takeovers in past; photo (M)

headline: Higher Yields, Low Threshold
abstract: Direct access notes, or DAN's, new way for individuals to invest in medium-term fixed-income corporate securities, have better returns than certificates of deposit but can be bought for $1,000 apiece, compared with minimum investment of $10,000 or more for bonds (S)

headline: 2 Civilians From Israel Killed In Palestinian Militant Attacks
abstract: Israeli Army officials say Palestinian gunmen kidnapped American Israeli Avi Boaz at Palestinian checkpoint, Beit Jala, West Bank and later shot him to death; two Palestinian gunmen fire at car outside Givat Zeev, part of northern Jerusalem Palestinians consider settlement, killing Yoela Chen and wounding her aunt; killings are first of civilians by Palestinian militants since Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat's Dec 16 call for halt to all attacks; his Palestinian Authority scores killings and affirms its commitment to cease-fire; detains Ahmed Saadat, leader of Popular Front for Liberation of Palestine, group that killed Israeli Min Rehavam Zeevi in Oct; militia whose leader, Raed al-Karmi, was recently killed by bomb in Tulkarm, West Bank, claims responsibility for killing Boaz; Israel tightens blockade of Tulkarm; map; photos (M)

headline: Magazine Ad Pages Continue to Decline
abstract: Publishers Information Bureau says ad pages in magazines for January fell 15.9 percent from January 2001; for 2001, ad pages declined 11.7 percent from 2000 (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Big Companies Combine To Negotiate Airline Fares  Large corporations, frustrated by the cost of travel from airports dominated by a single carrier, are teaming up in several cities to investigate ways to spur competition and negotiate lower fares.    The proposals include luring new carriers by guaranteeing corporate bookings; negotiating collectively with the airlines instead of individually to secure lower fares; and setting up air shuttles to frequently visited cities for corporate employees. [Page C2.]

headline: Patents; While Enron's future is uncertain, its trademarked name could live on for a decade.
abstract: US Office of Patent and Trademarks publishes Enron's application for trademark for its tilted 'E' logo; Enron has so many pending trademark applications that trademark office continued throughout December and January to churn out requests for further information, amendments and publication notices; Enron has no plans to abandon its trademarks or pending applications despite its bankruptcy (M)

headline: Milosevic Roughly Questions Albanian Documentor of War Crimes
abstract: Slobodan Milosevic cross-examines Albanian activist and documentor of war crimes for four hours, seeking to discredit him; activist Halit Barani has provided most comprehensive account in Milosevic's war crimes trial of what prosecutors say were atrocities in war in Kosovo; Milosevic focuses on list Barani says he discovered naming 66 Albanians, himself included, to be 'liquidated' by Serbian forces; Milosevic claims list is forgery (M)

headline: U.S. Says 16 Killed in Raids Weren't Taliban or Al Qaeda
abstract: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that 16 Afghan fighters killed by American troops north of Kandahar last month were not members of the Taliban or Al Qaeda. While he described the deaths as ''unfortunate,'' he issued no apology and said there was no reason for disciplinary action.    In describing the results of the official inquiry into the Special Forces mission, Mr. Rumsfeld said the United States alone generated the intelligence that pointed to two compounds in the Hazar Qadam Valley as enemy garrisons.

headline: Beijing Journal; Buicks, Starbucks and Fried Chicken. Still China?
abstract: Pres Bush and Pres Jiang Zemin differed politely on many issues during Bush's recent trip to China, but ordinary people in China's cities find much common ground with Americans, with way they live converging rapidly in marketplace; in last few years, China's major cities have sprouted American stores and restaurants at prodigious rates; new housing compounds bear American names, and high-end Buick is sought-after luxury car; Chinese have mostly welcomed American invasion, even internalized it; recent survey finds many Chinese children think McDonald's is domestic brand; photos (M)

headline: Yahoo Posts Lower-Than-Expected Loss; President Says He Will Quit
abstract: Jeff Mallet will resign as president and chief executive of Yahoo; company reports sales of $188.9 million for fourth quarter, down from $310.9 million year earlier; lost $8.7 million in quarter, compared with loss of $97.8 million year earlier (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Sales Executive Finds A Role Undercover
abstract: Donald R Rogers, longtime sales manager for NetSupport, and Julio O Naboa are arrested for trying to sell valuable NetSupport database to Andrew Parsons, vice president for sales and marketing at rival Victor Networks; Parsons reported offer to NetSupport and took part in FBI sting operation; drawing (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Job Cuts At Hitachi
abstract: Hitachi Corp will eliminate 4,000 jobs before June 30 through early retirement buyouts for workers more than 40 years old (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Former Enron Treasurer Said to Cooperate in Inquiry  A senior official from Enron's finance division, himself a subject of the criminal inquiry into the company's collapse, has begun cooperating with federal officials, people who have been briefed on the situation said.    Ben F. Glisan Jr., Enron's former treasurer, who played a central role in the establishment and operation of a byzantine series of affiliated partnerships, has offered information and evidence to both criminal and regulatory investigators, these people said. Government officials are said to consider Mr. Glisan a key participant in the demise of Enron. [Page A1.]    A partnership managed by Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, bet money on a deal that did not turn out well, then returned the investment to Enron. [C7.]

headline: China Invites Backers of a Free Taiwan to Visit
abstract: China extends an invitation to members of Taiwan's officially pro-independence governing party to visit mainland, apparently signaling more conciliatory approach toward disputed island (M)

headline: India Seeks to Head Off Any New Violence
abstract: India's Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee, facing anger over failure of governing party in Gujarat State to prevent killing of hundreds of Muslims by Hindu mobs, assures Parliament he will keep peace in another potential flash point: northern Indian city of Ayodyha; militant Hindus who belong to group affiliated with Vajpayee's Hindu nationalist Bhatariya Janata Party say they will hold ceremony in Ayodhya on March 15 as part of campaign to build temple on site of 16th-century mosque they helped tear down nine years ago; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Unemployment Rate Falls
abstract: France reports number of people out of work fell by 4,000 in Feb, leaving unemployment rate unchanged from Jan at 9 percent (S)

headline: AGENCY FILES SUIT FOR CHENEY PAPERS ON ENERGY POLICY
abstract: General Accounting Office sues Vice Pres Dick Cheney to try to force White House to reveal identities of energy industry executives who helped administration develop national energy policy last year; this is GAO's first suit ever against member of executive branch for failing to turn over records to Congress; suit sets up showdown between GAO and White House over access to records of national energy task force, of which Cheney was chairman; GAO wants to know whether executives from corporations that contributed to Pres Bush's presidential campaign, including Enron Corp, helped shape administration's national energy policy; Cheney says disclosure of records would hamper executive branch's ability to solicit advice of outside experts; photo (M)

headline: WASTE MANAGEMENT SAYS IT WILL CUT 2,000 JOBS
abstract: Waste Management will cut 2,000 jobs, or 3.5 percent of its work force (S)

headline: MEDTRONIC RECEIVES BACKING FOR HEART DEVICE
abstract: Medtronic Inc receives narrow backing of Food and Drug Administration for medical device, InSync ICD, that treats heart failure and works as defibrillator (S)

headline: In Argentine Crisis, Military Stays in Step
abstract: Argentina's military, which has history of intervening to topple unpopular or discredited civilian governments, avoids involvement in current economic crisis; Army head Lt Gen Ricardo Brinzoni says both civilians and military oppose military takeover, interview; military is in far weaker position than when it last seized power, in 1976; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Skyscraper Record
abstract: London borough council approves plans to build office tower on bank of Thames River that will become Europe's tallest building (S)

headline: A New Theory Puts Chinese Fleet Ahead of Columbus
abstract: Theories about pre-Colombian contacts between Old World and New abound, and now British amateur historian says he has gathered evidence showing that, in double challenge to accepted history, Chinese beat Columbus to America by 72 years and also circumnavigated globe century before Magellan; Gavin Menzies, retired Royal Navy submarine commander and navigation expert, has concluded, using his home computer, that Chinese explored coasts of Africa, South America and Australia and sailed into Caribbean and Sea of Cortez, off what is now Baja California; map (M)

headline: Afghan Warlord's Rivals Link Him to U.S. Attacks
abstract: Pacha Khan Zadran, anti-Taliban warlord from southern Afghanistan, denies accusation that he provided information for American airstrikes last month on convoy of tribal leaders traveling to Kabul to pay homage to new government; Pentagon officials say targeting information comes from many sources and that they are confident in accuracy of process; Zadran says Americans were right to bomb houses in village of Niazi Kala where villagers had taken Taliban weapons stock; incident report by international aid workers provides chilling account of human cost of destroying weapons stash left by fleeing Taliban; report notes villagers report finding remains of '17 men, 10 women and 25 children' in rubble; Zadran and other leaders are summoned to Kabul to discuss bombing with Hamid Karzai, chairman of interim authority; Zadran, like other tribal leaders, is not shy about accusing political opponents of supporting Al Quada terrorism regardless of evidence; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Nazi Loses Court Appeal
abstract: Court in Karlsruhe, Germany, rejects appeal by former SS officer Anton Malloth, who is serving life sentence for role in atrocities at Theresienstadt concentration camp during World War II (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PROCTER & GAMBLE CO., Cincinnati, the maker of consumer products, said it would sell a cooking school it opened 14 months ago in Norwood, Ohio, to a group of investors led by Amy Tobin, who helped set up the school and has run it since. Terms were not disclosed.    CELERA GENOMICS GROUP - APPLERA CORP., Rockville, Md., a provider of genomic and related medical and agricultural information, said it had sold its AgGen animal-gene business to MetaMorphix Inc., a closely held company in Savage, Md., that makes genetic technologies to improve livestock production. Celera also gained a stake in MetaMorphix. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Enron's Auditor Says It Destroyed Documents
abstract: Arthur Andersen discloses that it destroyed 'significant but undetermined number' of documents related to Enron Corp and its finances as fortunes of Enron unraveled in late 2001; SEC investigator says document destruction began in September and continued into November, after Enron announced that SEC was conducting formal investigation of Enron's finances; SEC subpoenaed Andersen for records related to Enron in November, and Andersen told its employees that such documents should be preserved, but Andersen now says documents may have been destroyed even after that; documents included correspondence and both electronic and paper records; photos (M)

headline: China, on Eve of Bush's Visit, Goes Easy on Bible Smuggler
abstract: A Hong Kong citizen accused of bringing tens of thousands of annotated Bibles into China for use by a banned evangelical Christian group was given a two-year prison sentence.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Heating oil rises as colder weather in Northeast leads homeowners and businesses to buy fuel; in New York, heating oil for February rises 2.53 cents, or 4.6 percent, to 57.86 cents per gallon; graph; chart (S)

headline: Investing; The Rise of the Fee-Based Account
abstract: Article on growing number of brokerage firms that are instituting fee-based accounts; says although trend reflects Wall Street strategy to produce steadier stream of revenue, some investors welcome chance to pay fixed fees for bundle of services, including buying and selling stocks and bonds; new fee-based accounts at Merrill Lynch & Co, UBS Paine Webber and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter discussed; chart; photo (M)

headline: Betrayed by the Bar
abstract: Wolfhard J Vogel letter on privacy concerns over bar-code information on drivers license

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Rise In Unwed Parents
abstract: Economic and Social Research Institute reports one in three Irish children born in 2000 were born to unmarried parents, up from one in 20 in 1980 (S)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for JOHN LONSKI; Rising Debt Brings Rising Risk
abstract: John Lonski, chief economist at Moody's Investors Service, answers Five Questions on rise of consumer borrowing in US and how it might hurt individual households and general economy; photo (M)

headline: Andersen Chief Says He Quit As a Sacrifice To Aid the Staff
abstract: Joseph F Berardino, former chief executive of Arthur Andersen, says his decision to resign as chief executive sends message to Andersen's employees to keep up their fight for survival of company, interview; says he resigned to prove to government how much Andersen was willing to change; reveals details of how firm discovered document destruction that led to its indictment; also talks about failed negotiations with government and possible merger partners and plans that Andersen has for coming weeks and months as it continues to struggle to survive; photo (M)

headline: Asylum Seekers Detained in Australia Suspend Hunger Strike
abstract: Hundreds of asylum seekers at Woomera, Australia's largest immigration detention center, say they will suspend 15-day hunger strike while negotiations continue with government over their detention; government says it has made no change in its policy of detaining illegal immigrants while their visa applications are processed, sometimes for years; protests and hunger strikes continue at some other immigration detention centers; asylum seekers at Woomera, largely from Middle East, say their chief demand is to be moved out of mandatory detention; government resumes consideration of visas for Afghan immigrants, process that had been suspended after Taliban government fell (M)

headline: TWO AIRLINES TO SELL STOCK IN THEIR COMMUTER UNITS
abstract: Northwest Airlines Corp and Continental Airlines Inc says their commuter-carrier units will sell stock to public, giving parent companies chance to raise cash amid losses; Northwest plans to raise as much as $400 million in initial public offering for Pinnacle Airlines, commuter unit now called Express Airlines I; Continental unit ExpressJet Holdings files proposal to raise as much as $320 million (S)

headline: A new wave in Tokyo pursues the next Cool Look
abstract: TOKYOâ€”  The economy is in shambles. The nation is going down the tubes. Amid the moans and groans, it seems like the only bastion of mental security, the examples of real creativity, are in fashion.

headline: A.I.G. Quits Talks on Buying Korean Firms
abstract: American International Group confirms that it has ended talks to be among investors in three financial firms owned by Hyundai Group of South Korea after failing to reach accord with Korean government (S)

headline: Earthlink Is Dropping TBWA/Chiat/Day
abstract: Earthlink Is Dropping TBWA/Chiat/Day EarthLink, an Internet service provider, said yesterday that it was ending its 18-month relationship with the Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group. EarthLink eliminated the agency as it narrowed an account review. Billings were estimated at $40 million to $50 million.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Walkout At Oil Company
abstract: Workers and managers at Venezuela's state oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela, begin one-day strike, challenging Pres Hugo Chavez to follow through with his threat to militarize company; workers are protesting last month's appointment to board of five employees strikers say were not qualified and were selected for their political loyalty to Chavez; strike has not affected oil production; photo (S)

headline: Tens of Thousands Flee a Devastating Volcano in Congo
abstract: Tens of thousands of refugees pour across Congo's border into Rwanda, fleeing vicious volcano outside Goma that is spewing torrents of burning lava through town; lava flows are six feet deep in some areas, devastating town and fueling vast humanitarian crisis in region already suffering from long-running civil war; there is no information yet on deaths or injuries; photos; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Ebay Exits Japan For Taiwan
abstract: EBay agrees to buy NeoCom Technology, which runs popular Taiwan Web sites ubid.com.tw and bid.com.tw, for $9.5 million in cash and additional sum to be determined when deal closes; eBay says it will close is operations in Japan on March 31, laying off its 17 employees there (S)

headline: Progress In Colombia: New Talks About Talks
abstract: Analysis: even through Pres Andres Pastrana of Colombia and rebel commanders agree to return to table, significant step like cease-fire remains months, perhaps years, away; Colombia remains as violent and divided as ever; even foreign diplomats who helped broker deal that averted wider war have no illusions that it will be easy to end 37-year-old conflict; one positive development is new, active role of third-party participants (M)

headline: Court Rules Chinese From Mainland Cannot Stay With Parents : Abode-Seekers Lose in Hong Kong
abstract: HONG KONGâ€”  Hong Kong's highest court cleared the way Thursday to deport thousands of immigrants from mainland China by rejecting pleas from children to join their parents who reside here permantly.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer Cuts Shares
abstract: British retailer Marks & Spencer will return $2.9 billion to shareholders and reduce number of shares held by stockholders; restructuring is expected to raise earnings per share 3 percent to 7 percent in year to March (S)

headline: Even Last Year, Option Spigot Was Wide Open
abstract: Initial batch of annual proxy statements indicate that top executives at American companies got more stock options as part of their pay in 2001; trend disturbs compensation experts, since it would seem to make mockery of concept of pay for performance; executives who receive options can usually count on rich rewards eventually, even if company does only marginally better; shareholders, however, will see their holdings diluted; photos; graphs (L)

headline: Fire Started on Train Carrying Hindu Activists Kills 58
abstract: Angry Muslim mob sets fire to train loaded with Hindu activists seeking to build temple on site of demolished mosque, killing 58 people and raising prospect of more religious violence; more than dozen children are among those burned to death; mob that had been stoning coaches set fire to train as it pulled out of station in Godhra in western state of Gujarat; Hindus had reportedly been chanting religious slogans as train paused in Godhra, which is 40 percent Muslim and has been among cities in India most prone to Hindu-Muslim riots; police detain more than 80 people and charge 5 of them with crimes; photos (M)

headline: Lazard's Chief Planning To Give Partners Equity
abstract: Bruce Wasserstein, new chief executive at Lazard, the largest privately held investment bank, names four deputy chairmen; he also plans to distribute equity to firm's 140 partners worldwide in attempt to halt defections; Kenneth Jacobs is promoted to lead New York office; Marcus Agius will lead London office; Georges Ralli will manage Paris and Lazard's biggest client, Vivendi Universal; Gerardo Braggiotti will control other European countries (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Utility Acquisition
abstract: German utility RWE will buy Innogy of Britain for 3.1 billion pounds ($4.4 billion) (S)

headline: Wild Card Of the Recovery: Inflation
abstract: Louis Uchitelle column on how declining rate of inflation has supported economy through recession and uncertainty over whether it can stay down long enough for economy to reach next, more durable stage of recovery; graph (M)

headline: JONES APPAREL WILL CLOSE STORES AND CUT 240 JOBS
abstract: Jones Apparel Group will close 30 to 40 of its less-profitable stores this year, eliminating about 240 jobs; will open 15 to 20 stores in 2002 (S)

headline: U.S. Mission Lifts Filipino Hopes for Peace
abstract: Most residents of Zamboanga, Philipines, where American military troops will be housed, give at last qualified support to United States mission to train and advise Filipino soldiers in their war against Abu Sayyaf guerrillas, who hold American couple hostage in nearby island of Basilan; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Carrier Halves Investment
abstract: J-Phone Co, operator of Japan's third-largest cellular phone system, will invest slightly more than 300 billion yen ($2.3 billion) in its network in year ending in March, about half its original target (S)

headline: 94-Year-Old Becomes Case Study in British Health Care Woes
abstract: Reported neglect of Rose Addis, 94, during recent 48-hour visit to London emergency ward has made her latest high-profile example of problems confounding Britain's creaky National Health Service; chief complaints against underfunded and overstretched service include neglect of elderly patients and long, doctorless waits in squalid emergency room; Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith has seized on case to score points against Prime Min Tony Blair (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   8.50       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   5.00       Federal funds   1.81   1.77   5.52       3-month T-bills   1.73   1.70   4.92       6-month T-bills   1.83   1.81   4.75       10-yr. T-infl.   3.35   3.40   3.45       10-yr. T-note   4.90   4.98   5.17       30-yr. T-bond   5.35   5.39   5.49       Telephone bd.   7.45   7.50   7.71       Municipal bds.   5.28   5.29   5.32          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: U.S. Officials Try to Assure Europeans On NATO
abstract: Senior American officials seek to reassure Europeans at global security conference in Munich that NATO still matters, but also warn that Bush administration would continue its war against terrorism with its allies or without them; Paul D Wolfowitz, filling in for his boss, Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, says war against terrorism is not over, and that what happened on Sept 11 is pale shadow of what would happen if terrorists use weapons of mass destruction; cites Pres Bush's State of Union address, in which he described Iraq, Iran and North Korea as 'axis of evil' that is seeking weapons of mass destruction; reaction from European participants is mixture of questioning and dismay (M)

headline: On Stages and Screens, AIDS Educators Reach South Africa's Youths
abstract: New AIDS education initiatives in South Africa seek to find livelier way to deliver message, with younger teens the crucial target audience; open discussion of sex has had only short history in South Africa and even now, uneasiness is widespread; activists are pinning their hopes on such efforts as 'Soul City,' educational soap opera wtih nationwide audience; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Menem's Foreign Accounts
abstract: Geneva prosecutor says Swiss bank accounts linked to former Argentina Pres Carlos Saul Menem contain about $10 million; Switzerland blocked accounts at Argentina's request for probe into suspected illegal arms sales (S)

headline: STATE STREET'S CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER IS LEAVING
abstract: State Street Corp's chief financial officer Ronald O'Kelley is leaving company; executive vice president Stefan Gavell will be interim chief financial officer until permanently replacement is found (S)

headline: Italy Says It Can Destroy Illegal-Immigrant Ships
abstract: Playing to anti-immigrant feelings among Italians, the government issued a decree today empowering the government to destroy any ships used for the illegal transport of refugees.    The announcement of the decree, which is part of broader legislation to deal with immigrants, was made one day after Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi warned that Italians faced the menace of being thrown out of their own country ''by a wave of immigrants.''

headline: Business; Airlines Are Humbled
abstract: Outlook for airlines remains dark, despite some recovery from big drop in passenger traffic after Sept 11 terrorist attacks; industry is expected to lose $2 billion to $4 billion in 2002; graph of number of scheduled flights (S)

headline: Lawmakers Contend Lawyers for Enron Should Have Raised Concerns
abstract: Members of Congress investigating Enron Corp's collapse say Vinson & Elkins, lawyers for Enron Corp, failed to recognize serious conflicts of interests and did not act on information that clearly should have raised concerns about company's accounting; Rep James C Greenwood suggests that law firm's review was coverup that failed to fully investigate serious questions that had been raised about Enron's financial dealings; House Ways and Means Committee, 36-2, approves pension reform bill that, among other provisions, would force companies to warn employees at least 30 days before instituting so-called blackout period during which trading in their 401(k) retirement plans is frozen; measure is expected to be considered by full House as soon as next month (M)

headline: Malaysia's Canny Autocrat Grows Stronger Since Sept. 11
abstract: Malaysian Prime Min Mahathir Mohamad, still crusty and combative at 76, displays his canny political dexterity in response to Sept 11 terrorist attacks on US; he has managed to bolster popularity at home, where moderate and conservative Islamic forces are locked in struggle for soul of country, while at same time improving relations with US by exchanging letters and call with Pres Bush, cracking down hard on suspected terrorists and sharing intelligence with US (M)

headline: Argentina Is Still Shaky Despite Currency Measures
abstract: Argentine government's devaluation of peso by nearly 30 percent was supposed to bring end to emergency bank holiday, which began before Christmas, but banks and foreign exchange houses have still have not resumed normal operations, and it is not clear when they will; irritation, uncertainty and nervousness continue unchecked; black-market streets dealers remain only certain source of dollars, often at rates that stray far from official 1.40 pesos to dollar set by government; bank transactions as simple as cashing paycheck or paying credit card bill remain out of reach of ordinary Argentines; government imposes tighter restrictions, effectively freezing all savings accounts above $3,000 for at least one year; at least one-third of nation's $67 billion in savings balances are affected by order; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Veteran Politician Seeks Top Job
abstract: Longtime South Korean political figure Kim Jong Pil, 76, will run for president; photo (S)

headline: Rising Savings Could Mean A Weaker Recovery
abstract: Daniel Altman column warns that increasing savings, which will help economy grow in long run, could dampen recovery this year; graph of American savings rate (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Global Crossing Inquiry Broadens to Include Qwest  The federal investigation of Global Crossing, the troubled communications company, expanded into an inquiry of a financial marketplace in which Enron and several other companies were also major participants.    Qwest Communications, the main local phone company in 14 Western states, said that it had received a subpoena from the Securities and Exchange Commission about transactions with Global Crossing. The S.E.C. wants to know whether contracts in some cases were sham transactions to create the appearance of revenue that did not exist. [Page A1.]

headline: Somali foreign minister, in U.S., pledges support on terror
abstract: WASHINGTON:â€”  With his country under intense U.S. scrutiny for possible terrorist connections, the foreign minister of the transitional government of Somalia has pledged full cooperation in the fight against terror even while denying any Al Qaeda link to his shattered country.

headline: They Had Fun, Fun, Fun Till the Stock Fell
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on rise and fall of AES Corp stock; links collapse of stock to AES Corp's use of financing technique called SELLS, or 'secured equity-linked loans'; stock peaked at $72.81 per share in fall of 2000 and closed on March 28 at $9 per share (M)

headline: Archbishop of Canterbury to Step Down This Fall
abstract: The archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. George Carey, leader of 73 million Anglicans in 160 nations, announced today that he would step down this fall, three years before he was due to retire.    ''By the end of October I shall have served 11 1/2 years in a demanding yet wonderfully absorbing and rewarding post,'' Archbishop Carey, 66, said in a statement. ''I feel certain this will be the right and proper time to stand down.''

headline: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Airline Selects Airbus
abstract: Airbus Industrie wins order for 41 planes from South African Airways, defeating Boeing Co, which once supplied most of carrier's fleet (S)

headline: Some Confusion Over 2001 Rebates
abstract: Income tax refund checks sent out during summer of 2001 are causing some confusion in preparation of tax returns for year (S)

headline: Sudanese Foes Give Consent For Relief Aid For Civilians
abstract: International effort led by United States to expand area where aid workers can operate safety in Sudan's civil war, one of Africa's longest, bears fruit with word that aid may soon be flowing to thousands of civilians isolated in rugged mountain region (M)

headline: Software Company's Shares Fall 26%
abstract: Shares of the Vignette Corporation slid 26.5 percent today after the company, a maker of software for Web sites, said its fourth-quarter loss would be wider than forecast as some customers cut spending more than expected.    Vignette's shares fell $1.45, to $4.02 on Nasdaq.

headline: R. M. Hare, British Philosopher, Dies at 82; Looked for Logic in Morals
abstract: R M Hare, British philosopher who wrestled ethical questions out of murky realm of emotion and into hard-edged arena of logic, dies at age 82; photo; Hare's theory of prescriptivism dominated moral philosophy in 1950's and 1960's (M)

headline: Yugawaramachi Journal; Japan's New Insider Speaks Up for the Outsiders
abstract: Finnish-born Marutei Tsurunen is first Westerner to hold seat in Japanese Parliament; in 1979 he won Japanese citizenship after surmounting major hurdles, including 50-page essay in Japanese for immigration authorities, who also inspected his house to verify that he was living in traditional Japanese way; complying with law, he 'Japanesed' his name; he wants to promote intercultural tolerance and laws banning discrimination in housing and employment; he was unexpectedly elevated to Parliament when lawmaker from opposition party resigned his seat, making way for Tsurunen, runner-up; photo; map (M)

headline: Auction Sites In Japan Fear Move to Limit Online Sales
abstract: Japanese National Police Agency is circulating proposal to require sellers of used goods through Internet auctions to obtain licenses, raising more fears among American online auction companies that they may face more stringent international control; National Police Agency is also arguing that Japanese government should take steps to create 'guidelines' for auction sites; proposal, which is opposed by number of Internet executives in US, has created intense debate among Japanese officials; it is opposed by country's Ministry of External Trade and Industry, which is intent on supporting electronic commerce initiatives; Japanese trade officials have contacted US trade representative in Japan, looking for support for their view that legislation would violate international trade agreements (M)

headline: Investing; The Dividend Gains New Respect
abstract: Money managers and securities analysts say companies that consistently raise their dividends often make excellent long-term investments, especially time of lower stock returns; graph (M)

headline: Interactive commercials get an Olympic tryout with viewers who have the right software.
abstract: Interactive television commercials make their Olympic debut during opening ceremonies; commercials for AT&T and TD Waterhouse permit interactivity only on television cable or satellite boxes equipped with Wink Communications software; photo (M)

headline: Author's Attempt to Promote Book Backfires
abstract: Author David A Vise decided in January to take promotion of his book The Bureau of the Mole into his own hands by selling signed copies over Internet; to obtain copies, he took advantage of free shipping and discount prices at Barnesandnoble.com to buy nearly 20,000 books at favorable price; Vise's strategy backfired last week in awkward dust-up with Barnesandnoble.com that left many in book industry wondering about his motives; executives at Barnesandnoble.com noticed that in four weeks ended Feb 16, Vise ordered nearly 20,000 copies and returned 17,500 copies and asked for his money back; publishers say they never heard of author who bought so many copies of his own book; executives complained angrily to Vise's publisher, Grove/Atlantic, that he was taking unfair advantage of discounts meant for ordinary purchases; photo (M)

headline: Enron Paid Some, Not All, Deferred Compensation
abstract: Former and current Enron Corp executives say in weeks before company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, it allowed small group of executives to withdraw their money from deferred compensation program, giving them preferential treatment over some former managers who had also requested early withdrawal; Enron paid millions of dollars in deferred salaries and bonuses to midlevel and high-level executives still working in late November, just before Dec 2 bankruptcy filing, which forced company to suspend payments; number of employees who had retired or recently left company were denied similar payments; some former Enron employees are considering lawsuit in hopes of recovering millions of dollars in deferred compensation they say they are owed; among those unable to withdraw money in November was Charles B Bowman, former senior vice president at Enron Facilities Services; Bowman, who took early retirement in October 2000, says he lost about $750,000 in deferred compensation plan; photos (M)

headline: Zimbabwe Tightens Curbs on Media and Foreign Journalists
abstract: Governing party lawmakers in Zimbabwe enact tough new media law that will require all local journalists and news organizations to be licensed and will restrict foreign reporters in country; some of harshest elements of early draft of legislation are eliminated, in bow to pressure from powerful moderates within Pres Robert Mugabe's own party; law is latest measure by government to clamp down on political opponents and to buttress Mugabe's sagging position(M)

headline: Trial Centers on Role of Press During Rwanda Massacre
abstract: Three former Rwandan news media executives stand accused of genocide and incitement to genocide through their use of radio broadcasts and newspapers; their trial before United Nations war crimes tribunal will examine scope of role played by news media in massacre of more than 800,000 people in Rwanda in 1994; this is first time group of journalists stand accused before international tribunal on such grave charges since 1946, when Julius Streicher, Nazi publisher of anti-Semitic weekly Der Sturmer, appeared before Nuremberg judges; prosecutors in Rwanda case are drawing stark parallels between Der Sturmer's vitriolic campaigns against Jews before World War II and actions of some Rwandan media before and during 1994 slaughter of Tutsi; legal specialists believe outcome of current trial may set crucial precedent for future international cases; photos (M)

headline: OXFORD HEALTH POSTS 12% DROP IN 4TH-QUARTER PROFIT
abstract: Oxford Health Plans Inc says fourth-quarter profit fell 12 percent; net income fell to $94.3 million from $107.4 million year earlier; revenue rose 7.9 percent, to $1.12 billion (S)

headline: Some Executives Link Productivity and Attire
abstract: Many executives responding to recent survey say they are requiring employees to dress more formally; believe casual attire has led to relaxed attitudes and behaviors, which have hurt productivity (S)

headline: United Nations Leader Urges International Action on Mideast
abstract: Warning that the Israeli-Palestinian conflict was ''sliding toward a full-fledged war,'' Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that it had become essential for an active international effort and ''new thinking'' to get the sides talking again.    The notion of any outside involvement in the conflict, other than American mediation, has been strongly resisted by Israel and the United States, as it was by their representatives today after Mr. Annan spoke.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bank Profit Rises
abstract: Royal Bank of Canada reports its profit rose 9.2 percent in its last quarter ended Jan 31; net income rose to 722 million Canadian dollars ($454 million) from 661 million Canadian dollars ($416 million) year earlier; revenue rose 17 percent, to 4.09 billion Canadian dollars ($2.6 billion) (S)

headline: The Rising Price of the Final Curtain
abstract: Average cost of traditional funeral, adjusted for inflation, is put at $6,130 in 2001, up 26 percent since 1991; graphs (M)

headline: Pfizer, facing competition from other drug makers, looks for a younger market for Viagra.
abstract: Pfizer Inc, facing competition from other drug makers, is looking for younger market for its erectile dysfunction drug Viagra; ad campaign was developed by Cline, Davis & Mann; photo (M)

headline: Inaction by Bank of Japan Raises New Concern
abstract: Bank of Japan leaves monetary policy unchanged, decision that puts added pressure on government to bolster weakening financial system and answer mounting criticism from abroad; says it will pump more money into markets should risk of financial market instability arise (M)

headline: An AIDS Skeptic in South Africa Feeds Simmering Doubts
abstract: Peter Mokaba, member of South African parliament nd fiery speaker, insists HIV does not exist, in statements that feed into suspicions of those who are eager to believe; Mokaba charges Western antiretrovirals aer 'poison' for his people; photo; African National Congress says he was defeated during debate in which party formally accepted 'assumption that HIV causes AIDS,' but critics say some politicians still take his view, even as disease devastates country (M)

headline: BANK OF NEW YORK BUYS ASSET MANAGEMENT FIRM
abstract: Bank of New York Co acquires Gannett Welsh & Kotler Inc, asset manager based in Boston; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Bermuda Havens To Be Reviewed
abstract: Treasury Department is reviewing laws that allow multinational companies based in US, like Tyco International, to reduce taxes by incorporating in Bermuda; study comes as Rep Richard E Neal and Sen John F Kerry are drafting legislation to ban arrangements; Tyco saved $400 million last year by becoming Bermuda company via paper transaction while continuing to operate in US (S)

headline: Tipping the Scales
abstract: Susan Kemp letter on Dec 27 article on shopping online for high-tech scale

headline: An A.T.M. That Laps Up Checks Without an Envelope
abstract: NCR develops ATM that optically scans checks being deposited, eliminating need for envelop and speeding processing; technology can also allow ATM's to count paper money inserted by customer; photo (S)

headline: Rescuing Memories Trapped in Old Film
abstract: Comment on some Web sites that provide high-quality video-editing equipment to transfer vintage home movies; drawing (M) (Online Shopper column)

headline: Cheney Asks Yemen to Join the Pursuit of Al Qaeda's Remnants
abstract: Vice Pres Dick Cheney flies to Yemen to press for joint efforts against remnants of Al Qaeda; uses his meeting with Pres Ali Abdullah Saleh to discuss assistance to prevent Yemen from becoming haven for terrorists; many militants who fought with Taliban in Afghanistan came from Yemen; Yemen has also become magnet for militants from other nations; in Yemen, as in Egypt and Jordan, Cheney encounters opposition to Bush administration's efforts to mobilize support for tough action against Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Suit to Be Filed on Behalf Of Three Detainees in Cuba
abstract: Families of 26-year-old Australian man and a pair of young British citizens captured with fighters for Al Qaeda and Taliban in Afghanistan and flown to American military base in Cuba will file suit in federal court, Washington, DC, demanding their release; lawyers say clients David Hicks, Asif Iqbal and Shafiq Rasul are not terrorists and that their detention is fundamental violation of due process guarantees of Constitution; photo (M)

headline: Bush Vows to Help Peru Fight Rebels and Keep Andes Region Stable
abstract: Pres Bush, visiting Peru, pledges to help Pres Alejandro Toledo fight Marxist guerrillas on Colombian border to keep Andes region stable; photos; reaffirms commitment to Andean trade agreement and says Peace Corps will return after nearly three decades; Bush also meets with leaders of Colombia, Bolivia and Ecuador and expresses irritation at US Senate's delay in renewing treaty; says he has not decided on resuming drug surveillance flights over Peru (M)

headline: Returning Tundra's Rhythm to the Inuit, in Film
abstract: Saturday Profile of Zacharias Kunuk, whose film The Fast Runner (Atanarjuat), based on Arctic folk tale, has won awards at Cannes and in Canada; 44-year-old Kunuk is first Inuk to direct feature-length motion picture, one performed entirely by Inuit actors in their own language; Kunuk himself still lives in Igloolik, 125 miles north of Arctic Circle, where he edits videotape in shack on edge of tundra, and dons extra dog skins to keep warm; interview; photo (M)

headline: With Candor, Powell Charms Global MTV Audience
abstract: Secretary of State Colin Powell candidly fields earnest questions on US government policies posed by MTV audience of young people from around world, linked via satellite on program Be Heard; questions range from condoms and AIDS to Afghanistan and Powell's experiences as African-American (S)

headline: New Agency Will Not Lie, Top Pentagon Officials Say
abstract: Senior Pentagon and administration officials say new Pentagon office will not be allowed to tell lies to promote American views overseas; office has come under criticism; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld defends Pentagon's need to conduct secret activities intended to deceive adversaries during times of conflict, including current war on terrorism; new agency, Office of Strategic Influence, was formed after Sept 11 attacks to coordinate disparate information operations geared toward assisting military overseas; Vice Pres Dick Cheney tells reporters that Pentagon should not use public information channels to disseminate false or misleading items as part of military campaign against terrorism (M)

headline: U.S. Team to Start Helping Afghans Build New Army
abstract: US will open complex, dangerous military mission in Afghanistan when Maj Gen Charles C Campbell arrives to make good on Pres Bush's pledge to help Afghanistan build national army and end decades of warlord rule; Campbell interview; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LIBERTY INTERNATIONAL, London, Britain's fifth-largest real estate company, said it had bought the 850,000-square-foot Serramonte Shopping Center in Daly City, Calif., for $119 million.    MAYTAG, Newton, Iowa, the maker of washers and dryers, said it would sell its parts business in Jefferson City, Mo., to an unnamed powdered-metal manufacturer. Maytag will shift limited refrigeration manufacturing to a plant in Amana, Iowa, and continue to buy washer and dryer components from the Jefferson City plant.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: DVD Service Plans Stock Offering
abstract: Online DVD rental service Netflix Inc files to sell as much as $115 million worth of stock to public (S)

headline: Vote at Delta Is Key Test For Unions
abstract: Results of largest organizing vote at any company in more than three decades will be learned Feb 1 when federal officials are scheduled to announce whether majority of 19,000 flight attendants at Delta Air Lines voted to join Association of Flight Attendants; some of union's supporters at Delta doubt that four-year campaign will succeed; other are less pessimistic but admit that winning at Delta, which has long resisted unions, was always uphill battle; Delta has fought hard to defeat organizing drive; photo (M)

headline: Wall Street Highflier to Outcast: A Woman's Story
abstract: Interview with Allison K Schieffelin, former convertible-bond sales representative at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter who has filed sex discrimination suit against brokerage firm; Schieffelin says she was fired in October after complaining she had been denied additional pay and promotion she had earned; photos (M)

headline: Bush, Calling U.S. 'a Nation Guided by Faith,' Urges Freedom of Worship in China
abstract: Religious freedom should be welcomed rather than feared, President Bush said in a speech broadcast across China today, and he held up the United States as an example of ''a nation guided by faith.''    Mr. Bush repeatedly pressed his theme that religious and political freedom would not lead to chaos, using words that were both a forceful projection of his own religious faith and a subtle criticism of what he sees as the oppressiveness of President Jiang Zemin's government.

headline: Soldier and Son Who Thrived On Risk and Army Discipline
abstract: Profile of Sgt First Class Nathan Ross Chapman, who is first American serviceman killed in Afghanistan by enemy fire; photo (M)

headline: Gains in Chip Industry Fuel Hope in Korea
abstract: Computer chip business is source of economic hope in South Korea; Hynix Semiconductor say it has raised prices about 30 percent, its third increase in month; there are also indications Hynix, deep in debt and struggling to revamp, is making progress in talks to sell some operations to American rival, Micron Technologies, to raise cash; Samsung Electronics also reports prices are heading higher, and major German manufacturer, Infineon Technologies, could expect better terms in new sales contracts with customers; South Korea's commerce ministry announces that weak prices for semiconductors and other electronic products left country about 5 percent short of its goal of $10 billion trade surplus for 2001; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: U.S. Trade Official Cites New Approach
abstract: United States trade representative Robert B Zoellick says during visit to Kenya that African Growth and Opportunity Act of 2000 represents new US approach to helping Africa; act gives 35 African countries duty-free access to American markets (S)

headline: Nothing Says 'Mogul' Like a Free Whatsit
abstract: Vignettes from World Economic Forum meeting; hottest item is hand-held computer given every participant (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Loss At Airline
abstract: Air Canada reports fourth-quarter net loss of 380 million Canadian dollars ($236.9 million) compared with loss of 274 million Canadian dollars year earlier; chief executive Robert Milton pledges aggressive program of cost and debt reduction; photo (S)

headline: Importance of Being Important, With Music
abstract: Irving Azoff holds talks about buying several small music artist-management concerns and melding them into one big powerhouse; sees opportunity for managers to reassert themselves at time when record companies are under assault on many fronts, from regulators to renegade online music services to newly asertive artists; bill in California's legislature would repeal law that ties artists to record company for seven-year contracts; Azoff is courting banker Ethan Penner to back his music venture; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: More Asylum Seekers
abstract: Interior Min Otto Schily reports that number of asylum seekers in Germany rose 12.4 percent last year to 88,287, and that 5.3 percent were granted right to stay, up from 3 percent in 2000; says rise underlines need for reform of immigration laws including asylum policy (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Linda Davis was named a production artist at Archer/Malmo, Memphis. She had held a similar post at Sossaman & Associates, Memphis.

headline: Argentine Leader Seeks Broad Powers in Economic Crisis
abstract: New Argentine Pres Eduardo Duhalde, having urged Argentines to stop buying foreign goods, sends Congress 'public emergency law' that would give him sweeping powers to deal with economic crisis, including ending policy of pegging peso's value to US dollar; public anger grows as banks refuse to acceept pesos; photos (M)

headline: Pakistan Pursues Taliban And Al Qaeda Fighters Who Fled Afghanistan
abstract: Pakistani officials say government is pursuing large numbers of Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters who crossed into country from Afghanistan in recent months and are now believed to be hiding in tribal villages or large cities; say border is mostly secure and they do not believe forces now battling American troops in eastern Afghanistan have re-entered Afghanistan from Pakistan (M)

headline: ENRON SOUGHT AID OF TREASURY DEPT. TO GET BANK LOANS
abstract: Bush administration says Enron Corp president Greg Whalley repeatedly called Treasury Dept official Peter R Fisher last fall seeking help in arranging bank loans for company as it scrambled to avoid collapse; says Fisher did not intervene on Enron's behalf; Enron spokeswoman claims Whalley's conversations with Fisher, under secretary for domestic finance, were 'informational'; Treasury Dept also discloses that Robert E Rubin, who was secretary in Clinton administration and is now official at Citigroup, called Fisher to ask if Fisher would consider calling credit-rating agencies to encourage them to work with Enron's bankers to avert immediate downgrade in Enron's debt; says Fisher said such a call would not be appropriate, and Rubin agreed; analysts say Citigroup has lent at least $750 million to Enron; photo; chart (M)
