headline: Under Pressure, Chinese Newspaper Pulls ExposÃ© on a Charity
abstract: China's most influential liberal newspaper, Southern Weekend, reportedly cancels article on misuse of funds at large government-backed charity, Project Hope, which helps poor children stay in school; government pressure suspected (M)

headline: Executive Life: The Boss; Life Is a 3-D Puzzle
abstract: Alan J Lacy, chairman and chief executive of Sears, Roebuck & Co, writes The Boss column, recalling his years at Georgia Tech; photo (M)

headline: Personal Business; Home Selling Is No Longer 'One Size Fits All'
abstract: Home sellers now have options beside real estate broker charging 6 percent commission; depending on how involved seller wants to become, he or see can use real estate Web sites, discount brokers and companies like America's Choice International, which have Web sites and also provide limited assistance for do-it-yourself home sellers; even some full-service brokers are cutting their commussions or offering 'a la carte' services; photo (M)

headline: That P in PC Now Stands For Picture
abstract: Software for managing and editing digital photographs proliferates; chart details features; user can manipulate photos with relative ease, transmitting them or using them on Web sites; drawings; photos (M)

headline: Connecticut Feels Fallout From Enron
abstract: Trying to make up for $220 million lost in a murky deal with the Enron Corporation, the Connecticut state trash authority voted yesterday to raise its rates, effectively increasing household garbage fees in 70 towns -- representing more than a third of the state -- by nearly $50 a year.    Though the State Legislature may challenge the fees, they represent perhaps the most concrete example of how Enron's collapse has jolted the finances of people who never worked for, held shares in, or knew the first thing about the company. The deal with Enron, meanwhile, has set off an election-year political fight in Connecticut.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Chinese Leader Visits
abstract: China Pres Jiang Zemin visits Vietnam and calls for neighborly relations (S)

headline: Bleak Phone-Equipment Outlook Leads Marconi to Cut More Jobs
abstract: Marconi of Britain will lay off additional 4,000 workers, about one-quarter of them in US, to cut costs because it believes that telecommunications market is unlikely to recover before 2003; sales in core phone-equipment business dropped 37 percent in quarter ended Dec 31, to about $1 billion, excluding revenue from profitable units that Marconi is selling; those sales will bring in $1.16 billion (M)

headline: Storm Brews in Japan Over Seaweed
abstract: Seaweed farm near Ariake, Japan, is being choked by $2 billion causeway; Mitsunobu Shinozuka, who grows seaweed delicacy known as nori, has grown seaweed in Isahaya Bay for 25 years, but he fears for his farm's future; causeway, which cuts off bay from Ariake Sea, was completed in 1997; in very next year, output in Isahaya Bay dived nearly 50 percent; photos; map (M)

headline: People
abstract: Luana Floccuzio is named to new post of partner and chief operating officer at Dan Klores Communications (S)

headline: For Women, the Price of Success
abstract: Lisa Belkin column on childlessness among high-achieving, high-earning women, subject of forthcoming book by Sylvia Ann Hewlett, Creating a Life: Professional Women and the Quest for Children; drawing (M)

headline: Annan Cautions Business as Forum Ends
abstract: UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan closes World Economic Forum in Manhattan with stern message from devastation of terrorist attacks on September 11; says world has entered new millennium through 'gate of fire' such as no one ever wished to see, but which is summons to global elite to provide hope to many condemned to lives extreme poverty and degradation; warns business leaders cannot ignore inhuman conditions in which much of world lives; photo (M)

headline: Layoffs at Morgan Stanley
abstract: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter lays off 120 employees who worked in its information technology department (S)

headline: Who's Keeping the Accountants Accountable?
abstract: Collapse of Enron Corp and role of its auditors, Arthur Andersen & Co, have strengthened discussion in accounting profession, among regulators and within Congress over future of industry; Rep Jim Leach says alleged actions by Arthur Andersen, including shredding of Enron documents, is potentially breach of CPA standards and ethics and result is likely to be careful analysis of profession's standards and means for enforcing those standards; accounting firms have come to rely more on consulting work rather than on traditional audits for their revenues, raising questions about their ability to stand up to clients if improper bookeeping is suspected; industry may be greater oversight; photo (M)

headline: What Ails Kmart?
abstract: Barry Hornstein letter comments on problems at Kmart; drawing

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Soldiers Executed For Killing Priest
abstract: Ugandan firing squad executes two soldiers found guilty of murdering Irish priest, Declan O'Toole (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Stalemate Continues
abstract: Congo government and two main rebel groups remain in deadlock over which political parties should be allowed to take part in talks in South Africa (S)

headline: Microsoft Hearings Are Postponed for a Week
abstract: Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly delays for week hearings to determine whether Microsoft Corp should face tougher sanctions in antitrust case; complains state attorneys general gave court revised remedy proposal with numerous changes just week before hearings were to begin (M)a

headline: Monterrey's Poor Sinking in Rising Economic Tide
abstract: Pres Vicente Fox of Mexico says Monterrey is example of prosperity possible in developing nations; world leaders and ministers in Monterrey for UN conference on how rich naitons can help pooor ones are surrounded by business-class bubble; outside, on streets of Monterrey, many people are dirt poor, surviving on few dollars a day or less; photo; map (M)

headline: A TV spot, to be broadcast nationwide, will honor the man who had a dream.
abstract: Seattle office of DDB Worldwide is introducing powerful public service television commercial to honor Rev Dr Martin Luther King Jr and his civil rights campaign; photo (M)

headline: Sexual Harassment: Are Curbs Working?
abstract: Sexual Harassment: Are Curbs Working?*

headline: GLAMIS TO BUY FRANCISCO GOLD FOR $121 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: Glamis Gold Ltd agrees to buy Francisco Gold Corp for 192.2 million Canadian dollars ($121.5 million) in stock to expand in Latin America (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Eurotunnel's Loss Widens
abstract: Eurotunnel says losses grew to 132 million pounds ($187 million) in 2001 from 124 million pounds year earlier; graph (S)

headline: Custom-made chic is edging out brands
abstract: LONDONâ€”  It used to be the rule that to be fashionable all you needed was the right label. If the inside of your jacket bore the name Giorgio Armani and your polo shirt featured a small polo player, you could consider yourself stylish and that was the end of that. But brands and labels are losing their power to denote class instantly. Instead, if you want prestige it better be custom-made.

headline: Several Strands Seem to Twist Around Global And Investors
abstract: Financial relationship between group of Singapore investors and two Global Crossing directors became more extensive in days after Global Crossing filed for bankruptcy protection; relationship of directors with Singapore investors, whose full scope has not been disclosed, is significant because investors have links to Singapore Technologies Telemedia, which has made offer to buy Global Crossing; Global Crossing delays reporting its full financial results because it says its auditor Arthur Andersen has not concluded its audit for 2001; says it expects to report significant loss for quarter, including write-downs of about $8 billion to reflect drop in value of some assets; Global Crossing's chairman Gary Winnick and another director Steven J Green became part owners of last fall in Singapore investment firm KI Ventures Ltd; KI Ventures is ultimately controlled by Singapore's Temasek Holdings, which also controls Singapore Technologies; Winnick, who has resigned from KI's board, and Green say their involvement with KI Ventures was not related to effort to buy Global Crossing; closer look indicates that Winnick and Green's involvement with Singapore investors deepened after bankruptcy protection filing on Jan 28; KI Ventures on Feb 7 said it paid $14.2 million for minority stake in American wireless company; announcement did not mention that wireless company, PrimeCo Personal Communications, is partly owned by Winnick's investment firm, Pacific Capital Group (M)

headline: 2 Early Enron Lenders Didn't See the End Coming
abstract: Citigroup and J P Morgan Chase, biggest lenders to Enron Corp when it collapsed late last year, did not see end coming; banks have been lending Enron money since mid-1980's; Citigroup disclosed last week that its exposure to Enron exceeded $1 billion; J P Morgan Chase had even more exposure to Enron at end; ties have been so broad and deep that it is possible one or both of banks will have made money from Enron even after big losses they estimated they would suffer; together, they took more than $680 million in charges against their fourth-quarter earnings to cover potential losses related to company (M)

headline: Seized Arms Would Have Vastly Extended Arafat Arsenal
abstract: American officials claim Palestinian Authority officials drew up shopping list of advance weapons more than year ago that closely matches cargo of rockets, antitank grenades and explosives carried by Karine A, freighter that Israeli commandos stormed in Red Sea on Jan 3; Israel has seized on Palestinian effort to buy weapons from Iranian sources through senior official of Lebanese group Hezbollah as evidence of its vulnerability in region; it portrays attempt at smuggling as proof that Palestinian leadership is planning for war while talking of peace; it is also laying foundation for central contention of Prime Min Ariel Sharon: that Israel must retain territory in West Bank as buffer against enhanced threat it fears may arrive with Palestinian state in West Bank and Gaza Strip; photo; map; chronology (M)

headline: Israel Eases Armed Blockade as U.S. Peace Envoy Returns
abstract: The Bush administration's peace envoy returned to the Middle East today with the seemingly modest goal of trying to bring the Israelis and Palestinians together to resume negotiations for a cease-fire.

headline: Railtrack Bailout Expected This Week
abstract: Nonprofit company set up by British government will offer Railtrack Group 500 million pounds ($712 million) for its Railtrack unit, insolvent owner of Britain's train tracks and stations, as part of 1.3 billion pound bailout; government will contribute 300 million pounds to bailout; move, seen by some as effort to compensate shareholders and placate private sector, spurs renewed calls for Transportation Sec Stephen Byers to resign (S)

headline: Briefly Noted
abstract: DISCUSSING SURRENDER More than 15 top Taliban leaders, most of them ex-cabinet members, are in contact with Afghan authorities in Kandahar over their possible surrender, according to Khalid Pashtun, a senior aide to Gov. Gul Agha Shirzai. Asked whether the Taliban's supreme leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, was among them, he said:

headline: E.P.A. Official Disputed Energy Panel's '01 Report
abstract: Environmental Protection Agency associate administrator Thomas J Gibson objected to draft of Bush administration energy report last year that said environmental regulations caused energy shortages, according to copy of confidential memorandum released by Rep Henry A Waxman; Waxman releases report as part of his campaign to force Vice Pres Dick Cheney, who was chairman of energy task force, to release records; General Accounting Office has said it will sue Cheney to try to force administration to turn over task force documents (M)

headline: Father Knows Best, Including Ozzy
abstract: MTV plans reality series following everyday life of British rock star Ozzy Osbourne, 53, and his family in their Beverly Hills mansion; family comments, session with critics; photo (M)

headline: Personal Business; Consumer Tools for Holding Bill Collectors at Bay
abstract: Debt collection efforts appear to be rising in number, sophistication and aggressiveness; Fair Debt Collection Practices Act of 1996 protects consumers from third-party debt collectors who engage in unfair, deceptive or abusive practices; Federal Trade Commission Act prohibits unfair or deceptive practices by lenders, and this protection extends to in-house collectors of lenders like banks and credit card companies; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Identity Services Challenged
abstract: Electronic Privacy Information Center urges state law enforcment officials to investigate Microsoft Corp's online identity services, saying they expose consumers to fraud, increase in unsolicited commercial e-mail messages and 'release, sale and theft of their personal information'; Microsoft spokesman Rick Miller says claims are totally unfounded (S)

headline: A Long Time Ago, in a Lab Far Away . . .
abstract: Article traces genesis of video games back to Spacewar, created at Massachusetts Institute of Technology by six programmers: Dan Edwards, Martin Graetz, Alan Kotok, Steve Russell, Peter Samson and Wayne Wiitanen; game was early inspiration for innovators who founded Apple and other computer companies; brief profiles; drawings illustrate game; photos (L)

headline: Voters in Slovakia May Offer Ousted Leader a Fourth Chance
abstract: Vladimir Meciar appears likely to win parliamentary elections in Slovakia four years after he was ousted as prime minister amid charges of corruption, crony capitalism and economic stagnation; his re-election could cost country its chance to be admitted to NATO and may slow its entry into European Union; hard core of Slovaks apparently still find Meciar's brand of populism and nationalism appealing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Pipeline Approval Expected
abstract: Thai government is expected to approve $500 million gas pipeline project by Malaysia's Petroliam Nasional and Thai national oil company, PTT, by end of March (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: ID Card Contract Awarded
abstract: Hong Kong awards government contract to manufacture digitally encoded identification cards to consortium led by Pacific Century CyberWorks; contract, worth $21 million, calls for CyberWorks to supply 1.2 million ID cards, as well as related hardware and software; cards will hold chip that has digital replica of cardholder's thumbprint; cards will be introduced next year (S)

headline: Business Travel; Pants and profiling: Life on the front lines of checkpoint security at the nation's airports.
abstract: JOHN D. CORNELIUS, a flight attendant for Alaska Airlines, already has a nomination in mind for 2002 Person of the Year. The nominee is a male airline passenger, identity unknown, who recently made the ultimate gesture of futility while being rudely prodded and frisked at a security checkpoint at the Seattle airport.    ''They started wanding and wanting to check everything, really giving the guy a hard time, and he just went and dropped his pants, right there in the middle of everybody,'' Mr. Cornelius said. ''To myself, I'm like, right on!''

headline: Accountants Balk
abstract: A board that oversees accounting ethics and disciplinary issues resigned after the S.E.C. chairman proposed creating another body that could render it irrelevant.      Business Day, Page C1.

headline: Briefly Noted
abstract: Brief reports on events in Afghanistan and war on terrorism

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: The trade publications Advertising Age and Adweek named their agencies of the year for 2001. Advertising Age, part of Crain Communications, made these selections: Global agency of the year, BBBO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group; global media agency of the year, Carat, part of the Aegis Group; and United States agency of the year, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group. Adweek, part of VNU, made these selections: Global agency of the year, also BBDO; United States agency of the year, Deutsch, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: Uneasy Mix Of Contrasts At Airports Of Moscow
abstract: Article on different ways Moscow's Domodedovo and Sheremetyevo airports are operated; says sluggish, state-owned and -operated Sheremetyevo, near-monopoly on international flights since it was built in 1980, has begun losing clients to competitor called Domodedovo International Airport; holds Domodedovo, also state owned, is run by nimble, privately owned air transport company called East Line Group; says British Airways is considering moving its flights to Domodedovo from Sheremetyevo because ground services at Sheremetyevo are destroying whole traveling experience; Sergei Belyayev, new chief executive of Sheremetyevo, has promised to fix some of airports problems; photos (M)

headline: Personal Business; When Pension and Unemployment Checks Don't Mix
abstract: People who have been laid off from their jobs may sometimes run afoul of provision of Federal Unemployment Tax Act that requires states to offset or reduce unemployment benefits against pensions to avoid what may be perceived as 'double dippling'; each state interprets law as it sees fit; New York and North Carolina are among the few states that count rollovers from defined-benefit pension plans or 401(k)'s into an Individual Retirement Account as receipt of pension and will reduce unemployment benefits accordingly; 20 states will also offset unemployment benefits if someone is collecting Social Security benefits; photo (M)

headline: Disney Is Cutting 250 Jobs at Animation Unit
abstract: Walt Disney Feature Animation tells 250 employees that they are either being laid off or that their contracts will not be renewed over next 12 months; president Thomas Schumacher comments (M)

headline: Son and Sister Of Enron Chief Secured Deals
abstract: Sister and son of Enron's former chairman Kenneth L Lay benefited from extensive business dealings with company; public records and interviews reveal that over last three years Lay and son Mark invested about $1 million in two privately-held technology companies in which Enron was involved and that in 1997, as shareholder group complained about such ties, Enron acquired company owned by Mark Lay; Enron hired Mark Lay with guaranteed $1-million deal over three years, and for years has used Houston travel agency co-owned by Sharon Lay; Mark Lay, who left Enron last year to enter Baptist seminary, paid nearly $315,000 to settle civil case related to federal probe of energy company he controlled; no criminal charges were brought; Mark Lay discusses dealings; chart tracking his career with various companies (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sirius Offering Draws $158 Million
abstract: Sirius Satellite Radio expects to gross nearly $158 million in stock offering scheduled to close Jan 8; new funds should sustain its operations into second quarter of next year; Sirius network, which includes 100 channels of digital radio programming, is to begin limited service in February and is expected to be available nationwide by third quarter (S)

headline: ALLTRISTA, MAKER OF CANNING JARS, AGREES TO BUY TILIA
abstract: Alltrista, largest seller of Ball-brand home-canning jars, acquires Tilia International, which makes vacuum-packaging products for home use, for $145 million and $15 million in Tilia debt (S)

headline: Ex-Publisher of The Times Is Giving Up Seat on Board
abstract: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger is retiring from the board of The New York Times Company, completing the transition to a fourth generation of family leadership at the company.    Cathy J. Sulzberger, Mr. Sulzberger's daughter and a partner in the LHIW Real Estate Development Partnership, has been nominated for election to the board, the company said yesterday. Her great-grandfather Adolph S. Ochs acquired the newspaper in 1896.

headline: Bomb Kills at Least 8 Near Lima Embassy
abstract: A bomb exploded outside the U.S. Embassy in Lima, Peru, late last night, killing at least 8 people and injuring 40, just three days before President Bush is scheduled to arrive for talks as part of his trip to Latin America. No Americans were reported killed in the blast, which severely damaged a hotel, shops and restaurants in a busy neighborhood in the Peruvian capital. It was the first time in several years that a car bomb had been set off in the city. No one claimed responsibility for the explosion.    Article, Page A20.

headline: Company Stock in 401(k)'s
abstract: Letter from Steve Hill (Weyerhaeuser Co) replies to David Leonhardt's Feb 17 article on 401(k) plans; defends his company's plan

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Keep Hands On Wheel, Not Phone
abstract: New Irish law, spurred by outrage over road deaths, sets heavy fines and possible jail terms for using hand-held mobile phone while driving; exempts hands-free devices (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Trades Equity For Debt
abstract: Qwest Communications International, in effort to reduce its debt load, says it has traded 9.9 million shares of stock for just over $97 million in outstanding bonds; says Securities and Exchange Commission has expressed qualms about Qwest's recent filing to sell new securities, forcing delay in that part of company's financial restructuring; chief executive Joseph P Nacchio comments; photo (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Amazon.com Posts a Profit, Helped by Efficiency Drive  After losing $2.8 billion since it was founded in 1995, Amazon.com reported its first quarterly profit, $5 million, validating at least in part its strategy to grow rapidly first and worry about profits later.    The results were far better than expected because a yearlong efficiency drive sharply cut costs even as sales grew. An accounting gain related to the decline of the value of the euro provided a final push. [Page C4.]    Bush 'Outraged' by Enron's Actions  President Bush said he was ''outraged'' that Enron misled its employees and investors, including his mother-in-law, who apparently lost more than $8,000 in an ill-timed investment in Enron. For the first time, Mr. Bush called for government action to force greater corporate disclosure of financial information. [A1.]

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Congress to Investigate Wall St.'s Ties With Enron  Congressional investigators are widening their investigation of the Enron debacle to focus on Wall Street and the role it played in the company's rise and collapse.    The Congressional inquiries will examine the way Wall Street firms structured and sold Enron's limited partnerships and will look into the reasons Wall Street firms were issuing recommendations to buy Enron stock while the firms had detailed information about Enron's poor financial condition. [Page A1.]

headline: Commercial Lending Increased in 2001
abstract: Mortgage Bankers Association of America says commercial mortgage lending rose 19 percent in 2001 as property owners took advantage of falling interest rates to refinance loans; lending rose to $73.8 billion from $62 million in 2000; American Council of Life Insurers says commercial mortgage rates averaged 7.22 percent last year, down from 8.17 percent in 2000 (S)

headline: The Perils Of Relying Too Heavily On Credit
abstract: William H Gross, who manages world's largest bond fund for Pacific Investment Management, answers questions on his concern that General Electric has become too reliant on commercial paper; says he was blindsided by GE's sale of $11 billion worth of bonds several weeks ago and its filing to sell additional $50 billion of debt; says GE and other big issuers of commercial paper do not disclose enough to bond investors; remains bullish on corporate bonds; photo (M)

headline: Investors Feel Some Ripples At J. P. Morgan
abstract: J P Morgan Chase finds itself on defensive after string of losses and bad publicity; company has large loans to Enron, Kmart and Global Crossing, all now in bankruptcy, and additional exposure in Argentina; its large portfolio of venture capital investments continues to fall in value, though some of those losses are hedged; J P Morgan's executives have been reassuring employees in recent weeks and telling investors that much of market's anxieties about company are overblown; chief executive William B Harrison told employees on Feb 4 that company is addressing its problems; several Wall Street analysts believe bank's shares, down 12.4 percent this year, are relatively cheap; they say stock will not rally until investment banking activity picks up; graph; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 2nd Satellite Radio Service Begins
abstract: Sirius Satellite Radio introduces its satellite-delivered radio service in Denver, Houston, Phoenix and Jackson, Miss, hoping to catch up with competitor, XM Satellite Radio, whose service began operating last September and expanded nationwide in November; service costs $12.95 per month and requires customers to buy antenna and receiver for $249 (S)

headline: Saluting the Tape Cartridge
abstract: Abbott Wool letter comments on Feb 21 article on backing up a PC; cites tape cartridge drives as having great advantage for backup

headline: FOX WILL LEASE ITS SATURDAY MORNING SLOT TO 4KIDS
abstract: Fox Broadcasting will lease its Saturday morning programming slot to 4Kids Entertainment Inc for $101.2 million over four years, making Fox second network to leave children's time period (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Opposition To Sun Life Deal
abstract: Canada's Jarislowsky Fraser says it will vote against Sun Life Financial Services' bid of 6.9 billion Canadian dollars ($4.3 billion) for Clarica Life Insurance because of it calls excessively high breakup fee that would be paid to Sun Life if its bid fails to go through (S)

headline: Mayhem, and Far From the Nicest Kind
abstract: Matt Richtel's Backslash column on whether violent video games have any redeeming content focuses on Grand Theft Auto III, popular new video game from Take Two Interactive Software that has been banned in Australia because of its violent nature, denounced by Sens Joseph I Lieberman and Herb Kohl, and disdained by some video game industry followers and players as unwelcome plunge to new depths; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Cross-Border Telecom Merger
abstract: Sonera of Finland and Telia of Sweden say they will merge to form Nordic region's largest telecommunications company; Finnish government still owns 53 percent of Sonera, and Swedish government owns 71 percent of Telia (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Tyco says its earnings will fall short, and the company backs away from a planned deal.
abstract: Tyco International Ltd says its earnings will fall short of its previous forecasts and that it will not complete takeover of C R Bard Inc, medical supplies company; Tyco had agreed in May to buy Bard for $3.2 billion, but Bard grew skittish about deal as Tyco's stock plunged; Tyco chairman L Dennis Kozlowski comments (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Citi Man Is Thinking Big but Thriftily in the Midwest
abstract: Jay S Fishman, who left Citigroup to become chief executive of St Paul Companies, is following game plan much like that of Citigroup chief executive Sanford I Weill; Fishman has been sketching sweeping vision of lean, hard-charging financial conglomerate; it will concentrate on most profitable lines of insurance, but also expand investment products like mutual funds and variable annuities; Fishman says he is thinking about acquisitions; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Aether To Cut 25% Of Work Force
abstract: Aether Systems, which develops software and wireless data products and services, will cut about 225 jobs, or about 25 percent of its work force (S)

headline: Club Med Has First Loss in 4 Years and Closes 6 More Resorts
abstract: Reflecting the plunge in international travel since Sept. 11, the resort operator Club Méditerranée said today that it would close six more of its locations and eliminate its dividend.    The company reported a loss of 70 million euros ($62.5 million) for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, its first loss in four years and a sharp reversal of fortune from the previous year.

headline: Enron Avoided Income Taxes In 4 of 5 Years
abstract: Enron paid no income taxes in four of last five years, using almost 900 subsidiaries in tax-haven countries and other techniques; analysis of its financial reports to shareholders shows it was also eligible for $382 million in tax refunds; company used strategies common among businesses to avoid taxes; it also used some unusual methods, including creation of so many subsidiaries abroad; two such subsidiaries are accused by group of insurers of engaging in sham transactions in tax haven; study by Citizens for Tax Justice in Oct 2000 found that of half of Fortune 500 companies, 24 owed no tax in 1998, up from 13 in 1997 and 16 in 1996; tax-haven subsidiaries enabled Enron to create partnerships to eliminate taxes using techniques that came under attack from Treasury Dept and Internal Revenue Service during Clinton administration; chart (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: Kind Words for Andersen
abstract: Enron Corp chairman Kenneth L Lay, in Sept 2000 letter to then Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Arthur Levitt, praised its auditors, Arthur Andersen & Co; Enron fired Arthur Andersen last week (S)

headline: Japan Says It Will Double Its Annual Whale Harvest in Pacific
abstract: Japan notifies International Whaling Commission that it will double number of whales it kills in North Pacific each year under program that it describes as scientific research but that American and some European officials say is commercial whaling; Amerian officials say expanded whale hunt by Japan would bring condemnation from US (M)

headline: Internet Offering Soars, Just Like Old Times
abstract: PayPal, service that lets people pay for goods and services online, goes public at $13 a share, hits high of $22.44 before closing at $20.09, raising $70.2 million by day's end; is first consumer-oriented Internet start-up to go public since dot-com bust; offering succeeds despite fact that company has lost hundreds of millions of dollars and faces old-economy stalwards; provokes questions about whether investors are responding to promise of single company or demonstrating renewed appetite for dot.coms (M)

headline: Tokyo Journal; Fujimori, the Exile, Repackages His Peruvian Past
abstract: Alberto K Fujimori, former president of Peru, is highly popular in Japan, where he lives in self-imposed exile; he has reportedly consulted leaders of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party about running for seat in Japan's Parliament; political friends advise him to wait for year, so voters will not see candidacy as ploy to duck his extradition on charges of involvement in human rights abuses and embezzlement during his time in office; photo (M)

headline: Chinese Police Detain Westerners in Falun Gong Protest
abstract: More than 40 Westerners are detained in Beijing as they stage racuous demonstration in Tiananmen Square in support of outlawed Falun Gong movement; photo; 14 Europeans are later detained in hotel rooms; incident comes as Pres Bush prepares to visit (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Another Bidder For Dabhol
abstract: Government-owned Gas Authority of India Ltd declares its intent to bid for Dabhol Power, which is 65 percent owned by Enron Corp; India's Tata Power and BSES are already in process of due diligence ahead of making their bids (S)

headline: Foe's Identity Still Unclear In a Skirmish Aided by U.S.
abstract: Article on skirmish involving US forces near provincial town of Khost, Afghanistan, in which air strikes were used to quell fighting among rival warlords; incident underscores murky nature of fighting in Afghanistan; US warplanes went to aid of Afghan government commander whose soldiers came under attack, even though exact composition and identity of foe was unclear (M)

headline: Local Voters In India Stun Leader Of Top Party
abstract: Hindu nationalist party suffers stunning defeat to Congress Party in Delhi city elections, following losses in all four recent state elections; Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee says his government is partly responsible and calls for introspection (M)

headline: Four Finalists Vie For RVing Account
abstract: GO RVing Coalition, group of companies involved in recreational vehicle industry, narrows review for its advertising account to four agencies from seven; billings estimated at $40 million over three years (S)

headline: Tread the Boards, Watch the Rubble
Fire, Alligators, Maybe 500 Flies: Stay Tuned
abstract: Latest versions of television game shows try to draw in viewers with gimmicks and shock tactics; photos; many shows have flopped in last year but lure of low production costs and hope of finding new blockbuster keeps networks exploring altnerative formats (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Sales Off 40% In January
abstract: Semiconductor Industry Association says worldwide sales of computer chips fell 40 percent in January; sales fell to $10 billion from $16.6 billion in January 2001 and dropped 1.7 percent from $10.2 billion in December; graph (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Earthlink Expands Wireless Offerings
abstract: Technology Briefing: Earthlink Expands Wirel

headline: To Shrink the Pay Gap, Turn Up the Volume
abstract: Letter from Linda Chavez-Thompson (AFL-CIO) comments on Jeffrey Seglin's March 17 column on widening pay gap between men and women who are managers

headline: Times Are Tough, but Those Who Save Aren't Panicking, Poll Finds
abstract: New York Times poll finds people continue to invest in 401(k)'s and IRA's, even as stock market volatility affects their retirement savings; some are changing allocations of savings and many try to save more in uncertain economy; photo; (special section, Retirement) (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Land Prices Fall
abstract: Land prices in Japan fell for the 11th year, a sign that deflation is persistent and growing. A government report said property prices fell 5.9 percent last year, the fastest decline in nine years. Commercial real estate prices, a crucial i2

headline: Shift of Emphasis In Saturn Campaign
abstract: Saturn plans shift in advertising stress, while retaining core elements of car brand's current campaigns (M)

headline: JUDGE DELAYS DECISION ON CAR RENTAL CONSOLIDATION
abstract: Federal Bankruptcy Judge Mary F Walrath declines to rule on motion by ANC Rental Corp to consolidate rental car operations at four airports and instead asks objectors to file briefs in support of their argument by April 5; says she needs briefs to summarize relevant state statutes and specific provisions of contracts that Hertz Corp and Avis Rent a Car contend prohibit ANC's proposal; ANC Rental estimates that consolidating its Alamo and National rental car chains at four airports will save about $4.3 million per year (S)

headline: Oval Office or Corner Office?
abstract: 150 executives responding to Council of Public Relations Firms survey on which of eight current and former government officials they would want as their boss said Vice Pres Dick Cheney and Secretary of State Colin L powell, each with 23 percent, followed by Pres Bush and former New York Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani, with 15 percent, and former Pres Bill Clinton, with 3 percent; no one picked former Vice Pres Al Gore (S)

headline: Computer Associates Names 2 to Board Seats
abstract: Computer Associates International Inc names Walter Schuetze, former Securities and Exchange Commission chief accountant, and Jay Lorsch, corporate governance consultant, to its board; announcement comes as shareholder, Sam Wyly, reemerges as dissident seeking to oust chairman Charles Wang (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bayer Forecasts Better Results
abstract: Bayer issues surprisingly optimistic forecast for 'much higher' net income this year; confirms that its net income fell 47 percent in 2001 (S)

headline: Personal Business; Networking and Social Graces Aren't Incompatible
abstract: Courses and seminars are available on etiquette of networking, whether to find job, drum up business, become appointed to corporate board or professional organization or even break into particular social circle; career and etiquette consultants say race to network has fostered almost appalling breakdown in manners; photo (M)

headline: ROYAL BANK OF SCOTLAND CONSIDERING PURCHASE IN U.S.
abstract: Royal Bank of Scotland chief executive Fred Goodwin says bank is considering further American acquisitions after posting surge in 2001 net profit, to 2.64 billion pounds ($3.75 billion) from 2.1 billion pounds year earlier (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   9.50       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   6.00       Federal funds   1.69   1.75   5.94       3-month T-bills   1.56   1.55   5.20       6-month T-bills   1.60   1.58   5.03       10-yr. T-infl.   3.37   3.37   3.55       10-yr. T-note   4.83   4.83   5.16       30-yr. headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: A Warning From China
abstract: Japan weighs whether to salvage ship that sank in gun battle in East China Sea (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Google Adds Ad Option
abstract: Technol

headline: Market Place; After Sept. 11, diverging attitudes about the market.
abstract: Six months after Sept 11 terrorist attacks individuals have emerged newly optimistic about stock market, with many believing that any fall in prices will be temporary and that market is fairly valued or even undervalued; institutional investors have become more nervous about risks of market that remains near record high, relative to corporate earnings; results of monthly survey of investor sentiment to be released by Yale School of Management, and written by Robert Shiller, discussed; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: U.S. CONCRETE, Houston, a maker of ready-mixed concrete, said it had bought the assets of a quarry in Hamburg, N.J., from a unit of Lafarge S.A., Paris. Terms were not disclosed.    MEDTRONIC, Minneapolis, a maker of pacemakers and other heart-rhythm devices, said it had acquired the Paceart business from Medical Systems, a unit of General Electric, Fairfield, Conn., adding systems that monitor patients through the Internet. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Court Ruling May Change Landscape For Media
abstract: Analysis of Federal appeals court ruling that government has to reconsider sharp limits on number of stations network can own and striking down regulation that had restricted cable operators from owning television stations; says rulings will probably prompt executives at companies including News Corp, Viacom and Walt Disney Co, which each own many television stations, to seriously consider expanding their empires by acquisition; holds major players in cable television market like AOL Time Warner and Cox Enterprises can now consider significantly expanding their relatively small broadcasting operations (M)

headline: France Confirms Debris Caused Concorde Crash That Killed 113
abstract: French aviation safety agency confirms initial theory that debris on runway led to fiery crash of Air France Concorde in July 2000; says piece of metal left on runway by previous plane, a Continental Airlines jet, punctured tires of Concorde as it rolled down runway on takeoff; says debris flew up into plane's fuel tanks, setting off fire that killed 113 people; holds that Continental conducted maintenance operations that did not conform to regulations, charge Continental has denied; Continental spokesman claims Concorde has history of problems with its tires (M)

headline: Don't Just Multitask, Gadgets Shout: Accessorize
abstract: Panasonic introduces new products, including miniature thermal printer and combination audio-video recorder that is about size of business card; photo (S)

headline: Guarding Your Electronic Wallet
abstract: Advice on guarding home computers against hackers (S)

headline: Be Kind to Your Hard Drive: Clean Out the Cobwebs
abstract: Advice on Systems Tools programs built into Windows operating system and other software to help maintain computer hard drive; drawing (M)

headline: Bush Joined Unit of Enron In '86 Venture To Seek Oil
abstract: Pres Bush, in his earliest known tie to Enron Corp as Texas oil man, joined energy drilling venture organized in 1986 by Enron Oil and Gas subsidiary; drilling operation, which succeeded in striking oil and natural gas in Martin County, Tex, came as Bush's company, Spectrum 7 Energy Corp, was struggling to stay afloat during collapse in world oil prices; company was also in final negotiations to be taken over by Harken Energy; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: AVANEX TO BUY A COMPETITOR, OPLINK COMMUNICATIONS
abstract: Avanex Corp, which makes parts for fiber optic equipment, will buy rival, Oplink Communications Inc, for $287.2 million in stock (S)

headline: Business; Landlord Prepares For a U.S. Makeover
abstract: landlord prepares

headline: A Notebook With Touch Screen For Typing in Close Quarters
abstract: Fujitsu offers tiny LifeBook P-1000 notebook computer featuring touch screen and keyboard and measuring just nine by six inches; photo (S)

headline: Combative Milosevic Displays A Flair for Courtroom Tactics
abstract: Former Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic displays flair for courtroom tactics while acting as own lawyer in war crimes trial in the Hague; conducts combative cross-examination of Mahmut Bakalli, first prosecution witness who was high Communist Party official; pounds Bakalli with questions intended to show Albanians in Kosovo turned to 'terrorism' in quest for separate state leading to war in 1999 in which over 5,000 Kosovo Albanians died; is charged with genocide and other crimes during three wars in Balkans in 1990's--in Bosnia, Croatia and Kosovo; photo (M)

headline: A Brief Spin on a Turntable And, VoilÃ , a 3-D Photograph
abstract: Olympus 3D ScanTop works with digital camera to automatically produce accurate 3-D images of relatively small objects; photo (M)

headline: Business Travel; A flight attendant's new book covers sex and absurdity in the not-always-friendly skies.
abstract: Business Travel column on Elliott Hester's book Plane Insanity: A Flight Attendant's Tales of Sex, Rage and Queasiness at 30,000 Feet; Hester says second printing of book is good sign that we are starting to come out of Sept 11 terrorist attacks (M)

headline: Global Crossing Under Inquiry Of Panel Today
abstract: House Financial Services Committee is scheduled to hold first Congressional hearing on fallout from bankruptcy filing of Global Crossing, whose financial collapse has fueled concerns about accounting practices at some telecommunications companies (M)

headline: After Lilco, A Calmer Arena
abstract: William J Catacosinos comments on investment career he took up after ending stormy tenure as chairman of Long Island Lighting Co in 1998; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | World: Mine Treaty Seen As Success
abstract: International Red Cross marks third anniversary of global treaty banning land mines with report of sharp decline in land mine casualties (S)

headline: U.S. Could Free Up $200 Million in Afghan Funds, Powell Says
abstract: The secretary of state said today that the United States should be able to help free up more than $200 million that could be used to pay government expenses "in the course of this week."

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SWISSAIR GROUP, Zurich, said it would sell Gate Gourmet, its airline catering business, to Texas Pacific Group, San Francisco. Terms were not disclosed.    MARTEK BIOSCIENCES CORP., Columbia, Md., a maker of nutritional oils used in baby food, said it would buy its closely held rival OmegaTech, Boulder, Colo., for about $50 million in stock.

headline: U.S. and Philippine Governments Revive Old Relationship
abstract: Special relationship forged between US and Philippines during World War II, which soured in early 1990's, is revived in aftermath of September 11 terrorist attacks; most visible sign of revival is arrival of American troops to work with Filipino soldiers to defeat Abu Sayyaf terrorists holding two Americans hostage; two nations are discussing treaty that would give US right to store weapons, permanent overflight rights for combat aircraft and right to set up camps in archipelago for short periods; photo (M)

headline: DENDREON SAYS ITS CANCER VACCINE IS IN DOUBT
abstract: Dendreon Corp says its Provenge vaccine for prostate cancer may not make goals set for late-stage study, and its shares fall 38 percent (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA PHILIPPINES: SAFER CELEBRATION New Year's Eve is getting safer, Philippine authorities said. They reported that at least 475 people had been injured nationwide by fireworks and stray bullets. That number is down from 500 last year and is much lower than the 1,500 injuries recorded in recent years. A police spokesman credited economic hardship, saying fewer people today can afford firecrackers or bullets. Â Â  Seth Mydans (NYT).

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Google Removes Anti-Scientology Links
abstract: Google Inc says it removed some links to anti-Scientology Web site from its popular search engine after Church of Scientology told it that linked pages infringed on church copyrights; pages were part of Operation Clambake, site based in Norway that is well-known hub for critics of Scientology (S)

headline: U.N. Aide Asks More Security Troops for Afghanistan
abstract: Senior United Nations official Francesc Vendrell, who has spent weeks monitoring tensions between warlords who control much of post-Taliban Afghanistan but is quitting his post says that he believes international security force deployed in Kabul should be expanded across country and increased to perhaps as many as 35,000 soldiers; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Former Kremlin Aide Won't Pay Fine
abstract: Former senior Kremlin aide Pavel Borodin refuses to pay fine imposed after court found him guilty of laundering $25 million in kickbacks from Swiss construction firm that won big Russian government contracts (S)

headline: Afghanistan Endorses Plan That Gives Autonomy to British-Led Peacekeepers
abstract: Afghanistan's interim government formally endorses plan giving autonomy to 4,500-member multinational peacekeeping force led by Britain; photo; Gen John McColl does not rule out extending force beyond Kabul vicinity, but says it would require UN mandate; says UN may also extend tenure beyond six months (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: November Chip Sales Show Gain
abstract: Semiconductor Industry Association says global computer chip sales were $10.6 billion in November, 42 percent decline from year earlier but up 1.6 percent from October, when sales were $10.44 billion (S)

headline: Detainees Are Not P.O.W.'s, Cheney and Rumsfeld Declare
abstract: *Vice Pres Dick Cheney and Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld say war captives in Afghanistan and Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, will not be designated as prisoners of war, regardless of what decision administration makes on Sec of State Colin Powell's request for review of how Geneva Convention on captives' rights might apply; Powell agrees captives should not be given prisoner of war status, but has asked Bush administration to reconsider whether to adhere to convention's governing treatment of prisoners in wartime, adopted in 1949; Cheney says convention does not apply to captives because they are not conventional soldiers, but terrorists operating outside internationally accepted norms; Rumsfeld tours Guantanamo Bay naval base where prisoners are being held; says there is no ambiguity in case and that detainees are not prisoners of war (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Premier Visits War Zone
abstract: Sri Lanka Prime Min Ranil Wickremesinghe becomes highest-ranking elected official in 20 years to visit Jaffna peninsula, scene of most devastating fighting between government and separatist Tamil rebels (S)

headline: Baltimore Currency Trader Is in a State of Legal Limbo
abstract: Daniel B Irwin and Bruce S Lamdin, lawyers for John Rusnak, currency trader for Allfirst Financial in Baltimore who is under investigation for circumventing company's safety controls, running up losses of $750 million and concealing them with fictitious transactions, says Rusnak is in state of legal suspension; no legal charges have been filed and Rusnak is still employee of bank, although he has been suspended; US attorney for Maryland, Allfirst and Rusnak's lawyers are conducting investigations to determine exactly what happened and who is responsible (M)

headline: Prague Journal; At the Cradle Cafe, Therapy for the Troubled Mind
abstract: Interview with Ivo Lorenc, who runs Prague cafe in which people recovering from serious mental illness work alongside normal workers without doctors' supervision; says he was motivated by poor treatment his mother got in Soviet-era Czech mental hospitals; photo (M)

headline: PENTAGON READIES EFFORTS TO SWAY SENTIMENT ABROAD
abstract: Pentagon's new Office for Strategic Influence is developing plans to provide news items, possibly even false ones, to foreign media organizations as part of new effort to influence public sentiment and policy makers in both friendly and unfriendly countries; seeks to broaden longstanding practice of information warfare against hostile nations in Middle East, Asia and even Western Europe; would assume role traditionally led by civilian agencies, mainly State Dept; office was established after September 11 terrorist attacks in response to concerns that Bush administration and US were losing public support overseas for war on terrorism, especially in Islamic countries; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, while broadly supportive of new office, has not approved specific proposals and has asked Pentagon's top lawyer William J Haynes to review them; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Ex-Nazi To Face Charges
abstract: Prosecutors in Hamburg say they are preparing to charge former SS officer, Friedrich Engel, 93, in connection with killing of at least 246 Italians in 1944 and 1955; Engel denies killing anyone; case came to national attention last year when German television reported he was living in Hamburg (S)

headline: Player Brings Convergence To the Family Room
abstract: Home theater systems are becoming simpler to set up; RCA's new home theater system combines DVD player that can also handle audio CS and MP3 playback with Dolby Digital decoder and AM-FM radio tuner in one thin box; photo (S)

headline: Objections may scuttle NBC's plan to accept hard liquor commercials.
abstract: Outcry from members of Congress and advocacy organizations opposed to expanding ads for distilled spirits may scuttle NBC's efforts to accept commercials for hard liquor; complaints could lead to Congressional hearings aimed at producing bill banning broadcast spots for hard liquor, but it may not stop there; opponents lined up against NBC may seek to roll back decision in 1996 by trade organization for liquor marketers, Distilled Spirits Council of US, to lift voluntary ban against such commercials; NBC is requiring liquor companies to run socially responsible spots for four months before network will run ads for specific products; photo (M)

headline: Downloads? I'll Take Vinyl
abstract: Donald Waxman letter on March 7 Basics article on downloadable music

headline: OUTLOOK: Markets & Investing; Prognosis for Stocks Brightens After 2 Years of Big Declines
abstract: Analysts expect stocks to rise only moderately in 2002; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ended 2001 down 13 percent, second straight year index fell more than 10 percent; Nasdaq composite index performed even more poorly, giving up 21.1 percent after 39.3 percent loss in 2000; Charles Pradilla, chief market strategist for SG Cowen, Stuart Hoffman, chief economist at PNC Financial Services Group, Tobias M Levkovich, equity strategist of Salomon Smith Barney, Gail P Seneca, chief investment officer of Seneca Capital Management, and Michelle Clayman, chief investment office rof New Amsterdam Partners, comment; drawing (M)

headline: Intel Introduces Chips for Servers Using Pentium 4 Technology
abstract: Intel Corp introduces first server-computer chips based on its Pentium 4 line of microprocessors; new chips, latest member of Xeon family, can run applications for e-mail and Web servicers 30 to 80 percent faster than Xeon chips now on market, which use Pentium III technology (M)

headline: Good Year for Gamers
abstract: For the video game industry, at least, 2001 was a very good year. According to data from the market research firm NPD Group, retail sales of video game hardware, software and accessories reached a record $9.4 billion last year, a 42 percent increase over sales of $6.6 billion in 2000.      Much of the success can be attributed to the popularity of the Sony PlayStation game consoles and the release of three new consoles last year: Nintendo's GameCube, Nintendo's Game Boy Advance and Microsoft's Xbox. But Richard Ow, an NPD senior account executive, said the software itself had a lot to do with the market's rise. Increasingly realistic, graphically sophisticated games have helped drive hardware sales, he said, and attract a broader audience to a pastime once limited to teenage boys.

headline: Dow Slips a Bit as Investors Fear a Rise in Interest Rates
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average loses 29.48 points, or 0.3 percent, to 10,577.75; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is down 0.61 point, to 1,165.55; Nasdaq composite index rises 8.76 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,877.06; graph; chart (M)

headline: Business; Still Alive and Growing Online, Without Fanfare
abstract: Global Sports, operator of Internet

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 2 Big Names Said to Drop Idea of Bidding For WorldCom
abstract: Verizon and SBC Communications have backed out of bidding for Worldcom Inc amid concerns that WorldCom's core long-distance businesses face continued difficulties; telecommunications experts say Verizon and SBC may have also been scared by WorldCom's accounting practices; some investors and analysts have worried that WorldCom has used aggressive accounting techniques in past, particularly in reporting revenue; WorldCom spokesman Brad Burns says company does not have accounting issues; shares have lost about 50 percent of their value since Jan 1, closing at $6.97, down $1.16; graph (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Finance: Venture Capitalists Raise Less
abstract: National Venture Capital Association and Venture Economics say amount raised by venture capitalists dropped sharply in fourth quarter; say venture capitalists raised $4.6 billion in quarter compared with $23.4 billion year earlier; for all of 2001, venture capitalists raised $40.6 billion, down from $104.6 billion in 2000 (S)

headline: Grieving and Looking for Survivors in a Charred Lima
abstract: Survivors in Lima, Peru, search morgue for loved ones missing since fireworks explosion set narrow streets ablaze in Mesa Redonda shopping district, killing nearly 300 people; many of bodies are burned beyond recognition (M)c

headline: Defaults Seem Near for Latin Units of BellSouth and Verizon
abstract: BellSouth Corp and Verizon Communications say their Latin American operations are preparing to default on hundreds of millions of dollars of debt because of economic problems in Brazil and Argentina; BellSouth's subsidiary in Brazil, mobile phone carrier BCP, misses $375 million debt payment; BellSouth and its Brazilian partner, Safra Group, have been unable to reach definitive solution for BCP's debt situation with its creditors; Verizon is seeking to distance itself from problems of its wireless communications company in Argentina by transferring 17 percent stake in company, CTI Holdings, newly created trust for its Argentine employees; Verizon will reduce its stake in company to 48 percent from 65 percent as result of transfer; move will allow Verizon to shift CTI off its balance sheet (M)

headline: Questions Raised of Conflicts At 2 Hospital Buying Groups
abstract: Article in ongoing series, Medicine's Middleman, on organizations that negotiate purchasing contracts with suppliers of nation's hospitals; focuses on conflict-of-interest issues raised by Premier Inc and Novation, middlemen for approximately half of nation's nonprofit hospitals who negotiated contracts for estimated $34 billion in hospital supplies in 2001; extensive and highly unusual ties to medical supply companies have raised question over whether their mission to use market power of more than 1,500 hospitals to find best medical products at lowest prices, is being compromised; problem stems from fact that groups are financed not by hospitals that buy products, but by companies that sell them and make money from very companies they are supposed to evaluate objectively; each year, companies pay Premier and Novation hundreds of millions of dollars in fees that represent percentage of hospital purchases; more hospitals spend on medical supplies, more money both companies get from suppliers; Premier and some of its officials have also received stocks or options from companies which Premier contracts; small manufacturers complain of competitive disadvantage; say they have been effectively blocked by groups, which have secured exclusive contracts with hospitals and largely determine which products many hospitals buy; critics say such conflicts of interest can mean that buying groups do not always choose products that are best for patients, hospitals or taxpayers or insurance that pays their bills; photos; drawings (L)

headline: Author Miscue Places Focus On Pressures Of Publishing
abstract: David A Vise insists that The Bureau and the Mole, his book about FBI and Robert Philip Hanssen, is legitimate best seller, even though he acknowledges ordering nearly 20,000 copies of book from Barnesandnoble.com with free shipping, then returning more than 17,000 of them for his money back; purchases, mixed with returns and reorders, raise suspicions among journalists and publishing executives that Vise was trying to inflate sales of book reported to national best-seller lists; Vise says he intended to buy about 4,000 books in effort to resell signed copies online; photo (M)

headline: Mideast Turmoil: The Fighting; Sharon Calls Arafat an Enemy and Sends Tanks To Isolate Him at Headquarters In Ramallah
abstract: Israeli government declares Yasir Arafat an 'enemy' and sends tanks and armored personnel carriers to fully isolate him in his Ramallah headquarters and to launch 'extended operation in Palestinian territories; Prime Min Ariel Sharon, recalling deadly suicide bombing of Netanya hotel as well as two subsequent terrorist attacks, says no sovereign state can ignore such events; says 20,000 reserve soldiers are being called up to free regular forces for operation that could last long time; officials in Arafat's compound say tanks and armored personnel carriers have fully ringed them and bulldozers have breached hole in wall; gun battles break out between Israeli troops and Arafat's guards; Israeli Defense Min Benjamin Ben Eliezer calls Ramallah 'capital of terror,' but says operation will continue elsewhere; Nabil Aburdeineh, senior aid to Arafat, calls on United States to call off Israelis and to isolate Sharon and his government; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Bush Defends His Refusal To Reveal Enron Contacts  President Bush defended his refusal to turn over information to Congress about contacts between Enron and the administration's energy task force, saying the request was ''an encroachment on the executive branch's ability to conduct business.''    The president's comments makes a constitutional showdown all but inevitable between the White House and the General Accounting Office, an investigative agency of Congress. [Page A1.]

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Profit At Jet Maker
abstract: Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica says fourth-quarter net income fell to $632 million from $637 million year earlier (S)

headline: Dutch Company's U.S. Malls Being Bought for $3.1 Billion
abstract: Westfield America Trust of Australia will join with two US rivals, Simon Property Group and Rouse Company, to buy department stores and shopping malls from Rodamco North America for $3.1 billion (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Commerzbank Barely Makes Profit
abstract: Commerzbank posts fourth-quarter pretax loss of 189 million euros ($164 million); barely made profit for all of 2001 (S)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: Stock Indexes Tumble Again On New Fears About Audits
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 220.17 points, or 2.2 percent, to 9,687.09; Nasdaq composite index falls 55.71 points, or 2.9 percent, to 1855.53; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 27.76 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,094.44; graph; Treasury securities prices rise sharply; 10-year note jumps 19/32, to 100 24/32, to yield 4.90 percent; 30-year bond rises 20/32, to 100 12/32, to yield 5.35 percent; graph; tables (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BEHR, Stuttgart, Germany, a maker of air-conditioners for cars, said it would buy a cooling-components factory in Dayton, Ohio, from DaimlerChrysler, Stuttgart.    ARCHER DANIELS MIDLAND CO., Decatur, Ill., won European Commission approval of its purchase of Toepfer International, a grain trader in Germany, to expand its international shipping and trading operations.

headline: Europe Places Penalties on Zimbabwe's Chief
abstract: European Union, after wavering for weeks, votes to impose tough sanctions on Zimbabwe Pres Robert Mugabe and more than dozen top aides; foreign ministers say they are left with little choice following expulsion of Pierre Schori, head of European election observer mission; sanctions which come three weeks before Zimbabwe's presidential election will bar Mugabe and 19 others from traveling to European Union nations; will freeze any European assets held by Mugabe and advisers; photo (M)

headline: Belfast Journal; Icy Relations in Ulster Melt at the Hockey Games
abstract: Catholics and Protestants in this deeply divided city have long found reasons to avoid one another, but now they have discovered an unlikely one to come together: a professional ice hockey team.    ''In the land of the Giants everyone is equal'' says the game programs of the hard-skating Belfast Giants. Sellout crowds are filling the new 7,000-seat Odyssey arena in Belfast's redeveloped docklands area and breathing vibrant life into the motto.

headline: Citibank Wins Access to Chinese Consumers
abstract: China grants Citibank rights to offer banking services to local Chinese residents and companies, making it first wholly foreign-owned bank to gain access to country's $120 billion in individual and corporate foreign-exchange savings; similiar rights, which China must begin granting under terms of its new membership with World Trade Organization, will be extended to other banks soon, as country gradually opens one of most sensitive sectors of its economy to international competition (M)

headline: 3 MORE AIRLINES ELIMINATE COMMISSIONS TO TRAVEL AGENTS
abstract: United Airlines and US Airways Group join rivals in scrapping most commissions paid to travel agents in US and Canada; American Trans Air also matches change, while Vanguard Airlines says it will keep paying 5 percent commission (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Main Stock Gauges Fall For Second Year in a Row  The three major stock market averages have now fallen for two consecutive years for the first time since the brutal recession years of 1973 and 1974. But a rally in the final three months helped to create optimism that the worst is over for both stocks and the economy.    With moderate declines on the final day of the year, the Dow Jones industrial average finished 2001 off 7.1 percent, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 13 percent and the Nasdaq composite sank 21 percent. [Page A1.]    The last three months of 2000 were wonderful for foreign stocks, but the first positive quarter in the last seven made the year only a little less painful. [World Business, Section W.]

headline: Turning Out Guerrillas and Terrorists to Wage a Holy War
abstract: Second article in series, The Jihad Files, on training of Al Qaeda guerrillas in Afghanistan to wage holy war, or jihad, as detailed in hundreds of documents and thousands of pages collected from network of training bases and terror schools by New York Times reporters and in interviews with US government and military officials; schools were divided into two-tiered university for waging Islamic war; one tier, by far busiest, prepared enlistees to be regular ground combatants; other provided small fraction of combatants for terrorist assignments abroad; implicit in split levels of training was Islamic groups' understanding of need for different sets of skills to fight on several simultaneous fronts; schools applied ancient forms of instruction to modern methods of killing to instill diverse lessons; photos (L)

headline: A Profitable Amazon Looks to Do an Encore
abstract: Saul Hansell analysis of outlook for Amazon.com now that it has posted its first profit; says what is most striking about company is that, unlike nearly every other Internet company, it is not pulling back from audacious combination of ambition and idealism set by Jeffrey P Bezos, founder and chief executive (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Earthlink Drops Overture
abstract: Shares of Overture Services plunged 41 percent after Internet search engine loses its contract with service provider EarthLink; Earthlink names Google its search engine (S)

headline: Recovery Near, But Its Vigor Is in Doubt, Greenspan Says
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, in testimony before House Financial Services Committee, says recession appears to be ending but that recovery is likely to be sluggish; forecast is taken by analysts and economists to mean central bank will leave interest rates unchanged at least until middle of year; says he does not expect collapse of Enron Corp to have any broad economic impact, though he suggests it should result in changes, including new accounting rules for stock options; suggests he has little sympathy for calls from domestic steel makers for imposition of big tariffs on imports; sees less of need for Congress to pass package of tax cuts and other measures to help economy with business conditions improving, although he supports Bush administration's position that such package could be helpful should recovery not continue as expected; says despite disruptions engendered by terrorist attacks of Sept 11, typical dynamics of business cycle have re-emerged and are prompting firming in economic activity; says central bank's forecast is for economy to grow at 2.5 percent to 3 percent annual rate this year; says unemployment will be 6 percent to 6.25 percent, up from current level of 5.6 percent; says Fed expects inflation to remain restrained, with price index for personal consumption expenditures increasing 1.5 percent (M)

headline: Cadbury Is Said to Be Close to Nantucket Nectars Deal
abstract: Cadbury Schweppes reportedly is close to acquiring Nantucket Nectars, majority owned by Ocean Spray Cranberries Inc (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Panamsat Profits Increase
abstract: PanAmSat Corp says net income rose in fourth quarter to $3.2 million from $559,000 in year-earlier period; sales increased to $203.7 million from $202.9 million (S)

headline: Private Sector; There Is Life After Praising Kmart
abstract: Retail analyst Jeffrey Feiner, who retained buy rating on Kmart as chain's fortunes sank, comments on his retirement from Lehman Brothers (S)

headline: NATIONAL EQUIPMENT BUYS PART OF BRAMBLES INDUSTRIES
abstract: National Equipment Services acquires North American operating unit of Brambles Industries of Australia for $122 million (S)

headline: Mail Delay at the S.E.C.
abstract: SEC receives thousands of documents that were mailed as early as October and quarantined because of anthrax contamination at Postal Service center in Washington; mail is irradiated; delivery o paper documents, including reports of executive stock transactions, continues to be delayed because of security procedures (S)

headline: G.I.'s Feared Dead in Crash In Philippines
abstract: An Army Special Operations helicopter carrying 10 American servicemen on a nighttime flight has crashed in the southern Philippines and several on board are believed killed, the Pentagon said today. The cause of the crash was unknown, but the helicopter did not come under hostile fire, said a Pentagon spokesman, Lt. Cmdr. Jeff Davis.     The Pacific Command could not confirm local media reports that indicated as many as three crew members may have been rescued.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Adviser May Bid For Imagis
abstract: Imagis Technologies, producer of software for security systems that identify people by patterns of their facial features, says Pembroke Group, investment firm it has retained for financial advice, might formally offer to take Imagis Technologies private in buyout valued at more than $50 million (S)

headline: Pakistan May Be Unable to Calm Kashmir
abstract: Pakistan's president says he is taking steps to crack down on Islamic militants who use his country as a base to drive India from Kashmir. But it seems that word has yet to trickle down to this Himalayan border region, where the countries have fought on and off for 50 years.    There are still fresh killings here every day, by militants and Indian security forces alike, and Indian security officials say more than half of the militants still active in the Kashmir valley are foreigners, mostly Pakistanis and Afghans.

headline: JUDGE DENIES NEGOTIATIONS PLEA BY UAL MECHANICS
abstract: Judge James Robertson says he will not intervene with presidential panel's review of United Airlines mechanics negotiations, thus barring union from striking carrier until at least Feb 20 (S)

headline: Rabbani Holds Court in Kabul
abstract: Burhanuddin Rabbani, Afghanistan's former president, agreed to step aside to make way for United Nations-brokered transitional government, but he continues to act much like Afghanistan's president; he lives in presidential compound in Kabul, in house that is stone's throw from seat of interim government; he receives visitors from all over country, and from around world; he says he fully supports new government of his successor, Hamid Karzai, but skeptics are keeping wary eye on him and his close ally, Pashtun commander Abdul Rab Rassoul Sayyaf; Rabbani is vague about his future plans; photo (M)

headline: Marion Countess DÃ¶nhoff, 92, a Leading Journalist Who Opposed Hitler
abstract: Dr Marion Countess Donhoff, an architect of German postwar journalism, joint publisher of liberal weekly Die Zeit and one of last prominent survivors of German resistance to Hitler, dies at age 92 (M)

headline: Tyco Shares Decline 2.8% On Talk of a U.S. Inquiry
abstract: Shares of Tyco International fall 2.8 percent after research firm SEC Insight questions whether Tyco is subject of government investigation; Tyco says it is not currently being investigated by SEC (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: State Of Emergency Extended
abstract: Nepal's Parliament votes to extend state of emergency imposed in November to battle Maoist rebellion that has spread across nation (S)

headline: Elisabeth Mann Borgese, 83, Writer and Defender of the Oceans
abstract: Elisabeth Mann Borgese, writer, International Oceans Institute founder and daughter of writer Thomas Mann, dies at age 83 (M)

headline: President Is Leaving At DDB Worldwide
abstract: Jake Schroepfer, president and chief executive at Dallas office of DDB Worldwide, will resign to become president and chief executive at Electronic Billboard Technology; Schroepfer's duties will be handled by new management team composed of Janet Bustin, who becomes managing director, and Steve Sweitzer, who joins firm as executive creative director and managing partner (S)

headline: An Intricate Web Lured U.S. Reporter to Meet a Cleric Who Then Vanished
abstract: Daniel Pearl, American reporter for The Wall Street Journal who was kidnapped in Pakistan, was drawn into well-laid trap by abductors who had been in contact with him for more than two weeks and promised to arrange secret meeting with Sheik Mubarik Ali Shah Gilani, cleric who has ties with Muslims in United States and who has disappeared from sight; Pearl, who was reporting on militant Islamic underground, apparently believed that Gilani had links to Al Qaeda; Federal Bureau of Investigation has entered investigation that so far has no suspects and mysterious motives (M)

headline: U.S. Official Predicts Drop in Colombian Cocaine
abstract: High-level arrests and huge drug seizures in Mexico have had no effect on the quantity of Colombian cocaine entering the United States, the American drug-enforcement chief, Asa Hutchinson, said here today.    But Mr. Hutchinson said the offensive opened today by the Colombian military against guerrillas, whom he called ''narco-terrorists,'' could be a significant turn in the war on drugs.

headline: Sharon Gets in Step After U.S. Steps In
abstract: Analysis: Pres Bush's decision to send envoy back to Middle East seen as signal to Pres Ariel Sharon that he has gone too far in his latest stepping up of war against Palestinians; for Sharon, American intervention could mean he will be forced to start negotiating again with Yasir Arafat, Palestinian leader he declared irrelevent last year and has rstricted to West Bank city of Ramallah; if that happens, Arafat would claim major diplomatic victory, and his political standing among Palestinians would rise accordingly; return of American envoy could help Sharon's standing in Israeli public opinion polls, which has been eroding amid rapid rise in violence and absence of any evident chance of respite; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: People
abstract: Douglas B Leeds, chairman and chief executive at Thomson-Leeds Co, is relinquishing his chief executive post to president Vince Esposito; Leeds will serve as chairman through end of year; Michael Parkes, executive vice president, will succeed Esposito as president; Marc Capra, chairman and chief executive of Southeast Asian operations at J Walter Thompson, is named chief operating officer for New York office, succeeding Michael Gross (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Bank Fires Two Traders
abstract: Banco Santander Central Hispano fires two traders in Brazil after internal investigation found 'irregular' securities transactions worth 3 million reais ($1.2 million) or less; police are investigating (S)

headline: After Talk, Miramax to Refocus on Movies
abstract: Interview with Miramax Films head Harvey Weinstein on his plans to refocus on smaller, independent films; return to roots follows collapse of Miramax's co-publishing venture, Talk magazine; photo (M)

headline: 53 Expelled in Falun Gong Protests in Beijing
abstract: The Beijing police said that they had expelled all but six of the 59 foreign members detained in protests.

headline: People
abstract: Marty Donohue, senior vice president and group creative director at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, is promoted to executive vice president and executive creative director (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Pastor Sentenced For Killing Family
abstract: Belgian court sentences pastor Andras Pandy to life imprisonment and his daughter Agnes to 21 years for murdering most of their family (S)

headline: Varying the Subject Line To Fool the Spam Filter
abstract: Q.  I often get spam messages that contain some sort of code or sequence of numbers on the far right side of the Subject line. Do these numbers mean anything?    A.  Companies that send unsolicited commercial e-mail messages, or spam, are always trying to find new ways to get recipients to open them.

headline: Indian General Talks Bluntly Of War and a Nuclear Threat
abstract: India's army chief, Gen S Padmanabhan, says military is fully prepared for large-scale conventional war with Pakistan and is also ready to deliver devastating nuclear strike should Pakistan use its nuclear arsenal first; senior Indian official is quick to say that general's pithy, bellicose remarks were not cleared by prime minister's office, but timing of general's remarks seems to cause more unease than their substance; delivery comes on eve of crucial speech by Gen Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan and could make it harder for him to offer commitment to shut down extreme Islamic groups battling India in Kashmir; spokesman for Pakistan's military regime responds to Indian general's remarks by stating that Pakistan is militarily prepared if India 'undertakes a misadventure'; Indian government has downplayed importance of Musharraf's recent arrests of some Islamic militants, calling efforts largely cosmetic and bringing no reduction in violence in Kashmir; photo; map (M)

headline: Behind Letterman Turmoil, An Icy Clash With His Boss
abstract: Article examines roots of turmoil that may determine whether David Letterman will abandon CBS to sign with ABC, sweeping away Ted Koppel and much admired Nightline news program; frosty relationship between Letterman and CBS Television president Leslie Moonves over past several years discussed; poor and often nonexistent communication between both has helped stoke high emotion on each side and has become critical intangible in most closely watched negotiation in industry in years; photo (M)

headline: A Nation Challenged: The Scene; Americans Battling Closer to Qaeda Bunkers
abstract: American-led ground troops fight their way under withering fire toward Taliban and Al Qaeda strongholds in eastern Afghanistan mountains, reportedly pushing to within few hundred feet of bunkers and caves of enemy fighters apparently ready to fight to death; American officials call battle fiercest of war as stress shifts from intensive bombing to ground assault; United States helicopters continue shuttling fresh troops and supplies up into Shah-i-Kot valley, heart of battle zone; map; photos (M)
