headline: Low-Key Satisfaction With Managed Care
abstract: DIARY Low-Key Satisfaction With Managed Care.

headline: Hidden Currency Losses Go Back 5 Years, Irish Bank Says
abstract: HiÃ˜

headline: In Beirut, Arab Officials Vow To Move on Saudi Peace Plan
abstract: Senior officials at Arab League summit conference, Beirut, say they will push ahead with Saudi-proposed plan for peace with Israel despite absence from meeting of Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat and Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak; question Bush administration's ability to restore calm in Mideast in light of its inability to get Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon's government to let Arafat attend meeting; blame that failure for Mubarak's absence; photo (M)

headline: South Koreans Criticize Bush's Methods, if Not His Message
abstract: Many South Koreans say they are shocked and even insulted by Pres Bush's recent statements including North Korea in so-called axis of evil; many say they agree with Bush, up to point; few take direct issue with his characterization of North Korea; instead, they express chagrin that Bush showed so little delicacy in addressing government that their own government has struggled to engage; they worry that Bush has made things worse; photos (M)

headline: Stealing Cars and Telling Stories
abstract: Charles Herold reviews latest Metal Gear stealth-action game from Konami and game from DMA Designs that forces player into life of crime; photos (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Globalism and the liberal model: Playing the invisible hand that's dealt us.
abstract: Virginia Postrel's Economic Scene column on liberal model of globalism as espoused in Brink Lindsey's book Against the Dead Hand: The Uncertain Struggle for Global Capitalism; says Lindsey writes that there is at present only one viable vision of economic development: liberal model of markets and competition; says it is neither widely loved nor widely understood, but it is all there is; photo (M)

headline: Deals That Helped Doom Enron Began to Form in the Early 90's
abstract: Court records show that financial dealings that played central role in Enron's collapse were begun decade ago by Andrew S Fastow, newly hired finanicial officer, in part to keep debt off company's books so it could grow unimpeded; early deals by Fastow--first links of complex chain of thousands of partnerships--were far simpler than ones that company developed in late 1990's; but records show they contained many hallmarks of transactions that later helped bring company down; Fastow was ousted in Oct and he has not spoken publicly about matter; in 1997 deposition he provided answers to some questions investigators are puzzling over, including why Enron's assets were moved into partnerships and what role accountants played; ultimately, decision by Enron and its auditing firm, Arthur Andersen, to allow certain partnerships to be pushed off company's balance sheet helped set in motion events that crippled Enron (M)

headline: U.S. AGENTS SEIZE TERROR SUSPECTS IN PAKISTAN RAID
abstract: Team of American law enforcement and intelligence officials storm several houses in Pakistan and capture five Taliban fighters and 25 Arabs suspected of having links to Al Qaeda; operation in Faisalabad and Lahore was carried out with Pakistani government's permission and with special Pakistani police forces; at least two Pakistani policemen and one suspect were killed; Interior Min Moinhuddin Haider says Ahmed Omar Sheikh, main suspect in killing of American journalist Daniel Pearl, will not be handed over to US anytime soon, if ever (M)

headline: Duisenberg to Step Down as Head of Europe's Central Bank
abstract: Wim Duisenberg will retire as president of the European Central Bank in 2003, the ECB announced today, ending months of uncertainty over how long the Bank's first president would stay in office.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  None

headline: JUDGE OVERTURNS GUIDANT VERDICT, SAYING WITNESS LIED
abstract: US District Judge David F Hamilton says Guidant Corp cannot collect $140 million jury award in patent case, and may owe millions of dollars in penalties, because central witness, Joe D Bourland, lied in dispute with rival cardiac-device maker, St Jude Medical; Hamilton overturns judgment in dispute over patents for implantable defibrillators; rules two Guidant patents are invalid and says $140 million in damages is 'grossly excessive' (S)

headline: Russia Calls for Binding Pact To Reduce Nuclear Arsenals
abstract: Russia tells United States in arms talks that it wants binding agreement that both sides would make real and irreversible cuts in their nuclear arsenals, and that Washington would not simply store excess warheads, as it proposed, but destroy them; Russians seek treaty that would reduce arsenals to 2,000 warheads each during next decade; hope to have accord ready for signing when Pres Bush meets with Pres Putin in Russia later this year; Bush administration prefers to talk of 'codification' agreement, in which each side decides how many warheads to eliminate and informs other side (M)

headline: PHILIP MORRIS PROMOTES SEVERAL EXECUTIVES
abstract: Philip Morris Companies names Michael Szymanczyk chairman of its Philip Morris USA tobacco unit; promotion is effective April 25; he was president and chief executive of unit and will be succeeded by John Nelson, president of company's inernational business; Dinyar Devitre is returning to Philip Morris as chief financial officer; he succeeds Louis C Camilleri, who takes over as chief executive on April 25 from Geoffrey Bible, who is retiring; Bible will remain chairman until August, when Camilleri assumes job (S)

headline: ONLINE DIARY
abstract: So-called barncams allow viewing of birth of foals at more than 20 American horse farms...Gallup Poll takes measure of technical literacy of Americans...Number of idea banks on Web have no commercial aspirations, only desire to share ideas that could benefit society...Test of random-link generators on Web by newsletter ResearchBuzz finds they produce error messages 30 percent to 75 percent of the time; drawings (M)

headline: Singapore Accuses Islamists of Bomb Plan
abstract: Singapore has arrested 15 Muslims and accused them of planning to blow up military targets and embassies in the small city-state. The government said at least some of them might have received training from Osama bin Laden's terrorist organization, Al Qaeda.    Announcing the arrests on Saturday, the Singaporean government said the men -- detained between Dec. 9 and Dec. 24 -- had been found with bomb-making instructions and with photographs and videotape of buildings apparently being considered as targets.

headline: Accounting Change Cuts Assets of AOL
abstract: AOL Time Warner, the world's biggest media company, said that it would take a charge of $40 billion to $60 billion in the first quarter to reflect the costs of its corporate merger because of a change in accounting rules.    The charge will involve no cash outlay and will not change the company's cash flow, the most watched financial measure for media companies. On paper, though, the company will post a big loss for the first quarter, perhaps among the biggest in corporate history. Though investors have readily forgiven such charges as one-time events in recent years, AOL's move will sharply reduce its total assets.

headline: Compressed Data; Venture Capitalists Are Making a Comeback
abstract: MoneyTree survey finds venture capital investment rose in 2001 fourth quarter, to $7.1 billion, after falling for five successive quarters from second quarter 2000 peak of $26.3 billion (M)

headline: Swelling Linked to Experimental Drug
abstract: Elan Corp's experimental treatment for Alzheimer's disease known as AN-1792 has been linked to more cases of inflammation of central nervous system, side effect that has caused company to suspend study (S)

headline: Europeans So Eager for Euros, Stores and Banks Run Short
abstract: Soaring demand for euros forces many European commercial banks to order more, and producing some shortages of cash at stores and banks (S)

headline: Through The Enron Looking Glass
abstract: Corporate insiders at Enron say Enron Broadband Services was huge cash drain on corporation, with out-of-control spending and very little real business to show for it; say illusion of active business was created through accounting gimmicks (M)

headline: New Chief Named At Optimedia USA
abstract: Michael Drexler is named chief executive at Optimedia USA, succeeding Gene DeWitt, who is leaving (S)

headline: Hopes Rise for a Mideast Truce, Despite Attacks
abstract: Two terrorist attacks in Israel and heavy gunfire in Bethlehem mark fourth day of shuttle diplomacy by US envoy Gen Anthony C Zinni, who appears to make substantive headway toward brokering cease-fire between Israelis and Palestinians; Zinni holds separate meetings in West Bank and Gaza to work out security arrangements for Israeli withdrawal from all Palestinian-controlled areas; reportedly meets with Yasir Arafat in Ramallah; Israeli forces withdraw from most Palestinian areas invaded in large-scale military operations over past two weeks; remain in and around Bethlehem and on fringes of other areas; gunman opens fire in Kfar Saba killing 18-year-old Isreali high school student and wounding several other people before he is shot dead; suicide bomber sets off explosive near bus stop in northern Jerusalem, wounding woman; map; photo (M)

headline: Survey Finds 'Extensive' Abuses Of Refugee Children in Africa
abstract: UN survey finds that children in refugee camps in West Africa are being widely exploited by locally hired camp officials who demand sex in exchange for food and medicine children need to survive; most of abused children are girls ages 13 to 18; surveyed were camps in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone (S)

headline: Support for Afghan Army from American Commander
abstract: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 26 â€” The commander of the American military operation in Afghanistan has pledged the United States' help in building an Afghan national army.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Consumer Prices Sag
abstract: Japanese consumer prices fall 0.7 percent in 2001, largest decline in three decades (S)

headline: U.S. Commander Orders Moves to Protect Friendly Afghan Forces
abstract: General Tommy R. Franks said today he had ordered his officers to tighten their coordination with friendly Afghan forces.

headline: U.S. to Continue Afghanistan Bombing Despite Civilian Casualties
abstract: Two days after he arrived in Afghanistan, the new United States special envoy today defended the continued bombing there, even though it is causing civilian casualties.

headline: Fox Suspends Mexico's Tax On Fructose From U.S.
abstract: Mexico's Pres Vicente Fox issues executive decree suspending 20 percent tax on American high-fructose corn syrup used by soft drink industry; Mexico's Congress created tax in January to help sugar industry battle growing surplus amid repeated refusals by US to increase its quota on sugar from Mexico; government suspends tax for seven months to allow more time to negotiate deal that would grant Mexico greater access to America's sugar market (M)

headline: U.S. Seizes Bank Business Of Web Credit Card Issuer
abstract: Federal Deposit Insurance Corp last week seized banking operations of NextCard, company that issued credit cards over Internet, saying that it has grown too fast and with scant attention to lending quality and had endangered safety of its $525 million in government-insured deposits; company has stopped issuing new cards, but existing cardholders can continue to use their Visa accounts, paying their bills for benefit of government insurance fund; FDIC is seeking buyer for some or all of NextBank's assets; depending on its success, depositors stand to lose up to $29 million, representing deposits in accounts in excess of $100,000 (M)

headline: China Tells Lawyer Who Aids Injured Workers to Close His Office
abstract: Zhou Litai, lawyer who represents injured factory workers, says he will not comply with order by Shenzhen, China, officials to shut down his practice in area, phone interview; questions order's legality; sees it spurred by fears his high-profile work could scare off investors (M)

headline: Esther Ocloo, 83, Pioneer in Microloans to Help Women Become Entrepreneurs, Dies
abstract: Esther Afua Ocloo, who pioneered small loans for women, dies at age 83; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Rollerblades Slow Benetton
abstract: Benetton Group says fourth-quarter profit fell 2.3 percent because it overestimated demand for Rollerblade in-line skates that had to be sold at discount to clear inventories; profit dropped to 64.4 million euros ($56 million) in quarter from 65.9 million euros year earlier; graph (S)

headline: An Accountant Who Raised Enronian Issues
abstract: Roy L Olofson's lawyers describe him as old-fashioned accountant who was fired by Global Crossing for blowing whistle on dubious bookkeeping; company says Olofson has made his charges only because he wants better termination package (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Beth Collins was named vice president and group director at the Parenting Group, New York, which includes BabyTalk, Healthy Pregnancy and Parenting magazines.

headline: METLIFE REPORTS LOSS OF $296 MILLION FOR QUARTER
abstract: MetLife Inc reports fourth-quarter loss of $296 million compared to net income of $591 million year earlier; revenue was little changed at $8.4 billion (S)

headline: Argentine Peso Drops Sharply After Link to the Dollar Ends
abstract: Argentine peso drops sharply on foreign exchange markets after its 11-year-long link to American dollar ends; reopening of banks comes after night of street protests culminating in violence outside presidential palace; several thousand middle-class demonstrators bang pots and pans in march on palace, to object to expanded freeze on their assets that government of Pres Eduardo Duhalde imposed on Jan 10; photo (M)

headline: Mixed Praise For Efforts To Stanch Terror Funds
abstract: Lawmakers at hearing held by Senate Banking Committee praise Bush administration for its quick use of new money-laundering provisions of last fall's antiterrorism law, but push it to do more and question some newly imposed regulations (M)

headline: 8 Die in Blast Outside U.S. Embassy in Peru
abstract: Car bomb explodes near American Embassy in Lima, Peru, killing at least 8 people and wounding 40, just three days before Pres Bush is due to arrive for talks; no one claims responsibility; State Dept official says no American citizens were hurt in explosion; photos (M)

headline: An Investor Traveling An Unusual Career Path
abstract: Article on unusual business relationship of Global Crossing chairman Gary Winnick and board member Steven J Green, which goes back to 1980's, when Winnick was lieutenant of junk bond king Michael R Milken at Drexel Burnham Lambert (M)/

headline: Nokia's Earnings Surpass Expectations
abstract: Nokia, world's biggest maker of mobile phones, reports earnings that exceed it own projections and those of analysts; earnings in fourth quarter declined 63 percent, to 450 million euros ($396 million) from 1.20 billion euros year earlier; company sticks to its forecast of 15 percent sales growth for its phone and network units this year; shares close up 5 percent, to $23.30; company increased its share of handset phone market in 2001 to 37 percent from 32 percent in 2000; chief executive Jorma Ollila comments; photo (M)

headline: Bush's Policy on Argentina Signals Shift in Approach
abstract: Pres Bush's decisions to allow Argentina to suffer consequences of its own economic mismanagement contrasts with Pres Clinton's bailout of Mexico seven years ago, action that was backed by then-Gov George Bush; Bush administration offifials say hard line on Argentina is meant to send message that US will not be financial firefighter (M)

headline: Iraqis Will Face Blunt Terms In Weapons Talks at the U.N.
abstract: Diplomats and United Nations officials say agreement by Iraqi delegation headed by Min Naji Sabri to meet at UN with chief UN arms inspector Hans Blix shows Iraq fears threat of American attack is real, if not imminent, interviews; say Security Council's permanent members are unified on demand that sanctions not be eased before inspectors return to Iraq on Council's terms; Blix says Council wants inspectors to have unrestricted access with no Iraqi veto over their nationality, interview; photos (M)

headline: Anheuser-Busch To Feature Mascots
abstract: Anheuser-Busch Companies plans to expand its long-running campaign aimed at encouraging college students to drink responsibly by featuring mascots of various colleges and universities in television advertising; Center for Science in the Public Interest opposes expansion of advertising for alcoholic beverages (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Explosives Maker Renationalized
abstract: Czech government will take back control of Explosia, company that makes plastic explosive Semtex, less than two months after its parent, chemical conglomerate Unipetrol, was privatized; Finance Min Jiri Rusnok says another state-run company will pay nominal amount, $270,000, and assume $19 million in debt to take over Explosia (S)

headline: Russian Court Orders Dissolution of Independent TV Network
abstract: Moscow Higher Arbitration Court orders owners of embattled TV-6 television network, heir to NTV television network, to start immediately liquidating company, overturning two-week-old court ruling that had annulled earlier liquidation order; ruling is major defeat for Boris Berezovsky, who controls network from self-imposed exile in London; Berezovsky is vociferous critic of Pres Vladimir V Putin, and has long been under federal investigation for his dealings during wild early days of Russian capitalism (M)

headline: Sharon Opposes Lawmaker's Plan to Meet Palestinian Council
abstract: Avraham Burg, speaker of Israeli Parliament, says he will accept invitation to address Palestinian legislative council, over objections of Prime Min Ariel Sharon, in bid to break cycle of violence and revenge; calls invitation from council speaker Ahmed Qurei, known as Abu Ala, chance for dialogue; they are on joint visit to Paris; Sharon holds move will hurt Israel; two Israeli women die of wounds sustained in shooting spree by Palestinian gunman in Jerusalem; thousands of angry Palestinians march in funeral, Nablus, West Bank, for three of four Hamas militants killed in Israeli raid; demand revenge (M)

headline: Central Bank Of Europe Leaves Rates Unchanged
abstract: European Central Bank leaves monetary policy unchanged even though economic outlook for first half of 2002 remains bleak; prospects remain dim despite mostly smooth and successful introduction of new euro coins and bills to replace national currencies in 12 countries this week; central bank president Wim Duisenberg predicts growth in euro zone will be stagnant for next few months (M)

headline: Ex-Workers Say Unit's Earnings Were 'Illusory'
abstract: Several former employees say that major division of Enron Corporation overstated its profits by hundreds of millions of dollars over last three years, and senior Enron executives were warned almost year ago that the division's profits were illusory; division, Enron Energy Services, competed with utilities to sell electricity and natural gas to commercial and industrial customers; it was run by Lou L Pai, who sold $353 million in Enron stock over last three years, more than any other Enron exec, and Thomas White, who left Enron to become secretary of Army last June (M)

headline: Pension Bubble Loses Some Air
abstract: Daniel Altman column on danger that Americans might not save enough for retirement; notes impact of stock market's decline on pension fund assets, people's disillusionment with performance of their 401(k) plans and danger that proposed legislation to limit share of 401(k) plan that may be held in company stock could reduce everyone's desire to save even if it prevents cases like Enron's, in which employees overinvested in company stock and lost most of their retirement savings after its collapse; graph (M)

headline: You Listen, You Pay: Post-Napster Music Services
abstract: Basics column on legal online music services; three of them, Rhapsody, Pressplay and MusicNet, offer similar features and content; diagram; chart compares and contrasts three (M)

headline: Bush Says Taliban Leader Will Be Found
abstract: Pres Bush says it is 'just a matter of time' before Taliban leader Muhammad Omar and Osama bin Laden are captured; comments while lunching on cheeseburger and onion fries at Coffee Station in Crawford, Texas; photo; Bush also repeats that Osama bin Laden will be found; White House names Valmay Khalilzad, Afghan-American on National Securuity Council, as special envoy to Afghanistan; Bush tells reporters 'whole culture' of FBI has changed to concentrate on protecting Americans from further terrorist attack; also reports talks with Indian and Pakistani leaders, urging them to avoid war (M)

headline: Fear Stalls Health Push In India
abstract: Mistaken belief that dozens of children died from doses of vitamin A halts public health drive in Assam, India, that international experts say is essential to save tens of thousands of children from dying of variety of diseases; decision by national government to halt campaign underscores politics and suspicion that can surround even best-intended efforts at foreign assistance in India; even though public health officials say none of deaths was caused by vitamin A, government has turned matter over to committee of experts who will recommend strategy in coming weeks, which will include decision on whether campaign should be restarted or ended for good; photos; map (M)

headline: A Gerstner Loyalist Cut From Quite Different Style
abstract: Article on Samuel J Palmisano, who is replacing Louis V Gerstner Jr as chief executive of IBM, focuses on different management styles of two executives; chart (M)

headline: Germany and Portugal Face Warnings to Rein In Deficits
abstract: European Commission recommends that Germany and Portugal be sent early warnings over size of their national budget deficits; public chastisement comes at delicate time for Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's government, as economic policy becomes important campaign issue with German elections looming this fall; commission expects Germany's budget deficit to rise to 2.7 percent of gross domestic product this year from estimated 2.6 percent in 2001, dangerously close to 3 percent ceiling set in stability pact signed by all 15 members of European Union in 1997; Pedro Solbes, commissioner for economic and monetary affairs, says Germany should implement 2002 budget outlined by Finance Min Hans Eichel, pointing out German economy has suffered more than other European economies from world slowdown; Portugal's budget deficit for 2001 is expected to be over 2 percent, more than 1 percentage point larger than target it set itself for last year; Solbes urges Portuguese government to make extra effort to tackle revenue shortfalls (M)

headline: So, Who's Your Daddy? In DNA Tests, TV Finds Elixir to Raise Ratings
abstract: DNA paternity tests are increasingly popular with television viewers, which is main reason talk-show hosts promote them especially hard during sweep months, period when advertising rates are set; most talk shows see rise in ratings when shows focus on DNA paternity tests; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Sinn Fein Pressed
abstract: Pres Bush's envoy for Northern Ireland, Richard N Haass, urges Sinn Fein, political wing of Irish RepublicanArmy, to name members to serve on province's new police board and to stop discouraging Catholics from joining new cross-community Police Service of Northern Ireland; Sinn Fein has refused to join police board, saying reforms do not go far enough (S)

headline: 5 Bankers Fired From Barclays Over $62,700 Spent at Meal
abstract: Barclays Capital fires five of six investment bankers who racked up $62,700 dinner bill at London restaurant Petrus last July; photo (M)

headline: Climate Control, On the Slopes
abstract: Interview with Thomas Laakso who managed development of self-heating jacket for North Face, outdoor clothing company; photos (S)

headline: A D.L.L. File Is Missing: Responding to the Alert
abstract: Q.  My Windows 98 computer keeps giving me an error message about missing D.L.L. files. What should I do?    A.  Dynamic link library (D.L.L.) files are small programs that hold information and code used by programs to perform certain tasks efficiently. Windows and Windows-based programs use them, but things can go awry when a D.L.L. file is damaged in a system crash or is accidentally overwritten by a poorly designed software installer file.

headline: Shifting Tone, Annan Takes Tough Line On Violence
abstract: United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan, speaking to Security Council, criticizes Israel and Palestinians for 'horrifying carnage' in Middle East and accuses both sides of 'disproportionate' and 'indiscriminate' violence; this is harshest language he has used since present crisis began 17 months ago; he chastises Israelis for use of heavy weapons in civilian areas and calls Palestinian suicide bombings on civilians 'morally repugnant'; for what is believed to be first time, he uses term 'illegal' to describe Israeli presence in lands captured in 1967 war; he expresses support for Crown Prince Abdullah's recent initiative (M)

headline: Ready to Quit, but Deep in Debt
abstract: Many Americans nearing retirement age will not be able to stop working because they are deeply in debt; credit counselors confirm that they are seeing large numbers of older consumers; couples having children later in life are likely to have more debt; ease of credit in 1990's together with stagnant stock portfolios have also increased financial problems (special section, Retirement) (M)

headline: Military Contractor In Bid to Buy a Rival
abstract: The Northrop Grumman Corporation announced an unsolicited $5.9 billion stock offer for the TRW Corporation in the hope of becoming the nation's leading satellite and missile contractor.    Analysts and industry executives said Northrop, like its rivals Lockheed Martin and Boeing, was preparing for coming years when more taxpayers' dollars are expected to be sent to military contractors as the nation combats terrorist threats in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: S.E.C. Studies Accounting Of Specialty Chip Maker
abstract: Nvidia Corp, manufacturer of specialty computer chips, says Securities and Exchange Commission and federal prosecutors are examining its accounting practices; SEC and prosecutors are examining whether company improperly shifted $3.6 million in costs from first quarter of its 2001 fiscal year, which ended in January 2001, to second and third quarters; chief executive Jen-Hsun Huang comments; company reports sales of $500 million in fiscal fourth quarter ended Jan 31 and profits of $72 million (M)

headline: Filipinos and G.I.'s Falter In Effort to Free Hostages
abstract: Plans to use military force to free American missionary couple held hostage by Muslim terrorists in southern Philippines are complicated by captors' tight control and Filipino military's inexperience with night raids; some 80 Abu Sayyaf terrorists on Basilan island are vastly outnumbered by more than 5,000 Filipino troops and scores of US Special Forces, but commanders fear raid could jeopardize lives of Martin and Gracia Burnham; photo of soldiers (M)

headline: Mining Giant Set to Depart From Zambia
abstract: Anglo American PLC is pulling out of Zambia, where company has been struggling to turn around crumbling mines that it acquired from state 22 months ago; news is staggering blow to Zambia, which is already one of world's poorest countries and now faces prospects of thousands of jobs lost in its most important industry; Pres Levy Mwanawasa calls emergency cabinet meeting as word spreads that Anglo suspends trading of shares in its subsidiary Zambia Copper Investments Ltd in anticipation of announcement by Anglo American; Simon Thompson, chief executive of base metals unit of Anglo American, says without additional financing, Konkola Copper Mines PLC, subsidiary of Zambia Copper that operates mines, will be out of business within year; Anglo owns 51 percent of Zambia Copper, which in turn holds 65 percent of Konkola Copper Mines, biggest copper mining operation in Zambia; it accounts for about two-thirds of Zambia's total production; Anglo says Konkola lost about $108 million from March 2000, when Anglo took over, through end of 2001 (M)

headline: Pardon Ruled Out in Peru for New York Woman
abstract: Lori Berenson, whose conviction on charges of collaborating with Marxist rebels was upheld by Peru's highest court on Monday, will not be granted a presidential pardon.

headline: Wanted, Virtually Dead
abstract: Demand for so-called first-person shooter computer games with counterterrorism themes has surged since Sept 11 and Afghanistan war; such games involve military simulations in which user typically plays member of Special Forces unit employing stealth tactics; enthusiasts like Andrew Baye, who invent user-created modifications to customize off-the-shelf games, have altered games to let users hunt Osama bin Laden; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Biometrics Company Goes Public
abstract: IQ Biometrics, which makes facial recognition software, becomes publicly traded company by acquiring JV Web, Internet marketing concern; deal is valued at $23.1 million (S)

headline: RALSTON CHAIRMAN TAKES STAKE IN CHURCH & DWIGHT
abstract: William Stiritz reports taking 5 percent stake in Church & Dwight Co, maker of Arm & Hammer products (S)

headline: Enron Cases Await. Let the Swaggering Begin.
abstract: Some of nation's leading celebrity trial lawyers will help determine fate of Enron Corp and Arthur Andersen, its auditor; include Rusty Hardin, now defending Andersen against obstruction of justice charge, and Stephen D Susman, helping Enron in civil cases over its collapse; Joseph D Jamail Jr prepares to defend Vinson & Elkins, Enron's outside legal counsel; photos (M)

headline: CIGARETTE TRACKING STOCK OF LOEWS SELLS BRISKLY
abstract: Shares of Carolina Group rise as much as 7.3 percent in their first day of trading afer its parent, Loews Corp, finds enough demand to increase to $980 million the sale of stock in company, which makes Newport and Kent cigarettes (S)

headline: LEAR TO CLOSE 4 PLANTS AND CUT 1,200 JOBS
abstract: The Lear Corporation, a leading maker of automobile interiors and seats, plans to eliminate about 1,200 jobs and close four plants to consolidate production. The company will shut plants in June or July in Marlette, Mich.; Bowling Green, Ohio; Peru, Ind.; and Wentzville, Mo., a spokeswoman, Andrea Puchalsky, said. An undetermined number of workers will be able to apply for other jobs. The cuts represent 1 percent of Lear's work force of 116,900. Lear said in October that it would eliminate an unspecified number of jobs and close under-used plants and offices at its seating, interior and electrical businesses, moves it expected would result in as much as $150 million in fourth-quarter costs.  Lear is based in Southfield, Mich.

headline: Zanzibar Journal; Tourists and Islam Mingle, Not Always Cozily
abstract: Conflict in Zanzibar, Tanzania, spurred by dual roles as Islamic society and tourist spot has intensified as segment of its Muslim community pushes hardline religious view; anti-alcohol teachings in local mosques have spurred series of bombings at local bars, none regular tourist haunts, tarnishing island's image as tranquil resort; map; photos (M)

headline: Some spots fell short, but other commercials during Olympics were worthy of the gold.
abstract: Some of television commercials shown during Olympic Winter Games assessed; photos (M)

headline: Nortel Officer Forced to Quit On Suspicious 401(k) Trades
abstract: Nortel Networks' chief financial officer Terry G Hungle is forced to resign after company says it has notified Ontario Securities Commission in Canada, where Nortel is based, and Securities and Exchange Commission in US, of suspicious trades in his 401(k) retirement account; says Hungle moved money out of Nortel stock soon before company announced lower revenue forecast last March and moved it back into stock in December soon before Nortel announced relatively good news on new credit arrangement; Hungle declines comment; president-chief executive Frank A Dunn will serve as acting chief financial officer until replacement is found (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GREENBRIER COS., Lake Oswego, Ore., the third-largest maker of railroad freight cars, said it had orders for 900 railcars, valued at about $50 million, and would decide within a week whether to build them in Portland, Ore., or Trenton, Nova Scotia. The work could add up to 500 jobs.

headline: At 11th Hour, He Bought Enron. But Why?
abstract: Alliance Capital star money manager Alfred Harrison faces questions about why he bought more and more Enron shares for Florida state pension fund as stock plunged; fund lost $328 million, among most lost by any Enron shareholder; some people question whether Gov Jeb Bush or Frank Savage, Enron board member and Alliance executive and board member, played role; Gov Bush is among those calling for probe of Alliance; graph of fund's Enron purchases; photos (M)

headline: A new report says ad spending in major media fell 9.8 percent last year, more than first thought.
abstract: CMR report shows advertising activity in major media fell even more than had been feared last year; says ad spending fell 9.8 percent, to $94.3 billion compared to $104.5 billion in 2000; says national newspapers suffered largest decline, down 23 percent; cable television was up 1 percent, and nationally syndicated TV programs was up 0.1 percent (M)

headline: Attention, Totally Awesome: At Job Interviews, Like, Chill
abstract: Hiring professionals advise young job hunters to pay much more attention to their manners and speech now that casual culture of late 1990's has given way to more formal workplace; Ell Miocene is among those driven to distraction by what one recruiter calls Valley girl speak; photo (M)

headline: Publicity Council Names New Chief
abstract: Kathy H Cripps is named president at Council of Public Relations Firms (S)

headline: American Describes Arafat's Post Under Siege
abstract: Adam Shapiro, American living in Ramallah, describes conditions inside Yasir Arafat's compound, which under Israeli siege; Shapiro says he is volunteer with international group supporting Palestinians and entered with doctor in ambulance (S)

headline: Desperation Drives a Zimbabwean Exodus South
abstract: Thousands of Zimbabweans are fleeing nation increasing beset by hunger and violence as Pres Robert Mugabe battles for re-election; over 7,000 emigrants have been caught slipping into Messina, South Africa over last six weeks, up three fold from similar 2001 periods; South African officials expect influx to surge before Mar vote; prepare military base, Messina, that could house up to 70,000 refugees should civil unrest or military coup follow vote; map; photo (M)

headline: Pepsi Bottling Ordered to Pay Overtime to Drivers
abstract: New Jersey appeals court rules that for nearly decade, Pepsi Bottling Group has wrongfully denied overtime pay to hundreds of truck drivers, issuing decision that could cost company upwards of $100 million in back wages and penalties; under state law, Labor Department could demand as much as $100 million in penalties alone, or practically nothing, depending on what it finds in Pepsi's personnel files (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | South Africa: South Africa: No Higher Gold Mine Bid
abstract: AngloGold Ltd says it will not increase its offer for Normandy Mining Ltd, setting stage for end to its protracted bidding contest with Newmont Mining Corp (S)

headline: Misdirected Rage
abstract: Daniel Rosenblatt letter comments on Jan 24 article on battles between remote-controlled devices

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: CFM Direct, Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., promoted two employees. Steven Prince, junior copywriter, was named copywriter, and Sheila Sternberg, project manager, was named production manager.

headline: India Holds A Gangster For Attack At U.S. Center
abstract: Aftab Ansari, gangster who claims responsibility for Jan 22 attack that killed five policemen outside American diplomatic office in Calcutta, India, is deported from Dubai and interrogated by officers of India's Central Bureau of Investigation in New Delhi; Indian officials accuse him of having links with Pakistan-based terrorist groups and Pakistan's Inter-Services Intelligence agency; say Ansari is believed to have developed close relationship with Ahmed Omar Sheikh, leader of anti-India militant group that was recently banned in Pakistan; Sheik is chief suspect in kidnapping of Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl (M)

headline: Business; Wall Street Moves On
abstract: Sept 11 terrorist attacks have had little long-term effect on securities trading, beyond scattering some of Wall Street's biggest firms; firms have also been devising new ways to send orders to New York Stock Exchange; stock price graph (S)

headline: E-Book 'Borrowers' Beware
abstract: Letter from Peter Warfield on Feb 21 article on offering library patrons accesss to digital books online (S)

headline: Soup to Peanut Butter, It Was an Innovative Year
abstract: diary: soup to peanut butter, it was an inno

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Verisign Sees Return To Profitability
abstract: VeriSign president-chief executive Stratton Sclavos says company will report first-quarter profit in line with analysts' expectations; photo (S)

headline: Text of Watkins' Testimony at House Hearing on Enron
abstract: Text of a hearing of the Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee on the financial collapse of the Enron Corporation.

headline: Iraq Calls U.N. Meeting On Weapons 'Constructive'
abstract: Iraq and United Nations end first talks in more than year with little to show beyond Iraqi pledge to return stolen Kuwaiti property and agreement to meet again in mid-Apr; neither side discusses talks in any detail, but atmosphere around talks is noticeably friendlier than in past, largely due to cordial demeanor of Foreign Min Naji Sabri, head of Iraqi delegation; diplomats caution that history of dealing with Iraq is littered with apparently conciliatory bids made when Pres Saddam Hussein came under serious pressure; latest talks are held with threat of Americcan attacks hovering in background (M)

headline: Hometown Remembers Man Who Wore Success Quietly
abstract: J Clifford Baxter, former vice chairman of Enron Corp who committed suicide, is remembered by residents of his hometown in Amityville, NY; photo (M)

headline: At Star-Crazy Magazines, Brand's the Thing
abstract: Magazine publishers are responding to difficult economic environment by forming alliances with celebrities and groups with established brands to control increasingly prohibitive cost of acquiring readers; industry, which used be be in business of manufacturing celebrity, is now intent on using celebrities as platform for new magazines; graphs; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Anti-Terror Bill Rejected
abstract: India's upper house of Parliament rejects anti-terrorism bill favored by ruling Hindu nationalists; opponents fear law, which would let suspects be detained for 30 days without appearing in court, would be used against Muslims (S)

headline: Wear Me, Use Me, Flaunt Me: Hitching a Product to the Stars
abstract: Sony, Palm and Apple Computer are among electronics companies offering perks to celebrities and the wealthy in bid to benefit 'halo effect'; idea is to promote adoption of companies' new technology by having it used by people with high profile (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Flat Panel Profits
abstract: Samsung SDI posts 29 percent increase in profit for fourth quarter; earned 141 billion won ($105 million) in period; graph (S)

headline: Enticements Are Cited By Bankers In Enron Case
abstract: Bankers for Enron Corp told former Enron treasurer Jeffrey McMahon that company that they had been led to believe that they could obtain lucrative businss from Enron if they agreed to invest money in outside partnership LJM controlled by Enron's chief financial officer Andrew S Fastow; legal experts say statements raise specter of potentially improper activity in solicitation of stakes in Enron's partnerships; say statements describe circumstance in which Enron executives may have sought personal benefits from Wall Street in exchange for awarding participation in company's vast business in underwriting securities; lawyers say such arrangements create serious issues for both banks that chose to invest based on such understanding and executives who communicated tie between partnership investments and company business (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Yen Rallies
abstract: Yen rises from three-year low against dollar after Japan's finance minister, Masajuro Shiokawa, says currency's 1.3 percent decline was 'too rapid' (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: VeriSign Will Acquire H.O. Systems
abstract: VeriSign, a  provider of Internet address and payment services, announced a deal yesterday to acquire H.O. Systems, which makes billing and customer service software for wireless carriers. VeriSign, based in Mountain View, Calif., will pay about $340 million in stock and cash for H.O. Systems, based in Savannah, Ga.. In addition, VeriSign announced yesterday that it had acquired the .tv Corporation International, a Los Angeles company that negotiated the exclusive right to market Internet addresses ending in .tv from the Pacific Island nation of Tuvalu, which was originally assigned the .tv extension. VeriSign shares fell $2.26, to $34.05.   Susan Stellin (NYT)

headline: Patents; A doctor researches the possibility of reducing weight with drugs used to shrink tumors.
abstract: IF Maria Rupnick turns out to be right, losing weight may one day become easy for millions of obese people.    In laboratory experiments at M.I.T. and the Children's Hospital in Boston, Dr. Rupnick has shown that an entire class of compounds designed to inhibit cancer may also, without any obvious side effects, cause extraordinary weight loss.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Sale Of A Unit Of Homestore Is Approved
abstract: Homestore.com receives antitrust clearance for sale of ConsumerInfo.com, its consumer credit-reporting unit, to Experian for $130 million; Federal Trade Commission says federal review has been completed, but FTC does not disclose whether it or Justice Department have considered matter (S)

headline: Catering to the Elderly Can Pay Off
abstract: Fred Brock column says too many companies fail to consider elderly consumer and are missing out on huge market as a result; praises Borders bookstores and Cracker Barrell restaurant chain as senior-friendly businesses; cites Gary Onks, author of Sold on Seniors: How You Can Reach and Sell the $20 Trillion Senior Marketplace; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Trinidad And Tobago: Selection Criticized
abstract: Outgoing Trinidad and Tobago prime minister, Basdeo Panday, criticizes election of political rival, Patrick Manning, as successor after parties tie in parliamentary vote; calls for new elections (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Water Utility Sold
abstract: Scottish Power to sell its Southern Water utility for 2.05 billion pounds ($2.9 billion) to First Aqua, consortium formed for deal led by Royal Bank of Scotland Group; First Aqua will try to sell Southern Water to trade group; stock price graph (S)

headline: Mexico Opens Investigation Into Money From Union
abstract: Mexican comptroller general, Francisco Barrio Terrazas, announces that government is investigating allegations that state-owned oil company Pemex and leaders of oil workers union misappropriated at least $100 million in union funds; he reportedly suspects that money was funneled into 2000 presidential campaign of Institutional Revolutionary Party (M)

headline: U.S. to Explore Aid to Colombia, Citing Threat of Terrorism
abstract: Bush administration hopes to use concern over terrorism to build support in Congress for direct aid to Colombian government to fight leftist rebels; Pres Bush says US will continue to comply with laws restricting American military involvement in Colombia to war on drugs, but administration officials are beginning to portray Colombian government's struggle as part of broader, worldwide fight against terrorists, and they say it deserves military support program; Sen Bob Graham says Colombia's instability must be viewed as regional security threat; says administration is sending conflicting signals; Secretary of State Colin Powell and national secuity adviser Condoleezza Rice are known to be urging cautious approach to Pres Andres Pastrana's appeal for military help (M)

headline: Investing; Russia's Stock Market Comes of Age
abstract: Analysts believe that Russia's stock market is becoming hospitable for investors, not just speculators, as in its first seven years; stocks are still relatively cheap despite 80 percent jump in value of Russian market in 2001, partly because market fell so far in 1998; easiest way for Americans to invest is through mutual fund listed in US; photo; graph (M)

headline: Critics Say Koizumi's Economic Medicine Is a Weak Tea
abstract: Japan's long-awaited economic reform package is issued, but disappoints analysts by talking not about bold measures but of forming committees; observers say Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi, elected last year as reformer, seems overwhelmed, clinging to Japan's 'old sotry of no accountability'; high expectations that greeted his election have been reduced to hope that Japan can muddle through to end of fiscal year without major bank collapse (M)

headline: Mideast Turmoil: The Bloodshed; SYRIA CHIEF BACKS SAUDI PEACE PLAN AS MIDEAST BOILS
abstract: Syrian Pres Bashar al-Assad meets with Saudi Crown Prince Abdullah, Riyadh, and backs his plan for Arab nations to normalize ties with Israel in return for full Israeli withdraw from land occupied in 1967 war; Syria calls for Israeli withdrawal from Golan Heights and for right of return for Palestinian refugees; Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak, meeting with Pres Bush, Washington, urges greater American role in peace effort; calls for immediate meeting between Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat; bomb planted in Arab schoolyard on Jerusalem outskirts and crude rockets fired from Gaza Strip at Sderot, Israel, fuel rapidly expanding Israeli-Palestinian feud; Israeli officials question claim that bomb, which exploded after students were ushered indoors, limiting injuries, was planted by previously unknown Jewish vigilante group; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FOSTER WHEELER, Hamilton, Bermuda, an engineering and construction company, said it won contracts worth $70 million to build three power plants in Germany.    TELEPHONE AND DATA SYSTEMS, Chicago, a provider of phone services, said it would buy the closely held Telecommunication Systems of New Hampshire, Wilton, N.H. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Court Rejects Limits On Owning TV Stations  A federal appeals court handed a huge victory to the nation's largest television networks and cable operators, ruling that the government had to reconsider sharp limits on the number of stations a network can own and striking down the regulation that had restricted cable operators from owning television stations.    The decision, which was seen as a setback by smaller owners of broadcast stations and consumer groups, could open the door for a new wave of megamergers in the entertainment and media industries and a continued concentration of power among the biggest media companies. [Page A1.]

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kashmir: Pro-India Politician Killed
abstract: Kashmiri militants assassinate local leader of pro-India National Conference Party, Abdul Rashid Dar, in Tailbal; it is third killing of ruling party politician in Indian-controlled sector this year (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: In Zimbabwe, Mugabe Runs Against an Old Rival: Colonialism
abstract: Zimbabwe Pres Robert Mugabe presides at campaign rally of supporters and assails opponent Morgan Tsvangirai as front man for whites; photo (M)

headline: USAIR TO RESTORE MOST OF ITS TRANS-ATLANTIC FLIGHTS
abstract: US Airways

headline: Andersen Says It Is Losing Clients
abstract: Arthur Andersen chairman-chief executive Joseph F Berardino says clients and potential clients are asking 'hard questions' about firm's role in collaspe of Enron Corp and Andersen is losing business as result, news conference, Chicago; says overall level of support for Andersen among its major clients remains high and firm has no need or desire to consider merging with rival as possible way out of its troubles; one potential client raising questions is New York City; city's Comptroller William C Thompson is considering disqualifying Arthur Andersen from list of approved accounting firms that city agencies can use; city officials say Andersen does not have contract with city; National League of Cities says New York is first city to consider disqualifying Andersen; Thompson has asked Andersen officials to come to New York on Jan 30 to explain why firm should not be removed from city's list of 97 approved firms; Andersen spokesman Patrick Dorton says firm hopes New York City will not drop firm from approved list; Berardino and Larry Gorrell, managing partner of Andersen's operations in Chicago, stress Andersen's long history of contributions to civic life in Chicago and cast Andersen's 85,000 employees worldwide as victims of Enron debacle; photo (M)

headline: His Rallying Cry at First Boston: Smaller, Cleaner, Fairer
abstract: First Bosl

headline: Private Sector; From Wall Street Stage to Screen
abstract: James Plutzik, vice chairman at Credit Suisse First Boston, comments on his addiction to Sid Meier's Civilization, video game, and decision to become chairman of its maker, Firaxis Games; photo (S)

headline: EXIDE, A BATTERY MAKER, PLANS TO CLOSE 2 PLANTS
abstract: Exide Technologies, which makes automobile batteries, will close two plastics plants in Mississippi and lay off more than 200 workers (S)

headline: J. P. MORGAN MUST ALLOW DISCLOSURE VOTE, S.E.C. SAYS
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission says J P Morgan Chase must allow shareholders to vote on proposal to force company to bar analysts from owning stocks they cover; J P Morgan Chase fails to get SEC permission to block motion by AFL-CIO, federation of trade unions sponsoring benefit plans with more than $400 billion in assets; proposal would also prevent J P Morgan's analysts from participating in investment banking (S)

headline: Ruling Accelerates Key Depositions
abstract: Federal Judge Melinda Harmon overseeing lawsuits against Enron Corp and its executives lifts certain trial rules, allowing lawyers to interrogate quickly some partners from company's accounting firm, Arthur Andersen & Co; under order, lawyers could schedule depositions in as little as three weeks from David B Duncan, who was lead partner in charge of Enron account, as well as four other partners and in-house lawyer (S)

headline: Audit Firms Await Fallout and Windfall
abstract: Some of America's biggest companies will be thrust into period of uncertainty if Arthur Andersen cannot find buyer; Anderson's more than 2,300 clients are under pressure to convince shareholders that their financial reports will remain reliable even though Andersen's fate is increasingly uncertain; more client defections are likely if Andersen's efforts to find merger partner fail; some accountants say predictions of Andersen's demise might be premature and exaggerated; Andersen's rivals foresee windfall even though they cannot quickly absorb thousands of new clients; former Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Richard C Breeden says Andersen's collapse would be 'major event, if it happens'; charts (M)

headline: Providian Settlement Small Change to Many
abstract: DIARY Â  Providian Settlement Small Change to Many.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Sentences After Genocide
abstract: Rwandan courts have sentenced 660 people to death for crimes related to 1994 genocide; others will serve life sentences and many still await trial (S)

headline: Rumsfeld Says He Held No Enron Stock
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says in statement that he did not own any shares of Enron stock; statement takes issue with news reports, including chart in New York Times, that said Rumsfeld owned $1,000 to $15,000 worth of Enron stock at time of his appointment (S)

headline: WATCHGUARD IS BUYING RAPIDSTREAM FOR $48 MILLION
abstract: WatchGuard Technologies, maker of Internet-security software and hardware, plans to buy RapidStream Inc for $48 million (S)

headline: Rumors Roil Shaky Prague Market
abstract: Ceske Radiokomunikace, Czech Republic's largest telecommunications company, says there is nothing to rumors that it is planning to delist its shares on Prague Stock Exchange and move to Cayman Islands; trading in stock resumes, with shares gaining 7.18 percent in heavy trading after falling 17 percent on March 20; investors do not have any clearer picture now of company's future than they did week ago, and market watchers in Prague say incident is symptomatic of Prague market's continuing problems with opacity and mistrust; graph (M)

headline: U.S. Growth Rate, at 1.4%, Is Far Better Than Expected
abstract: Commerce Department reports economy grew at 1.4 percent annual rate in fourth quarter; says in January gross domestic product, after declining at annual rate of 1.3 percent in third quarter, rose in fourth at meager 0.2 percent, adjusted for inflation; spending on durable goods rose to annual rate of $1.021 trillion, up $81.1 billion from third quarter; graph (M)

headline: Departure Expected to Have Little Impact on Kodak
abstract: There is little question that Patricia F. Russo's departure is disappointing to Eastman Kodak.     The company is in the throes of a transition from products built around chemical-based film to those involving digital photography. Last April, when Kodak announced that it had hired Ms. Russo as its president, Daniel A. Carp, Kodak's chief executive, readily acknowledged that she was bringing technological expertise that he lacked.

headline: Enron's Ex-Chief Ties the Knot
abstract: Jeffrey K Skilling, former chief executive of Enron Corp, marries Rebecca Carter, who was corporate secretary for Enron's board and senior vice president for board communications, Houston, Tex (S)

headline: Enron Names an Interim Chief to Oversee Its Bankruptcy
abstract: Enron Corp names Stephen F Cooper, specialist in revamping troubled companies, as interim chief executive, replacing Kenneth L Lay, who resigned; also names Jeffrey McMahon president and chief operating officer, succeeding Lawrence G Whalley, who resigned; Raymond M Bowen Jr, formerly treasurer, is appointed executive vice president and chief financial officer; photos (M)

headline: Getting Remote Access To Another's Computer
abstract: Q.  How can I assume control over another PC over the Internet to help the person on the other end solve system problems?    A.  A number of programs let you take control of another computer remotely and can even show you everything on the desktop of the person who needs help. Both computers will usually need to have the software installed and properly configured. This kind of program is used for everything from troubleshooting to telecommuting.

headline: Primedia Quarterly Loss Widens
abstract: Primedia Inc reports fourth-quarter loss of $608.4 million compared with loss of $257.3 million year earlier; sales fell 1.7 percent, to $451.4 million (M)

headline: After Founder Dies, Wendy's Ponders New Ways to Pitch
abstract: The death yesterday of R. David Thomas, the founder of the fast-food chain Wendy's International, ends a second career he reluctantly began 13 years ago as the public face of his company, in what became the longest-running and perhaps most successful campaign of its kind. Now, Wendy's and its longtime agency, Bates USA in New York, face considerable challenges in determining what to do.    ''When a human so dominates the brand image, few brands survive the demise of the personality,'' said Clive Chajet, chairman at Chajet Consultancy in New York, a corporate identity consulting company.  He gave as an example the struggles by another fast-food marketer, Kentucky Fried Chicken, now the KFC division of Tricon Global Restaurants, after the death of its founder, Col. Harland Sanders, in 1980. Since then, KFC has careered from one campaign to another, alternately trying to revive Sanders or ignore him; the reprises have ranged from animated cartoons to archival film to actors impersonating his looks or his voice.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Macedonia: Guerrillas Fight Each Other
abstract: Rival groups of ethnic Albanian guerrillas wage fierce nighttime battle, killing two fighters and wounding five bystanders (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Triples
abstract: Japan's current account rose to 709 billion yen ($5.5 billion) in January, 224 percent more than in January 2001; imports fell 11 percent, while exports dipped 2.9 percent (S)

headline: DELTA PETROLEUM BUYS PROPERTY TO DOUBLE OIL OUTPUT
abstract: Delta Petroleum Corp acquires all of Castle Energy Corp's oil and gas properties in US for about $57.3 million in stock and cash to double its daily production of oil (S)

headline: KELLOGG AND DISNEY ANNOUNCE CEREAL DEAL
abstract: Walt Disney Co and Kellogg Co announce partnership that will put animated superstars of one company on cereals, waffles and cookies of other (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Impath Buys Software Maker
abstract: Impath Inc. of New York agreed to buy the closely held Tamtron Corporation to expand its business helping pharmaceutical and genomics companies develop drugs. Impath, which provides doctors cancer testing and treatment information, said the purchase would add about 5 percent to its quarterly earnings. Tamtron's software helps with cancer diagnosis and treatment decisions.

headline: In Reverse; From the Stereo to the Hard Drive
abstract: Guide to transferring music on casssete tapes and records to personal computer; photo (M)7

headline: Cram Sessions: The Evolution of an Ever Deeper Disc
abstract: Development of digital versatile disc standard (DVD) has greatly increased amount of sound and video that can be stored on one disc; drawing (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Aerospace Loss Narrows
abstract: European Aeronautic, Defense and Space Co's second-half loss narrowed 48 percent last year, to 285 million euros ($251 million); chief financial officer Axel Arendt comments (S)

headline: Britain Downgrades Status of Iran's Ambassador
abstract: Britain today downgraded the status of the Iranian envoy in London after Iran turned down Britain's choice of ambassador to Tehran.

headline: Dause L. Bibby, 90, Electronics Executive
abstract: Dause L Bibby, longtime executive in emerging fields of electronics and technology, dies at age 90 (S)

headline: After Days of Give and Take, Afghans and British Reach Agreement on Peacekeepers
abstract: Afghanistan's interim administration and British Maj Gen John McCol reach agreement on terms for operation of peacekeeping force in Kabul; photo ()

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: The First Saint
abstract: Pope John Paul II to canonize first Brazilian saint, Amabile Lucia Visintainer; Italian-born nun known as Mother Paulina arrived in Brazil in 1875 (S)

headline: A Language Barrier
abstract: Alan Turboff letter says he uses shreds of Spanish he learned in college to put off telemarketers (March 10 article)

headline: As Enron Searches for Auditor, Some Big Names Don't Apply
abstract: Enron Corp faces difficult task of finding another accounting firm willing to take Arthur Andersen's place; two of other four large accounting firms say they do not intend to compete for Enron account; remaining two--Deloitte & Touche and KPMG--refuse comment; that may mean much smaller firm will have to wade through Enron's finances; PricewaterhouseCoopers said last week it does not intend to do audit; Ernst & Young is already advising Enron on its Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Publisher's Profit Declines
abstract: Pearson reports 12 percent decline in pretax earnings in 2001; pretax profit was 294 million pounds ($417 million), compared with 333 million pounds year earlier; sales rose 15 percent, to 4.2 billion pounds, compared with 3.7 billion pounds year ago; graph (S)

headline: CARNIVAL TO SWEETEN OFFER FOR P&O PRINCESS
abstract: Carnival Corp is preparing to raise its hostile bid for P&O Princess Cruises (S)

headline: Satellite Maker Fined $20 Million in China Trade Secrets Case
abstract: Loral Space and Communications Corp reaches accord with State Department to pay $14 million in fines and spend $6 million to improve its compliance procedures over seven years to settle federal probe into charges it passed sensitive materials to China after abortive 1996 satellite launching there; department calls penalty apparently largest paid by American company under Arms Export Control Act; Loral chairman Bernard L Schwartz accepts full responsibility for matter, statement (M)

headline: Rebound Helps Gucci Beat the Pessimistic Expectations
abstract: Gucci Group says profits fell to $278.4 million for fiscal year ended Jan 31 from $336.7 million year before; revenue grew 1.2 percent, to $2.3 billion (M)

headline: I.M.F. Backs Official Shift To U.S. Dollar By Afghans
abstract: Afghanistan weighs plan to adopt United States dollar as legal tender until it introduces new currency; local currency, the afghani, has been ruinously devalued as warlords and counterfeiters print their own notes; Afghanistan's move toward dollar wins support from International Monetary Fund; country's currency woes are only most visible manifestation of economy that has given up any pretense to international standards (M)

headline: Gordon Matthews Dead at 65; Invented Corporate Voice Mail
abstract: Gordon Matthews, who invented voice mail in 1970's, dies at age 65; photo (M)

headline: 'It Takes a Lot of Courage To Do Something New'
abstract: Shira P White, author of New Ideas About New Ideas, contends that American companies need to be more creative; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Zimbabwe Press Law Criticized
abstract: Abid Hussain, United Nations investigator for press freedom, says Zimbabwe's new restrictions on journalists violate international human rights law (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Enron Official Sought Help From Government Last Fall  The president of the Enron Corporation repeatedly called a senior Treasury Department official last fall and sought help arranging bank loans for the energy company as it scrambled to avoid collapse, the Bush administration said.    The official, Peter R. Fisher, the under secretary of the Treasury for domestic finance, spoke six or eight times during late October and early November with Greg Whalley, Enron's president, a Treasury Department spokeswoman said. [Page A1.]

headline: Managers Say This Decade Belongs to Health Care
abstract: Health care mutual fund managers predict sector, which outperformed overall market over last decade, despite disappointing 2001, will dominate market in next decade; health care sector funds fell average of 10.9 percent in 2001; returned 13.8 percent a year over last 10 years, versus 12.9 percent for Standard & Poor's 500-stock index; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: More Defectors From North
abstract: South Korean intelligence service reports 20 more defectors from North Korea, bringing total this year to 74; total of 583 Koreans defected last year (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Meeting On Peace Effort
abstract: Norwegian delegation meets with Sri Lanka's newly elected government in first step to formalize cease-fire with separatist Tamil rebels (S)

headline: Chevrolet Sales Surpass Ford's For First Time In 10 Years
abstract: Chevrolet outsells Ford brand in February for first month in more than decade, further highlighting resurgence of General Motors Corp and struggles of Ford Motor Co; GM's use of aggressive promotions and incentives like $2,002 rebates help make Chevrolets, including Corvette, country's top-selling vehicle brand in February; chart; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Top Bid For Enron Assets
abstract: Iberdrola of Spain is top bidder with offer of $315 million for bankrupt Enron Corp's turbines, generators and unfinished power-plant project (S)

headline: MIRAVANT SHARES SKID ON DRUG'S DISAPPOINTING TESTS
abstract: Miravant Medical Technologies says its leading product, drug known as SnET2 to treat major cause of blindness, did not work in late-stage study, setting off 75 percent decline in its stock price; company says it will work with its partner, Pharmacia Corp, to determine whether to continue developing drug (S)

headline: Help Wanted (And Unwanted)
abstract: Readers share some of career advice they have received over years, good and bad; drawing (M)

headline: IN SHIFT, BUSH SAYS GENEVA RULES FIT TALIBAN CAPTIVES
abstract: Pres Bush decides that Geneva Convention will be applied to Taliban captives being held in Cuba but not to Al Qaeda detainees; decision will make little difference in day-to-day treatment of either but may help protect American soldiers captured in foreign conflicts; administration decision not to grant prisoner-of-war status to any captives will hold; decision to apply Geneva Convention to Taliban was urged by Secretary of State Colin L Powell after pressure from European allies; Powell seeks to send signal to world that US respects convention and expects its own captured soldiers to be accorded its protections; critics argue that Bush's action makes mockery of convention and may or may not protect American soldiers (M)

headline: WIDE EFFORT SEEN IN SHREDDING DATA ON ENRON'S AUDITS
abstract: Rep James C Greenwood, whose House subcommittee probes Enron Corp collapse, says up to 80 people who worked at Arthur Andersen's Houston office were told to destroy documents related to Enron; questions Andersen's efforts to blame rogue employees for episode; Congressional investigators make public memo David B Duncan, Andersen's lead partner on Enron account, wrote last Oct noting he warned Enron chief accounting officer Rick Causey that way in which Enron was about to disclose huge losses from controversial deals was misleading and possibly illegal; Andersen calls memo routine; again holds it did not sanction destruction of documents ordered by Duncan and and other Houston partners; Duncan's lawyer says he will invoke Fifth Amendment at subcommittee hearing unless granted immunity (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Resignation At Deutsche Bank
abstract: In a continuation of the shake-up at Deutsche Bank as Josef Ackermann, left, prepares to take over as chief executive in May, Michael Philipp resigned as the bank's head of global asset management. The bank said Mr. Philipp, an American, wog

headline: Vatican Curbing Deacons in Mexico
abstract: Vatican orders Diocese of San Cristobal de las Casas in southern Mexico to halt ordaining deacons for at least five-year period for evaluation; deacons who do much of work of priests except consecrating Communion or hearing confession, are married men with limited education; their special brand of evangelism, infused with tenets of liberation theology as well as pre-Columbian symbols and songs, does not sit well with church, which feels their growing numbers have broken with traditional church hierarchy; Vatican feels their loosely defined responsibilities and their wives deviate from church doctrine and could set bad example for indigenous parishes worldwide; photo (M)

headline: Behind the Kidnapping: Pakistan Feels Pressure
abstract: Analysis: mixture of bravado and inscrutability with which Pakistani officials are addressing case of kidnapped American journalist Daniel Pearl is being watched as clue to intense pressures abuduction has placed on government; Pres Pervez Musharraf's upcoming White House visit for meeting with Pres Bush is being clouded by kidnapping and some aspects of Pakistan's response; kidnapping is reminder that Pakistan continues to be riven by rivalries between security agencies unwilling or unable to dissolve old ties with Muslim militants (M)

headline: Drug Middlemen Are Facing Pressure Over Rising Prices
abstract: Pressure is building against handful of powerful companies that have prospered for years as middlemen between drug manufacturers and those who pay for medicines; companies, called pharmacy benefit managers, administer drug plans for some 200 million Americans and play critical role in determining which drugs people take for different ailments; large corporations and major public employers say pharmacy benefit managers have not done enough to stem rapid growth in national spending on prescription drugs, which narly tripled in last eight years from $50 billion in 1993 to $150 billion last year; consumrs and employers have filed lawsuits against several pharmacy benefit managers, claiming that they inflate drug costs for some customers and violate their duty to act in best interest of customers; pharmacists in dozen states are pressing for laws that would tighten regulatory oversight of pharmacy benefit managers; critics say pharmacy benefit management companies negotiate deals with drug makers that benefit themselves and drug companies more than anyone else; suits have been filed against Merck-Medco, Express Scripts and AdvancePCS; Peter E Shumlin, president of Vermont Senate and chairman of Northeast Legislative Association on Prescription Drug Prices, comments; chart; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ex-Global Crossing Worker Accused of Making Threats  The F.B.I. arrested a disgruntled former employee of Global Crossing and charged him with using the Internet to post threats to injure or kill company executives and to display personal information, including the Social Security numbers, of nearly 2,000 of the company's employees.    The arrest ended a five-month investigation into the activities of Steven William Sutcliffe, a 40-year-old former technical support worker at Global Crossing's offices in Beverly Hills, Calif. Federal agents arrested Mr. Sutcliffe in Manchester, N.H. [Page C2.]

headline: Accounts
abstract: Advertising account changes noted (S)l

headline: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Nuclear Program Could Resume
abstract: world b

headline: Economic Scene; A bull market and a boom in 401(k)'s must mean fat pensions? Think again.
abstract: Jeff Madrick 'Economic Scene' column on whether bull market and boom in 401(k) pension plans resulted in big pensions; cites figures by New York University Prof Edward N Wolff showing that two-thirds of American households have not increased their retirement wealth from pensions at all since 1983; Wolff calculated value of both defined-contribution and defined-benefit plans, based on data from Federal Reserve and Internal Revenue Service; says 65 percent of all American households headed by person between 47 and 64 in 1998 had either same pension wealth, adjusted for inflation, than households headed by people in that age group did 15 years earlier, or even less; for household in middle retirement wealth fell 13 percent from 1983 to 1998; says what disguised facts before was that overall gains in these retirement accounts were large; holds problems is that these gains went disproportionately to wealthy; graph (M)

headline: Victory or Martyrdom. 'So How Could They Retreat So Easily?'
abstract: Excerpts from letter found in house used by Al Qaeda members in Kabul; letter appears to describe battle between Arabs allied with Taliban and Northern Alliance forces; photo (L)

headline: HOSPITAL-EQUIPMENT MAKER CUT 189 JOBS
abstract: Graham-Field Health Products Inc, maker of hospital beds and wheelchairs, cuts 189 jobs as part of closing of its Bay Shore, NY, factory (S)

headline: Brown Brothers Harriman Names Managing Director
abstract: Brown Brothers Harriman & Company names Michael W McConnell managing partner, position akin to chief executive, succeeding Anthony T Enders, who is retiring (M)

headline: Milosevic Is in Court as Trial Plan Is Set
abstract: Former Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic challenges legitimacy of United Nations war crimes tribunal, pre-trial hearing, Hague; Judge Richard May seeks to organize efficient and speedy trial; chief prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, is appealing court's decision that trial deal only with charges relating to 1999 war in Kosovo, move that could delay or slow down proceedings; photo (M)

headline: An Orange Grove Illustrates Japan's Economic Woe
abstract: Japanese agriculture is glaring example of country's political diversion of money to industries that are no longer doing well; agricultural protectionism is thought to cost Japanese consumers, overwhelmingly city dwellers, about $60 billion in extra food costs; Japanese taxpayers pay additional $30 billion in government subsidies to farmers; despite this largess, full-time farmers account for just 5 percent of nation's work force, and overwhelming majority are aging or weekend farmers; subsidies and protections roll on because governing Liberal Democratic Party is dependent on rural votes for its survival; photo; map (M)

headline: Stock Options Are Faulted By Buffett
abstract: Warren E Buffett uses Berkshire Hathaway annual report to renew attack on widespread use of stock options and at ways corporations assure that executives will profit from options even if company's share price declines; argues that stock options often do not give executives same stake as shareholders have, since shareholders will suffer if price declines; statement follows disclosure that General Electric took unusual step of issuing new round of options shortly after Sept 11, when sharp slide in GM stock made it appear less likely that executives would profit from options issued two months earlier (M)

headline: Old Rules Gone, Argentines Brace for the Unknown
abstract: For more than a decade, Juan Carlos Meluso and his wife, Silvia Cataldo, awoke each morning knowing that one Argentine peso was worth one American dollar. Although the system was far from perfect, at least the rules were clear.     But when banks resume normal activities here Wednesday, after operating under emergency restrictions since before Christmas because of an economic crisis, the Melusos and millions of other middle-class Argentines will confront a brand new, uncertain world. After the peso was devalued by nearly 30 percent Sunday night, fears of a burst of inflation are growing, basic goods are in short supply and the economy remains prostrate.

headline: Suspects in Singapore Are Linked to Al Qaeda and Plans for Anti-U.S. Attacks
abstract: Singapore government says 13 terrorist suspects it arrested last month are linked with Al Qaeda and planned bomb attacks against Western embassies, American naval vessels, American companies and shuttle bus carrying American troops; says suspects belong to clandestine organization called Islamic Group, and that 8 of them received training in Afghanistan from Al Qaeda, network led by Osama bin Laden; these allegations, along with arrests of 13 terrorism suspects last month in Malaysia, shift focus of concern in region to these two nations with significant Muslim populations; evidence released by both governments suggest significant cooperation among radical groups in region, as well as active links with Muslim terrorist groups elsewhere; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Rebels Set Condition For Talks
abstract: Ethnic Tamil rebels demand that ban on their group, Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, be lifted before they will enter peace talks with government of Sri Lanka to end 18-year civil war that has killed more than 62,000 people; group has been designated terrorist outfit not only by Sri Lanka but also by India, United States and Canada (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: European Union: Dispute Won't Block Czechs
abstract: Senior European Union official Eneko Landaburu says dispute between Austria and Czech Republic over Czech nuclear reactor would not affect Czechs' application to join union; far-right Freedom Party, member of Austria's governing coalition, wants government to veto Czech entry if it does not shut reactor that has been plagued by technical problems (S)

headline: Diverse Group Opposes EchoStar-DirecTV Deal
abstract: Diverse group that includes News Corp head Rupert Murdoch, Rev Al Sharpton, powerful members of Congress and Missouri soybean farmer Charles Kruse opposes EchoStar Communications' efforts to win regulatory approval for takeover of DirecTV; Justice Department, in consultation with Federal Communications Commission, will approve or reject $26 billion acquisition, deal that would create near-monopoly in subscription TV service; Sharpton is arguing that deal be rejected unless EchoStar agrees to carry more religious programming and programming aimed at minority groups; Missouri Farm Bureau Federation president Kruse says merger could keep households in sparsely populated areas from having choice of pay television providers; many members of Congress from rural and Western states agree, and coalition of state attorneys general may form to oppose merger; Murdoch, whose News Corp was losing bidder, says merger would give television programmers fewer competing buyers for their shows; few parties speaking out in favor of merger are EchoStar and DirecTV's corporate parent, Hughes Electronics (M)

headline: New Riddle for Xbox: Will It Play in Japan?
abstract: Bill Gates will personally introduce Xbox, Microsoft Corp's video game console, to Japan; Microsoft is expected to have hard time competing against Sony and Nintendo on their home turf, but then North American rollout of Xbox was much stronger than analysts and software makers anticipated; company has built smaller game controllers, with buttons closer together, to better fit hands of average Japanese player; photos (M)

headline: FLEETBOSTON LOST $521 MILLION IN ARGENTINA LAST YEAR
