abstract: FleetBoston Financial Corp loses $521 million doing business in Argentina last year (S)

headline: Modules Turn Visor Hand-Helds Into All-Purpose Containers
abstract: New line of Springboard modules from Portable Innovation Technology offers multiple ways to expand memory of Handspring's Visor palm-based organizers; photo (S)

headline: PRESIDENT OF UPN NETWORK IS LEAVING VIACOM
abstract: Dean Valentine, president of UPN television network, is leaving Viacom, which has folded UPN into larger CBS Television unit (S)

headline: D.E.A. Extends Its Deadline For Banning Hemp in Food
abstract: Drug Enforcement Administration says it will extend by 40 days grace period for companies to dispose of food products made from hemp, plant containing small amounts of tetrahydrocannabinol, same psychoactive substance found in marijuana; seeks to give appeals court time to rule on appeal by nascent hemp food industry (S)

headline: More trouble arrives for Bates Worldwide as Hyundai Motor puts a job up for review.
abstract: South Korea's Hyundai Motor Co has placed in review American advertising creative account, which has been handed since 1986 at Bates Worldwide; billings estimated at $150 million to $200 million (M)

headline: The Ups, Downs and Fine Print of Sector Rotation
abstract: strategies: the ups, downs and fine

headline: Powell Now 'Very Encouraged' on Kashmir
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell says he received strong signs from India and Pakistan that tensions are decreasing, but his 36 hours of cross-border diplomacy ends without concrete agreements from either side on easing their military standoff; Pakistan's military ruler, Gen Pervez Musharraf, says for first time in standoff that he is confident war could be avoided, but he warns that Pakistan would respond strongly to attack; Indian Foreign Min Jaswant Singh again calls on Pakistan to take action against 20 suspected terrorists and criminals living in Pakistan and wanted by India; map (M)

headline: U.S. Supports Colombian On Ultimatum to Rebels
abstract: Bush administration voices support for Pres Andres Pastrana's ultimatum to leftist rebels in Colombia, even as officials and experts express misgivings that it could lead to further violence and disrupt counternarcotics efforts; Secretary of State Colin L Powell lays blame on rebel group, FARC, for collapse of peace talks after three years; administration officials have backed peace talks because they have concluded that Colombia's security forces are incapable of victory over 17,000-member FARC; but they acknowledge that Pastrana has nothing to show for negotiations and that rebels have little incentive to make deal (M)

headline: Bank Report Says Trader Had Bold Plot
abstract: Allied Irish Banks issues internal report showing Baltimore currency trader John M Rusnak, who hid losses of $691 million over five years, was 'unusually clever and devious'--and also bold; report by Eugene A Ludwig, former US comptroller of currency, puts much of blame on Allfirst Financial and Allied Irish Banks; it describes environment at Allfirst so absent of proper controls or oversight that it was easy for Rusnak to do what he did; says uncovering what Rusnak was doing would have been easy; holds big banks that traded with Rusnak, including Bank of America and Citibank, should have raised questions about what he was doing; Citibank has suspended indefinitely, with pay, foreign exchange sales representatives Richard Marra and Joseph Craven, who dealt with Rusnak (M)

headline: Thailand Development Faces Rare Challenge
abstract: Thai government's approval of dispute project, $500 million Trans Thai-Malaysia Pipeline, has provoked rare challenge to Prime Min Thaksin Shinawatra's development plans and signals that days of unfettered development in Thailand may be over; plan for pipeline, conduit to carry natural gas from fields in South China Sea to Malaysia, was held up for more than year by objections from review panel and by protests of villagers in region where pipeline is to be built; when policy office approved project last month, Walwipha Burusratanaphand, member of 12-person exprt panel, publicly accused government of railroading it through; photo (M)

headline: In El Salvador, Bush Talks of Trade and Criticizes Democrats
abstract: Pres Bush says he will push hard for trade accord between US and Central America, but takes time during visit to El Salvador to criticize Democrats for calling four-day trip to Latin America excuse to pander for Latino votes; meets with Salvadoran Pres Francisco Flores, whom he lauds as democratic reformer and friend; says El Salvador, which decade ago was mired in violent civil war, is one of great stories of economic and political transformation of current era; criticisms of Bush trip by former California State Assembly speaker Antonio Villaraigosa, whose sees trip as part of orchestrated strategy to curry favor with Latinos, noted (M)

headline: Belgrade Journal; Milosevic Spouts Facts. Who's Spilling Secrets?
abstract: Focus on controversy over source of information being tapped by former Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic, being tried for war crimes in the Hague; he seems to have good and accurate information about everything in cross-examining witnesses; claims information is obtained from associates in Serbia, process lawyers describe as organic telephone tree of informers, including some Albanians, who pass along bits of information as testimony unfolds; weekly Serbian newspaper having close contacts with state security official suggests otherwise; reports Milosevic transferred thousands of Army documents to his own archives before losing power in October 2000; photo (M)

headline: Business; Lifted by a War Budget
abstract: Post-Sept 11 military spending boom has provided big boost for defense industry and revived some endangered military programs; graph (S)

headline: Sharon's Condition for Talks: Tougher Action on Militants
abstract: Senior Israeli officials said today that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon would press the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat to take tougher action against militants before Israel agrees to resume talks.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Trade: W.T.O. Resolves Dispute
abstract: Member countries of World Trade Organization resolve dispute on how to structure negotiations on new round of talks aimed at opening global markets (S)

headline: Paralyzed Woman Has Right To Die, a British Judge Rules
abstract: British High Court judge, Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, rules that paralzyed woman has right to die and that it is her decision rather than her doctors' whether life-support machine should be shut off; woman, 43-year-old former social worker, appealed to court after doctors at hospital where she is in intensive care say ethics blocks them from following her wishes to end her life; woman has needed ventilator to remain alive since ruptured blood vessel in her neck year ago left her unable to breathe unaided (M)

headline: Patents; A Sinatra-style crooner comes up with a way to use computers, not sheet music, to call the tune.
abstract: Harry Connick Jr patents system and method to coordinate music display among orchestra players; says system is designed to replace sheet music with computer displays, phone interview; photo (M)

headline: Junk Bonds Still Have Fans Despite a Dismal Showing in 2001
abstract: After a year filled with failures in the high-yield debt market, junk bonds are expected to live up to their name again in 2002.

headline: Supreme Court To Decide Fate Of 200 Licenses For Wireless Use
abstract: Long-running battle over more than 200 valuable wireless communications licenses reaches Supreme Court, which agrees to consider government's argument that it has right to seize licenses from bankrupt NextWave Telecom Inc and auction them to nation's largest communications carriers, including Verizon Wireless; decision breathes new life into effort by Federal Communications Commission to confiscate licenses from NextWave; Verizon agreed to pay $16 billion for licenses, but they were never released, as NexWave sued FCC, arguing that government did not have right to seize assets of bankrupt company; federal appeals court upheld NextWave's argument last June (M)

headline: Hyundai Chooses 10 Agencies for Review
abstract: Hyundai Chooses 10 Agencies for Review Hyundai Motor America in Fountain Valley, Calif., a division of the South Korean automaker Hyundai Motor, has named 10 agencies to compete in a review for its creative account. Billings were estimated at $160 million.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Loss At Electronics Maker
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics reports net loss for 2001 of 2.6 billion euros ($2.3 billion), compared with record profit of 9.6 billion euros in 2000; company's shares rise sharply as chief executive Gerard Kleisterlee forecasts return to profitability this year (S)

headline: Mugabe Takes Office Again, Appealing for National Unity
abstract: Zimbabwe Pres Robert Mugabe is sworn in for another six-year term after being declared winner of most contentious election since he came to power in 1980; delivers inauguration speech replete with blunt appeals for African solidarity and predictable criticisms of Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain; opposition has rejected his claim to victory on grounds that results of March 9-11 voting were rigged; photo (S)

headline: Terror's Confounding Online Trail
abstract: Federal investigators searching for terrorists and information about terrorist activity find that despite their superior electronic arsenal and digital tools, tracking activities of terrorists proves elusive; photo of David Lang, director of computer forensics at Veridian Corp (M)

headline: Looking In On a Loved One
abstract: Dr Keith Bolton, vice president and chief technology officer at Digital Angel, describes development of company's product, also called Digital Angel, which remotely monitors condition of old people or children and tracks them if they wander off; photo (M)

headline: Statuette Is Traced to Midas; Alas, Not Golden, Just Ivory
abstract: Dr Keith DeVries holds ivory statuette found in Greece's Delphi ruinsin 1939 was likely part of gift to God Apollo by famous King Midas, who ruled Phrygian kingdom at Gordion in what is now central Turkey; cites new findings of Phrygian art and revised radiocarbon dates of Gordion chronology to support stand, phone interview; map; photo (M)

headline: Qaeda's Grocery Lists And Manuals of Killing
abstract: Article in series, The Jihad Files, examines documents found at safe houses and training camps across Afghanistan abandoned by fleeing Islamic militants; 5,000 pages of documents left behind by Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters deal with everything from grocery lists to notes for positioning truck bombs; taken together, pages tell rich inside story of network of radical Islamic groups that Osama bin Laden helped assemble in Afghanistan; show that training camps, characterized by Bush administration as terrorist schools, were instead largely focused on creating army to support Taliban in its long ground war against Northern Alliance; show that only small group of recruits got elite training for terrorist actions abroad; above all, documents show how far bin Laden progressed in realizing his central vision: joining Muslim militants, energized by local causes, into global army aimed at West; recruits at Afghan camps came from more than 20 countries, including Iraq, Malaysia, Somalia and Britain; detailed description of findings; excerpts from some documents; photos (L)

headline: Indonesian in Terror Inquiry Lauds bin Laden
abstract: Abu Bakar Baasyir, Islamic cleric who is questioned in Jakarta, Indonesia, by police after Singapore and Malaysia demand his arrest, lauds Osama bin Laden as 'a true Islamic warrior' who has shown courage and skill to fight United States; summons of Baasyir follow disclosure this month of plan for Islamic militants to blow up American Embassy and other American installations in Singapore; Singapore accuses Baasyir of leading regionwide Southeast Asia terror netowrk, Jamaah Islamiah, or Islamic Group, that is suspected of having ties to bin Laden's network, Al Qaeda; photo of Baasyir; map (M)

headline: A Lid on Drug Prices
abstract: Jeanette F Huber letter on Jan 13 article on Medicaid official Ray Hanley calls for ban on prescription drug advertisements

headline: GE CAPITAL PLANS TO RAISE $6 BILLION IN DEBT SALE
abstract: General Electric Co's financing unit, GE Capital Corp, plans to raise $6 billion in biggest corporate debt sales this year, tapping bond market before economic recovery drives up borrowing costs (S)

headline: American Honors Germans Who Preserve Jews' History
abstract: Arthur Obermayer, American Jewish entrepreneur, awards Obermayer German Jewish History Awards to six Germans for their efforts to preserve Jewish history in Germany; recipients identified as Heinrich Schreiner, Monica Kingreen, Gunter Boll, Olaf Ditzel, Josef Motschmann and Gisela Bunge (S)

headline: Enron Chief Quits Under Pressure And Calls Inquiries a Distraction
abstract: Kenneth L Lay resigns as bankrupt Enron Corp chairman and chief executive under pressure from outside creditors; will remain director; photo (M)

headline: Tap. Tap. Tap. Check the Risk in Those 401(k) Nest Eggs
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column says employees increase their risk by having major part of their 401(k) retirement plan invested in their own company's stock; cites Enron Corp's example as well as analysis performed by RiskMetrics; graph (M)

headline: Red Cross Oversees Afghan 'Place of Aid,' Where a Man Has Been Chained for 35 Years
abstract: International Committee of Red Cross has since 1994 financed and monitored Afghanistan's 'marastoons,' places of aid for beggars and homeless; one of six inmates at Kandahar marastoon has for unknown reason been chained by ankle for 35 years; Gianni Bachetta, who recently arrived in Kandahar to repalce longtime Red Cross representative there, says he is appalled at what he has found but that he must be careful not to offend marastoon's Afghan management by acting too boldly (M)

headline: Executive Life; Last Days of the Corporate Technophobe
abstract: Many senior executives who have resisted digital revolution are at last caving in, and thinning ranks of the computer-illiterates are feeling pressure to log on and catch up; photo (M)

headline: Powell Says Arafat Takes Responsibility
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell tells Congress that Yasir Arafat has accepted responsibility for attempt last month to smuggle Iranian weapons for use against Israel; says Arafat does not admit to personal role, but accepts responsibility in his capacity as chairman of Palestinian Authority; Arafat had disavowed any connection to arms shipment in letter to Pres Bush last month that Bush has angrily dismissed (M)

headline: A Familiar Capital Script
abstract: The Enron inquiry presents elements reminiscent of earlier Washington scandals.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Nasdaq Increases 5.6% In First Days of New Year  The Nasdaq composite index has climbed 5.6 percent in the first three days of trading this year, as investors buy on the belief that technology purchases will fuel the economic recovery. The Nasdaq composite index rose 15.11 points yesterday, or 0.7 percent, to 2,059.38. Since their lows of Sept. 21, technology stocks have gained more than 44 percent.    The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 87.60 points, or 0.9 percent, at 10,259.74, providing a gain of 1.2 percent for the week. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 7.24 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,172.51, and was up less than 1 percent for the week. [Page C4.]

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Chip Maker Sells Bonds
abstract: Four months after denying that it needed to raise cash, Infineon, the world's fourth-largest memory chip maker, successfully sold a billion euros ($890 million) of convertible bonds. It was the company's first debt sale and came after a 1.5 billion euro ($1.3 billion) equity offering in July. Infineon, based in Munich, posted a 591 million euro ($526 million) loss in fiscal 2001 after prices for DRAM chips fell sharply to less than a third of production costs. Siemens, the company's largest shareholder, also announced that it had sold 40 million Infineon shares worth 974 million euros ($867 million).   Desmond Butler (NYT)

headline: The Producers Who Measure Profit Against Beautiful Odds
abstract: Ron Howard and Brian Grazer, partners in Imagine Entertainment, have earned reputation making films like A Beautiful Mind and Splash that have mass-market appeal and earn good money but that generally avoid baser instincts of many Hollywood movies; that Imagine thrives at all is remarkable in a Hollywood obsessed with franchising, cross-promotional marketing strategies and teenage demographics; best-picture Oscar for A Beautiful Mind would be fitting tribute to Howard's and Grazer's 16-year partnership; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Interest Rate Raised
abstract: Sweden's central bank raises its benchmark repurchase rate quarter of point, to 4 percent, first increase since July and first time Western central bank has raised rates this year (S)

headline: U.S. Planning Gradual Curb On Emissions, Taking Years
abstract: Bush administration outlines climate policy that calls for far more gradual approach to global warming than 1997 Kyoto Protocol; says uncertainty surrounding science of climate change suggests that cautious approach is in order (M)

headline: Putting 'Lost Everything' In Perspective
abstract: Personal finances of former Enron Corp chief executive Kenneth Lay and his wife Linda remain mysterious despite Mrs Lay's televised statement on Today show that they have 'lost everything'; couple appears to have at least $8 million in stock in two outside companies where Lay was director and another $25 million in real estate holdings, various properties in Aspen, Colo, and their Houston apartment (M)

headline: Senate Finance Panel Wants Tax Information From Enron
abstract: Senate Finance Committee asks Enron Corp to disclose its corporate income tax returns; Sens Max Baucus and Charles E Grassley, in letter to Enron's chief financial officer, says it is critical that public and Congress have more informed understanding of activities and transactions related to Enron's tax returns and pension programs (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Burundi: Another Step In Peace Effort
abstract: New senate, equally divided between Hutus and Tutsis, is formally installed as part of Burundi's continuing effort to end ethnic strife (S)

headline: For Fatah, Only a War Can Bring Peace to Mideast
abstract: Marwan Barghouti, West Bank leader of Yasir Arafat's Fatah faction, says attacks on Israelis in Palestinian territory must continue, because violence strengthens Fatah, and is essential to bring Israelis to bargaining table and keep them there; favors attacking Israeli soldiers and settlers in West Bank and Gaza Strip; he opposes suicide bombings and other attacks within pre-1967 Israel, and he recognizes Israel's right to exist; he has been Palestinian legislator and supporter of peace, but says Israel's expanded settlements and broken promises make it harder to support peace talks; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Norway Indicts Teenage Programmer
abstract: Jon Johansen, Norwegian teenager who helped create program that can break technological safeguards on DVD's, is indicted on charges originally intended to protect telephone and bank records; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Newspaper Acquisition
abstract: Johnston Press agrees to buy Regional Independent Media Holdings for 560 million pounds ($793 million), bringing together fourth- and fifth-largest regional newspaper publishers in Britain respectively; Johnston Press says operating profit in 2001 was 90.7 million pounds compared with 83.9 million pounds year earlier; revenue rose 2.9 percent, to 300.6 million pounds (S)

headline: U.N. Officials Press White House To Free Family-Planning Money
abstract: United Nations Population Fund head Thoraya Obaid meets with Bush administration aide Elliott Abrams to urge release of $34 million for international family planning suspended because of objections from conservatives about China's abortion policies; later meets with State Department officials to press case; fund denies stand by Rep Christopher Smith and anti-abortion groups that fund condones forced abortions and involuntary sterlizations in China; Rep Nita M Lowey and several other legislators score funding hold up, charging Bush seeks to appease conservative Republicans (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Intuit Posts Sharp Profit Gain
abstract: Intuit Inc says net income was $119.9 million in its fiscal second quarter ended Jan 31, compared with $26.6 million year earlier; sales rose 20 percent, to $547.2 million from $457.6 million (S)

headline: Pakistani Group Offers Bleak View of Pakistan's Rights Record
abstract: Pakistani human rights organization issues report painting bleak picture of respect for human dignity there, particularly for women and children; says women have 'almost no rights' and are bound to follow wishes of male family members, that nearly half country's children are malnourished, that physical and sexual abuse of children is 'rampant' and that young boys are smuggled to Middle East to serve as jockeys in camel races; report expands conventional definition of human rights, looking at social and economic conditions, including health and education; State Dept's annual human rights report had similarly critical assessment of Pakistan, although it took note of fact that Pakistani press is able to publish 'relatively freely' (M)

headline: MORE NATIONS JOIN AFGHAN AID EFFORT
abstract: International donors meeting in Tokyo pledge more than $4.5 billion over five years for rebuilding of Afghanistan, coming close to goals set by World Bank and UN; major Western donors and Japan pledge $1.3 billion, Iran $560 million and India and Pakistan $100 million each; Saudi Arabia pledges $220 million, Kuwait $30 million and South Korea $45 million; list; Afghan Foreign Ministry spokesman Omar Samad expresses gratitude, and concern over whether promises will be kept; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: UBS Warburg Is in Talks To Buy an Investment Bank  Broadview International, an investment bank that specializes in technology company mergers, is in serious discussions to sell itself to UBS Warburg, several Wall Street executives said. Warburg, the investment banking arm of the Swiss bank UBS, could announce a deal to buy Broadview as soon as this week.    Exact terms of the transaction could not be determined. People close to the firms said the price could be as low as $100 million, a fraction of what Broadview could have sold for just two years ago, an example of how far the technology sector has fallen. [Page C2.]

headline: Accent on Tension: Afghan School Shelled
abstract: Mortar attack on boys' school 40 miles from Kabul kills one child and wounds 30, heightening concerns that local power struggles could plunge Afghanistan again into violent strife; school is located on strategic highway between Kabul and Jalalabad; area has been troubled by tensions between contending warlords in 15 weeks since Taliban power began to disintegreate, although officials say it is not clear whether school had been hit by mistake (M)

headline: The Last Word in Dictation. Period.
abstract: Copytalk software from Norman Worthington gives user taste of having personal assistant; dictated messages are transcribed by real people to e-mail, and appointments or reminders are added to PDA's, all as per user's telephonic instructions; cost for service is determined by amount of use, for example, $10 per months buys 20 Palm entries or e-mail messages; system has high rate of accuracy; drawing (M)

headline: Private Sector; Marketing the Power of Plaid
abstract: Ian M Russell, chief exec of Scottish Power, will lead 10,000 bagpipers who are expected to march in St Andrew's Day Parade in New York City to celebrate National Tartan Day, marking signing, in 1320, of Scottish Declaration of Independence; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Energy Acquisition Considered
abstract: Australia's Woodside Petroleum wants to buy oil and gas exploration and production assets of Germany's Veba Oil and Gas; details undisclosed, but media reports in Australia suggest assets could be worth $2 billion (S)

headline: Initial Jobless Claims Fall, Spurring Optimism
abstract: Labor Department reports number of workers filing new claims for jobless benefits dropped last week to level that suggests worst of recession might be over; state unemployment offices received 395,000 first-time applications, down 56,000 from previous week; number of people drawing benefits fell to three-month low of 3.53 million in final week of 2001; department reports three-month decline in oil costs drove down import price index for December and contributed to record decrease in 2001 from 2000; prices fell 0.9 percent and 8.9 percent from period year earlier; graph on jobless claims (M)

headline: Ex-Operative Writes of Decline at C.I.A.
abstract: Robert Baer, veteran Central Intelligence Agency field operative, writes book, See No Evil, in which he charges that before Sept 11 CIA had largely been out of spy business for years, not hiring new agents and avoiding delicate inquiries for fear of embarrassing itself, other nations or White House; says only way to defeat terrorism is for CIA to resume learning secrets; CIA censors have blacked out many names and titles, but Baer's book spells out in great detail operations he ran in many countries during his 21-year career; he retired in 1997; photo(M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   8.50       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   5.00       Federal funds   1.69   1.74   5.44       3-month T-bills   1.66   1.68   4.91       6-month T-bills   1.75   1.77   4.72       10-yr. T-infl.   3.35   3.36   3.42       10-yr. T-note   4.87   4.92   5.02       30-yr. T-bond   5.37   5.41   5.38       Telephone bd.   7.50   7.52   7.71       Municipal bds.   5.28   5.29   5.32          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: D'Arcy Selected for Heineken Duties
abstract: D'Arcy Selected For Heineken Duties.

headline: A Suit Says WorldCom Deals Obscured Millions in Bad Debt
abstract: Suit brought by bankrupt Communications Telesystems International accuses WorldCom of using concealed transactions and sham contracts to avoid reporting uncollectible debt of $165 million; WorldCom says suit has no merit; suit grows out of WorldCom's relations with Cherry Communications and World Access, small long-distance companies that went bankrupt after extensive dealings with WorldCom and each other; San Francisco judge rules that accusations are detailed enough for case to proceed; two sides are disputing whether WorldCom's chief executive Bernard J Ebbers and chief financial officer Scott D Sullivan must submit to pretrial questions and cross-examination; suit, filed last June, says Cherry Communications and World Access were pawns in intricate and deceptive plan that began in 1997 as effort by WorldCom to avoid writing off as uncollectible $165 million debt that Cherry owed WorldCom; suit contends WorldCom helped engineer bankruptcy filing by Cherry and arranged for Cherry's subsequent merger into World Access in 1998; suit says WorldCom then took part in transactions that misleadingly inflated value of World Access; contends goal was to help World Access use its high-priced stock to buy numerous small companies that had sprung to offer phone services in Europe as telecommunications there were being deregulated; plaintiffs are Roger B Abbott and other former shareholders of Communications Telesystems International, which operated under name WorldxChange; Communications Telesystems was acquired in April 2000 by World Access in stock swap; year later, World Access filed for bankruptcy protection, and stock that Abbott and others received in deal became worthless (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Phone Law Could Snare Police
abstract: Irish police will not enforce new law barring drivers from using hand-held mobile phones because law appears to apply to emergency workers (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Court Upholds Napster Ruling
abstract: US Appeals Court, upholding lower court decision, rules that Napster cannot resume its free online music sharing service until it can be certain that service will not be used to swap copyrighted songs owned by major record labels; ruling has little effect because Napster has not tried to resume service, which it took offline in July, after it was found guilty of aiding in copyright infringement (S)

headline: INVESTING WITH/W. Whitney George; Royce Low-Priced Stock Fund
abstract: Royce Low-Price Stock

headline: Letter to Kmart Starts an Accounting Inquiry
abstract: The Kmart Corporation said yesterday that it had hired outside accountants to investigate charges made in an anonymous letter ''expressing concern regarding unspecified accounting matters.''    Kmart, the third-largest retail chain, which filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday, said that it had informed the Securities and Exchange Commission about the letter and that the commission had ''subsequently authorized a private investigation.'' The commission declined to comment.

headline: Philips and Nike In Joint Venture
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics and Nike Inc sign agreement to develop audio sports products; financial details undisclosed (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe Introducing Image Campaign
abstract: TeÃ˜

headline: Office Promoting U.S.
abstract: In a plan approved by President Bush, a temporary wartime effort to shape information and coordinate messages will be expanded into a permanent office of global diplomacy, intended to spread a positive image of the United States.       Article, Page A11.

headline: U.S. Goal Seems Clear, And the Team Complete
abstract: News analysis of indications that, after weeks of internal debate, Bush administration has now set toppling of Saddam Hussein in Iraq as next major goal in war against terrorism, and is putting into place diplomatic and military means; Pres Bush appears to have grown more certain even as allies grow nervous, Sec Colin Powell, considered voice of caution, is signaling that there is now no daylight between himself and his more hawkish boss (M)

headline: Leon Mandel, 73, Former Publisher of AutoWeek, Dies
abstract: Leon Mandel III, influential figure in auto industry as editor and publisher of AutoWeek magazine, dies at age of 73; photo (M)

headline: Patients Surge And Hospitals Hunt for Beds
abstract: Many hospitals struggle to cope with surprising increases in number of patients, after years in which they closed beds and laid off workers; since 1985, number of hospitals has declined about 14 percent and number of beds declined 18 percent; at current levels, hospitals have almost no ability to handle unexpected increase in patients; some hospitals are being forced to turn away ambulances; at others, emergency room patients who are admitted wait hours or even days for rooms; reasons cited for increased demand for hospital rooms are: insurers have loosened their controls and now allow more patients to be treated in emergency rooms or overnight; many people have lost their jobs and their health insurance and now rely on emergency rooms as health care providers; aging baby boomers are more likely to experience serious illness or injury; experts are divided as to whether increase in patient visits is lasting change; photo; graphs (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Argentina Is Preparing For Currency Devaluation  With a substantial devaluation of their currency now certain, Argentines braced for the worst as President Eduardo Duhalde and his newly appointed cabinet discussed ways to cushion the blow and avoid a repetition of the riots and protests that toppled his predecessor.    Economists and political leaders predict that the government will lower the exchange rate of the peso, which has been valued at one to one with the dollar for the last decade, by 30 percent to 40 percent. A formal announcement is expected as early as today. [Page A4.]    Newmont Raises Bid for Normandy  Newmont Mining of Denver sweetened its bid for Normandy Mining of Australia to $2.2 billion and appeared set to win the contest for the company after AngloGold of South Africa bowed out. [World Business, Section W.]

headline: Judging Bush's $1.35 Trillion Bet
abstract: Pres Bush's $1.35 trillion tax cut of 2001 is focus of debate between Republicans, who argue that it was prudent measure that will enhance economy's long-term growth, while holding down size of government and giving nation much-needed dose of recession-fighting medicine, and Democrats, who say it was irresponsible giveaway to the wealth that squandered budget surplus, ruined any hance of addressing big social problems of day and endangered economy by putting upward pressure on long-term interest rates; tax experts say Americans should assume for now that current tax law will not change this year in any substantial way; drawing (M)

headline: 4 Audit Firms Are Set to Alter Some Practices
abstract: Four of five biggest accounting firms say they will reject industry practices that prompted extensive criticism of Arthur Andersen, which audited financial statements of and provided consulting services to Enron Corp; PricewaterhouseCoopers and Andersen say they will no longer provide certain consulting services to clients whose books they audit and will stop providing internal and external audit functions at same company; Ernst & Young and KPMG, which shed their consulting businesses, say they support measures intended to avoid perceived conflicts of interests; remaining big firm, Deloitte & Touche, has repeatedly stated its intention to keep consulting and audit services under one roof; scramble by most big firms to bolster their image shows how worried accountants are about prospect of new regulations or legislation that would call for tougher measures than they have proposed; photo of Arthur Levitt, who championed idea of separating consulting from auditing when he was chairman of Securities and Exchange Commission (M)

headline: Tracking Work Hours By Touch, Not a Punch
abstract: New punchless time clocks recognize employee's fingerprint when finger is placed on pad; are among latest applications for biometrics, measurement and use of single human characteristic to identify someone; photos (M)

headline: Troubles at Enron and in Argentina Hurt J. P. Morgan
abstract: J P Morgan Chase & Co reports loss of $332 million in last quarter of 2001, compared to profit of $708 million in fourth quarter of 2000; earned $247 million compared with $763 million year ago, excluding restructuring and merger costs; earnings for company's first full year since merger of J P Morgan and Chase Manhattan were $1.69 billion, compared with $5.73 billion in 2000; operating income was $3.41 billion, compared with $5.93 billion in 2000; bank says it wrote off $456 million of Enron Corp trading losses and loans in quarter; says bank has reduced its Argentine exposure 'considerably' from early last year, by almost $1 billion; wrote off $351 million for its exposure to Argentina in quarter; photo (M)

headline: Supplies vanish as well as dealers with the competence to track them down : Is the objet d'art culture dying out?
abstract: LONDONâ€”  Slowly, a major chapter of Western culture is coming to a close. Those who think of art as painting and sculpture and have never been involved in collecting, may react with skepticism on hearing that objects, to use a simple word, played a central part in the traditional Western approach, European and North American, to artas they did, too, in the East, but that is another story.

headline: They're Ready for Me
abstract: Sandra Baldwin's The Boss column on being president of US Olympic Committee; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Group Pushes For Broadband Policy
abstract: TechNet, Silicon Valley lobbying group, issues report urging Bush administration and Congress to create national policy for bringing high-speed Internet access to 100 million homes and businesses by end of decade (S)

headline: Israel Promises a Pullback As Death Toll Keeps Rising
abstract: Israeli tanks and armored personnel carriers roar through main streets of Ramallah hours after Prime Min Ariel Sharon orders gradual withdrawal of troops from city; Sharon's office says withdrawal will be phased over time, and even when complete there will be troops and tanks ringing city; elsewhere, Israelis and Palestinians inflict casualties on each other in steady violence and death that have become norm (M)

headline: New West Bank Violence Chills Dispirited Settlers
abstract: Violence by Palestinian militants in Jordan Valley prompts some Israeli settlers to move back across boundary between West Bank and Israel; Jordan Valley settlements are far smaller and less self-sufficient than those on West Bank and Gaza Strip with thousands of residents; photos (M)

headline: Interactive TV Deal Unites Moxi Digital With Digeo
abstract: Moxi Digital says it is being acquired by Digeo, interactive television company founded by Paul Allen, co-founder of Microsoft Corp; two companies decline to give financial details about merger; Allen's investment company, Vulcan Ventures, will hold majority of stock in merged company and existing investors will continue to be shareholders (M)

headline: Snow and wind hamper allied offensive in Afghan mountains
abstract: WASHINGTON:â€”  U.S. warplanes resumed heavy bombing attacks Thursday in the eastern Afghan mountains, inflicting heavy casualties on Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters, but snow, bitter winds and plunging temperatures made air and ground operations increasingly difficult, according to reports from the area.

headline: Kabul Rushes 1,000 More Men To Join G.I.'s in Battle's 6th Day
abstract: Afghan government sends 1,000 reinforcements to American led effort against well-fortified positions of tenacious Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters in frigid peaks near eastern border; fierce battle is in 6th day; new deployment from Kabul comes on top of additional American commitment of 300 troops; extra manpower and intensified bombing appear urgently needed to meet dogged, even fanatical resistance; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld predicts victory by end of week; strength of Al Qaeda force is matter of fluid estimation, with numbers ranging from several hundred to few thousand; photo; map (M)

headline: Sharp Rise in Federal Spending May Have Helped Ease Recession
abstract: Unexpected surge in government spending--along with remarkable strength in consumer spending--helps to explain why recession in US has been been so mild and may be ending; surge in government spending, which started in October, has continued into March at rate of more than $100 billion; income tax cuts that went into effect at beginning of this year are expected to provide further lift to economy; photo; chart (L)

headline: Technology Briefing | Europe: Britain: Strong Year-End Spending
abstract: Sainsbury, Britain's second-largest supermarket chain, says sales increased 6.4 percent in 12 weeks ended Jan 5; GUS, Europe's biggest catalog-shopping company and owner of Argos chain of stores, says sales rose 17 percent in 14 weeks ended Jan 5 (S)

headline: Net Surges 69% at Fannie Mae On Record Mortgage Activity
abstract: Fannie Mae says fourth-quarter net income rose 69 percent, to $1.97 billion (M)

headline: Did Enron's Auditors Think They Had Something to Hide?
abstract: Floyd Norris column on report that Enron Corp's auditors, Arthur Andersen, began destroying Enron documents and purging computer files in September and continued to do so while Enron collapsed and perhaps even after SEC issued Andersen a subpoena; notes that many of Enron's financial officials, including Richard A Causey, chief accounting officer, came to Enron after working on Enron audits for Andersen; suggests that some deleted files could indicate that Enron's accounting had become controversial within Andersen and had started an internal fight (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: RULING FAVORS GENERIC ANTIDEPRESSANT FROM ANDRX
abstract: Andrx Group says judge ruled that its generic version of GlaxoSmithKline's Wellbutrin antidepressant does not infringe Glaxo patent, which may clear way for Andrx to sell copy of blockbuster drug (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Existing-Home Sales -- Feb.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Ciena Posts Loss As Sales Fall
abstract: Ciena said yesterday that it had lost $70.6 million, or 22 cents a share, during the three months ended Jan. 31, as revenue tumbled 54 percent, to $162 million from $352 million a year earlier. Ciena, one of the last telecommunications equipment suppliers to be hit by the carriers' sharp slowdown in capital spending last year, also warned that sales in the current quarter would be about $100 million, well below recent projections. Ciena's shares fell $1.60 in heavy trading yesterday, to $7.60, down more than 90 percent from their 52-week high of $84.25 a year ago.   Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

headline: SHREDDED PAPERS KEY IN ENRON CASE
abstract: Enron case presents enormous challenges to government investigators and could take years of digging to unravel, despite eye-popping revelations; legal experts say best thing to have happened for criminal investigators is shredding of documents by company employees and auditor Arthur Andersen & Co since no one knows for sure whether actions that led to company's collapse constituted financial crimes and, if they did, which should be focus of investigation; say document shredding gives investigators comparatively simple cases of possible obstruction of justice and that focus in earliest days will be on pursuing possible criminal cases from those events (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; LVMH Luxury Conglomerate Sells Its Art Auction House
abstract: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton chairman Bernard Arnault sells his company's majority stake in auction house Phillips, de Pury & Luxembourg to partners Simon de Pury and Daniella Luxembourg, former Sotheby's officials who run art dealership based in Geneva and are chairman and president, respectively, of Phillips; LVMH will keep about quarter of Phillips; financial terms undisclosed; graph; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Mideast Balance Sheet
abstract: News analysis of escalating Israeli-Palestinian violence of past 17 months; steadily narrowing ratio of fatalities, to one Israeli for every three Palestinians from one for every 25 during Palestinian uprising almost 15 years ago, has demoralized Israelis and eroded faith in Prime Min Ariel Sharon; Israeli Army and police are struggling to combat essential Palestinian weapons of speed, surprise and suicide; Palestinian militants are better armed, better trained and more ruthless; graph (M)

headline: A Grocery Chain Stays in the Family
abstract: Weis Markets, which includes 163 food stores and 33 pet-supply stores, pay $434 million for stock owned by Janet Weis and her family, resolving longstanding family debate; photos (S)

headline: HEAD OF RETAIL INVESTING AT CHARLES SCHWAB RESIGNS
abstract: Head of Retail Investing At Charles Schwab Resign

headline: For Chief, $200 Million Wasn't Quite Enough Cash
abstract: Enron Corp chairman Kenneth L Lay's personal lawyer Earl Silbert says Lay was forced to borrow millions from company last year to meet his obligations despite receiving more than $200 million either from Enron directly or through exercising stock options over three years starting in 1999; disclosure is aimed at countering impression that Lay might have disposed of Enron stock in late August because he feared collapse of company; new information could leave impression that his personal investments produced large losses that he was unable to support despite his large income from Enron; Lay appears to have parlayed his paper gains in Enron to buy other securities that also declined in value, including Compaq Computer, i2 Technologies and NewPower Holdings; graph; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Burundi: More Hutu-Tutsi Violence
abstract: Hutu rebels in Burundi step up road ambushes following army crackdown on their stronghold (S)

headline: Bush Officials End Support Of Sharon's Tough Stance
abstract: Bush administration decides to terminate its unequivocal support for Prime Min Ariel Sharon's hard-line strategy and declares that his approach will likely fail; administration officials are alarmed by Sharon's recent comment that Palestinians must be 'hit hard' because they will only negotiate after they are beaten; officials decide to respond strongly to Sharon, lest he interpret Washington's silence as implicit permission to intensify conflict or declare all-out war; Secretary of State Colin Powell's comments to House subcommittee asking Israel to take 'hard look' at its policies are sharpest criticism to date of Sharon's tough policy; Sharon quickly responds that he, like Pres Bush, is simply fighting terrorism (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Lawmaker Quits In Corruption Scandal
abstract: Japanese opposition lawmaker Kiyomi Tsujimoto resigns after accusations that she misused government funds intended for aide's salary; photo; she has led corruption charges against governing party (S)

headline: I.S.P.'s Demise Brings A Bumpy Switchover
abstract: Ivan Berger article on problems he experienced making transition to Comcast's own high-speed Internet service after bankruptcy court allowed ExciteAtHome to cancel its contract with cable companies; drawing (M)

headline: Before Going, Van Susteren Told CNN of Hurt Feelings
abstract: Hurt feelings appear to have played significant role in Greta Van Susteren's decision to leave CNN for Fox News Channel even after CNN offered her more money to stay; letter from her husband and lawyer, John Coale, to CNN's chairman, Walter Isaacson, complained that Van Susteren felt neglected when CNN was showering attention on network's new star anchors, Paula Zahn and Aaron Brown; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: U.N. Campaign Begins
abstract: Swiss government begins campaign to persuade citizens to join United Nations; nationwide vote is set for Mar (S)

headline: Barnes & Noble Reports Profit
abstract: Barnes & Noble says net income in fourth quarter was $84 million in contrast to loss of $34 million year earlier; sales increased 13 percent, to $1.82 billion (S)

headline: Victor Posner, 83, Master of Hostile Takeover
abstract: Victor Posner, corporate raider whose exploits over three decades earned him place in rogue's gallery of American business, dies at age 83; photo (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: The Aegis Group, London, acquired Market and More, a European market research company with operations in Belgium, France, Germany and the Netherlands.

headline: CARMAX EXPECTS TO BEAT FORECASTS IN FOURTH QUARTER
abstract: CarMax Auto Superstores unit of Circuit City Stores Inc expects fiscal fourth-quarter earnings to beat forecasts because company is selling more used cars than estimated; quarter ends Feb 28 (S)

headline: Saudi Affirms Ties to U.S.; Castigates bin Laden as 'Deviant'
abstract: Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia today embraced the United States as a close friend, but criticized American policy in the Middle East.

headline: SPANISH HOTEL CHAIN AGREES TO BUY CRESTLINE CAPITAL
abstract: Spain's Barcelo Hotels and Resorts acquires Crestline Capital Corp for $601.8 million to expand its operations in US (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Chancellor Weathers Storm
abstract: Austria's far-right Freedom Party withdraws its call for early elections, easing coalition crisis in government of Chancellor Wolfgang Schussel; photo (S)

headline: Judge Orders An Extra Day For Balloting In Zimbabwe
abstract: Zimbabwe High Court judge orders government to extend voting in presidential election to accommodate thousands of people unable to cast ballots before polls closed; government says voting will be extended only in Harare and Chitungwiza settlement, two places cited by opposition in its plea to court for extension; will appeal ruling (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Churches Bombed
abstract: Four bombs explode at churches in Palu, capital of Indonesia's Central Sulawesi Province, where Muslims and Christians are engaged in sectarian warfare; grenade explodes in shopping center in Jakarta killing one man (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Tire Maker's Profit Falls
abstract: Michelin reports 28 percent decline in net earnings for 2001, to 314 million euros ($271 million) on 2.5 percent revenue increase, to 15.7 billion euros; chief executive Edouard Michelin comments on outlook for 2002; photo (S)

headline: INVESTING WITH/Jeremy J. Hosking; Vanguard Global Equity Fund
abstract: Carole Gould profile of Jeremy J Hosking, director of Marathon Asset Management, adviser to $145 million Vanguard Global Equity fund, who believes that biggest investment bargains in world are now in Southeast Asia; photo; graph (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Unisys Loss Meets Expectations
abstract: Unisys says fourth-quarter loss was $169.4 million compared with net income of $39.1 million year earlier; chief executive Lawrence A Weinbach comments; photo (S)

headline: Death of Reporter Puts Focus On Pakistan Intelligence Unit
abstract: Inquiry into kidnapping and murder of Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl could raise lid on ties between radical Islamic groups and Pakistan's main intelligence service; Gen Pervez Musharraf has vowed to prosecute everyone involved; Pakistani military and intelligence officials disclose that Pakistani intelligence officer known as Brigadier Abdullah played key role in nurturing Army of Muhammad, militant group, after its formation in 2000, and he helped facilitate frequent travels between Afghanistan and Pakistan of Ahmed Omar Sheikh, man thought to have enticed Pearl to meeting that led to his abduction on Jan 23 and brutal execution; Abdullah was among those pushed aside late last year in Musharraf's shake-up of country's secretive spy service; Sheikh told Pakistani court that he helped kidnap Pearl, but his statements raise as many questions as they answer; new disclosures of links between Sheikh and two recently dismissed spy agency officials only intensify suspicions about its role in Pearl case; photos (L)

headline: F.D.A. Wants Drug Retrial, Dealing Blow To Corixa
abstract: Corixa Corp says Bexxar, its drug for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, will not win approval anytime soon; company says it has been told by Food and Drug Administration that it has not adequately demonstrated safety and clinical benefit of drug and that new clinical trials will be required (M)

headline: The Rise And Fall Of Global Dreams
abstract: Gary Winnick faces variety of woes in wake of collapse of Global Crossing, which he founded; detractors note large chunk of $734 million he realized from Global Crossing stock came from share sales after company's troubles became clear; excess and controversy have periodically played roles in his career; photo (M)

headline: No Strangers to Sweat
abstract: Survey commissioned by Oppenheimer Funds finds

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Renault To Raise Stake In Nissan
abstract: Renault will bolster its stake in Nissan Motor Co to 44.4 percent, from 36.8 percent, one year earlier than it planned under agreement reached in 1999 (S)

headline: Pinched Pennies and the Stranded User
abstract: This business of trying to hide from your own customers is only the latest in a disturbing software-company trend: eliminating help services in the name of saving a couple of bucks.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer's Sales Rise
abstract: Mark & Spencer says same-store sale rose 8.3 percent over holidays; cautions that growth rate will fall; photo (S)

headline: The Brick Stood Up Before. But Now?
abstract: Growth and safety of asset-backed securities discussed in light of Enron collapse; holders of Enron's asset-backed commerical paper collected all $58 million owed them at time when Enron's stock and bonds plummeted; tools of so-called structured finance used to create such securities are attracting new scrutiny because they were abused by Enron to build elaborately camouflaged and booby-trapped partnerships blamed for company's collapse; diagrams; drawing (M)

headline: Private Sector; Managing Stars and an Ex-Mayor
abstract: Profile of Brad Grey, chairman of Brillstein-Grey Entertainment, Hollywood talent management and production company, whose latest client is former Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani of New York; photo (M)

headline: Waiting Out the Siege, Arafat Remains Defiant
abstract: Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat is waiting out siege in Ramallah on West Bank, where he has been confined by Israeli forces for past two months since wave of suicide bombings in Israel in early December; chafes at his house arrest and maneuverings of old rival Prime Min Ariel Sharon; seethes at American antagonism, which he considers deeply unjust; Pres Bush has ignored his recent pleas for American intervention and assailed his credibility and his commitment to peace; photo (M)

headline: Dave Thomas, 69, Wendy's Founder, Dies
abstract: Dave Thomas, founder of restaurant chain Wendy's International, dies at age 69; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Interest Rate Increase
abstract: Bank of Israel raises its monthly benchmark interest rate from 3.8 percent to 4.4 percent, first raise in more than three years in bid to stem inflation; decision will increase borrowing costs during Israel's worst economic slump in 50 years (S)

headline: Tiny Technologies Slip Unseen Into Daily Life
abstract: Nanotechnology is turning up in host of everyday life, including khakis, sunscreen, 'self-cleaning' glass and telecommunications gear; sales of nanocomponents are only around $30 million a year, but sales of producing using microscoptic materials generated sales of $26.5 billion in 2001; nanomaterials in current products can have wide variations, not the uniform features and numbingly precise layouts that will be needed for future nanoproducts, like sugar-cube-size devices capable of storing as much data as Library of Congress; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Study Finds Less Data Collection
abstract: Survey conducted for Federal Trade Commission by Progress and Freedom Foundation shows Web sites seem to be collecting less personal data on consumers and are giving slightly more information about how that data is used; report concludes at least some of reduction in data collection can be linked to dot-com downturn and growing sense that data collection is not as lucrative a business as many companies had hoped (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Filipino Rebel Deported
abstract: Nur Misuari, a prominent Muslim separatist leader in the southern Philippines, was deported to Manila from his refuge in Malaysia. Mr. Misuari became a governor after signing a peace agreement in 1996, then turned against the government in November when it appeared that he would lose an election. His supporters staged an uprising and Mr. Misuari fled.   Seth Mydans (NYT)

headline: Michael Young, 86, Scholar; Coined, Mocked 'Meritocracy'
abstract: Michael Young, sociologist and reformer who was chief architect of Britain's postwar welfare state, dies at age 86; photo (M)

headline: Sony Appoints Universal McCann
abstract: Sony Appoints Universal McCann The Sony Corporation of America, part of Sony of Japan, said yesterday that it had selected Universal McCann in New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group, to handle its consolidated media planning and buying account.

headline: Indian Patriotism Gets a Bollywood Makeover
abstract: Bombay's film industry, called Bollywood, taps into India's current high-octane nationalism with series of movies about swaggering, self-assured heroes who beat back terrorist 'baddies' and their Pakistani henchmen; diplomatic niceties of past have been scrapped, and Pakistan is now identified as malevolent power; Indian films, though officially banned in Pakistan, are hugely popular there; latest Bollywood movies, even most patriotic numbers, are ferried over to Pakistan to eager customers; shopkeepers there report that some movies are being returned by angry customers; Pakistani psychologist observes that Pakistan's culture is not nearly as obsessed with enemy nation as India's seems to be now; photo (M)
