headline: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: New Prime Minister
abstract: Haitian Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide selects Senator Yvon Neptune as prime minister to replace Jean-Marie Cherestal, who resigned amid complaints of corruption; photo (S)

headline: Defying a Taboo, Nazi Protagonists Invade Video Games
abstract: Video games like Return to Castle Wolfenstein and Day of Defeat break taboo on Nazi protagonists; swastikas and Nazi symbols are so pervasive in Day of Defeat that game might be viewed as illegal in Germany; game attracts many players with enthusiasm for neo-Nazi role playing, but programmers insist they are not interested in providing outlet for neo-Nazi sentiment (M)

headline: Conseco Unit Chief Quits
abstract: Conseco Inc says Thomas Kilian, executive in charge of its life insurance and annuity businesses, is leaving company as it consolidates to save money (S)

headline: With Losing Week, This Year's Gains Are Largely Gone
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 10.95 points, to 1,145.60; Nasdaq composite index falls 24.78 points, to 2,022.46; Dow Jones industrial average falls 80.33 points, to 9,987.53; 10-year Treasury note rises 26/32, to price of 101 1/32; note's yield falls to 4.86 percent from 4.97 percent; price of 30-year Treasury bond rises 22/32, to 100 3/32; bond's yield falls to 5.37 percent from 5.41 percent; graph; table of key rates (M)

headline: OUTLOOK: Markets & Investing; Oversupply and Slackened Demand Vex Commodity Markets
abstract: Commodity prices for most part moved lower for better part of 2001 because supplies were high, demand contracted and US dollar was strong; outlook for 2002 is not much different, even if global economy begins to recover; photo (M)

headline: In Shattered Kabul, Powell Vows Long-Term Support for Afghans
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell, in quick visit to Kabul, says United States has restored its crumbling, long-shuttered embassy to full diplomatic status, and he assures Afghanistan's interim leader Hamid Karzai of America's long-term support; Powell catches grim glimpses during 6-hour visit of shattered land, where 270,000 Afghan civil servants are without pay, and armed men still roam main roads; Karzai is struggling to impose order in face of rival warlords and skepticism about his six-month interim administration; he gently reminds Powell that many Afghans wonder whether Washington will abandon country again once hunt for Taliban and Al Qaeda leadership is over; Powell says US will make 'significant contribution' to estimated $15 billion cost over 10 years of rebuilding Afghan infrastructure and institutions, but adds that Bush administration expects other nations to contribute bulk of reconstruction costs and troops needed for peacekeeping operations; photos (L)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Accord On Fishing-Boat Payments
abstract: United States Navy agrees to pay $10 million to local government of Uwajima for sinking of Ehime Maru, fishing school training boat, by American nuclear submarine Greeneville in Feb 2001; separate compensation talks continue between Navy and families of victims (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Government Must Offer AIDS Drug
abstract: South African judge affirms government most distribute AIDS drug nevirapine at public hospitals while it appeals ruling that it make drug available; drug cuts risk of transmission of HIV from pregnant mothers to their unborn babies (S)

headline: Private Sector; Tearing Down Corporate Walls
abstract: Detroit Mayor Kwame M Kilpatrick giÃ¸

headline: On Both Sides in the Mideast, Fear and Stress Are Building
abstract: Fear and stress on both sides in Mideast is being felt even by household pets; Jerusalem veterinarian has taken to prescribing Valium for pet dogs so nervous from days and nights pierced by gunfire, explosions and sirens that they shake and will not eat; psychic shakiness of some pets is sign of how fear, and coping with it, has become stitched into daily life; in Ramallah, families sleep in basements, order their children not to go outside, and stretch out groceries to last until crossfire dies away; people on both sides are sick of living in fear, and that is chief resource for Anthony C Zinni, Bush administration envoy who arrived in hopes of arranging cease-fire; but along with fear has come anger, and that is Zinni's foremost obstacle; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: AIDS Fund Falls Short of Goal And U.S. Is Given Some Blame
abstract: Donations to UN's global AIDS fund have fallen far short of $7 billion sought by Sec Gen Kofi Annan nine months ago; advocates blame White House, saying $200-million pledge set bad example; Sen Richard Durbin wants Congress to authorize $1.2 billion a year (S)

headline: Facing Down Diehards
abstract: Military analysis; Al Qaeda fighters in rugged mountain redoubt near Gardez, Afghanistan, have demonstrated after five months of war that they are resilient and deadly foe, bloodying US Afghan allies and forcing Afghan column to retreat; have turned aside calls to surrender, and have extracted heaviest American combat toll thus far, of at least eight dead and 40 wounded in three days of fighting; even though Al Qaeda fighters will eventually be defeated by qualitatively and numerically superior American force, American victory will not come easily and battle will not mark end of war; fighters have put up stiff resistance because so many in ranks are foreigners, namely, Arab, Uzbek and Chechen militants; photo (M)

headline: Lorillard Tobacco to Sue Over 'Vilification' in Ads
abstract: Lorillard Tobacco Co plans to sue American Legacy Foundation, nation's biggest anti-smoking group, for breaching 1998 settlement that governs industry; suit accuses group of 'engaging in a campaign of vilification against tobacco companies'; Lorillard contedns that foundation's advertisements have violated agreement's restrictions against direct attacks on tobacco companies; foundation, expecting suit, filed suit last week in effort to derail Lorillard's legal strategy (M)

headline: BANKS GIVE CONSECO MORE TIME TO MAKE DEBT PAYMENT
abstract: Banks led by J P Morgan Chase and Bank of America give Conseco more time to repay $1.5 billion of debt in exchange for higher interest rate (S)

headline: Arms Cache Uncovered In U.S. Raid On 2 Camps
abstract: Rear Adm John D Stufflebeem reports raid on two Taliban leadership compounds north of Kandahar by American special operations forces uncovered large ammunition depot unknown to coalition intelligence; reports up to 15 Taliban soldiers were killed and 27 others captured (M)

headline: Lawmakers Look at Wall Street's Role
abstract: Rep Bill Tauzin says Enron promised bond underwriting business to Merrill Lynch and Wachovia in return for investments in some of its partnerships (S)

headline: A Nation Challenged: The Drug Makers; A New Batch of Old Smallpox Vaccine
abstract: a new batch of old smallpox vaccine*

headline: PRESIDENT TO RETIRE FROM UNITED TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: Karl J Krapek will retire as president and chief operating officer of United Technologies Corp (S)

headline: Founder of Barnes & Noble to Step Down as Chief Executive
abstract: Leonard Riggio, founder, chairman and chief executive of the Barnes & Noble, is stepping down as chief executive and naming his brother, Stephen Riggio, to succeed him.

headline: Dublin Court Convicts Man in Ulster Blast That Killed 29
abstract: An antiterrorism court here today convicted the only person to be tried so far with the bombing of Omagh, Northern Ireland, in 1998, despite allegations of police impropriety and a bungled investigation.    The man, Colm Murphy, a 49-year-old building contractor, was found guilty of assisting the conspirators behind the attack, which killed 29 people and was the worst act of violence in Northern Ireland's 30-year sectarian conflict.

headline: Briefly Noted
abstract: ANTHRAX EXPOSURE? A building at the Army Reserve Command headquarters in Fort McPherson on the south side of Atlanta was evacuated yesterday after a powder on a mailed package tested positive for anthrax, Army officials said. Six people in the mailroom were decontaminated after they were exposed to the package, a spokesman said. It was taken to the Centers for Disease Control for further tests. Â Â  David Firestone (NYT) CRASH VICTIMS The bodies of three American servicemen killed in a helicopter crash off the Philippine coast arrived at Kadena Air Base in Okinawa, Japan, as rescue crews searched for the other seven.

headline: Broadview-Warburg Deal May Be Near
abstract: Broadview International, investment bank that specializes in technology company mergers, reportedly is in talks to sell itself to UBS Warburg (M)

headline: History Course Ignites a Volatile Tug of War in Moldova
abstract: Moldova, tiny nation of 4.3 million that left Soviet Union in 1991, is embroiled in volatile tug of war over who will get to write its history; thousands of protesters have jammed central square of capital, Chisinau, for last six weeks, protesting government requirement that college students take course called History of Moldova; some see new history course as effort by solidly Communist government to recast past in rosy pro-Soviet light and ignore its Romanian roots; country is ethnically two-thirds Romanian and only one-eighth Russian; it spent most of last 200 years under Russian rule, often unhappily; photo; map (M)

headline: Plane With 7 Marines Aboard Crashes on Way to Pakistan Base
abstract: A Marine Corps refueling plane with at least seven marines aboard crashed into a mountainside today in southwest Pakistan.

headline: Rule Makers Take On Loopholes That Enron Used in Hiding Debt
abstract: Regulators, legislators and Financial Accounting Standards Board propose changes in way companies do business and report their finances, including closing loophole that Enron used to hide hundreds of millions of dollars of debt and inflate its profits; Financial Accounting Standards Board seeks to force companies to include in financial statements results of partnerships like those that Enron was able to hide for years; in separate development, Securities and Exchange Commission proposes rules that would require companies to provide quicker and more comprehensive information about their finances, insider stock sales and critical accounting decisions; if enacted, changes would overhaul some Wall Street practices in place since Depression; Federal Energy Regulatory Commission announces plans to investigate whether Enron and other companies manipulated electricity prices in California last year; photo (M)

headline: A Leg With a Mind of Its Own
abstract: Prosthetic legs can now have microprocessors, strain gauges, angle detectors, hydraulics and electronic valves that create stability and step of normal leg; most advanced is C-Leg, made by German-based company Otto Bock; Curtis Grimsley says his C-Leg got him to safety from 70th floor of World Trade Center on Sept 11, allowing him to place only one foot on each step during his descent; photos (M)

headline: In a Merger Of Networkers, Ciena Will Buy ONI Systems
abstract: Ciena Corp, maker of fiber optic network equipment, will acquire ONI Systems, in stock transaction worth $900 million; president-chief executive Gary Smith comments (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: World Briefing

headline: WILLIAMS REPORTS A LOSS OF $1.24 BILLION
abstract: Williams Companies reports fourth-quarter loss of $1.24 billion that includes charges from former communications unit that may file for bankruptcy (S)

headline: What If The Big Five Turn Into A Final Four?
abstract: Jack T Ciesielski, publisher of Analysts' Accounting Observer, research service for institutional investors, discusses how accounting profession, corporations and shareholders may be affected if Arthur Andersen should disappear from scene as result of Enron investigation and the reforms he would like to see in accounting profession and kinds of information made available to investors; photo (M)

headline: Bridgestone Settles Firestone Tire Lawsuit
abstract: Bridgestone Corp and Ford Motor Co agree to settle lawsuit related to recalled Firestone tires, avoiding what would have been Bridgestone's first trial in US involving tires (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: P.L.O. Offices To Remain Closed
abstract: Israel extends closing of Palestine Liberation Organization's East Jerusalem headquarters by six months and closes two offices linked to Palestinian Authority to assert its authority over East Jerusalem (S)

headline: The Collections / Paris : Dior's magpie magnificence
abstract: PARISâ€”  With skirts whirling, fur from Mohican boots flying and colors vibrating along with the 1980s dance music, John Galliano finally got Dior products out on the runway. His joyous show brought pep and energy to the opening day of the Paris autumn/winter 2002 shows Thursday and proved why Dior's latest figures are as hot as its designer's clothes.

headline: Pakistan Arrests Top Suspect in Abduction of U.S. Reporter
abstract: Omar Saeed Sheikh, the Islamic militant who was arrested today, told investigators that Daniel Pearl was still alive, Pakistani officials said.

headline: Personal Business; Education as an Investment. Really.
abstract: education as

headline: UAL CHANGES PLANS FOR ITS BUSINESS AVIATION UNIT
abstract: UAL Corp drops search fÃ„

headline: Offer to Take NCH Private
abstract: DALLAS, Jan. 7 (Bloomberg News) â€” The Ranger Merger Corporation offered to buy the 43 percent of the NCH Corporation it does not already own for $119.8 million, or $52.50 a share, to take NCH, a seller of specialty chemicals and plumbing parts, private.

headline: Colombian Rebels Go on Killing Rampage
abstract: Leftist FARC rebels in Colombia go on killing rampage in region where they still move freely, sweeping through in bloody operation to settle scores with unarmed villagers; photos (M)

headline: SHARON HAS PLAN FOR BUFFER ZONES TO PROTECT ISRAEL
abstract: Ariel Sharon, the Israeli prime minister, said tonight that Israel would create buffer zones to achieve ''security separation'' from the Palestinians, as he urgently appealed for national unity in the face of sharpening criticism that he lacks a plan to end 16 months of grinding conflict.     ''The state of Israel is not collapsing,'' Mr. Sharon said in an address to the nation. ''And it will not collapse.''

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Central Bank Still Downbeat
abstract: Bank of Japan leaves basic view of economy unchanged in its monthly report, saying that overall conditions continue to deteriorate; sees signs that current recession will not deepen further, although only mild recovery is expected; says exports might begin rising over next six months; leaves monetary policy unchanged (S)

headline: European Meeting Will Focus on Freer Rein for Economy
abstract: Leaders of 15 European Union nations gather in Barcelona for two-day summit that begins March 15; Spain's Prime Min Jose Maria Aznar, whose economic policies favor free markets and less regulation, identifies union's main priorities as job creation, education and training, development of single market in financial services and integration of European energy, transportation and communications networks; most attention has been paid to energy; European Parliament approved draft legislation this week that would allow crossborder energy competition by 2005; analysts say it is unlikely that national leaders will reach agreement on energy liberalization at meeting; photos (M)

headline: Some Japanese Are Hoarding Gold
abstract: Small but growing number of Japanese investors are preparing for worse economic times and hoarding gold; World Gold Council says with limits looming on bank deposit insurance, banks tottering under bad debts and government printing money in effort to create inflation, sales of gold are expected to come close to quadrupling this quarter; photo (M)

headline: Getting Some Online Help In Sorting Out Terrorists
abstract: Council on Foreign Relations launches Web site devoted to terrorism (S)

headline: 'I Don't Have a Business Card. Would a Head Shot Be O.K.?'
abstract: Polaroid's Mio camera produces instant prints the size of credit cards; photo (S)

headline: India Passes Antiterror Bill Over Protests About Rights
abstract: Indian Parliament approves broad antiterrorism bill after caustic debate during rare joint sessions called after upper house rejected bill; ruling Hindu nationalist party defends bill, which curbs some individual rights; opposition members warn law will be used against ordinary citizens and religious minorities, but not members of hard-line Hindu groups favored by ruling party (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Qualcomm Uses Internet To Aid Extended Family
abstract: Qualcomm Internet Services uses its popular Eudora Mail software program to distribute missing person ads; photo (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; In the current Internet wilderness, some consumer community sites are hanging on, and even making money.
abstract: MORE than most other big ideas of the early Internet days, so-called community Web sites sounded like a true innovation, reflecting the medium's special capabilities. The premise -- build a site where people can freely chat or post messages or home pages, then get advertisers to pitch their goods to those people -- represented one of the lead horses of Wall Street's Internet stampede.     Among the more obscure spinoffs of that trend were consumer feedback sites, which hoped to attract people who were so vehement about consumer issues that they would log on to let others know exactly how they felt about, say, the quality of Ford Explorers or customer service at Amazon. Word-of-mouth advertising would finally have a home, the thinking went, and that home was being promoted as a palace.

headline: Three-Decade-Old Echoes, Awakened by Enron
abstract: SOMETIMES it's hard to care about Enron.    The endless investigations. The faux outrage of politicians who not so long ago were gladly on the company's dole. The partnership deals, so complex that even a diligent reader cannot help feeling lost but all adding up to fake profits and hidden losses.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kyrgyzstan: Death Penalty Moratorium
abstract: Kyrgyzstan extends moratorium on death sentences and adopts human rights program under which death penalty could be abolished by 2010 (S)

headline: Goldman Sachs Moves to Tighten Stock Analysts' Independence
abstract: Moving to address concerns about the independence of stock analysts, the Goldman Sachs Group said yesterday that it would break its research department out of its investment-banking operation and place it under two newly appointed managing directors.    To drive its point home, the firm also banned all its analysts from owning stocks in sectors they cover.

headline: Pakistan Will Hold Elections in October, Military Chief Says
abstract: Gen. Pervez Musharraf confirmed today a plan to allow free elections for Pakistan's national and provincial assemblies, but said he will remain in power as president.

headline: Russian Troops Seal Off Town In Search for Chechen Rebels
abstract: Russian troops surround and seal off town of Argun in Chechnya, saying they are searching for rebel fighters and weapons in latest phase of major security sweep in region; Pres Vladimir V Putin contends rebels are linked to Islamic extremists (M)

headline: Scolding Socialists, Chirac Opens His Re-election Effort
abstract: French Pres Jacques Chirac begins his re-election campaign; defends himself against accusations of corruption and lashes out at Socialist government, accusing it of squandering benefits of France's recent economic growth; will likely face off against longtime rival, Socialist Prime Min Lionel Jospin, in rerun of 1995 presidential campaign; photo (M)

headline: Court Bars Hindus' Rite Where They Razed Mosque
abstract: India's Supreme Court rules that Hindu fundamentalists will not be allowed to perform ceremony in their campaign to build temple in Ayodhya, on site of mosque they helped tear down nine years ago; judges fear that ceremony could unsettle delicate peace in last 10 days since almost 600 people were killed in one of country's worst bouts of Hindu-Muslim violence (M)

headline: Liaoyang Journal; Where Workers, Too, Rust, Bitterness Boils Over
abstract: Liaoyang, China, onetime showcase of Communist enterprise, is now ringed by rusting remains of defunct state industries, and more than half of city's factory workers are said to have lost their jobs; has been site of angry protests, latest called to demand release of Yao Fuxin, labor leader detained on March 17; photo; map (M)

headline: EATON WILL CUT 1,100 JOBS AND FORECASTS SLUMP IN PROFIT
abstract: Eaton Corp, maker of hydraulic equipment, will eliminate 1,100 jobs; says fourth-quarter income fell 48 percent, to $30 million, as sales fell 13 percent, to $1.7 billion (S)

headline: Buyout Firm May Join Lineup Of Suitors for Global Crossing
abstract: Texas Pacific Group reportedly weighs bid for bankrupt Global Crossing Ltd (S)

headline: Opposition Leader in Zimbabwe Calls for Reconciliation
abstract: Morgan Tsvangirai, candidate for opposition party in Zimbabwe, appears at rally in Bulawayo, country's second-largest city and stronghold for opposition party; calls for national reconciliation in country that is so politically polarized that violent clashes often erupt between two competing parties; promises to create truth commission that would investigate political crimes and to ease Zimbabwe's economic crisis; man he hopes to unseat, Pres Robert Mugabe, derides Tsvangirai as front man for nation's white minority, which is helping to finance opposition campaign; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Drug Charge Flung Back At U.S.
abstract: Myanmar rejects US listing of country as major source of illegal drugs, saying real culprit is US as largest consumer (S)

headline: Optimistic Reports by G.M. and Lowe's Push Shares Up
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average climbs 177.56 points, or 1.8 percent, to 10,145.71; Nasdaq composite index rises 45.34 points, or 2.6 percent, to 1,769.88; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advances 19.59 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,109.43; graph; chart (M)

headline: Veuve Clicquot's 2nd Female Chief Takes Charge
abstract: Profile of Cecile Bonnefond, second woman to run venerable French Champagne house of Veuve Clicquot; photo (M)

headline: F.T.C. ASKS CONOCO AND PHILLIPS FOR MORE INFORMATION
abstract: Conoco Inc and Phillips Petroleum Co say Federal Trade Commission has asked for more information about their $17 billion merger; Phillips says request is routine (S)

headline: Bankruptcy Maneuver Stirs Fight In Airport Car Rental Industry
abstract: The ANC Rental Corporation, which filed for bankruptcy protection in November, has begun to combine the operations of its National and Alamo rental car brands at major airports, but not without a fight. The move has set in motion a legal battle with ANC's biggest competitors.    Hertz, a unit of Ford Motor, and Avis Rent a Car System, which is owned by Cendant, say ANC is using bankruptcy as a cover to evade airport contracts governing rental car companies. They have begun filing suit in courts across the country to block ANC, and are appealing to airport officials to stop the action.

headline: Two Airlines to Ease Frequent Flier Rules
abstract: Northwest Airlines says it will eliminate blackout dates from its frequent flier program, enabling its customers to redeem miles for travel on any day of year; American Airlines says it will lift its restrictions by Feb 1, one month before Northwest; analsyts say moves are less consumer-friendly than they appear because date restrictions are not much of issue; say bigger problem is limited number of seats on any one flight that are available for frequent flier redemptions (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Creditors Resist Asian Bid for Global Crossing
abstract: Global Crossing's creditors are strongly resisting offer by Hutchison Whampoa of Hong Kong and Singapore Technologies Telemedia to acquire bankrupt company's assets after reports of competing bid emerges from Los Angeles-based Gores Technology Group; creditors say Asian companies' bid of $750 million is unacceptable (M)

headline: Philippine Army Awaits New U.S. Gear
abstract: Philippine Army is in stateof high anticipation as US prepares to send 650 soldiers, including 150 Special Operations forces, to help in defeat Abu Sayyaf guerrillas holding American missionary couple, Martin and Gracia Burnham, on Basilan island; Americans say one of weaknesses of Philippine Army has been too much reliance on conventional war tactics, including use of artillery and infantry in dense forest in situation that requires small units of soldiersrelying on up-to-the-minute intelligence (M)

headline: A Secret Iran-Arafat Connection Is Seen Fueling the Mideast Fire
abstract: American and Israeli intelligence officials conclude that Yasir Arafat has forged new alliance with Iran that involves shipments of heavy weapons and millions of dollars to Palestinian terrorists; believe partnership was arranged in secret meeting during Arafat's visit to Moscow last May; photos; Iranian support for terrorism has otherwise been on wane in recent years except for Hezbollah in Lebanon; US officials agree with Israeli concern, adding suspicions that Iran is harboring Al Qaeda terrorists; ship full of Iranian arms seized earlier in year is now seen as part of new link, which both sides deny; CIA Dir George Tenet has told Congress Iran's reformers are losing ground to conservative clerics who control intelligence and security agencies that support extremists; intelligence reports on Iranian activities detailed; Jordan also reports thwarting many attempts by Iran and proxies to mount attacks against Israel (L)

headline: So What, Exactly, Do Online Gamers Want?
abstract: Computer game companies search for ways to get more online gamers to play longer, and to pay for privilege; Jupiter Media Metrix, research form, says nearly 50 percent of Internet users play games, but so far most casual games are free; companies seeking to develop games that more casual players will be willing to pay for say they need more compelling content than typical simple online version of board or racing game; phtos; chart (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Paypal Offering Delayed
abstract: Salomon Smith Barney says PayPal, which was to have set price for its initial public stock offering, postpones offering; adds timing of offering now is unclear (S)

headline: 'Wintel' takes aim at cell phones
abstract: PARISâ€”  Hoping to repeat what they have done in the personal computer industry, Microsoft and Intel unveiled an alliance Tuesday that could extend the dominance of their "Wintel" platform to the multibillion dollar cell-phone industry, an area where the two companies have had little success so far.

headline: Auto Sales Climb in December
abstract: U.S. auto sales were up last month, as the nation's automakers had a strong end to a difficult year.

headline: NEXTEL HIRES I.B.M. FOR CUSTOMER SUPPORT
abstract: Nextel Communications hires International Business Machines to provide certain customer-service functions; values outsourcing deal at $1.2 billion over eight years (S)

headline: Cott Hires Executive From Coke to Run U.S. Soft Drink Business
abstract: Cott Corp appoints John K Sheppard, 20-year employee of Coca-Cola Co, to take charge of its US soft drink market (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Credit Outlook Improving
abstract: Standard & Poor's says Malaysia's credit rating may be raised for first time in more than two years, citing resilience of nation's currency peg and government progress in returning ailing company's to health; raises its outlook on Malaysia's rating to positive from stable, first step toward upgrade (S)

headline: CNN Names a Rising Star to Head Its U.S. Network
abstract: Teya Ryan, who oversaw overhaul of CNN Headline News last summer, is named executive vice president and general manager of CNN domestic network, succeeding Sid Bedingfield, who is appointed executive editor of all CNN networks (M)

headline: Service Companies Show Growth at Strong Pace
abstract: Institute for Supply Management says its index of service companies, builders and other nonmanufacturing companies rose more than expected in February after unexpected retreat in January; index rose to 58.7 from 49.6; reading above 50 signals expansion; Challenger, Gray & Christmas survey shows number of job cuts planned by American employers dropped in February to lowest level in eight months; businesses announced plans to eliminate 128,155 positions in February, down 40 percent from month earlier (M)

headline: Bush Tells Iran Not to Undercut Afghan Leaders
abstract: Pres Bush tells Iran that if it tries to undermine new interim government of Afghanistan, it faces consequences from same American-backed coalition that ousted Taliban from power; says Iran must be contributor in war against terror; comments are prompted by reports that Iran is seeking to exert its influence in border regions in western Afghanistan in ways that could undermine interim government and Washington's long-term interests; American military officials say Iran is shipping arms to its allies among Afghan factions that pushed Taliban regime from power; Iran's Foreign Ministry spokesman issues statement denouncing Bush's remarks as 'unfounded comments that rely on undocumented information' (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett May Sell French Factory
abstract: Hewlett-Packard says it is close to completing deal to sell computer-making factory in France to contract manufacturing company Sanmina-SCI; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Profit at SBC Declined 4% in 4th Quarter
abstract: SBC Communications says profit declined to $1.25 billion in fourth quarter from $1.3 billion year earlier; sales dropped 2.5 percent, to $11.9 billion (S)

headline: U.S. Moves to Seize Saudi Charity Assets
abstract: Bush administration, in coordination with Saudi government, moves to seize assets of Al-Haramain Islamic Foundation, Saudi charity group, asserting that organization uses cover of supporting Islamic schools and orphanages to funnel money to terrorists (S)

headline: Britain Sends 1,700 Troops to Afghan Fight
abstract: British government will send 1,700 troops trained in Arctic and mountain warfare to Afghanistan to help US forces flush out remaining Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters; says move is in response to US request; Defense Sec Geoff Hoon tells House of Commons that battle group, Britain's largest combat deployment since Persian Gulf war in 1991, will be built around Royal Marine commandos and operate under overall US command as part of American brigade; photo (M)

headline: George Rochester, 93, Physicist Who Shaped Theory of Particles
abstract: George Rochester, architect of particle physics known for discovering kaon particle and regarded as one of Britain's most respected scientists, dies on Dec 26 in England at 93 (S)

headline: CONSECO EARNINGS BELOW PREDICTIONS
abstract: Conseco Inc. said its profit in 2001 failed to meet the 72 cents a share the company, involved in life insurance and finance, had predicted. Profit was hurt by a slumping economy, which led to a rise in losses on consumer loans, Mark Lubbers, executive vice president for corporate affairs, said in a statement. Conseco's announcement came days after its biggest rival in the mobile-home lending business, the GreenPoint Financial Corporation, said it would stop lending to buyers of mobile homes. GreenPoint said the business was not profitable enough.

headline: Terror Plan Born in Germany and Aimed at Turkey Gets New Scrutiny
abstract: Turkish officials are taking fresh look at Kaplan Group, little known Islamic group in Germany made up mostly of Turks who plotted to blow up mausoleum of Ataturk, modern Turkey's founding father, by crashing explosives-laden plane into it in 1998; move follows discovery of evidence linking group to Osama bin Laden; photo (M)

headline: Turkey Will Not 'Tolerate' Unilateral U.S. Action Against Iraq
abstract: ANKARA, Feb 13 (AFP) - Turkey warned its top ally the United States on Wednesday that it would not agree to any unilateral military action against neighboring Iraq, which Washington has described as part of an "axis of evil".

headline: Telmex's Dominance Draws Complaint From U.S.
abstract: US asks World Trade Organization to force Mexico to open its telecommunications industry to foreign competition or face trade sanctions, raising stakes in two-year dispute over $12 billion market; US trade representative Robert B Zoellick says Mexico's market remains dominated by single company, Telefonos de Mexico, or Telmex, with government mandate to set high wholesale prices (M)

headline: Units of WPP Group Get Lego Toy Account
abstract: Units of WPP Group Get Lego Toy Account.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Poland: Phone Company Eludes Bankruptcy
abstract: Elektrim, Polish telephone and industrial company that defaulted on 479 million euros ($423 million) in bonds in December, escapes forced bankruptcy proceedings when court orders it to begin talks with creditors (S)

headline: BANKNORTH BUYS IPSWICH TO EXPAND IN MASSACHUSETTS
abstract: Banknorth Group, Maine's biggest bank, acquires Ipswich Bancshares Inc for $41.1 million in effort to expand in Massachusetts (S)

headline: Toys 'R' Us Plans To Lay Off 1,900 And Close 64 Stores
abstract: Toys 'R' Us will lay off 1,900 people, close 64 stores and move its administrative offices into single location in New Jersey; will take $126 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings to cover costs of severance and other expenses; chairman-chief executive John Eyler comments; photo (M)

headline: DYCOM INDUSTRIES TO ACQUIRE ARGUSS COMMUNICATIONS
abstract: Dycom Industries, a cable installer, plans to acquire Arguss Communications Inc. for about $84 million in stock to add telecommunication system services. Dycom will pay $83.7 million in stock, or 0.3333 share, for each share of Arguss, the company said. Based on Friday's closing stock prices, the deal is worth $5.77 a share for Arguss stockholders, a 30.5 percent premium to Arguss's price. Dycom, which is based in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., will also assume $65 million of debt. Arguss Communications, based in Rockville, Md., provides system services to telecommunications and cable companies. It said in November that it had eliminated 500 jobs since last year.

headline: Chip Developer Buys Rival for $1.4 Billion
abstract: Intersil Corp, developer of microchips that power high-speed wireless networks, agrees to buy Elantec Semiconductor, which makes microchips for video and optical storage market, for $1.43 billion in cash and stock (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: INTERNET SHATNER RETURNS TO PRICELINE William Shatner, the star of the

headline: Text of Message from Wall Street Journal Managing Editor
abstract: Text of a message issued on Thursday by Wall Street Journal Managing Editor Paul Steiger regarding Journal reporter Daniel Pearl.

headline: PetroChina May Try to Acquire Husky Energy
abstract: CALGARY, Alberta, Feb. 19 (Bloomberg News) â€” Husky Energy, a Canadian oil company controlled by the Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing, said today that it was in talks with the PetroChina Company about a possible takeover that would give the Asian company access to consumers in the United States, the biggest energy market.

headline: From Sugar to Ethanol
abstract: Richard R Suchanec letter on Dec 30 article on Mexico's sugar industry

headline: WorldCom: Out of Obscurity to Under Inquiry
abstract: Telecommunications industry's long-simmering financial problems and accounting turmoil have boiled over, reaching WorldCom, nation's second-largest long-distance company and world's leading carrier of Internet traffic; Securities and Exchange Commission appears to be looking into many of business practices that helped WorldCom emerge from obscurity in last 15 years by acquiring dozens of companies, most notably MCI Communications; company used its highflying stock to complete many of those deals, with shares trading as high as $62 in 1999; stock has dropped in recent months, plummeting 12 percent on March 12, to $7.93, on word of SEC inquiry; SEC is looking into whether WorldCom improperly manipulated its financial reports to make its operations appear stronger than they were; it is also looking into hundreds of millions of dollars of loans company made and arranged for chief executive Bernard J Ebbers; some analysts believe SEC might be interested in WorldCom's dealings with Electronic Data Systems; in February 1999, WorldCom entered into complex transaction with EDC that has recently come under analysts' scrutiny; question for analysts is how each company booked nearly equal amounts of revenue from complex deal; graph; chart; photo (M)

headline: Italy's small jewelry designers shine
abstract: MILANâ€”  When it comes to producing sensational jewelry, Italy wins hands down. As the foremost manufacturer and exporter of mass-produced and crafted gold jewelry, the country is also the largest single consumer market in Europe and a leading trendsetter in jewelry design.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  None

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: PHILIPPINES: San Miguel Sale Approved INDIA: Privatization Continues.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway Announces Cutbacks
abstract: Gateway will eliminate 2,250 jobs, or 16 percent of its work force, and close 19 Gateway Country stores after sales slump in fourth quarter; reports fourth-quarter profit of $9.4 million compared with loss of $128.2 million year earlier; it sold 681,000 computers, 17 percent decline from third quarter; founder Ted Waitt comments; photo (S)

headline: Assembling A Big Merger: Hewlett's Man For the Details
abstract: Interview with Webb McKinney, senior Hewlett-Packard executive, who with Compaq Computer chief financial officer Jeff Clarke leads companies' merger integration team; team, which has grown to over 1,000 employees from two companies, has studied and talked to veterans of dozen successful large mergers; he stresses need for speed; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Rethinks Its Role in Saudi Arabia
abstract: American commanders re-examine their presence in Saudi Arabia, prompted by heightened security concerns since Sept 11 attacks and by restrictions Saudi government has imposed on American military operations; Saudi sensitivity about kingdom's need for American protection rus so high that publicly, mission does not exist; American military commanders who favor relocation argue that visible American troop presence weakens royal family rather than strengthening it; even White House acknowledges that change in American military presence is needed; CEntral Command, headquarters for Middle East operations, has prepared sweeping contingency plan to move out of Saudi Arabia, but no decision has been made; photos (M)

headline: Skilling Gives His Version Of Reality To Congress
abstract: Analysis of former Enron Corp president-chief executive Jeffrey K Skilling's testimony before House subcommittee hearing; says Skilling, who portrayed himself as ignorant of company's questionable practices, may not have persuaded many listeners, but he did make it clear to those who are investigating Enron at Justice Department and Securities and Exchange Commission that they will have to work to prove he was aware of anything at all during period he was running Enron; photos (M)

headline: A Turkish Doctor's Specialty: The Torture Victim
abstract: Interview with Human Rights Foundation physician, Dr Onder Ozkalipci, on his work rehabilitating people who say they were tortured by police and prison guards; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Unilever Sees Sales Decline
abstract: Unilever, the world's biggest food and soap maker, said that its first-quarter sales would fall as much as 2 percent, or about 370 million euros ($324 million), because of lost income from businesses it had sold. Growth will slow to about 1

headline: Business; At Rand McNally, Is the Future Drawn to Scale?
abstract: Rand McNally's future is clouded by technological shifts in map-making industry, particularly impact of global positioning systems, and upheaval at company; has been promoting itself as travel service provider, not just map maker, since AEA Investors acquired formerly family-owned company in 1997, and there are signs that AEA is frustrated with its progress and wants to sell it, perhaps at a loss; photo (M)

headline: Wholesale Prices Decline for a Third Month
abstract: Producer Price Index falls 0.7 percent in December, and 1.8 percent decline for all of 2001 is biggest since 1986; graph (M)

headline: Progress Is Reported in Mideast Security Talks
abstract: Israeli and Palestinian security chiefs met with the Bush administration's Middle East envoy today and agreed to take steps to tighten security cooperation and reach a cease-fire, according to an American statement issued after the meeting.    The envoy, Anthony C. Zinni, a retired Marine Corps general, wrapped up his four-day mission today. It was clouded by dispute over Israel's seizure of a ship carrying arms that it said were destined for the Palestinian Authority.

headline: Attack Puts Israeli Army On Edge In the North
abstract: Tense calm prevails along Israeli-Lebanese border nearly two years after Israeli forces withdrew from southern Lebanon following punishing guerrilla war with Hezbollah; two sides remain wary adversaries, poised for resumption of hostilities at any time; photos; map (M)

headline: 3 Israelis Killed in Ambush Of Settlers' Convoy in Gaza
abstract: Palestinian militant ambushes settlers' convoy in Gaza Strip, killing Israeli woman; also kills Israeli police officer and soldier by blowing himself up as they rush to scene; attack which wounded two other soldiers follow car bombing outside Jerusalem that killed Israeli policeman along with bomber; Isreali warplanes strike two Palestinian security buildings, in Ramallah and Rafah (M)

headline: Argentina Unlinks Peso From Dollar, Bracing for Devaluation and Even Harder Times
abstract: Argentina today formally abandoned a decade-long policy of linking its peso to the American dollar at a value of one to one, an arrangement that brought an initial, illusory burst of prosperity but departs with the country bankrupt and on the brink of political chaos.    Eduardo Duhalde, Argentina's fifth president in little more than two weeks, sought the change on Friday as part of a broader ''public emergency law'' giving him sweeping powers to deal with the collapse. Acting in record time, the lower house of Congress approved the plan without significant alterations before dawn today, and the Senate followed suit this evening.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen advances, fueled by rally in Japan's benchmark stock average; in New York, dollar settles 132.27 yen, down from 133.26 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: U.S. Role in Resolution On Mideast Startles Some
abstract: Passage of resolution demanding immediate cease-fire between Israel and Palestinians is praised as most significant response by Security Council since conflict began 17 months ago; it also represents what some diplomats call startling turnaround in how US handles such sensitive challenges in Security Council; in past, initiative for resolutions about Israel was often taken by its critics, with US on defensive having to veto resolutions deemed unfavorable; Israeli and Palestinian officials are seizing on different parts of resolution that shore up their own claims (M)
